Definition: In this task, you will be given an Amazon review and you have tell whether it is a positive review or negative review.

Positive Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Positive Examples.explanation: This rating is based on this review provided by the user as he liked the product very much and he was surprised that product is so good

Positive Examples.input: Bought cables in 3ft, 6ft and 9ft.  NONE of them worked.  NO FUNCTIONALITY WHATSOEVER.  Tested many times, its as if the copper wires are just not connected to the terminations.  Do these even go through Quality Control before they leave the factory?  Waste of money and time.
Positive Examples.explanation: User did not like cables at all and found all of them useless so it is a negative review.

Negative Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Negative Examples.explanation: User likes the product very much still rating provided is not according to his review. There is incorrect relation between review and rating given.

Negative Examples.input: Bought cables in 3ft, 6ft and 9ft.  NONE of them worked.  NO FUNCTIONALITY WHATSOEVER.  Tested many times, its as if the copper wires are just not connected to the terminations.  Do these even go through Quality Control before they leave the factory?  Waste of money and time.
Negative Examples.explanation: User feels the product is useless  and he tested it many times but it does not work so it should not be positive review here.

Instances.input:
We gave this to my daughter for Christmas and it was a huge hit. It was easy to learn to use. I will say there are things that are easier to do on a computer than on the Kindle. Some things...such as the Amazon site, has such small tabs that even with a stylist it is hard to click on the right thing.

Other than that one tiny thing....Awesome so far! I would recommend it to anyone as a first or low cost tablet choice. It does everything the "big guys" do.

This is not my first laptop backpack.  But it is the best!  I bought this for a new laptop and a long trip to Russia.  I needed a very protective pack, with lots of pockets for all my extra gadgets (external speakers, wireless mouse, etc.) I'd need for staying at a series of hotels with no conveniences for a long period of time and a lot of long flights, many with *no* entertainment (Aeroflot!)  I also wanted secure but accessible pockets for passports, etc.  Since I'd have it with me pretty constantly it also had to be comfortable.  Lastly, while roomy, it needed to fit under airplane seats.  ALL of theses conditions were met with flying colors!  It also turned out the build quality was excellent.  Oh, one last positive.  The backpack easily \\"butterflies\\" open at airport security, and very quickly comes back together after the scan.  The fact that it laid flat in the scan prevented me from delays.  With all the extra batteries, speakers, headphones etc. I envisioned getting manually inspected.  Never happened!

I am generally a no-frills kind of guy. So when I saw this wireless keyboard for $20, with the HP logo on it, the first thought that crossed my mind was \\"cheap, practical, and not fancy.\\" Which is perfect for me. Sadly, to my surprise, while cheap (and definitely not fancy) the HP Multimedia Wireless Keyboard is anything but practical.    To be fair, the wireless mouse works very well in my setup,in which the receiver is literally on the same table as the wireless mouse / keyboard combo. It is responsive, and feels ergonomic enough for me to sit with for hours. However, as soon as I began typing away on the keyboard, I knew there would be issues. In the 8 letter title for this review, the keyboard did not register 12 keystrokes, which meant that I had to go back 12 times and slowly retype each letter, or insert each space that was missed. After reading the reviews (WHY didn't I do this before?) I thought it might simply be due to the limited range on the receiver; no luck, the receiver is literally sitting next to my keyboard, with no improvement.    The keyboard responsiveness of this product is reminiscent to the old electric typewriter days, in which certain keys would just not work, or would get stuck. I will sadly  be returning this product today, leading to more money wasted towards this waste of a product.

I purchased what I thought was a Kodak product when I purchased with my new Kodak DC3400 digital camera, a Kodak Compact Flash Card Reader for Digital Cameras, what I recieved was a Datafab Compact Flash Card Reader for Digital Cameras. This product would work with my windows 98 but every time I booted up the PC I wouuld get "The blue screen from hell" to quote another reviewers description of a similar product. I have since done more reasearch on the compact flash card reader products and sent back my Datafab unit and ordered another comparable unit that had at least better reviews. Buyer beware...

This product is not fully designed. The issue-- you can't see what you saved. Do I have one .pdf, two .pdfs or three? What is there? There is no way to review the pages you have created on the device.

You plug it into the computer and .pdfs will appear with generic file names ending in 0, 1, 2, 3,.... Then, one by one, you look at them.

If you have Windows device, perhaps there is software to deal with these .pdfs other than one by one. My Mac (admittedly older) uploads from improvelectronics.com, then asks for an application to open it. This tells me this is Windows software only.

Documentation is close to non-existent, as described in other posts. You are supposed to intuit what it does.

This sums up this router:    1. Pretty easy to set up- but difficult to connect. SSID is found on most gear, but only about 50% connectivity. It is very sporadic. Some days \\"success\\" some days \\"failure.\\"    2. Play station 3- after finding a channel on the router that PS3 \\"likes\\" this router did pretty well staying connected with a PS3 upstairs. (router was downstairs) Although two weeks of connectivity would be dampened by a few days of non connection...but once again SSID is found no problem.    3. Wii- forget it. SSID found...1% connectivity. I only got it to connect twice over several months.     4. Nintendo DS- it worked pretty well with these and it seemed to stay connected.    6. HP Photo smart wireless printing- stayed connected once connected, but took forever to connect. Once again SSID found with some problems...but even after found, will not connect until you mess with channel after channel to find the right one.     9. Bluray LG BD-390- Router gives 50% connectivity. Hit and miss. Some days would connect and I could stream Netflix, other days would not. SSID found about 80% of the time...but connectivity 50%.    10. Desktop computer and apple macbook- no problems: never lost connection.    NOTE: The signal was not that bad...several green bars on all of this gear.    To sum it up I had about a 90% success rate at discovering the SSID, but far less than 50% connectivity...This router was an absolute waste of money. It just would not connect.  Amazingly enough I received the verizon FIOS wireless router, hooked it up and secured it in 5 minutes, and within 15 minutes had everything running wirelessly...SSID and connectivity on all of the above. This Belkin router just is too unreliable.
One of the nicer hubs I have. Build quality is fantastic. Only two downsides: included cable is really short, wont work unless the usb port is already an arms length away, and hub is not powered.

I had one of the original Kensingon trackballs in the early 90s and loved it. It was smooth, comfortable, and precise, but it broke a lot. I bought a supply of replacement microswitches and kept replacing them, but ultimately I couldn't use it, but don't remember exactly why. I think either the DIN-to-USB interface didn't work, or it was incompatible with Windows 2000 or something.

Anyway, I was hopeful when I found this trackball, but it was too exspensive. Lately on sale for around $[...] after rebate, I bought one.

Installation went smoothly, but that was the last \\"smooth\\" thing about it. The scroll ring jumps along in about 1/4\\" increments, making it unusable. There's no way to adjust the pointer variables to allow smooth tiny increments and speedy large ones. The toggle to slow down the pointer movement doesn't work when using the pointer on the scroll bar. The list goes on and on. If you unplug from one USB port and plug into another, all your settings disappear, but that may be as designed.

It may be a software issue -- the old Mouseworks package has been replaced with TrackballWorks, now at V1.0.4. I can't find anything like the Preferences XML file that you could tweak with Mouseworks, but there may be something in the Registry.

All in all very disappointing. Back it goes.

Update: Back it went, replaced with a new one by Kensington. The new one wasn't any better, and Kensington support said that was as good as it was going to get. I tried to make it work for aa couple more weeks, but ultimately gave up and returned it for a refund.

This review is for a different HD by Western Digital, but the customer service and product warranty are exactly the same...

My 250GB Western Digital hard drive died after only a month & took with it over 150GB worth of data that wasn't backed up anywhere else (for obvious reasons - who really \\"backs up\\" their backup drive anyway?). At first the drive worked very well: it supported plug-and-play, had a large amount of space, was competitively priced and was made by WD, a brand I thought to be trustworthy.

However, a company who boasts for you to \\"Put Your Life On It\\" (their external hard drives) should at least try to ensure data reliability & take accountability for their products. When I called customer service about my failed drive I obtained this list of information:

1. If you wish to recover your data, you must use one of their partners or risk voiding your warranty. There are only 8 in North America.
2. You are responsible for the cost incurred in using their data recovery partners.
3. Western Digital doesn't issue any refunds. If you purchased your drive from a store such as BestBuy you could return your faulty product. However, at online retailers such as Buy.com you are left without options.
4. You can obtain a replacement drive (what they call re-certified) but it'll be devoid of your precious data.
5. You are responsible for the shipping costs associated with returning the faulty drive back to WD. They pay for shipping of the replacement drive to you. This is apparently called \\"fair shipping\\".
6. According to the CSR, Western Digital is not responsible for your data. They are only a supplier of hard drives.
7. On a different note, the CSR never actually apologized for my failed drive but only used words such as \\"unfortunate\\" and \\"let's explore your options\\".

In summary, this product is fine if you happen to receive a unit that doesn't fail. However, I would not be willing to take that risk and I don't recommend anyone buying this product for any amount of money. It's acceptable that a device such as this is prone to failure. However, Western Digital's \\"it's not my problem\\" attitude is not.

This is a really nice screen protector if you're a digital artist. I chose a matte finish because I wanted the texture of my screen to feel more like paper. This does a nice job of that. The colors don't seem distorted, the brightness is the same. There is a little bit of grain to the screen, but it's not distracting or even really noticeable. I've actually had a couple people comment on liking the look of the screen surface because it isn't mirror glossy.

On the negative, I've had it on for about 3 weeks now and have a couple of scratches along the protector. They aren't enough to hinder any performance, but I can see the imperfections when the screen is off. I wouldn't give it any less rating for the scratches, as I'm a bit careless at times and even with a case, scratches are bound to happen. Besides, it's better to have the scratches on the protector than on the actual screen.

All in all, I'd say it's a good screen protector and I'd buy it again. Not indestructible, but I'd buy them again.

At first, I was pleased to have avoided paying Apple's seemingly overpriced cost for a stock power supply. The cord was longer, too. However after four months of use, the LED on the magnetic computer-end attachment began to flicker occasionally, and I had to fidget with the cord to make it stay lit. This problem became more frequent until it stopped working entirely at month #5.

I wrote the company to request a replacement, and the response was that the window for returns had closed one month after my purchase.

I gambled that I might get more than I paid for--and hopefully others have fared better--but this item clearly is designed cheaply. My original Apple cord lasted almost two years before crapping out, therefore I suggest buyers to consider whether they will really be saving money with this purchase.

I had high expectations for this product, but I would never recommend this to anyone who wants to use it with an iPad / iPhone. This device is NOT plug and play. To get it to work, you can only use a Windows PC that has WiFi. So, desktop PCs are out of luck.

The funny thing is you need a Windows based PC with WiFi only to run their setup program. After that, the device isn't actually designed for desktop PCs. You can't stream content to Windows PCs, so why require one to use it? By contrast, although it lacks the DVD drive, the Seagate Satellite lets you stream content right out of the box, with anything that can connect to it.

I called Samsung twice and essentially was told they are still working out the kinks and had no way to help me. They said they had some resources on their web site, including a PDF of the book (which is just a worthless sheet already in the box), and some videos. I asked what the videos showed and he told me he's never seen them because Samsung doesn't allow their employees to stream videos, even when they are from their site. So, essentially they don't train their staff at all and they can offer no advice.

I can only assume that if they actually sell any of these, the buyers must be using something other than an iPad to play the content, because out of the box, it doesn't work. The software, the setup programs and the instructions are poorly written and if you can get past that and complete the setup, it still doesn't work.

I eventually found a work-around. After reading online that their device has a DHCP server, that lets you use this as a router (assuming you plug your existing LAN into it), and that it often conflicts with other devices, I decided to try something before sending it back. I changed the device to a static IP, and I picked a number in the 192 .68 .1 .9, then used 255 .255 .255 . 0 as the subnet and left everything else blank. Viola... it worked, but how on earth would they expect anyone to figure that out?

Let's hope they update the firmware and software again to make it right. Until then, buy this only if you are good at puzzles.they expect anyone to figure that out?

Let's hope they update the firmware and software again to make it right. Until then, buy this only if you are good at puzzles.

Works great but is overkill for my point and shoot Olympus for photos.  I got the high-speed card to be sure that audio will stay synced with the video.  The 600x speed vs 300x speed makes no difference in 8GB Lexar CF cards that I use in matching Sony a700 DSLR's (e.g. five fps in bursts, but will slow down to one fps after 3 seconds, 14 frames total).  I think this is due to the cameras buffer not the card performance.  The Lexar 8GB 600x CF cards stay at the same capture rate as the 5 year old Lexar 8GB 300x CF cards, but that may be the 5 year old camera can not write at the faster speed.  Be sure to read the manual to determine the maximum card size your camera will take.  Most camera makers have pdf copies of the manuals available on their web site under “Support”.  I have a 2007 Ricoh at work that will not read anything bigger than 2GB.  My 2013 Olympus will not read anything bigger than 64GB.  The camera’s maximum data write speed may not be in the manual.  DSLR or Prosumer cameras can write to the card faster than lower priced cameras.  High-speed cards (e.g. 600x or Class 10 for this Lexar) will work in slower cameras, but they will only store data as fast as the camera can push it.

This is the best all around keyboard I've ever owned (which has probably been 10+ over almost 20 years). I'll start with the minor drawback: the sensor receiver emits an annoying blue LED light when any button on the keyboard is pressed. Simple solution: a two inch strip of electric tape completely masks the annoyance.    Now for the good: I have several wireless devices, and this one works uninterrupted from over 40 feet away through walls! Unless you have a huge projector screen, and are sitting further away than that, this keyboard appears to have no connectivity issues that often plague other wireless gadgets.    The feel, weight, profile, etc. of the keyboard is excellent. It appears to have fairly sturdy construction, and the keys depress effortlessly from their slim stature.    A few minor considerations: it does not have backlighting, so any midnight World of Warcraft rampage will require a secondary light source. It also has no indication for NUM/SCROLL/CAPS lock. It hasn't been an issue for me (I only use NUM lock, and it's always on).    I would highly recommend this product to anyone. I have spent over $50 on keyboards that faltered much sooner than this one has at $25.

Very nice cables.  We mostly use monitors with VGA connections but have computers with one each DVI-I and one each VGA connector.  So we initially had DVI-I to VGA adapters on the PC DVI-I ports (these came with the video cards) but these required more physical room for the computer (they stuck out the back father than any other component) and threatened the PC ports if any strain was put on those cables (they were flimsy:  the leverage of the video cable pulling on the video adapter pulling on the PC video port was considerable when somebody wanted to change out monitors or relocate monitors).  These cost little more than DVI-I to VGA adapters, removed the cable strain issues, appear to be well made, and do not cause any degradation in the video seen on the monitors.  A very good product.

I love this backpack!! I had seen this in one of the Staples Stores and liked it very much. The store had priced it very high and I wanted to check this one on amazon. I was extremely happy to find this bag for half the price and I grabbed it!....

The back zipper is very nicely padded with high quality materials and it can easily fit your 15.6'' laptop and can keep it very safe and protected as well.

Overall I would say that this is high quality product and I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a neat looking backpack that is superb in the build quality.

Recently I purchased this very bad wireless microsoft keyboard and mouse set (used).  I returned the item to the seller because I did not like it.  I returned it to the third party seller, because it was clunky, had some wear and tear (the paint job was chipped and worn-out in severel spots), came in oily (believe it or not), and there were a lot of other lighter, more ergonomical wireless keyboard choices on the market that were cheaper and a lot more attractive (with more features and capabilities)!  The springs on some of the keyboard buttons did not work (were damaged) or were worn out, aswell.  I had to go through my credit card agency just to issue a refund (something I definetly did not want to resort to, and something that will definely cause certain people not to get their monitary funds returned).  I'm embarrassed to say I spent 100$ for(by far) the cheapiest one.  Not only was the package highly mis-represented, this product, just does not work in so many ways!  I would recommend buying this product, used, for as little as 5$, no more...new 10$ max.  Even then, you would still be  a little upset about it (no joke).  You'll be asking yourself, \\"where did my 5 to 10 dollars go!\\"?  You could easily take a trip over to Best Buy and pick one out for under 50$ for which, you would be easily satisfied of...and not have to spend days waiting for your order to arrive via Amazon.com.  Moving on, the keys mounted on the keyboard are awkwardly placed so you have to re-learn how to type just to use them.  The word \\"acuity\\" and lack thereoff comes to mind when I think of this clunker as I'm scrolling and typing.  (As you can see I have nothing good to say about this product)  The lights are hard to look at (I would even say that they hurt your eyes when you look at them) and the Start Button is unnecessary and happens to be the center of the keyboard.  The package for return included all the items of the orginal order:  (1) wireless keyboard, (1) wireless mouse with wireless USB connector, (1) mouse charger, and a plug in cable.  Thank you for your time  .  The aforementioned takes care of the technical side of it(for return), now for the untechnical(after return):  Judging from the price tag and the pictures you see of this product you would think it would be made-up of some type of high quality metallic alloy or similar substance.......It's not!  It's made of some cheap, heavy, brittle plastic and is definately a quirky \\"clunker.\\"  Usually the heavier a substance is the more durable, this in an exception.  Even if this product were free, I still would not want it in my household.  My best guess is that all the other reviewers of this product live in the country some place and are very bored in their lives.  What is wrong with everyone?  The thing with Amazon is, they make all their profits based on the fact that there's a lot of sales and an even longer drawned-out return process that nobody wants to be a part of (-hence all sales are final?).  Therefore, for all intensive purposes, Amazon.com is 100% on the seller's side during the return process.  They even \\"fine tune\\" the negative feedbacks on the customer reviews section of their products in many different ways (something many other large companies with websites and opinions, that we all hear good things from, frequently do and are guilty, but we never hear of).  So what is with these \\"reviewers\\" and why do I know they'll come crying to me at some point in the future saying how \\"unfair\\" it all was.  Do not be fooled, many other big media and Newspaper websites monitor and do this too (-Not to put Amazon.com in a seemingly altruistic bubble).  The only \\"guarantee\\" websites and media makes is who \\"controls\\" it.  The only \\"guarantee\\" Amazon makes is that this product will be a huge waste of your time.  They'll even use the fact that there's only positive reviews viewable against you in the claim process...That's assuming that you have all your ducks in a row and are still ableto return the product.  Now let's go into detail about the return process.  They do absolutely nothing in the return process for you.  Proof of this after chatting with 8 different associates (they'll send you to India) and sending a plethera of \\"maniditory\\" and unmanditory emails that never get returned.  If you don't compleately see that they like to \\"scapegoat\\" a company that does not technically exist in the first place by sending you to India (something I think should definelty be illegal), YOU ARE A FOOL!!! ............But........were're expected to return all their emails immediately and/or according to their time frame, or the process gets cancelled?  -They'll even say corporations are individuals??  Btw, all of those emails and chats were necessary to send or it works against you in the \\"claim\\" process.  It gets better and better.  All this would be avoidable if Amazon took the time to review their products, but then again, corporations are indivduals??  This product should not be the most expensive, in closing.  IN THE LONG RUN,...DO NOT DO BUSINESS WITH AMAZON.COM (THERE'RE FAKE)!!!

My wife and I both have offices with sit-down desks and stand-up treadmill desks, and we move between them regularly throughout the day. Moving was a pain, even with laptops, because we had to disconnect/reconnect so much gear.

To remove the obstacles from using our stand-up desks, I duplicated our primary peripherals (monitor, mouse, keyboard, speakerphone, camera) at both locations, with the USB devices being plugged into a hub at each location. I then ran a single USB cable to each location, and plugged those two cables into this switch.

Now, if I move to my treadmill desk I simply turn off the port that connects to the hub at my sit down desk, and turn on the port that connects to the hub on my stand-up desk. It takes about 30 seconds for all the devices to be re-recognized when I do this.

All my applications (Lync, Webex, Windows, etc) automatically switch to the 'new' devices without any manual intervention, at least they do after the initial setups (one setup for each USB hub when it is first activated).

Separately, I use a VGA splitter to push video to both monitors simultaneously.

Now I have no excuse for not switching to my treadmill desk, other than entropy. Highly recommended.

If I switch the keyboard off for a few seconds and then switch it back on, it starts working properly again. I have a new battery and have moved the USB plug around to different ports to no avail. I am sitting 2m away from my PC with a clear line of sight and the receiver on a front port, so I really have nothing else to blame but some problem with the keyboard/receiver, which is a shame, because other than this recent issue, it has been a good product.

But I had a blue screen of death the other day, and it scared me. I ran all the diagnostics and couldn't find anything wrong,. but I figured a well used, 6 year old hard drive was getting on, so I plumped for an SSD to replace it.

What a breeze it was, putting this thing in! Very easy to install and clone my C drive. It was all installed, up and running within an hour. And blazing fast now. My windows index has gone from a fairly healthy 5.9 to a very healthy 7.1. It boots much quicker, and pages load much, much faster. Can wait to see how much quicker video renders.

I'd recommend this backpack even at the higher price, I have had a lot of backpacks that don't hold up (zippers break, rips/tears at the seam, not enough room...), I got it for a steal two years ago, and right now it seems like a decent price for a decent backpack

This card only supports two displays at a time, not three. 2 DVI or one DVI and one HDMI.

The DVI Y adapter is a tight fit and must be screwed into the card tightly.

On Windows 7 install drivers that are supplied. Then withOUT rebooting install/update to the latest version from NVIDIA. Then reboot.

DVI display is excellent.

Card works well after you get a good cable and the drivers updated.

Amazon makes this card a good purchase, not the manufacturer JATON.

ok this is how it goes, this is the only wireless router i have ever used and it happens to be that way because it has served all my wireless needs perfectly and hence i have had no need to try any other one. the only negative thing i might say about this product is not really about the product but about the company (Linksys). i called thier customer service line just to ask a general question about the router but was put on hold for a significant amount of time (which is common practice with a lot of companies). the question wasn't even related to the product's setup as that was just a cake walk. its funny cause i wonder why some people give this product a bad review, either they just cant follow instructions or they bought a damaged product. what ever the case may be, this is a great product and i recommend it to anyone wanting to go wireless.

I was nearly out of space on my 80gb ps3's hdd so I just decided to get this drive for it. In order for the ps3 to recognize it you must first format to FAT32 either using a laptop or a pc with a 2.5 sata case enclosure and usb cable connected to it. You will also need a program for the formatting since the drive is greater than 32 gb, I recommend using Easeus partition master home edition to do so. Anyway once your ps3 recognizes the drive it'll format on its own. This drive worked very well and was a good price for all the space left on it. I haven't had any lag issues or ps3 slowing down as others have reported and am very pleased with this drive. Highly recommended!

Had for a few weeks now and it is perfect, protects the screen when closed, all openings are avail, except for micro sd card.  Sometimes it takes a moment of adjusting when on a surface like the bed to prop it up, but on hard surfaces, no problem.  Actually has two different places that the back can slide into to give a different angle, the one that it is designed to go into, and the little pen holder elastic also works as a brace.  Price, design, and slimness factor  all  great!

I purchased this ACER Tablet 18 months ago and it is now out of warranty.  While it was working it had good performance and I was very pleased with it.  Now suddenly, the ON-OFF switch on the tablet does not make the faint, mechanical sounding \\"click\\" that it use to make when pressing it down to start up the tablet.  As a result, I cannot get my ACER A500 to turn on at all, which makes it an expensive paper weight at best.  All this wonderful 100% functional solid state technology inside the case and a poorly made, inexpensive on-off switch breaks down and makes the whole system USELESS. Such a switch should be the BEST micro switch money can buy since it is the one switch on the tablet that users press over and over again.  Alas it is not to be. I'll never buy an ACER product again and I would highly recommend that you do not purchase this particular tablet at all.

I bought my daughter a brand new kindle fire hdx and this case for her birthday. I figured I was being responsible getting a case. As it turns out, this case may have actually been the cause of a crack in the screen. Her Kindle fell off the night stand onto the floor. Most likely the crack was caused by the rigid outer edge of the case exerting pressure not the screen at just the right spot. At the time of the fall the case was closed and should have protected her Kindle.

I did a lot of research before I ordered this Dell Venue, and I am sure I read every review. One thing I never considered is that Amazon would deceive me. The Dell Venue 8 Pro I received was used. When I opened the package the first clue was the Dell box had all kinds of greasy fingerprints on the box. When I opened the box I was shocked, the front display and rear cover were covered with finger prints and smudges. I removed the tablet from the box and underneath everything, the charging cord, and owners manual were just crammed in the box on top of the plastic bags they used to be in. I turned on the device and it had the opening screen with someone else's picture and wanted their Windows Live password. I have been with Amazon for years and I am an Amazon Prime customer, and I will never think of Amazon the same way again. I am so disappointed with them. All I can say is beware, Amazon is not who they pretend to be.

Waiting a month to write this review has been hard as I just wanted to shout to the world what a wonderful experience it is having my Kindle.  Being fair I felt waiting a month would give a more reasoned review.  I was wrong.  I love my Kindle more today than yesterday and less than tomorrow.  I will never be without one again.  The ability to have any book I want available to read in 60 seconds or less is wonderful.  No more wasting gas going to the bookstore or spending money on books only to have less and less space to store them.  I give Amazon a huge Thumbs-up for giving us the Kindles and give myself a huge Thumbs-down for having waited so long to purchase one.

Mine failed on first power up, and I got no customer service/support from the manufacturer.  I would have returned it through Amazon had I not waited months before testing it.  Read the other reviews on this item: the frequency of failure is fairly high.  Get the one from Fusion....much better company to deal with.
This is great. works well and does exactly what it's supposed to do. The ads are kind of weird but they don't get in the way. The ads just when you turn it on do they pop up.

Rewriting my review of the EA6500. At first everything was great. Then came a barrage of firmware updates and the device is no longer stable. It doesn't maintain an AC link to my WUMC710. The Cloud Connect reports ridiculous device information. It will apply one device name to multiple devices and/or with apply multiple devices' mac addresses to one device. The management of the router becomes frustrating because I have to keep resetting it and reapplying the correct names and icons for each device because you can reserve the IP address to network appliances when the MAC address for a server gets attached to a Printer. The QOS is not stable. The internet problems started 2 firmware updates ago with slow speeds, unresponsiveness, and 404 errors, on some wired devices, while simultaneously wireless nodes were reaching the domains with out issues or vice versa. The fact the device required so many firmware updates and poorly tested ones at that makes this device unreliable.

I no longer support Cisco or its products with my Time or Money. I'm dumping this rubbish and going with ASUS.

Definitely this needs to be fixed.

I ordered this as a replacement for my husband's laptop. After a week, it shorted out and the adapter melted inside his computer! I took it to a tecnician thinking it was the computer itself that had shorted out, but he said it's a faulty cord.

Perhaps I am expecting too much from such a product, I am usually quite careful with my stuff but was very disappointed that a minor accident on my behalf caused it to completely crack. So if you are not a klutz like me, these may be satisfactory to you.

After looking at several cases both online and in-store, I decided on this one.  It fits the Kindle Fire perfectly and has easy access to the USB port and power button.  It is not a bulky as others and appears to be well made.  The stand feature is nice and works perfectly.
When I got it the case was warped so that my iPad didn't fit into it completely. I am returning this.

Samsung sent me this monitor to replace a syncmaster 225bw since they did not have any in stock to replace it.     First of all, the stand is awful. It's a round egg-shaped thing that fits into the monitor, but the force that's required to put it in can certainly damage the monitor. I was never able to get it in for over a month. Samsung tech support was not helpful about it and claimed that the stand issue was my problem.   I read on some obscure forum that some guy got his to fit by having it upside down on his bed as he forced it in by putting all his body weight into it. I tried it and it popped in. I finally was able to use it.     Fast forward 3 months later, the monitor just went to a black screen and no matter what I tried, it won't show anything other than black. I rma'd the monitor, shipped it back. they claimed they did a repair on it and shipped it back. I open the box to find the same issue. I swear all they did was wait a week, put it back in another box and shipped it back. I did another rma, shipped it to them, they claimed they did a repair and sent it back, same issue.     I am currently on hold with \\"customer relations department\\" to get them to just issue me a replacement. I've been on hold for 40 minutes now and still counting.     At this point, I would just say that samsung has gotten too big for their own good. I used to love their products, but now I wouldn't recommend any of their products to anyone. It's a good thing I waited on buying that samsung hdtv a few weeks ago...     EDIT: a follow up on this review - I was placed on hold with their customer relations department, they finally picked up around 6:50. I told her exactly what happened with this monitor, and how many times it was sent for repairs with no results. She said she will send another monitor and when I receive it, I can send back my old one. I said no problem, and she put me on hold. After about 5 minutes on hold, the phone hangs up. I tried to call back only to have the customer support person tell me that customer relations is closed now. After some arguing, he issued the exchange.     Today my monitor shipped and it's at home. I am just Hoping that Samsung ran out of 2233BW's and shipped me a better monitor...
i got this awhile ago and it still looks new. its very pretty and easy to wipe off. everyone seems to love it.i recommended it my friends and family.

Transfer speed between 2 and 6 Mbps. That translates to VERY slow. It would take many days to transfer all my contents onto this unit. I have looked at a lot of cases in stores and had a different case before this one that broke after I had it for 2 months. My husband has had this case in black for many months and it still looks new. He says there is a ding on it from when he dropped it once, but he has a hard time finding the ding, and his iPad was not damaged at all.

Positives:
Fits the iPad 2 and 3 really well.
iPad stays securely in the hard case, which covers and protects all 4 corners in case it drops.
The elastic strap holds the case closed to fully protect it, especially the screen, which seems to be the easiest part to damage.
The deep grooves in the case keep it propped open, even on a surface that isn't perfectly level and stable, like the bed, couch or my lap.
iPad can be propped up vertically or horizontally.
The "hinge area" is sturdy and flexible and well made (This is where my 2 month old case broke. It had a hard plastic hinge.)
I don't misplace my stylus anymore since there is a place for it.
It looks very professional and the calypso pink is a nice pinkish red. I didn't want it to look too juvenile, like a "Barbie" or bright pink.

Negatives:
I'm very pleased with the color, weight and size, but I would ideally like more color choices and for it to be a little thinner so it would fit in a bag or purse a little better.

I had the wireless usb adapter plugged into a usb 2.0 port on the front of my computer. Those ports are known to be slow on some machines. I then placed it into a usb 3.0 port on the front (even though this isn't a usb 3.0 keyboard) and it works great now. Like most people who buy a sub-$100 tablet, I was mostly attracted by the price. (So what if it's not great? I'm only out $100.) I've had the AGPtek 9-inch Android 4.0 tablet PC for about a week. First I found that the \\"user guide\\" in the box was worse than useless. It was poorly printed on pages of tissue-thin paper about 2x3 inches and contained many screenshots that were totally black. The downloaded version had legible pictures but was generally of not much help. It even contained inconsistent advice, such as admonishing the user to use the USB connection only for the transmission of data, but then on another page pointing out that it could be used for faster recharging (than the ac adapter). For the uninitiated Android user, a brief introduction to Android software might have been helpful, or at least a link to an Android tutorial. The worst problem I encountered was the tablet's poor wi-fi performance. The tablet consistently indicated that the signal from my home wi-fi network was \\"weak,\\" and sometimes too weak for the tablet to download anything. This is in spite of the perfectly normal performance of my aging LG telephone, my also aging netbook computer, and my even more remotely located Roku box under the TV. The only way I could get the tablet to operate through a wi-fi connection was to position myself about three feet from the wireless router, and even then the AGPtek would only show one or two arc-shaped bars, still indicating a very weak signal. In contrast, a signal strength app I have installed on my phone shows a \\"moderate\\" to \\"good\\" signal strength throughout the house. I can only conclude that the wireless transmitter/receiver function of the tablet is defective in either its design or its manufacture. The battery holds a charge only for a couple of hours or so, probably as a consequence of the perceived low signal strength of my home network. (The tablet probably ramps up it's receiver gain to the max in an effort to receive a better signal, andin so doing runs the battery down quickly.) My advice is to pay more up front and get a tablet with a brand name you can trust. Don't buy the AGPtek tablet. One way or another, this one is going back. I should probably give only one star and not two because most of the uses I had in mind for this device were online ones. But I suppose it's still possible to do a few things off-line, and it's always possible that you could use your \\"portable\\" tablet tethered to the router or to a wired network outlet. But that's not the way I would prefer to use a tablet PC. I think I just talked myself into dropping the rating to one star (I hate it).

The battery arrived nicely packed and fairly quickly.  There were no instructions of any kind, so I turned off the computer, removed the old one and inserted the new one, plugging in the wall charger. When I tried to re-start the computer, it came on, but the screen would not light up. Then it spontaneously shut itself down -- battery completely out of juice. I then re-started it several times, and each time the same thing happened. Finally, I turned off the laptop again and removed the \\"new\\" battery. Then I re-inserted the old, half-dead battery and re-started. The computer once again worked without any problem except that the old battery would only take a very partial charge.  At that point, I tried to contact Good Time, but got a weekend \\"away\\" message. I then went ahead and ordered a more expensive, OEM type of battery from a different vendor. Then I wrote back to Good Time asking for a full refund and requesting that they pay for return shipping since it was defective. After a day or so, they wrote back asking for the model # of my computer --  information they already had from the specified battery I had ordered. They then agreed to do the refund if I would send it back, but insisted that I take a photo of the return shipping receipt and e-mail that to them. The whole process was an incredible hassle, especially considering that they had supplied defective merchandise in the first place. (The second, more expensive vendor said that they test each battery before they send it out.) So that's my sad story with Good Time, but at least the second battery I bought from Laptop Battery Express works fine.)

First Let me say that this is a great keyboard. Just dont buy it.  The action of the keys is ok, it is very sturdy and heavy, and the actions of the keys (while they last) is pretty good.  The back lighting is phenomenal, and the color choices are nice, although I must say I only use the blue.    Now, on to the bad news.  In home use, NOT OFFICE, HOME use, the keyboard lasted about two weeks before the action on the keys started becoming squeaky and spongy, and the space bar became very loose.  After another month, the faces of the keys started wearing off, and unless you are a touch typist (who is these days?) it is very hard to figure out what key you are pressing, as the paint wears off very quickly.    Amazon refused to do anything about it since it was beyond their 30 day window (even for a prime customer who spends several thousand dollars a year.. but oh well...)So  after a day or two of google searches I finally found Saitek's website, and submitted a warranty claim.  After a few weeks I got a reply and an RMA, and asked to ship the keyboard for possible repair.  I shipped it to them, in the box that it was originally packaged in, and waited.  Several weeks later, I came home to find (happily I thouhgt) my keyboard, repaired or replaced.. asd was eager to go.      To my horror I found that the keyboard had been returned to me, no paperwork, no repairs had been done, and thrown in the bottom of the shipping box with one small piece of brown paper as packaging.  Several of the key caps were missing now altogether, and the keyboard was chipped on the edge.  So it is now a worthless hunk of junk.  Saitek as not returned any of my emails or inquiries, and I have no expectations that they will.    If you are rich, and can buy one of there a month, and throw it away when it becomes unusable, then its a great value.  it really is superb right out of the box, but with total lack of service and support, and the short life span of the keyboard.... Just not worth buying.  i hope this helps.

I wrote to Sharkk and explained that it was DOA - the laser would not light up. Their initial response was strange - \\"The mouse that you have is an optical mouse so there is no light underneath.\\" Eh?! An optical mouse uses laser light to track instead of a track ball. Their second message was asking if I'd clicked the mouse. I don't want to ding them unnecessarily, but of course I clicked the mouse. Would they really suspect that I'd put the batteries in and then just move it around without clicking?

I've had several emails back and forth from the customer service department, but thus far - two full weeks after the item was delivered - I do not have a working mouse.

I'm confident that the company will make this right, as they appear to take great pains to offer excellent customer service. Once this issue is resolved, I'll update my rating. I have other Sharkk products and am very happy with them.

UPDATE: My confidence in the company was undeserved. After our last round of email, I never heard from them again. That's too bad, I really thought they'd come through. To reiterate, the mouse was DOA, I informed the company, they emailed me a question which I answered, they emailed me another question which I answered, and I did not hear back from them. I emailed them again just in case my last email got lost somehow, but never received a response. I addition, they have not responded to this review like they have others.

I'm someone who may be considered technically knowledged, and going by this tablet's specifications, it is a remarkable package for $130. The processor is solid, 1.2 Ghz dual core, and could run Windows 8 if it needed to (albeit slowly). The integrated graphics card is nothing too special, and will get the job done. I tested several games, Asphalt 8, a graphically intense racing game, and Drastic emulator running Pokemon Black, very taxing on the cpu. Asphalt 8 ran well, indicating strong performance, and Drastic rarely lags, although I expected much more: emulators are HUGELY taxing on a system.

The physical design is nice, although I wish the micro USB port was on the bottom. Screen is good and performs well for its outdated technology. Don't expect the screen of a Galaxy S2+ product. The back appears to be rubberized, and its texture is a pleasant and strong grip.

NOTE: The speaker is not a stereo speaker along the bottom as I thought, but a small one on the left side of the bottom. However, it is a strong speaker of remarkable quality.

Overall, I give this tablet a 9.5/10, simply because the power button next to micro USB causes some problems. A wonderful purchase, and I will use it for a long while.

the cable arrived quickly and works fine, no problems whatsoever. i noticed one reviewer had issues where the device he connected it to was not recognized. in newer products it is becoming more the norm so as to prevent end users like us from getting less expensive though equally good chords, manufacturers have embedded microchips in their devices which recognize ONLY chords from the device manufacturer and no others will work. a recent but perfect example is the iphone 5, though i realize that is not a usb 3.0 cable the same proprietary issue applies. sadly it seems to be a growing trend but all you can do is try, do research and hope for the best. thankfully only a handful of device manufacturers have put this new tech out there so odds are it won't affect you. if you do have issues try the cable on another device first preferably from another maker. if that still doesn't work it could be related to your auto detect settings and of course there is always the remote chance the cable is bad. that said in my two plus decades of tech experience i have yet to have a bad cable out literally hundreds i have used between my business, clients and home.

After suffering a catastrophic loss with my first One Touch, and a secondary but less critical failure of another, I finally did my homework and discovered Maxtor's simple solution was not a reliable solution, and that the truly reliable solution was not all that complex.

I am writing this not only as a caution to others, but also as a suggestion on how to start a reliable approach to backup.

THE PROBLEM: Despite my customer research, the Maxtor one Touch II and One Touch III are the worst product decisions I have made in some time - and there is a reason for this.

Of the 2 Maxtor One Touch II's and one Maxtor One Touch III's only one of my II's continue to run. The first failure cost $3,000 to get the data recovered. Unfortunately I was also using it for data overflow at the time.

The second (This model One Touch III) also died about a year after I purchased it. Fortunately I was using only for backup.

They run great out-of-the-box, but after a year they wither and die. Why? I am not sure if it's the incremental file-backup software, or the hardware. Perhaps it is a combination of both, as Maxtor's incremental file-backup software progressively causes slower and slower operation, and more and more drive utilization.

Google the words \\"Maxtor repair\\". There are many vendors. And with most, once they have your drive, it's usually the most expensive thing that needs to be repaired, typically requiring rebuilding the physical electronics.

And considering the proprietary nature of Maxtor's drivers I don't find this price surprising.

Final point: You cannot recover your system if you suffer a complete crash. Expect to reinstall Windows, Office, get updates, and enter licenses, etcetera. You can recover your files, yes, if your unit is still running.

THE SOLUTION: Get a reliable high capacity internal or external bare bones hard drive, and use image backup software, not file backup software. There's a fundamental difference between \\"file\\" and \\"image\\" backups.

I had several misconceptions about image backup software. But I discovered one can also recover individual files. And MORE importantly, you can recover your entire system as well - very simply from the backup drive. It runs faster, it does a form of incremental backup based on image changes, and is much more reliable. It is rare that a solution is both cheaper and better. And I was not looking for cheaper.

For a hard drive I use a WD 1T Sata. And my software is ShadowProtect desktop. I am sure there are others.

By the way, with this solution, you own the software, so it's not tied to some device that will fail. I also (once a month) do a one shot backup to my inexpensive Western Digital Passport. Again as I own the software, I can apply it to any number of different physical backup devices that do not carry the extra overhead cost of proprietary software and hardware.

EXTRA: In addition, you might want to also consider iDrive, or Carbonite. I would use them for your documents only.

SUMMARY: Unfortunately only those that have experienced the loss of work-related or financial data, family pictures, or even that report that your child wrote of which you are most proud, will appreciate the advantage of being prepared.

Then to compound the problem, once we have experienced loss, we start out by looking for a simple solution. And we may be impressed with the concept of \\"One Touch\\".

But after suffering a catastrophic loss with my first One Touch, and a secondary but less critical failure of another, I finally did my homework and discovered Maxtor's simple solution was not a reliable solution, and that the truly reliable solution was not all that complex.n \\"file\\" and \\"image\\" backups. SUMMARY: Unfortunately only those that have experienced the loss of work-related or financial data, family pictures, or even that report that your child wrote of which you are most proud, will appreciate the advantage of being prepared. Do not buy this machine. I got my 1955-S803 for graphics and travel and have regretted it ever since.  Although the screen is large, the resolution is less than many 15" screens. The keyboard feels nice, but it simply quit working after about 4 months of lower-than-average use. In addition, wireless networking died. When I took the machine to a Toshiba-authorized repair center, they replaced the motherboard and keyboard, but put the (previously working) mousepad in upside down and never got it to work again. After three weeks, I demanded my computer back. Three weeks after that, the keyboard died again. I took the machine to a different repair shop. They replaced the motherboard again, but the machine only lasted another couple of weeks before the keyboard went again. This time, I wiped the hard drive to eliminate any unseen driver conflicts. Unfortunately, the repair disks that Toshiba sent me were bad and, after 1/2 hour of babysitting a system install, I discovered the machine wouldn't boot at all. Toshiba made me pay $10 for another set of boot disks, then shipped them to the wrong address. Two weeks later, I got them and reinstalled the system, took the machine back to the repairshop, and had the keyboard itself replaced.  At least this time, they figured out the mouse pad.  After just a week now, the keyboard is again dead. (I'm writing this on a Mac.) Do not buy this machine. I'm looking at four repair tickets on a machine that frankly gets light use. And did I mention that Toshiba support is chiefly stonewalling? Two months of non-productivity from a machine I bought for work. The 1955 a lemon. Shame on Toshiba for deceiving consumers with it. Shame on magazine reviewers for blindly reciting specs without noting the many, many unhapy user reports like this one.

Last year I had purchased a similar but much less expensive contrast keyboard for him to try which was helpful, but it only lasted 2 months - THIS is a MUCH BETTER QUALITY product and he likes it SO MUCH MORE! Both he and I can HIGHLY RECOMMEND this product!

I have now had 2 of these. The first one became corrupt within a month, but only after I had moved 3 years worth of my photography to it and saved family records dating back to the 1530s on it. Lost forever. Western Digital had me mail it in for data retrieval only to tell me later that it was impossible because of encryption that was military grade. They sent me a new one with no apology for the priceless records that I could never get back again.

During the next year I used the new one to store any new photos I took. Then I was injured in a car accident and didn't take any for a year, but continued to store documents on my WDMP. After under 2 years that drive also became corrupted and I once again lost everything; this time that included every paper I wrote for school for 2 years.

I would not recommend this product to anyone, not even an enemy. It will cause you heartache and grief and you will never be able to recover whatever is lost because of it. The company don't care for their customers at all. The sooner people learn to quit giving their money to such a dishonest company the sooner we can put them out of business and no longer have to worry about them.

What won't this thing do? That list would be much easier to type out. I bought the 212j a few months ago and installed two Western Digital Red 3TB drives in it. I have the drives set to mirror so that I only have 3TB of total storage, but I have two copies of everything so if one drive dies on me, I simply swap it out, the DS212j rebuilds it, and I haven't lost any data. Here's a list of all the features I use and love. Don't think of this thing as purely a NAS. It's a fully functional storage server running a Linux framework.

-It has a gigabit ethernet port which is essential if you'll be streaming to multiple computers and TVs simultaneously.
-It has a built-in DLNA server which can stream so any DLNA compliant Blu Ray players, TVs, and computers in your home.
-Built-in mail server if you want to manage your email storage and distribution from within your home/office
-photo management: once you've moved all your photos to the DS212j, it'll serve them up to any apple product running their iOS app, or to any computer, or via DLNA.
-built-in torrent client that can be managed over iOS. On the road and just thought of something you'd like to download? No problem. Grab your iPad or iPhone, run the app, add the download to your client, there you go! it'll start cranking away on the download without the need to involve/leave on 24/7 a computer.
-built-in iTunes server can serve up all your itunes music/movies/tv shows to multiple computers if you have multiple people that want to share the same collection in the house.
-two USB ports to aid in easy copying. friend coming over and they want to copy a bunch of your content? Plug their USB 3 drive directly into the DS212j, use a laptop or tablet to access the client management page on the 212j, start the copy process, and watch it move ahead at blazing speeds since it's not having to pass through a computer at any point.

It'll do hundreds of other tasks but I just don't have the time to type them all out. This thing is a HUGE step up if you're upgrading from just a plain old NAS.

This Uspeed USB 3.0 Multi-Card Reader is very fast indeed! We professionally produce instructional videos and mostly \\"film\\" onto SDHC cards and, while convenient, transferring the large files does take awhile at USB 2.0 speeds. We upgraded to USB 3.0 earlier in the year and have enjoyed the faster transfer speeds. This card reader allows us to take full advantage of the faster speeds and also supports a wide range of current and legacy card formats.

Installing the reader on our Win 7 64-bit editing PC was very straight forward, just plugged it in to an open USB 3.0 port and it self installed in just a few seconds. I also tested it on my older Vista laptop and it worked just fine at USB 2.0 speeds (backwards compatible).

The reader is fairly small, making it easy to keep in a laptop case or pants pocket, and has four slots that support SDXC*, SDHC*, SD*, CF*, High-Speed CF (UDMA), MS, M2, Micro SDXC, and Micro SD* (* Tested).

This is a very easy choice for those needing a \\"plug-n-play\\" portable USB 3.0 card reader.

Highly Recommended!

Immediately after setting up my 5N I had issues where the SMB share used for a surveillance camera looked strange.  I activated SSH login and started looking around the share while logged into the Drobo.  I got "Input/output error" for a large number of files on the share.  Rebooting the Drobo didn't fix it and the Dashboard said everything was fine.  I was able to delete these files on the command line after a few tries but it's very likely that volume corruption persists.  Drobo tech support agreed when I contacted them and said I could press Control-Shift-P in the Dashboard to initiate a filesystem check.  It doesn't do anything.  A quick check on Google verifies that nobody found it to work.  Drobo tech support's recommendation now is to BUY A SECOND DROBO and copy everything to it, then back.  Seriously?  The Drobo 5N has defective software and the solution is to buy two of them?  Other than that it's decently fast.  UPDATE: I figured out how unmount the RAID and run e2fsck while logged into the 5N's Linux system.  The volume was definitely corrupted despite everything in the Dashboard saying it was fine.  Don't trust your Drobo.  UPDATE 2: Lots more file corruption even though the Dashboard says everything is healthy. I’ve wanted an HTPC for some time now but couldn’t decide if I wanted to build one or buy a small form factor (bookshelf) offering. After reading countless reviews of today’s offerings, I wasn’t confident the performance from a bookshelf pc would be adequate for what I want my HTPC to do. I’ll mostly use it to stream content to my flat screen but would also like to run serviio and pogoplug’s desktop software.
I chose this i3 processor with HD 4000 graphics because I really didn’t want to purchase a dedicated video card. I’ll put my gaming pc’s card (Nvidia GTX 560Ti) in it when it can’t keep up with new titles.
Overall I’m completely happy with my choice. The computer takes about 60 seconds to start up and be usable; I know installing an ssd will make a huge difference. My gaming pc (i5 2500k) with ssd boot drive takes around 10-15 seconds in comparison.

Below is a summary of my findings over the past week of use in different scenarios.
Computer is running Windows 7 64bit
Scenario 1) Windows Experience Results with my setup (7.9 = Highest possible score)
Processor = 7.2
Memory = 7.6
Graphics (HD 4000) = 6.5
Gaming Graphics (HD 4000) = 6.5
Primary Hard Disk = 5.9 <---Note: this is with the 7200 RPM laptop drive.

Scenario 2) Running Prime 95 with all cores maxed
Core Temps ~60 deg C (I used my i5 2500k fan since it seemed better than the included i3 fan. I also used artic silver thermal paste.)
Saw 48 Watts max on my kill a watt meter

Scenario 3) Streaming High Definition Movie over my network (~7,000 kb/s)
Screen resolution is set to 1920x1080
Core Temps~33 deg C with 10-15% cpu usage
Saw around 26 watts on my kill a watt meter
I didn’t see any pixilation and vlc (using default settings) didn’t show any dropped frames. The HTPC is hooked up to my receiver with an hdmi cable.

Scenario 4) Computer sitting idle
Core Temps~30 deg C with 1-3% cpu usage
Saw around 23 watts on my kill a watt meter

Here is a list of the components used in my HTPC.
Build ~$335 after rebates (excluding hard drive)
Case: Cooler Mater Elite 120 Advanced
Motherboard: Asus P8H77-I
Processor: Intel Core i3-3225 Ivy Bridge
Memory: Corsair Vengeance 2x4GB DDR3 1600MHz
Power Supply: 400W MK III Silencer
Hard Drive: Seagate 7200 RPM laptop drive (had it lying around…)

Future Plans:
I want to get serviio and pogoplug desktop up and running. When my new 3tb hard drives arrive, I’m going to have the HTPC hold all my media files and become a central backup location.

The Venue 8 Pro is wonderful as a little backup computer, but don't expect to do any serious work on it, as the 8-inch screen is definitely hard on the eyes. But I absolutely love having it around to look things up without having to boot up my laptop, or to bring on a trip with me. (I visit family a few times a month doing overnight trips, so it's fantastic to have this in my bag. I own an Etsy shop, so it's much better working on my business on the Venue as opposed to my smartphone.)

If you do buy the Venue, get this less expensive version of the keyboard/case (VSTN®DEll Venue 8 Pro--Windows 8.1--Bluetooth Keyboard Portfolio Case), as opposed to Dell's, which is twice the price. It works great.

Just remember to turn the keyboard off when you're finished with it, as it needs to be charged up in order to run.

The case is cushioned, which makes things a bit bulky, but it also offers great protection for the Venue, and the kickstand for the screen is at a perfect angle.

For the price, this is a killer product.
I love it so far. The battery does not last as long as advertised when watching video but that's a minor problem.

Purchased this battery as a replacement for the Dell original. It does not work. When the computer's on, and the power cord plugged in, the battery reads fully charged. If the power cord (charger) is removed, the computer immediately shuts down, (not turn-off, not hibernate, it loses all power).
I'm returning this battery within a week of purchasing it.

I was pretty excited for this product. I like to take a loptop with me when I travel but don't like the weight. Tried to get connection with my wireless; this worked the first time okay. I loaded word and excell. Did some work played around and shut down. Next day booted it up and the same blackout and flicker started again. Then I could'nt get on the internet. No wireless connections found. So I got my regular laptop out and booted up, no problems connecting. SO I called Acer, only through the email, told me to do a e reinstall. Lost everything went through the whole process and the blackout flickering started all over again. Got ahold of Acer again and was told it was a hardware issue to return it. So Amazon (You are so wonderful to do business with Thank You.) sent me a new one and I packaged up the old one and sent it back. All excited I opened the new one (#2) booted it up, went through the whole thing again and the black out, flickering started again. And no wireless internet found. So I got my laptop booted her up and signed right on. So once again I contacted Acer did the whole email thing and was told to do a e reinstall. Forget it. I called Amazon and they are giving me a full refund and I am sending this thing back. I will be searching for another travel laptop, does anyone have a suggestion on a great light weight travel computer???? Anyway don't buy this thing, not worth the hassle.

So I dumped my Netgear wireless G router -- as it was dropping wireless connections like crazy, and constantly needed to be rebooted to work.

I liked D-Link in the past, and decided to go with Wireless N as my new laptop supports it.

This router was cheap, and it seems most of the bad reviews are from people who just can't figure out how to setup a router (it's easy).

So, some people are ripping on the setup disc... I wouldn't know anything about it, I never actually touched it.

For anyone even remotely familiar with routers, this d-link is plug and play. Plug it in, and it works instantly. To set it up, ignore silly discs, and just log in directly to the router, D-Link has a wonderful admin panel.

Just go to 192.168.0.1 and no password is required for your first log in. Setup a password on it, then go to wireless setting, create a WPA Personal password for that (if thats what you need) and voila, you have secured, wireless internet, all setup. I had mine working completely in less than 5 minutes.

This router hasn't dropped a signal yet in over a week of use, with multiple wireless connections and all 4 wired ports being used (TiVo, playstation, personal computer, network hard drive)... Hasn't skipped a beat... fast internet.

So please ignore the \\"can't set it up\\" reviews, throw the install disc away and just plug your computer in and use the onboard admin panel (d-links is VERY good).

Highly recommend -- especially for the price.

p.s. - I don't know much about the range, I have a 1200 square foot condo and it's full bars through the whole thing - so no complaints, if you have a larger house, you may want to consider the extended range version of this router.

MAKE SURE YOU USE A PALM GRIP IF YOU'RE GONNA BUY THIS MOUSE. I used a fingertip grip before I bought this but I chose to buy this mouse based on the reviews and the looks of it. If you don't know what I'm talking about, a fingertip grip is where no part of your palm touches the mouse, and you keep your wrist in one position and simply pivot your wrist and use your fingers to move the mouse. It is the grip of the master race to be quite honest :) A fingertip grip requires you to lift up the mouse a lot, thus a fingertip grip doesn't work well with this mouse, for two reasons. (1)- the lift off distance is too high (but I very easily fixed that by putting a strip of scotch tape over the laser, so that's hardly a problem :D (2) more importantly it's somewhat heavy and large so it causes finger strain. So I chose get used to the palm grip, and although I miss the precision of my old fingertip grip sometimes, the palm grip is very comfortable. It's a great mouse if you use a palm grip, and that's what it's made for so that's how I'm grading it. So...    Pros: uber-comfort, braided cord, 3 dpi settings, looks cool, 2 handy buttons in the thumb area, dpi switch buttons above the mouse wheel, unique/comfortable rubber-like texture. The box it came in is pretty cool lol.    Cons: you have to download and unzip the customization software on the Mionix website which is a hassle, the liftoff distance is at least 8 millimeters which is too high imo although it's easily fixed with some clear tape.     I know I've made a big deal about this being a palm grip mouse but hopefully I'm helping someone who was like me before I bought this.

This worked perfectly for nearly five months - and then failed catastrophically, losing all my data and refusing to boot. While it was working, I had no complaints. In the few days before its total failure, however, my machine locked up twice and I noticed strange disk-related pauses during operation. These were probably signs of the impending doom.  I see there are many others in the same situation: trouble-free operation for a few (very few) months, followed by total catastrophe.  The disk is now in such a state that I cannot even rescue the damaged raw sector contents. It reports itself to the system as being a 20MB (!) disk, so the sectors with my work on them seem to be unreachable.  I will be contacting MyDigitalSSD for a refund.  UPDATE: I filled in their RMA request form and returned the faulty disk to them. MyDigitalSSD processed everything in a reasonable manner, though it took a few days delay after submitting the form for the RMA to be issued, and almost all of the "allow two weeks" for the returned item to be processed and refunded.

**Update: I've found online that there appears to be driver incompatibility issues between Displaylink, which apparently makes the software within this device, and Nvidia graphics cards. Unfortunately, my XPS 15 has an Nvidia card, and so I have the issues listed below. Displaylink has been aware of these issues for about 2 years now and has not come up with a patch to fix this. Maybe they don't like money. As always, however, Amazon was willing to take it back without any fuss. Another good Amazon experience.

The docking station would have been the perfect solution for the intended use of my laptop at home...if it worked. There are two main deal-breakers for this device that I think warrant my sending it back.

First of all, I use Windows Media Center (WMC) in conjunction with a Home Run Prime TV tuner to record and watch TV through my laptop (XPS 15) and on my main TV in the living room. With all the cables going directly into my laptop, it works fine. With all the cables running through the docking station and the one USB 3.0 cable going into my laptop, WMC will not open full-screen; it just shows a black background with the cursor above it. Even if I run it not in full screen, the video and audio are very choppy. If I can't use the docking station with WMC in full-screen, that alone means I probably won't keep it.

Another issue I've found is that restarting laptops through the docking station doesn't work; instead of the laptop rebooting after shutting down, it stays shut down and I have to manually power it on. This doesn't seem like a big deal, but because I keep the laptop under my TV in a tight space with a million cords running around, it is not trivial.

I've updated the drivers for the docking station--which also was not intuitive because for some reason the Displaylink software will not look for updates when you are running your internet through the docking station, and so I had to enable my wireless card from mylaptop to do this)--and that still didn't help either of these issues.

First off, this keyboard is phenomenal. I was using a Logitech G series for years and loved it until trying out this keyboard (which I bought at a big box store at discount while working retail).

Only downside is this keyboard is NOT mechanical. I don't personally like mechanical keyboards as they are rather loud and I don't like the excessive noise plus the keys don't feel natural to me. If you don't know, a mechanical keyboard has a spring, very hard feel to each individual key. It's great for rapid typing as it will recognize every key press when a standard board may miss a keystroke if the key is constantly pressed and the pressure isn't registered.

Despite not being mechanical (a positive for me) it is all around an excellent keyboard.

It has a backlighting feature, three different colors Blue, Red & Purple and three brightness settings. The keyboard isn't as large as my Logitech either despite having the extra game pad. The standard format of the keyboard is the same, except the Middle collection of keys such as Num Lock, PG Dn, Del, etc are secondary functions on the numpad side of the keyboard (to reduce size). The keyboard also has solid media controls on the top of the board next to brightness settings.

This can be a hassle because say you want to delete the line of text, if Numlock is on, it will assume you want the number 1 key rather then the secondary function "Del". You must turn Numlock off then select Del for it to properly delete. This isn't a huge issue, a lot of laptops, tablets etc have this same concept. Think of it as a Function key but you don't have to hold it and combine keystrokes.

The gamepad:

This is the sole reason I bought the keyboard. The further distance for the standard WASD layout is naturally a better rest for my left hand; a great start. The keys are soft but easily register my motions, plus the keys for WASDQE are larger and better shaped for gaming. Above the directional keys are 1-6 rotating above with 7-11 just above those. They are small keys but wrap very nicely around the controls. For a while (few days) you will misclick quite a bit and hit wrong numbers due to the size but after practice you can really feel the layout and having 1-6 at extremely easy reach is a huge advantage, plus 7-11 being actually viable.

Next to the numbers is a quick "Load" key, "Print Screen" and "Save" key, perfect for fast actions, especially screen capturing.

Despite the perfect numbering layout above the WASD keys, I actually find myself using the alternate buttons spread across the gamepad more. Just left of Q is a Tab key (usually great for scoreboard checks) and a quick Caps Lock. Just further down is Alt, Shift & Ctrl all are perfectly placed and actually have a great natural feel for running/walk actions or keystroke combinations (alt + Mouse Button 1 etc).

Most people use R & F already but Steelseries have even fitted R & F better plus made T, G & V easily to hit. In addition, the space bar is a smaller button but perfectly lands on my thumb, which allowed room for C, B & P. The keys are tight but I rarely mis clicks with the alternate keys in the beginning like I did with the numbers. The compact design allows you to use your index finger to hit the alternate keys or your thumb comfortably or both.

Overall, the gamepad is the real highlight of the keyboard. Every key is exactly where you would want it to be. It definitely helped increase my speed and reaction times just by having the extra assortment of easy access keys to use. Not only that, the standard section of the keyboard, backlighting and media keys are all top quality as well. I highly recommend this for any gamer, casual or advanced. The gamepad alone just allows for a more comfortable gaming experience.

The keyboard also has 2 USB ports & Headphone/Microphone jacks at the top.

Highly recommend,

As many reviews of this product note, once it's working it's a great value and works well. And I assume for most buyers the powerline adapter truly is plug-and-play.

Which is a good thing. Because if anything goes wrong, you're totally on your own. The product comes with nothing in the way of useful documentation, either on paper or on the mini-CD. There is a configuration tool you can load on a PC, but no instructions of any kind on how to use it.

I tried installing three adapters--one for the router and two for outlets. The outlet connected to the PC came up with a lot of changes of settings on the configuration tool. The outlet connected to a PS/3 was never recognized, though all the lights were on. (The PS/3 had previously worked with a Cisco powerline adapter.)

The company's website offers multiple ways of contacting technical support. None of them work. For U.S. buyers, there is a toll-free number that is supposed to be \\"24/7\\". In fact, no one ever answers, no matter when you call. Sometimes you get a message that the tech support staff are all busy and please call back later. Sometimes you are asked to leave a message, but no one ever calls back.

I also tried emailing the company. After two days I received a reply that asked me to repeat information from the email I sent. I wrote back, then nothing.

After several days of trying to get some kind of technical support, I gave up. I could never get the adapter connected to the PS/3 to be recognized, and I tried every possible setting, resetting, switching the adapters, you name it. It worked fine for the PC, eventually.

Bottom line: great if it works out of the box. Otherwise, don't bother.

This ssd can't finish power on self initialization within 3 seconds.  The latest fast notebooks, take about 3 seconds from pushing power on button to transition to boot device. Within this time frame, computer sends \\"enumerate device yourself\\" request in the bus, and waits for responses until timeout. If drive does not respond, and does not report \\"I am ready\\", the drive is treated \\"not detected\\". That's exactly what happens to this ssd.  I used Samsung 850 EVO 1TB ssd, model MZ-75E1T0B/AM, on a notebook computer, Acer E3-111, it's always like this: when push power button, computer hdd detection of about 3 seconds timeout, the ssd does not respond within this time frame, computer reports no drive detected, and boot halts.  The solution is every time after non-detection occurs, hot restart computer by ctrl+alt+del. Because at that time, ssd has finished power on self initialization, then computer will always detect the ssd, and boot continues to succeed.   Tested the same computer with other brands of hdd, ssd, without non-detection issue. Confirmed the issue is this ssd is slow on power on initialization.  Samsung has to fix it.
