My first digital camera used Compact Flash card. I bought a PNY card which corrupts every so often. When that happened, I would have to turn the camera off and on again (sort of re-boot), and all the pictures already taken would lost. Originally, I thought it was the camera (a HP), but after some research on the web, I found out that it was a problem common to PNY cards as well as other cheap cards.
Therefore, when it was time for me to buy a SD card for my new digital camera, I got smart this time and did the homework first. Thanks to all the reviewers on Amazon.com, I narrowed my choices to Panasonic and SimpleTech, both with almost identical specs. I purchased the Panasonic card because of its slightly lower price at the time. I now have used this card for over 3 months, and am absolutely satisfied with its performance. First off, it is very fast. My camera has a "burst" mode in which it takes 5 consecutive shots a second. This cards handles it with ease. Most importantly, this card is extremely reliable. I have taken over 2,000 pictures with it and never once had problem with file corruption.
You will take countless number of pictures over the life of a SD card, so it is well worth the extra $20-$30 for the speed and reliability. Highly recommend it with any digital camera.

I love every thing about my new Kindle, from the size and weight of it to the handsome design and incomparable readability. But had I known that Amazon does not allow library access to Kindles, which means no free rentals of e-books, I would have chosen another e-reader. Log on to your library's web site and see the long list of devices that CAN download e-book rentals, and you will be amazed that Kindle appears to be the only one that doesn't allow library access.     I have never been dissatisfied with Amazon's products or services, and have always had positive results from shopping on Amazon. So I can only hope that Amazon will see the disservice they are doing to their customers by forcing them to buy what they could otherwise rent for free. Perhaps if enough Kindle owners and even more important, would-be Kindle owners, were to protest, Amazon might rethink their position and be magnanimous enough to change their policy. I was quite surprised and impressed by the difference the Creative Soundblaster X-Fi Surround 5.1 Pro USB Audio System with THX SB1095 made with my speakers. I have an ASUS laptop with Windows 7 64bit that has a very unimpressive sound system internally so I have been using external speakers to help with sound quality. Adding the Creative Soundblaster external sound card has made a tremendous difference. The sound quality is a 100 times improved, allowing for a much more pleasurable experience listening to music or watching a video. The volume set to it's highest setting is loud enough that to have a conversation, I had to raise my voice quite a bit, almost to a shout, to be heard.

I tried two different external speakers, both are 2.0 speakers, to see if there was a difference in sound quality with highly satisfying results:
[[ASIN:B000IF4788 Logitech X-140 2.0 Speakers]] and [[ASIN:B001ELK2NY Altec Lansing iM-237 Orbit Ultraportable Speaker for MP3 Players (Silver)]]

The whole process of setting up the Creative Soundblaster external sound card took about 20 minutes, 15 minutes of it was installing the software and downloading the latest update to that software. The instructions that come with it are very easy to follow and intuitive as to where everything plugs into.

Also, I love how small the external sound card is, just a little bigger than a deck of cards or an iPhone, so it takes up minimal space.

I highly recommend the Creative Soundblaster external sound card to anyone looking to upgrade their current sound system, I know I'm extremely happy with it.

The short story: DO NOT BUY THIS CHARGER. IT IS UNSAFE.

My original Mac charger took four years of pretty serious abuse before the cable became frayed at the connector. I figured another \\"Genuine Apple\\" charger would offer at least the same service life. Man was I wrong.

Less than a week in, after being perfectly gentle and kind to the new product, the transformer is cracked along the seam, and becomes too hot to touch under normal use. It is clearly unsafe. Do not buy this product. With no exaggeration, if you leave this charger unattended on top of a stack of dry papers while you go to work or to sleep, it could catch fire. I am returning it, and buying another one of a different kind. No, probably not from the Apple store, as I am not made of money, and I never learn my lesson about buying cut-rate stuff for my Mac.

There are a couple of major issues with this product. 1. The description says that the 3.5mm audio cables are 24 inches long, however they are actually 12 inches long. So if you are using this to hook up a laptop, and your laptop doesn't have the VGA and 3.5mm outputs on the same side of the laptop, this product will not reach both. 2. I hooked up our laptop to our TV using this VGA and it would not work in \\"duplicate\\" mode, so you either have to make the TV be a second extension screen, or have the laptop screen be off. In addition, it wouldn't display in the proper dimensions, so when watching things like videos on hulu, it doesn't fill the screen with a full widescreen picture. I know this is a problem with the cable, because I tried it with another VGA, and it worked in duplicate mode, and hulu vidoes filled the screen.  If you need the VGA and 3.5mm audio to plug into a laptop, and you want the have vidoes fill the TV screen, don't buy this.

I have read a lot of the reviews and appreciate the input.  It seems to me the DX and possibly the K2 are still just a bit \\"too new\\" and untested to invest this amount of money.  I love the concept and it seems the Kindle is a reasonably nice product.  However, things I have picked up from the reviews which tell me to wait for a year or two are:    1.  Price.  This is still a bit too expensive to feel comfortable that I am getting my money's worth.  Amazon should do what the ink-jet printer folks did which is give you the printer for almost nothing and you pay big on the refills -- give the Kindle away for almost nothing and make the money on the downloads.  This will get millions of Kindles out on the market creating a lot more demand for content.    2.  It appears the DX (and maybe the K2?) screen will likely break or get scratched even under fairly normal use - really bad design by Amazon and the current policy is to charge you $350 to get it fixed.    2. The other big issue is the battery.  If I understand correctly, you cannot buy a replacement battery, you have to turn your Kindle in for over $100 or more to have them ship you a new Kindle (so why can't they ship you a new Kindle if you screen breaks for the same price?)  This means that about every two years (average time for batteries to work for a long period of time) you are paying over $100 to keep your kindle working.    3. If you upgrade to the next Kindle, you have a good chance of losing books you previously bought that Amazon claims is \\"safe forever\\".    4. Amazon seems to believe they are the morality police and will delete whatever they feel is inappropriate on your Kindle - really bad policy.    5. I think having some kind of built-in led light would be useful to make it readable at night or while in a car or similar.  This would be a small drain on the battery, but very useful.    I think this space needs a really strong competitor to motivate Amazon to \\"do this right\\".  I don't see this taking off until there is a strong competitor and these core issues addressed.    Dale

I chose this device over the cheaper device because it advertised Push support. Upon receiving the device I set up my GAFYD (Google Apps for your Domain) account, and it started bringing *some* of my email into the Inbox on the Peek. After about 20 minutes of no longer receiving any new mail, I sent myself an email to test Push. After waiting about 10 minutes, the email finally arrived on my Peek... obviously not push, or \\"instant\\" as they advertise on the box.     I then called Tech support to see why Push was not working properly. I was told that due to \\"Network Capacity\\" issues, not all accounts will have push at this time, and that as the network capacity increases, more accounts will be given push functionality. I was then told that could be 1-2 months before I would see such functionality. I was unwilling to wait 1-2 months for the promise of functionality that was advertised to come right out of the box. It is now 45 minutes after un-boxing my Peek, and it is now back in the box, sealed, and has a return label on the box.     The one good thing I can say for the Peek is that their customer service was excellent. The tech I spoke with was quite informative, and the CSR I spoke with after being told Push was unavailable quickly deactivated my device, and got me set up so the $49.95 I paid for 3 months of service would be credited back to my card in full. Unfortunately, great customer service isn't a substitute for false advertisement.

My story: Bought this to replace a an older Kingston Datatraveler 101 that had survived two years of daily use and abuse on my keychain without a single glitch. I've had good luck with Patriot memory on my computer, and the design looked durable, so I picked it up at the end of June. I should have known that it would have problems, because from Day 1 it would get really hot when moving data back and forth. Still, it worked without a problem until early August, when I plugged it into my computer one day and found it blank. No partition, no data, no nothing. Testdisk couldn't recover the original partition, neither Photorec or any of my other utilities could pull any data from the drive, and even worse, nothing can put a partition back ON the drive. There are unrecoverable write errors when attempting to create a new partition, which means the memory itself is shot. After having such great luck with my previous drive, this short lived experiment has been a bit of a disappointment.

Patriot claims this has a 5 year warranty. And in the e-mail I got this response from Patriot Memory:

Manufacturer Response:

Dear -----:

Thank you for your purchase and review of our Tab 3 USB 3.0 flash drive. Our Tab continues to be one of the most reliable USB Drives on the market and has picked up many industry accolades for performance value and reliability. It is unfortunate you are experiencing write protection issues with one of our USB Drives, but rest assured Patriot stands behind our products and will work with you to resolve the issue as quickly as possible. Please apply this patch fix and follow-up with me if you have any further questions.

[...] Official Patch.zip

Thank you,

James
Patriot Support

I purchased this computer on behalf of my jr. higher, who had saved up and researched laptops good for gaming.  We bought it June 26, 2012, it started overheating and crashing in late March of 2013.  We purchased a cooling pad in April, thinking this would resolve the issue, it did not. Busy with the combination of school finals and traveling, I tried contacting the seller, ELECTRONIC777 in June (before our 1 yr. exp. date) and they said there was nothing they could do and to go to Dell directly. I contacted Dell, went through diagnostic testing, they confirmed there may be a faulty part, but could not advice me any further since the 1 yr warranty on the laptop expired in Jan 2013, because that was the purchase date they had on record.  They recommended I contact the seller since the seller should be obligated to honor the 1 yr. warranty I had understood it to have.  I contacted ELECTRONIC777 and they basically verified I was suppose to have a 1 yr. warranty, but it was Dell's responsibility and were ABSOLUTELY no help, in fact instead of helping me as one of their customers, it felt like they were basically giving me the finger and saying it's your problem.  I tried contacting Amazon, thinking they would step in on my behalf having records of my purchase date and the fact that I was indeed suppose to have a 1 yr. warranty.  I filled out all the requested information and they sent me an email saying it did not fall into the A-Z Guarantee.  Ok, glad they're there to protect their consumers, shame on you amazon.  So here I am with a laptop that is barely a year old does not work for more than 20 min without crashing, a seller who won't help me, and a 1 yr. warranty that was only honored for 7 months.  I'm still trying to haggle this out with Dell, but something is VERY wrong with the whole system, BUYER'S BEWARE.  I would never buy from this seller, ELECTRONIC777 again.

I received delivery of the product on 06/01/2012, and started testing on 06/02/2012.

Let me first say that up until I purchased this product, I never had a complaint regarding price, installation, and system requirements for any Maxtor or Seagate HDD product, external or internal.

The box states: \\"Windows 7, Vista, XP (32-bit and 64-bit) Operating System or...
backwards compatible with USB 2.0 ports...\\"

However, that is a bit misleading.

As per my usual caution, I downloaded and tested the new drive using \\"Seagate's SeaTools\\". It passed all basic and advanced tests EXCEPT \\"USB Full Disc Erase\\". Tested it twice, and failed both times after about 10 secs. I called Seagate support today (06/11/2012), and wasn't given a very good answer except that the drive had passed all the other tests. So, in their opinion, the drive was not defective. (See below for a more detailed account of my discussion with Seagate Support.)

Okay...

Started \\"MS's Adminstrative Tools\\" to setup the drive for use on my system. It came preformatted as a 2-TB drive and the balance of the drive as \\"unallocated\\" (Drive is the 3-TB version).

I saved the installation software in a backup folder on my data drive, deleted the existing partition, and attempted to create a single partition. This couldn't be completed as Windows has a 2-TB limit on the \\"Master Boot Record\\" (MBR) format. Okay, no worries, just create a 2-TB partition and a second partition with the balance. Unfortunately, that 2-TB limit applies to the entire drive and not just the partition.

However, Windows offers the option of setting the drive up as a \\"GUID Partition Table (GPT)\\" which is an \\"Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI)\\" format. OKAY! KOOL!

Now to performing a full backup... Only Windows' Backup finishes with an error message. So, I try the software by Memeo included on the drive. Using Windows' Backup, I can perform acomplete Image-File backup. The software by Memeo can't. Hence, even with the drive setup as GPT, I still cannot use my existing programs to do the work I have completed successfully in the past.

Today, 06/11/2012, I call support to determine if the drive is defective and require a warranty return? We discuss the test results, and determine that the drive has successfully completed all tests. The one failure allegedly has something to do with the 2-TB limit under Windows 7 (64-bit). Secondly, Windows' Backup has incompatibilities with the drive, and the included software hasn't the capabilities that Backup offers.

The solution to these issues appears to be another software product that is available for free download from Seagate's website: Seagate DiscWizard. I am currently testing this product as I am typing this review.

Regardless, I have come to expect better quality and service from Seagate. So, I am sadly disappointed by this product and lack of accurate information printed on the box.

At the very least, a software driver that allows full access to the drive's capacity and features would have been an a nice \\"invisible\\" solution, but even that is lacking.

So, my recommendation is to avoid this specific product: 3-TB, and stay with 2-TB's or less. My research suggests that there are hardware issues for older systems: the BIOS can't support GPT, and many operating systems can't fully support the capacity of drives larger than 2-TB's even with GPT.

I had been researching tablets for several months. I decided this one best suited my needs.  I was right. The price was in the range I was hoping for, the size is perfect, downloading is easy, it is easy to navigate and easy to read. The only drawback I see is the battery life is a little lacking.

We are a three Kindle family now and all of us, including my mother-in-law to whom we just gave one for her birthday, are, to say the least, thrilled. True, the current Kindle model takes a little - but very little - time to master the mechanics of holding it when reading, using the various function keys, etc., but what new piece of hardware doesn't require such time? Not many, and here the learning curve is NOT steep. Because we share one AMAZON account, we are able to download any book one of us might buy to the other's Kindle. This is a very cool aspect of Kindle ownership, since we can all read the same material at the same time and have a discussion without having to wait for someone to catch up. The battery life is phenomenal, downloads take seconds seemingly anywhere (we are vacationing in Kauai at the present time and I have downloaded several books while sunning on the beach!), and the selection of books, newspapers, and magazines for purchase and download seems to grow exponentially every time I visit the Kindle store. Finally, the cost of downloads is less than the cost of the print edition and will likely decrease as more people acquire a Kindle and begin to build their libraries. Oh, I almost forgot: an SD card can be used to store books within the Kindle itself so that an entire library will occupy the space of a few, or many, your choice, SD cards. As technology evolves and the cost of said technology drops as it usually does, I am confident that the Kindle will become the preferred reading method of all ages in all settings. I think that I just talked myself into buying AMAZON stock! If you are an avid reader, give yourself a gift, or list it for others who love you to buy at the appropriate time, and get a Kindle. It probably will be one of the better decisions of your life. Have fun!

I think ZAGG makes a fine product when it comes to anti-glare, smudge-resistant films for the iPhone and iPad, but they missed the mark with this HD film. I'm no novice to installing their protective films, but ZAGG decided to try something new with the HD film which was clearly a step in the wrong direction. Installation is not the same as their anti-glare, smudge-resistant films for iPad. Instead, you have to pry apart two outside, hard plastic covers (one so clear, you might mistake it for the intended film), and then go through the usual spray process. The problem, though, is that this film is a little thicker, stickier, and more prone to attracting the smallest particles in the air - so you have to act fast.
Once you get the film on the iPad, that's where the real fun begins. The film is thicker and seems to not want to lay correctly unless you soak it in the ZAGG solution (included). Once you get the film in position, even after spraying the outside of the film so the squeegee glides easily, hints of solution bubbles remain. Not air bubbles, but barely noticeable bubbles of the ZAGG solution, that, no matter how hard and carefully you squeegee, you will not get out. The first install attempt, I didn't even see them in a well-lit room. It wasn't until I walked by a window with natural light with the iPad off that I noticed. I pulled up the film, sprayed again, and it went downhill from there. At it's best, it looks like a clear piece of cellophane, shiny, and mirror-like. The iPad image is clear when on, but the surface looks like a mistake when it's off.
I will not purchase this version again, and will not recommend it to anyone else.

While I\\"m sure in a year the kinks will be worked out, this product isn't ready for mainstream deployment. After plugging it into my 2012 MacBook Air, it froze the entire machine. In comparing the USB 3.0 and Thunderbolt adapters to the GoFlex 1.5TB 2.5inch portable drive, the USB 3.0 was actually faster running BlackMagicDesign Disk Speed Test.

Other things to consider (beside the high price of the adaptor and cable) ... the Thunderbolt adapter nearly doubles the thickness of the drive since unlike the USB 3.0 adaptor, it has a 3x5 by 1/2 inch portion attached to the back of the drive. It also runs hot and transfers the heat to the drive. The Apple cable, which actually has logic chips in it, runs very very hot (the cable).

-- Mark

I wasn't expecting a whole lot and I got way more than I bargained for. I still can't believe this laptop is only $250. I have been an Apple user since 1989 and this is the first non-Apple computer I've ever purchased. I got this as a second (or third) computer as I have an iMac as my main system and an ailing MBP circa 2007 that is still chugging along. I was looking at replacing the MBP with a Macbook Air, but was balking at the pricetag. I really didn't need it to do any heavy lifting in terms of video, photo or web work, but mainly to catch up on email, keep up with scheduling, do some research and use office documents. I've since found a lot more uses for it...

For me the killer app on this system is the Remote Desktop app which means that you can access your main system remotely and use any app on that system, save to Google Drive or Drop Box and you're good to go while away from your office. It is small, light and very quick. I've had zero issues in the three weeks I've had it. I'm happy to be free of Apple's spinning beachball (curiously never happens when I'm buying something from their store...), the weight of my old MBP and am super happy that this cost me a sixth of the cost of a Macbook Air!!!

Cloud computing is easy to get used to. Google makes it ridiculously easy. They will need to beef up their app store to make this viable in the long term and I believe they will do it.

A quick note for Canadian customers. You're going to have to purchase this in the US and bring it back with you. A lot of Google's products like Google Play for music and movies don't work in Canada which really sucks. You only need the wifi version as the 3G is pointless here. There are plenty of great apps to do what you normally do in those bloated, overly expensive Mac apps (can't speak for Windows), it's just a question of finding the appropriate equivalent. To be honest, my MBP is sitting on my desk with the lid shut collecting dust. I don't have to think twice to take the Chromebook with me as it is so small and light. The build quality is really impressive, maybe not as sexy as a MBA, but definitely well built. Samsung and Google have really done an incredible job! Well done!!! I can't recommend this little laptop and Chrome OS highly enough. If you're on the fence, get off and pull the trigger.

I saw this product and it had great ratings, and so did the seller, so I ordered it. This was for my teen daughter's birthday.
She LOVES music and has been asking for speakers for a long time and after several reviews I found these that looked the most promising.
The product was delivered quickly (Prime) and we were all set, or so I thought.
On her birthday we opened them and found out that there must be a short in them, they kept shorting out and restarting and we would loose sound in one speaker all together. Perhaps they were damaged during shipping, but who knows.
I thought, no problem, surely I can just contact the seller and get an exchange. However, to my dismay, once I looked up the product on Amazon it said that this product was not eligible for return. My heart sank and I figured that I would need to go through an RMA with the manufacture.
Out of curiosity, I found a 'contact seller' link on Amazon and asked them why this product was not eligible for return.
Apparently, they were not aware or decided that providing great customer service was their priority, and they did just that.
Not only, did they tell me that they would accept a return, they even sent me a pre-paid return label so I did not have to pay to have it shipped back, amazing! It gets better, I had already been in contact with the manufacture about an RMA, but had decided to pursue the return with the seller first and if that didn't pan out then I would go back to them. Once the seller received the defective unit, they worked directly with the manufacture to get a brand new unit sent directly to me. I received communications from both the seller and manufacture letting me know the status of each step.
The new speakers worked great and sound awesome, my daughter is VERY happy. Separately, we also bought a stereo Bluetooth receiver and now she plays her music wirelessly, even better.
Kudos to both the seller and manufacture for taking complete care of the customer. Definitely recommend both them, and this product, to anyone.

The sound from these speakers are amazing, clear and full range, we listened to some binaural recordings and it sounded like we were in the room with them. The bass isn't as thumping as some speakers I have but it is all there and still strong and for the price these are the best sounding speakers I have heard.

-Happy Customer

Out of the box set up was easy with a Motorola cable modem. I found the TP-Link would drop connection when I had it cascaded to a Linksys. With that removed it has worked fine. We've got three computers and half a dozen other devices connected smoothly with no performance issues. While the cascaded router I removed was always dropping the signal, the TP-Link has been very reliable without it. The instructions for Mac users were very clear and did not require use of the cd. I appreciated the ease of set up and easy to understand menus. My older router was from 2007 so it had been some time since I had to install a new one. Visually this router is better placed out of sight. The slick gloss finish of the top is a complete fingerprint magnet and the grooves are begging for dust. It has a bigger footprint than I like - my old one was a vertical model - but the depth isn't bad so it fits into an Ikea Billy shelf nicely. Good option for a basic home unit.

UPDATE: starting in Nov of 2013 the router would not assign an ip or connect to my desktop. I thought the issue was my desktop until January when suddenly iPad, TiVo, phone - none of them could connect. I COULD connect to my network extenders, which were able to pick up signal from the router. The problem went from intermittent to continual. After three months of trying to find a work around I tossed the router out. With no firmware updates coming (it's no longer supported - that was quick) I dropped this from a four star to a 1 star review. Worked great until it didn't and the failure was much too fast in arriving.
Good replacement. However my laptop still has a clicking when then fan speeds up, so I don't think it's the product.

Then I bought the Intuos5 Touch Medium in November 2012. My opinion of Wacom and its products has done a complete 180. My advice to any prospective buyer is to do an extensive amount of research, and not on the Wacom website. Find out what people all over the web are saying.

Having been a long time Wacom user, I was honestly shocked to find that I disliked this tablet immediately. Simply put, it's too complicated. It tries to do too much. It took a long time for me to search out all of the information necessary to customize this tablet so that I could use it without cursing every 5 seconds at all the crazy defaults. Additionally, the Intuos5 does NOT play nice with Windows 8 and workarounds were necessary. This is a documented issue, so if you have Win8, do your homework before you decide to buy this product.

Furthermore, the Intuos5 USB plug is *extremely* loose at the tablet end & wiggles all over the place. This is also a documented issue. I was constantly losing the connection in mid stroke. I posted several requests for Tech Support to the Wacom website and never received a reply. In desperation I ordered a Wireless Kit from Wacom. Upon arrival, it didn't work.

I called Customer Service and they couldn't pull me up on their system so I provided all of my information over the phone. They walked me through hooking up the Wireless Kit to confirm that it didn't work. Then I was asked to email additional info so that they could ship a replacement Wireless Kit. Despite everything, Customer Service kept getting my address wrong when confirming info back to me. I kept correcting them and they kept acknowledging receipt of my corrections, but when I received the tracking number for the new Wireless Kit, I discovered that they were shipping to an incorrect address! There must have been 15 emails in all before they finally got my address right.

I finally received a replacement Wireless Kit and it does work, but problems with the tablet have rendered it useless. You must plug in the tablet's USB cable to charge the battery that comes with the wireless kit. My USB cable stopped making a connection to the tablet in March, 2013. I am certain that there's no break in the cord. The problem is the port on the tablet.

I ended up shelling out over $375 for 3 months of tablet use. Wacom products and support are a far cry from what they used to be.for the new Wireless Kit, I discovered that they were shipping to an incorrect address! There must have been 15 emails in all before they finally got my address right.

You must plug in the tablet's USB cable to charge the battery that comes with the wireless kit. My USB cable stopped making a connection to the tablet in March, 2013. I am certain that there's no break in the cord. The problem is the port on the tablet.

I ended up shelling out over $375 for 3 months of tablet use. Wacom products and support are a far cry from what they used to be.

I am typing this review from my NewTrent 38B Wireless Keyboard on my iPad2. So far so good. First of all, set-up is simple. Plug-in the USB charger to charge the keyboard battery for 3 hours on your initial use. Can't wait to try it out? No problem, the keyboard is fully functional while it is charging. The keyboard pairs to the iPad via Bluetooth. Again, simple. Just type in the code on your iPad screen and ensure it is connected and you're done.

My biggest complaint with using the iPad has always been the terrible typing interface. The iPad is a powerful tool, but I wouldn't spend the money on one over a laptop or iPhone if I had to choose. This keyboard (so far) solves that. I love the functionality of the iPad and larger screen size. One negative, however, is that autocorrect seems to be disabled while using the keyboard. Before, while awkwardly thumb-typing, most of my mistakes were conveniently fixed without notice. With this keyboard, that is no longer the case. I also haven't discovered a way to pull up the native iPad keyboard, thus, I can only use the NT38B to type.

The case holds the iPad securely, however, the iPad cannot be in a protective case. This thin plastic case likely offers little to no protection if I were to drop it, but I am not willing to test that theory. The case does allow you to position the screen in 3 different settings for both landscape and portrait settings, so that's pretty great, although it does make the case top-heavy if resting on your lap. You can also leave the iPad in its own case and use the keyboard entirely separate from the iPad, as long as you are within ~30 feet of the device.

The small size of the keyboard may be bothersome for some, but for a lightweight compact solution, it is excellent. The keys are responsive without requiring very much pressure, and the fn keys offer additional controls to the iPad.

Overall, I am very pleased with this device. I would recommend it foranyone looking for an affordable compact solution for typing on the iPad.

This PC has a nice and small form factor and is good looking with panels on the front covering devices when they are not in use. You get a panel on the left that opens up to reveal USB, Audio, and Memory card ports. Just below the left panel is a button that ejects a DVD-RW drive that is located under the right panel. Along the top right of the front is a white drive activity light and lit power button. There is also a standard keyboard and mouse in the box along with the power cord and quick start guides.    I got this PC as a gift for the in-laws so I opened it to set it up and make sure it worked ahead of time so I wasn't screwing around with it during Christmas. Overall it feels pretty responsive for a PC with a mechanical drive. There isn't a ton of bloatware installed, just a lot of links to things on the start screen that are easy enough to clean up. I think the only thing that I actually removed was an Amazon one click app. I'll let the antivirus run its course and then uninstall it later.    Some of the details I see now that I have it:    It has an Intel Core i5-4460S processor that has a Processor Base Frequency of 2.9 GHz and Max Turbo Frequency of 3.4 GHz.  It has a Western Digital HDD.  It has Realtek audio and LAN, I can't remember Wi-Fi / BT vendor.  I see a half height x16 and 1x PCIE slots inside.  I see two memory slots and both are populated.  The USB port count in the specs is for the back panel. You also get 2x 2.0 ports in the front.    You should buy a USB thumb drive or two to store backups of the system software. The PC doesn't come with restoration media. There is software installed that will create a bootable system restore setup either on DVD or USB thumb drive. I made a factory system restore thumb drive and put it away. There is also a option to do the same for the system apps and drivers only but it said it would wipe the thumb drive so I couldn't use the same thumb drive that I used for the factory restore. Thumb drives are cheap soget a couple and use them. The factory system restore was under 10GB so a 16GB and a 8GB stick would do it easily.    This seems like a nice general use PC that will serve my in-laws web browsing and casual gaming habits just fine for years to come. I didn't have any problems setting it up or updating it. It seemed to be pretty responsive and it is easy to open up so down the road you should be able to upgrade RAM or drives pretty easily. Overall it seems like a pretty nice general purpose PC that I'd recommend as such.

I bought this memory card for a Sigma camera, of which I have three: DP1, DP2, and SD15. They all take SD cards. All three rejected the Kingston card right out of package, displaying an error message. I called Kingston. They said that their lifetime warranty applies only to supported devices, of which they have a list on their website. According to the list, of Sigma products, they only guarantee that their 2GB SD card will work with Sigma DP1. That's it! For every other Sigma camera, and for every other Kingston card, their warranty does not apply. I have used several other 16GB SD cards from other manufacturers: Transcend, Patriot, Sandisk. They all work fine, in fact I never had any compatibility issues with any device or memory format. The worst part is that Kingston doesn't provide this list of compatible devices on the Amazon product page; not even a link to the webpage. So unless you have an explicit statement from Kingston that your device is supported, the card may not work and you are on your own.  It also doesn't help much that the Amazon refund policy is less than stellar. After I bought the card, it sat around in its packaging unopened for a couple of months, until I needed the card and discovered that it doesn't work. Although 30 days have passed, I thought I'd try and give Amazon a call after I called Kingston. They heard me out and promptly sent a return label my email. I sent the card back the next day. A week later they processed the refund. Without a word to me, they subtracted $4.00 for reason unknown, and $8.00 for return shipping. I could have mailed the card back for less than a dollar. As a result, I got less than half of my money back.  Lesson learned. I'll never buy another Kingston product, and will take extra caution when dealing with Amazon.

I swore to myself a long time ago that I would never buy a Kindle (or other e-reader) because I just loved books too much. Years passed and the idea of the Kindle started to grow on me. I read Kindle books on my Android device and thought it was pretty cool. So, finally, as a birthday present from me to me, I decided to buy a Kindle Touch. HUGE mistake. First, let me list the pros of the Kindle touch so you don't think I'm completely unreasonable.
-lightweight
-good size for holding in one hand even with expensive cover
-3G connectivity very good
-e-ink feature is pretty awesome

Now for the cons:
-non-intuitive interface (For example, I don't know why you can't access the Home page unless you click the home button. The Go To button at the bottom of the screen on my android has a go to home page feature but not on this Kindle.)
-touch screen is TERRIBLE (90% of the time I was trying to get to where I wanted to go rather than actually reading. The touch screen would either: not respond to taps AT ALL, would take ten to fifteen seconds to load a single page so that I think it wasn't working and tap it again, or would go to the next page when I didn't want it to [like when I breathed].)
-page turn--well there's no such thing. DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT IF YOU HAVE EPILEPSY! It kept FLASHING the pages whenever I tapped to turn. It would sort of dissolve, go black for a split second and then flash on the next page. After about an hour of this I got a terrible headache just reading. Amazon, what it wrong with a simple page turn?
-Can't see the covers of my books in the home page (not even in black and white). It's just a list. I know that sounds picky and dumb but I'm a very visual person and I like to see the covers of my books. They're more familiar that way and it doesn't seem like I'm just picking out an article to read online or somthing. My Android device shows the covers beautifully.
-Can't just tap to get it backfrom screensaver, you have to press the power button (took me a while to figure that out too because the thing doesn't come with instructions of any kind).

This drive is like no other drive I have ever bought. Once you connect it to your system, it FORCES a Virtual CD drive (VCD) onto your operating system that CAN NOT BE REMOVED IN ANY WAY by the user. This is GARBAGE! This drive is going right back. I have never heard of such an insane idea as this. There is nothing on the packaging to indicate that this drive will take over your OS. This feature is burned into the drive's firmware!     WORST IDEA I'VE SEEN IN 10 YEARS.  UPDATE 12-2-09  After removing my drive and returning it. We tried to remove the one on my wife's MAC tower. It took us 3 HOURS of horsing around to remove this WD software which had infected her OS/X system. Even with the drive disconnected, this WD \\"smartware\\" was running and dogging down her computer. We finally understood the slowness to be due to this dreadful software which is EXACTLY LIKE A VIRUS running in your computer. It took a LOT of work to remove all this WD software from her Mac. The WD Uninstall left behind many pieces of software which had to be discovered by running the process monitor.     Furthermore, you can not burn a CDROM from files you place on this drive. The entire system will freeze up and you won't get the CDROM out of the drive. All I can say at this point is that it would be stupid to purchase this drive when you can buy the IOMEGA Prestige 1T drive for $96 here on Amazon. I bought the Prestige and it is MARVELOUS. It is robust, heavy, runs like a machine and was setup on my mac in 30 seconds flat. It is a beautiful drive. When comparing the Iomega to this WD crap it is like comparing a Mercedes Benz to a Yugo.

I purchased the Toshiba Canvio Slim II 1TB Portable External Hard Drive in December of 2014. Thus far, the product has proven itself incredibly useful.

Compatibility:

I primarily use the hard drive with my MacBook Pro and was very impressed with how easy it was to format the hard drive to make it work with my computer. Sometimes with a non-Apple product it can be difficult to reformat the programs for them to work smoothly. I use the hard drive with Time Machine on my computer and it came in handy only a few weeks after purchasing the product when my hard drive crashed and I was able to use the external hard drive backup to restore all of my files. The included 10 GB of cloud storage allows me to access certain files from anywhere that I may not have saved on my computer. While this is a great feature, I wish there was a way to purchase more cloud storage for people who prefer to store more than the provided ten gigabytes.

Design:

The small slim design is very nice as a student for me to easily carry the hard drive around with me. The metal casing allows me not to worry about the hard drive getting damaged when I travel with it. On top of this, the brushed aluminum finish is pleasing to the eye when it is sitting attached to my silver MacBook on my desk.

Overall, I am incredibly satisfied with this product and would recommend it for anybody in need of more storage space or wishing to back up existing files on their computer.

I have a rather large case with a ton of fans, so I was hoping to get these to use in my side door to provide some extra cooling to my 2 video cards (7870s in crossfire mode), but I didn't want to make my case even louder. I had previously hooked up two fans that came with the case to use in the side door vent, and they were extremely loud. When I got and installed these (I actually purchased two), I couldn't tell they were running. Even on the highest setting. I can barely hear them if I put my ear right next to the vent where they're installed.

The only negative is that, as a quiet fan, it doesn't push as much air. It's not a problem for me since I just wanted a little additional airflow for my video cards. But these might not work as well as a single case fan, if your computer tends to run hot. If your computer isn't that warm, though, this would probably be fine.

I'm using this Keyspan/Tripp Lite UBS-->Serial port adapter to run Ham Radio Delux from Vista 64 machine with a Yaesu 450-D HF transceiver. I've used this before on other radios and computers without a problem. The first one I gotten since Tripp Lite took over Keyspan lasted about a month before it simply quit working. Amazon was great in letting me return it, and even had a new one on the way within a day. I'm hoping this isn't a bad sign for quality control for Tripp Lite. Some electronics just have infantile failure, so I'll udate this review in a few months. This is the only reliable adapter I'd recommend if you need a good USB adapter, and it will work on almost any computer, including a Mac and, with a little fiddling, Linux.

UPDATE: As I feared, quality control has indeed slipped since Tripp Lite took over Keyspan. I've now had a second adaptor fail in less than a month. One failing can be a random failure - two failing is a sign something's wrong at Tripp Lite, hence my revised one star rating. Unless you can round up a \\"real\\" Keyspan adaptor (pre-Tripp Lite), I'd give this one a pass. Too bad, because Keyspan made great adaptors.

This is a truly remarkable device - a mouse and fully functional keyboard combined, that sits flat on my desk along with all my other papers and books (try that with a traditional keyboard and mouse - its not easy). As with anything worth the effort, one needs to spend some time learning how to use it - one even does it with a car or a bicycle, and even a pen, so why not with a keyboard.  I have the QWERTY version, but type Dvorak and have also activated the mouse on the left hand side of the device.  I'ts endlessly configurable to suit just what you want.   I have a TouchStream at home and now want another to use another at work - but FingerWorks are now not operating any more, so i'm hoping to get one second hand.  It's beyond me why anyone would use a clunky keyboard and a separate erratic mouse (as most are) when something so remarkable is available, or rather, was available.  Is there not some other manufacurer that wants to take up making these keyboards?

I bought this for use with a raspberry pi b+. It worked well right out of the box. It required adding a few lines to the /etc/network/interfaces file, plus a sudo service network restart - then voila wlan0 appeared in ifconfig.
I bought this to be able to avoid wires while developing/debugging stuff on the rpi and it works quite well for that with a few caveats:

The interface is not quite as snappy as wired ethernet. I nfs mount a local directory on the pi to put code to run in - once in a while, I get a 'resource not ready' gripe from NFS (but only once in a while). This is nothing to really complain about though.

Whatever antenna they are fitting in this enclosure, is, by definition 'electrically small' and hence, crappy. You will probably have to be reasonably close to your hotspot (in fairness to them, I haven't experimented with this yet).

Even though the power consumption is small, it does consume about 60mA - the rpi can't source much power through it's usb ports. I haven't had any typical overcurrent issues though, like spontaneously rebooting.

Overall - excellent value and easy to use.

The included rubber nubs that dampen the noise didn't quite work as I'd hoped thanks to Corsair's ideology of putting rubber grommets on all of the screw holes.

Plenty of length on the cable (4 pin PWM) so it could reach the middle of my ASROCK Z97 Anniversary board's 4pin header and is now running at a smooth 35% speed at idle and 45% under load when the temps hit over 50C.

Keeps the fan branding uniform throughout the front and back panels of my case (I have some Spectre Pro PWM LED's in the front) and is stealthed thanks to the black on black color scheme.

REVISED November 2015- I WILL NEVER EVER BUY ANOTHER LOGITECH PRODUCT AGAIN. It's been flaky for weeks, but today, the Logitech Gaming software, for no reason- no updates, no system updates, no hardware changes- suddenly refuses to detect this mouse. No fix available- older drivers don't work, uninstalling and reinstalling doesn't work, re-connecting to the receiver doesn't work, downloading the driver from Windows Update doesn't work. I now have a mouse (which I am using with the generic Windows "HID-compliant mouse" driver) that has NO FEATURES. None. Without the Logitech Gaming Software to apply your custom profiles, there is NO REASON to use this mouse. I previously liked using the buttons to do auto-middle-click; mute; volume up/down, etc. NO MORE.
I WILL NEVER EVER BUY ANOTHER LOGITECH PRODUCT AGAIN. They always end up having some glaring problem, but not right away. You think "oh, finally they made one that works" but after a time, it fails- and always in a way that makes the product useless. Since Logitech seems to be the only other company besides Microsoft making full-featured mice/keyboards, I have ended up buying a number of them. I have 3 mice and one touchpad RIGHT NOW sitting on my computer desk, this will be the FOURTH ONE I have given up on using. (Mx705, M510, T650 and this Gaming 602.) IT IS A COMPLETE WASTE OF MONEY and time to buy Logitech- their support will NOT help you get the hardware going again once it has gone wonky. They give you the "reinstall the driver" and reboot the computer, which in my experience has NEVER fixed the problem. There appear to be no more fixes, and I am no longer a Logitech customer.
PREVIOUS REVIEW: (yes, I previously said I liked the mouse. Hard to like it when it doesn't work.)
I've tried various other Logitech mice before (non-gaming) and there was always something 'wrong' with them- something I didn't like that made me stop using them. Either the buttons were placedbadly, or the click pressure was too much/too light, the shape was wrong, etc (you might say I'm picky). I'm more partial to the Microsoft shape of mouse, they fit my hand better; I think they're wider. I have a large hand and this mouse fits great. The one thing I was worried about has turned out to be a non-problem: my thumb sits on the thumb rest, and it rests against the lower row of the 6 side buttons. I thought it might make me accidentally press a button occasionally; but since the buttons have a firm clicking threshold, it's not an issue. They aren't hard to press, but the light pressure of my thumb resting there doesn't trigger them- you have to deliberately click. Speaking of click pressure- the top left and right buttons are actually easier to press, they have a light click threshold. The left main button (index finger) is actually a little easier to press than the right or middle buttons. I'm not sure if this is a flaw, or was intentional. It hasn't caused any problems, I just have noticed it. I'm hoping as time goes on it doesn't get easier to press, as that would make it have almost no resistance. I've only had the mouse for about a month, so we'll see. The middle button/roller is very easy to roll, it has very light clicks while rolling, you can't turn them off like on some other Logitech mice. It also is a little narrower than the typical Logitech roller button, and has a somewhat grippy texture- not like shiny plastic, but not rubbery either, I like it - just right. I've also seen people say that it doesn't have the left-right (backward/forward) function on the scroll wheel - IT DOES. You just need to push a little, it takes a little more pressure. Not a hard push, just a nice solid click.
I'm not using the mouse for gaming, just normal computer use- browsing, editing, graphics, etc. The DPI adjustment seems to make little difference, it tracks well no matter what. The range is not a problem- it goes at least 10 feet, probably much longer,and there's a USB extension cable in case you need to move the receiver. The receiver is NOT the usual Logitech multi-receiver, it only works with this mouse. I just plugged it into a hub on my desk and it worked. Since I'm not a gamer, I like wireless mice; I really don't think it makes any difference that it's wireless, I've never had any glitches or lags in tracking. I do use a thin plastic mouse mat for optical mice, it works very well. I've actually tried it on two mats, the WowPad and a Corsair Vengeance (they are very similar surfaces). The mouse feet/pads make a slight sound when moving on the pad, it hasn't bothered me. I think it would be noisier on a cloth surface.
One thing I haven't been able to test is the battery life. I use it every day, and the battery level hasn't gone down one bar yet (I'm using both batteries it came with). Also, the performance/endurance modes seem the same- that might be different if you were far from the receiver. It apparently has great life like everyone says, which is typical for Logitech mice. The weight is very typical for a two-battery wireless mouse, I like a little weight in a mouse, again it's just right.
A comment on the software- it lets you assign keys to each button, you can assign any key to any button. You can also assign any mouse button function to any button (left click, right click, middle click, double click, back, forward), including the DPI up/down buttons. Those are a little out of my normal reach, so I really don't use them, the thumb buttons are handier. If you don't use it for gaming, there are probably too many buttons, but not really a problem :).
Appearance wise, using it at work, it looks a little odd (sort of Terminator-ish); but for gaming mice it's nice and reserved looking. The part on top that appears silver in the photos is actually more dark, more a gunmetal color, except the DPI buttons which are silver. The top and buttons are plastic, the sides are textured but not rubbery. My last Microsoft mouse had textured but more rubbery sides, that coating wore off on two mice after about a year of use. This looks more durable, but only time will tell.
All in all- a really good mouse. I think I've finally found 'the one.'

Upgraded my Late 2011 MacBook Pro from a 500GB spinning hard drive to this. Instead of taking a solid minute or so to boot up, it takes ten seconds and it's more responsive than my old HDD. My computer is faster than it ever was before and feels brand new. The battery is also better too.

This was my first time upgrading a Hard Drive, and it was incredibly easy. I used a StarTech.com USB 3.0 to 2.5" SATA III Hard Drive Adapter Cable & the TEKTON 2830 Everybit Tool Kit (both sold on Amazon) to help me with this. Here's how I did it:

1. Plug SSD into USB to SATA cable.
2. Use Disk Utility to format the SSD. > http://forum.crucial.com/t5/Crucial-SSDs/How-to-initialize-your-SSD-Mac/ta-p/111 490
- Erase Disk:
- Name: Macintosh SSD
- Mac OS Extended (Journaled)

- Partition Disk
- 1 Partition
- Name: Macintosh SSD
- Mac OS Extended (Journaled)
- Options: GUID Partition Table

3. Downloaded Yosemite onto the Mac directly. Clicked on 'Yosemite Install' application and installed it on the SSD. Go through installation process until it reboots, then the configuration process. Once complete, turn off the Macbook.
4. Remove old HD and install new SSD. > http://guides.crucial.com/Guide/MacBook+Pro+13-Inch+Unibody+Early+2011+SSD+Insta llation/419
5. Install iLife apps, Chrome & Skype
6. Update Yosemite using App Store.
7. Disabled:
- Sudden Motion Sensor > http://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201666
- 'Put Hard Disc to sleep when possible' > Since TRIM isn't supported this will help the Active Garbage Collection built into the SSD
8. Reset SMC & PRAM/VRAM > http://support.apple.com/en-us/HT204063 & http://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201295
9. Move items manually from External HD to SSD.

This is listed as an 8-cell battery, and may indeed contain 8-cells. However, it does not have the same high capacity that the manufacturer's (HP) 8-cell version has. It is comparable to the OEM 6-cell battery.

I immediately returned it when I realized this. The seller was very prompt in responding and took the return with very little hassle.

Please compare mAw/WH among batteries before purchasing! My original battery for my TX1020 has a stated capacity of 7365 mAH or 55Wh. The HP extended battery is 73Wh. The \\"extended\\" battery on this page is only 8800 mAh! That's only a life extension of 635mah for having 33% more cells. Huh?

After returning this I found a much better third party battery that had capacity (and construction!) more in line with the OEM extended version for about $45(US). The OEM version is built so that the cells are staggered and hang down below the unit, so that on a flat surface it is propped up for better ventilation than the 6-cell or \\"8-cell\\" on this page.

I recommend a battery with at least a capacity of 10,000 mAh instead of this battery.

In response to another review here, all of these batteries must be fully charged and discharged completely one full time before they are properly calibrated. The first charge will probably give really short life, and then perform properly after that. This is not explained anywhere, but is necessary.

Hope you find this review useful!

Lame.  * NO POWER ADAPTER? *  Seriously?  For $139 you couldn't include the power adapter?   Dear Amazon,   The Kindle used to be a premium product.  What happened?

Received this item from bigfootaccessories as a gift. The card had been reprogrammed to report its capacity as 16GB, when it is in fact an 8GB card. Windows reports the card as having a capacity of 16GB, but it will only hold 8GB. Once more than 8GB is added to the card, some files are corrupted and overwritten. This is a common, well-documented issue, so bigfootaccessories should be aware of this. This seller is selling illegal cards.

My Belkin F5D8231-4 Pre-N wireless router died and since it carries a lifetime warranty Belkin sent me a new F7D8301 Version 1000 (Play N 600 HD). I have a large network and use a Cisco VPN router for Internet access. I only use the Belkin for an access point. Since I have so many wireless printers and computers it is not feasible for me to reconfigure IP address, subnetmask and security features. The reason I say that is due to the Belkin F7D8301 not allowing me to set the IP and subnetmask for its access point feature to my settings. When I set the IP address to 10.0.?.? with a subnetmask of 255.255.255.0 it automatically reverts to 255.0.0.0 which of course will not work on my network. Plus I found that in the wireless security settings it only offers AES and not TKIP which all my wireless devices use. This demonstrates how little forethought went into this router, it allows using the IP of 10.0.?.? with 255.255.255.0 for the router itself, go figure??

I have installed Linksys, Cisco, D-link, Netgear and Belkin routers and access points for years. The newer Belkin products are the only ones that are missing crucial settings and features. I have numerous Gateway to Gateway VPN routers setup and wireless access points and Belkin is the only one that has done this. All their older products had all the features and options needed. Class A IP addressing is not an issue on a LAN and never has been. Belkin's Pakistani support tries to use that as a reason until they are advised that when it is setup as a router it allows entering any subnetmask. From the other reviews it is apparent that Belkin no longer wants router business from IT professionals.

When these devices work they are OK but the speed is about half of what I get with a wired connection. My dissatisfaction is that I have been through 4 of these bridges in 3 years. Note that everything in my house is connected to one of several Tripp Lite surge suppressors. As others have said, they work for a while and then just die. My current unit only worked for 114 days and now it is dead. I can reset the device, connect it to the router, run the web-based setup or WPS and it looks like it is working. The web-based utility even says it is connected to the internet. But when I connect it to a computer or laptop and ping the device it is as if the bridge does not exist. I reset and reconfigured it over 30 times and it still will not work.

Note also that the Linksys web site states "If you want to configure the WES610N v1 without connecting it to the router, you can use 169.254.1.250 to access its web-based setup page directly. If you have a WES610N v2, its default IP address is 10.100.1.1". However, when I spoke to Linksys Support they told me you have to connect this device to a router to perform the setup.

As long as I was running Windows XP Professional, this card worked wonderfully. As you know, Microsoft stopped supporting XP in April of 2014, so I upgraded to Windows 7. What a mistake. This card will only work now for email and internet, but pop in a game and it shuts down to a black screen forcing you to manually turn the PC off.

Enter offshore Tech Support. These guys only serve you via email and cut and paste manual passages. When asking you to do complex maneuvers inside the case, they don't provide step by step detail, leaving you high and dry. Of course, it is always your PC, your operating system, etc. It is never Nvidia's fault, like their drivers are failing to upgrade the device to the different OS.

I felt compelled to warn the world, so you don't go spend a ton of money on an expensive card that isn't going to deliver the goods on your Windows 7. Right about now, I am ready to drop it from the highest building in my area, while video taping its descent and destruction, then posting my warning on YouTube.com so the world can see how disappointed I am in NVIDIA's support of its products.

Corsair has great products BUT... this 8 GB kit is ONLY compatible by itself.  It won't function if you have another 8 GB kit of the exact same RAM.  So, if you want 16 GB like me, you have to buy a 16 GB kit.  Luckily, the 16 GB kit was on sale, and amazon was really good about getting me a refund with a small restocking fee.  So, in the end, upgrading from two 8 GB kits to one 16 GB kit only cost me an extra $15.  It surprised me that even with the exact same RAM, you now can't use two kits even when your motherboard can support it.  It could either be a marketing thing where they want you to pay for a whole new kit or it could be that RAM nowadays is too intricate to function properly when using a second kit.  This product worked EXCELLENT in it's original 8 GB kit, but just keep in mind that when you want more you have to buy a whole new kit.

I have been a diehard PC fan since I got my first IBM 640MB RAM, two-floppy-drive PC back in 1981. But with the technological advances of the last few decades, it really is all about the operating system. And I have so had it with Microsoft. I've been clinging to XP, eschewing the poorly written Vista, and dreading MS's threatened loss of support for XP. But what I finally tired of is the constant parade of digital hobgoblins that haunt the OS of every PC - viruses, malware, resident update monitors, anti-virus software, etc. All of these things erode and destroy the operating performance of a PC.

I purchased this low-end Mac mini because it had the same processor as my PC - and it was cheap. I bought 4GB of Crucial memory, watched the video on YouTube, and effortlessly upgraded the memory to 4GB in about 15 minutes. It was not the easiest upgrade I have made - and I definitely do not recommend it to the novice. But I have been building my own PCs for years now. Incidentally, in upgrading my memory, I also allowed my nVidia graphics memory to bump up to 256MB - nice!

What first amazed me was how QUICKLY the Mac booted up, since my PC takes FOREVER to load all the crap that is necessary to work with the flawed Windows OS. The second thing that amazed me was how much FASTER this computer was than my old PC, despite it having the same CPU and memory (I should add that I routinely did hard drive and registry cleanups on my PC, so that was not why it was running so slowly). The third thing that amazed me was how intuitive and simple the Mac OS X GUI was to work with.

My only regret is that I did not upgrade the hard drive at the same time. However, I have a 1TB USB external that works with Time Machine (what a great background backup program!) and another 1TB Firewire800 external I use for data storage, so there is little pressure on the standard 120GB 5400rpm drive. However, I imagine I will - at some point - swap it out for at least a 500GB 7200rpm drive, which should boost performance even more.

Well, this is a cheap video card, not in the ~$50 budget category, but still a far cry from the gamer-centric $150+ offerings. That being said, it offers excellent performance for the price in a very small package with very reasonable heat dissipation. Despite custom-building every single desktop machine for my own use since 1990, I was able to get a Dell XPS 420 at a stellar deal some years ago and for the first time ever ended up with a \\"branded\\" machine. Fast forward to today and my machine is really starting to feel dated, so I replaced a couple components. First, 8GB of Corsair memory replaced the old cheap stuff. The old video card was an ATI Radeon HD 3850, not a shabby card by any means but I was pleasantly surprised to see this card outperform it. I play Starcraft II, Mass Effect 2, Dragon Age: Origins, and the Civilization series, and everything looks fantastic and runs in 1920x1200 at medium to high settings with minimal lag. I also planned on upgrading my power supply from the stock 375W dell to a Corsair or PC Power and Cooling Silencer in the 500W+ range, but it appears at this point to be unnecessary as this card consumes less power (and doesn't even need the extra power connector). Bravo, nVidia and EVGA!

UPDATE: I've been playing ME2 and DA2 on this card for the past couple weeks and they do very well. Once thing that has worked great is EVGA's Precision overclocking utility. The GT440 easily handles a slight bump on its core clock up to 900MHz with shader clock to 1800 MHz, and if needed a slight nudge on the memory clock as well. The GPU never ran much over 50 degrees C and the improvement in framerate is noticeable. You're not going to fry your graphics card with these conservative nudges in performance, but you'll appreciate the extra kick for games!

[[ASIN:B003AM8OXK ASUS Eee PC Seashell 1005PE-PU27-BK 10.1-Inch Black Netbook (Up to 14 Hours of Battery Life)]]    I received this net book yesterday, and, to my very surprise, it turned out that the recovery DVD/Support CD that is included in ALL of the other versions of ASUS Eee PC Seashell 1005PE is NOT included in this particular version. (I simply cannot understand why Amazon made this the case.) The description on the Amazon website is misleading, since there is nowhere where it explicitly warns the customer that this will be the case for this particular package. True.. according to \\"what is included in the box\\" Amazon does not list the recovery DVD/Support CD among the things included. But, without an explicit warning that this is so, the potential customer will very likely assume that the only difference between this version and the others is in the soft-touch exterior and would very likely take for granted that what is included in the box would be \\"exactly the same\\" as the non-Amazon exclusive versions of the ASUS Eee PC Seashell 1005PE model, which DOES include a recovery DVD/Support CD. I am returning this net book, because I do believe that having a recovery DVD/Support CD is essential when your computer starts to cause problems. Any potential buyers who are considering to buy this Amazon exclusive soft-touch exterior version should bear in mind that a recovery DVD/Support CD is NOT included in this version of the product!

Not having purchased a hard drive in quite a while I picked this one - sadly.  My friends in I.T. later laughed because I bought a \\"Deathstar\\".  I shrugged it off and installed my OS and all updates/ software. Within a week I started getting a 'hard drive failure imminent' message.  I tried several solutions to back up data and image the drive but all failed.  I resigned myself to losing all the work I did reloading the computer and send the drive to the manufacturer as is.  By the way, they make an inscrutable set of rules for its return, setting you up to be denied warranty, including such things as 'write the RMA number a minimum of three times on the outside of the box' and 'use 2 inches of foam packing around all 4 sides' (here's a hint guys, 3 dimensional objects have more than 4 sides) etc.  All this for a brand new drive.  Of course, what they EVENTUALLY returned to me was a drive over 3 years old that had been refurbished, not even the same model I purchased I might add.  So, my review of one star goes for the product, the customer service, and the warranty.

Seconding the deceitful size claim. I purchased the 256 GB model, and according to Disk Utility on OS X, the drive's actual size is 240GB.  Despite this, the drive still performs extremely well and is very compact, so I won't be returning it – I just think that the title should certainly be changed. As far as performance goes, I give it 5 stars, but I am going to make my review 1 star to hopefully make the manufacturer pay attention and stop the lies.  In other words, if you're looking for a 240GB highly portable drive, I'd highly recommend this.  Update: the manufacturer responded, and claimed the missing 16GB was due to "firmware". This is BS. External drives don't need firmware, and even if they did, inspecting the drive would still show that its capacity is 240 GB. The CAPACITY is 240GB, not just the available space. Trust me, it's mislabeled.

I just replaced my Antec usb-laptop cooler with this one from logitech.  The Antec one worked well, but the power cord wouldn't make contact with it's connection after time and the fans wouldn't turn on.  I would have to play with it and get it just right for the fans to work.  And after a while it has become almost impossible to find the right position for it to work.  Plus the blue light got annoying after a while.    I got the logitech cooler today and it fits my Dell Inspiron 6400 laptop perfectly.  My laptop has a 15.4\\" widescreen monitor and there is plenty of space for it to sit on the cooler.  There is a single fan as compared to 2 on the Antec.  The logitech fan is very quiet, it sounds like the fan on my laptop when it tries to cool itself.  The curved design is good for creating airflow underneath the laptop, which helps it keep cool.  When placing the cooler on a flat surface, there is a slight incline.  Some might not like it, but I am fine with it.  It helps make typing more ergonomic.  When placing the cooler on your lap, there are vents on the bottom that keep your legs cool.  The plastic is actually quite comfortable on your legs too.  I believe the cooling design for the logitech is definitely better than that of the Antec. There is space underneath the laptop and above the cooler to create airflow away from the laptop.  The only drawback is that the Antec came with a usb port so you don't waste one plugging in the cooler.  The logitech will take up 1 of your usb ports.    I would recommend the Logitech cooler over the Antec.  They are pretty much the same price too.

This ASIN is a bundle of 2 items offered individually by several sellers elsewhere on Amazon; I'll start with the plastic 'skin' first: I own other protective skins made from this same "TPU" plastic, but the material used here is thin & flimsy, so the openings for buttons and ports were kept small to keep the plastic from tearing; as a result the openings aren't large-enough to access the buttons easily — particularly annoying around the Windows~Start button — which requires an extra-hard push to activate when the tablet is 'wearing' this skin.

Matters get worse with the bundled stand; I previously purchased a tablet stand looking just like this one thru Amazon and it works great! Unfortunately, the one in this bundle turns-out to be a cheap copy of the inexpensive stand I already own; the rip-off copy is all hard-plastic instead of having soft rubber feet and cradle — which prevents the tablet from sliding around the desk when attempting to use the touch screen, or slipping out of the stand when pressing any of the buttons. The illustrations accompanying this listing all manage to inconveniently obscure those critical differences between this bundled stand and the functional version sold by other Amazon Marketplace sellers. You will absolutely need to use both hands to operate your tablet when using this stand! Mr. Yong Chen (aka, iShoppingdeals) apparently just doesn't care... He gets an un-earned One-Star rating, because Amazon doesn't permit any lower!

Normally I don't have any problems with Amazon, well this time was different. The hard drive said "sold and shipped by Amazon", I ordered it along with about 5 other things. My other 4 things came, but no hard drive. Finally I went back to my email to check the shipping number, and I found out IT WAS SHIPPED VIA CHINA POST AND WON'T ARRIVE FOR ANOTHER MONTH. The customer service rep acted surprised that it wasn't acceptable for me to get my hard drive in a month. I need it now, I can't wait a month. So now I have to order another one, and return this one back to china!!!

Now when I order from Amazon, I can no longer be complacent. I have to look very carefully before placing my order. You would think that if something is going to ship from CHINA they would have it in big bold letters, "WARNING THIS PRODUCT SHIPS FROM CHINA"!.

So now I have to order another hard drives and wait who knows how many months to get my monty back on the first one.

I'm sure the hard drive is fine! Just be careful when you order, when you get that first email, double check who it's from and where they are located, so you can cancel it right away in case the seller happens to be IN CHINA!

I purchased this keyboard case from Amazon 3 weeks ago. Shipping was fast - I received the item sooner than my expected date. The keyboard case is matte black in color, and my iPad 2 easily snapped into it. The top portion of the case (which holds the iPad) rotates so that you can work with your iPad in either landscape or portrait view. I find that it is much more sturdy and easier to manipulate in landscape view. The iPad portion also easily detaches, which is convenient for setting the iPad on a table by itself for watching videos. All ports/buttons on the iPad are accessible, and the iPad can be charged while in the case.

The keyboard itself is sturdy and looks nice. It is a standard qwerty-style, with a row of functional keys at the top (home screen, brightness, sound, play, pause, lock screen, etc.); I rarely use these. The keyboard is a bit smaller in scale than a laptop or desktop keyboard (as to be expected, as it fits with the smaller iPad). It took me a few hours of use to be able to use the keyboard easily, but I have now acclimated.

My complaints: The lock-screen button is directly above the delete button. Before I adjusted to the keyboard's layout I kept hitting the lock-screen when I meant to hit delete, which was annoying. However, I found that if I hit delete or any other key after locking the screen, it would unlock, so I didn't have to take my fingers off the keys to get back to work. My other complaint is that the page up, page down, home, and end buttons do not work in Safari. They do however work when typing documents, so sometimes I jump up or down the page and don't realize it. I have found that I do this less often with time, so I guess it is all a matter of getting used to the scale and layout. Overall, I would recommend this product and would purchase it again.

Loathe as I am to leave such a low review, I think this one's earned it. I'm very adept at pone screen protectors, so I'm quite familiar with the process.

Nevertheless, I read the instructions several times before beginning, as is my practice. They are vague at best. I cleaned off the laptop screen perfectly and gingerly placed the protector down. Despite my care in doing so, I was met with a sea of air bubbles! The little squeegie supplied with it was completely unable to remove even half those bubbles. What a mess! And the instructions allow you to lift the protector up and place it again. WRONG! Once that thing's down, it's down. Pulling it up essentially destroys it. There was no way I was going to live with all those bubbles; I peeled the whole thing up and threw it all away in disgust.

Maybe some of you folks will have better luck than me in handling a screen protector of this size, but for me, it was money down the drain.

I am new to the world of Kindle and for quite sometime was opposed to the idea of an E-reader. I still love the real deal. I prefer paper books however I realized that getting to the bookstore or ordering myself books online was something I had less time for. I wasn't reading as much as I liked to and started to reconsider the E-reader. I am unable to provide insight on how this model compares to the others as I have stated I am new to the kindle world. I did get a small preview to one last year when my sister showed me her keyboard kindle.  I was not impressed too much. It seemed awkward to hold and didn't see much purpose in the keyboard. If I am going to highlight or take notes it will be with a good old fashioned pen or highlighter. When the new kindle models came out recently I was more intrigued. I liked the newest designs better. My husband struggled with what to get me for Christmas and I started to think the Kindle might be a nifty gift. I then was perplexed on which one. I did some research on Youtube watching self proclaimed experts fiddle with each model. My concern was that some complained about the touch screen usage and I was leaning more toward the 79 dollar kindle. I chose to go to a local retailer to test them out in person. I felt the 79 kindle was lighter than the touch. Not by much but I felt a difference. What I didnt like was scrolling through the keyboard with the directional button. I could then see the benefit of a keyboard at that point but again feel the newest designs are better. Unfortunately the stores only carry demos and the touch model was unresponsive. The store associate assured me the touch worked well and voiced his displeasure with the demo unit as it didnt help him with selling the product (with a degree in marketing, I have to say to amazon, this isn't a smooth move). With my husband in tow he suggested I go with the touch and was eager to get his Christmas present purchase for me taken care of. I was still unsure because ofthe performance of the demo. But then I had visions of a horrific orange ski jacket my husband bought me a few years ago. I chose the Kindle touch.   I got the unit home and plugged it into my computer. Set up was extremely easy and I found myself getting pretty excited about this new gadget. The kindle was charged within an hour and within seconds I was easily looking at book choices. I appreciated the free selection of books and had a few downloaded to get started. The reader is light and comfortable. I am a graphic designer and spend a lot of time looking at a computer screen so I appreciate the ink display that is easy on the eyes. The touch screen is responsive and occasionally I have tapped it a little too hard where it flips 2 pages instead of 1. This is a minor annoyance and I find most touch screens can get a bit glitchy at times. I was concerned about the ads but after reading many helpful posts from the amazon community, the ads do not pop up while reading a book. This was my concern. I ended up finding a few of the offers to be of value and recently was offered a best seller book for only a buck. Pretty cool. Another reason I chose the touch is the ease of tapping a word in the book to find its meaning or definition. I love words and like the quick easy access of looking it up. The kindle is the size of a paperback and fits easily into my small purse. It has been really handy especially sitting in a doctor office while most are fiddling with their smartphones I am getting another chapter in on my kindle. I am surprised that I became a fan so quickly with the E-reader. It really is pretty cool. So I can't give you major tech advice on the kindle but can at least share my experience as a new user. I'm pretty happy with it. Happy reading!

Perfect tablet. Strong, dependable, reliable. It's fast, doesn't crash, or have any weird bugs. Plus these tablets will last you for a very long time. I know people who have theirs for five years. Apple products are just built to last. Love how you can use your fingerprint to unlock your tablet. You can also add other people's fingerprints to unlock your tablet! Which is another really cool feature. You can also make phone calls from your tablet, and send and receive texts.
