The power supply doesn't work with Intel D2500CCE Atom D2500 Dual LAN & Dual COM Mini-ITX Motherboard, BLKD2500CCE. When I turn off the system I hear a ticking sound. I googled and I found other people describe this problem like this:
"
I bought this specifically to address an issue the stock PicoPSU-80 has with the D2500CC motherboard. With this combination when the system is powered completely off using the operating system or hardware power button soft off function the system will shut down as expected but then the power supply will cycle on and off about once a second making a clicking sound until the system is either powered back up or unplugged from the 12V supply that runs this PSU.
"
It doesn't look safe for the motherboard. Support team from http://www.mini-box.com/site/support.html is really disappointing. They probably want to help, but they probably cannot get information within the company to suggest a workaround/debug or replace the item.
It's very frustrating experience with the product and mini-box support.

I bought one of the 16GB Patriot Class 10 SDHC cards, looking to improve the burst rate on my camera (Canon T2i).
When I received the card I tested it with a few shots at home and I was amazed how much faster it was from the one I was using (AData class 6).
The test shots worked fine, so I took the card on a photoshoot.
Good thing I never entirely trust a new gadget and I had my older card as a backup in the bag.
While shooting with the Patriot card seemed fine the big surprise came when I was reviewing shots on the camera - images just didn't show up, the camera was showing an error screen for about 30% of all shots. Back at home the computer didn't do any better, a lot of the images were lost.

I formatted the card a couple times on the camera (low level format) and then put it back in the computer. The file system contained unintelligible files and gave me errors trying to access them - the card's file system was corrupt immediately after a format.

These problems have never happened with the AData class 6 sdhc that I've been using for a while.

Bottom line: DO NOT BUY, SPARE YOURSELF SOME FRUSTRATION.

perfect fit, it took me a little while to figure out exaxtly what to physical demensions were on my laptop,
the "demensions" are what you need when purchasing an adapter, NOT the model # of the Lap Top.
as in The outside of your existing plug is 5.5 mm / & the inner hole accepts a 2.5 mm pin (drill bit)
I used drill bits to calculate the size of my adapter / & 1mm=0.039 inch / 1/16 inch = 0.062 thousanthsinch / 3/32 = about 0.095 thousanths
so, 2mm = about 0.089 thousanths inch, a little under 3/32 Inch drill bit

I bought two of these cards to use with my Panasonic SDT750 camcorders.  I have a number of other Patriot, PNY, and Kingston cards that I use, but out of all of them, these Ultimate X cards are the *ONLY* ones that caused me to actually lose data.  (That's NOT good when you're working on a videography gig.  I'm so glad that I used multiple cameras or else the loses due to this card would have been irreparable.)  Even after letting my camcorder do the formatting, I still lost data.  Note that I was not recording in 1080p mode, so I wasn't even writing at the maximum speed of the camcorder.  I ended up getting others cards that actually work and have yet to give me a problem.  As it turns out, the write capabilities of these supposed class 10 cards are pathetic.  Transfers of things like digital photos to this card average 700 KB/sec and large files transfer at roughly 5 MB/sec, still well below the 10 MB/sec that they're supposed to write.  I doubt highly that the problem is due to the occasional defect because BOTH of my cards have exhibited this problem and BOTH of my cards have ended up being corrupted when being used with my camcorder to the point where all data is lost.  These cards might suffice for long-term storage or for storage of non-critical files, but after this experience there is no way in he-double-ell that I will ever trust the Kingston Ultimate line to my DSLRs or camcorders.  Just stay away from these.

I bought this (my first one) because it appeared more sturdier and durable-it was. One LED just wont cut it unless you want to illuminate only a few keys. Ive bought several other notebook lights since then, and I've learned the following:
* There is no way a single LED will provide enough lumen/light -- regardless.
* 6 LEDs is the minimum that will do any good. Trust me (think about it,one LED?)
* First time buyer? If your USB ports are in the back of you PC, most will not reach over/around your screen (not even a 12\\" display). So consider Length or use a USB Hub.
One caveat re: single LED --- I attached a small cut crystal over the light. The refractive properties creates a great psychedelic light show.

I bought this to connect my DVR and slingbox in my livingroom to my wireless network. The setup couldn't have been easier-- although, this assumes you have an existing wireless router that supports WPS (Wifi Protected Setup). It literally was as easy as pushing the button on the bridge and pushing the button on the router, and waiting for them to synchronize. Then, just plug in your wired devices, and that's it.

In my case, I was bridging it to a Linksys WRT310N, and connecting a Dish Network VIP622 DVR and Slingbox. I don't know how much more difficult it would be if the wireless router you're connecting it to didn't support WPS. You'd have to delve into manual configuration in that case.

I had wanted to purchase a larger monitor. My vision isn't as good as it was years ago (I'm getting more and more far sighted). I'm now using TWO monitors on my computer which gives me screen real estate. I had a 19\\" 1440x900 monitor and a 22\\" 1680x1050. I intended to replace the smaller one with a 24-27\\".
Actually, I was drooling over those 1440P or 1600P displays. The Korean 1440P 27\\" units can be had for about $300, but just how GOOD are they?

I did some research found many rave reviews for the Dell U2412M. At about $275 shipped it's a reasonable buy. Yes you can get a 24\\" 1080P TN monitor for about half the price. What you will end up with is a stripped down TV set panel. In fact, you could probably just go to Costco and buy a Visio full HD TV and use the darn thing as a monitor for even fewer bucks.

A computer wide screen monitor should be in a 16:10 format, not 16:9 IMHO. That extra height makes working on text documents in MS word (or Libre Office) easier as you can see more of the page. I was too used to the computer based screen ratio to put a TV set on my desk. The Dell U2412 is about the most affordable monitor in this format.

If you read the reviews you might come across with the idea that this unit isn't perfect. Well nothing is. Technically it doesn't have the fullest color rendition, and if you need PERFECT color you might find fault here. I've viewed photos taken with my Panasonic G3 on this monitor and flesh tones are correct with good contrast. I haven't tried to set the color balance yet, all I've done is fool around with the contrast and brightness settings. I'm not a professional photographer though, so take this with a grain of salt.

After ordering this monitor I found out about a controversy involving panel version numbers. Yes, mine is version A00 with a recent 2013 date code. I don't know what Dell is doing with the version codes, it may reflect where they are buying the panels, and they may have changed suppliers many times in recent history, only to go back to the original source. Who knows? I can't see any dead or stuck pixels, there is no yellow tint or any other kind of defect visible to my eyes. The unit was packed in a very ingeniously designed cardboard insert. Some reviewers have complained about this, preferring the older method of molded white foam packing. Well the cardboard is \\"greener\\" and made of renewable material. That foam is made from petrochemicals, in other words OIL. I prefer the cardboard.

So far I've had this monitor for under a week. It's brighter and crisper than the 22\\" AOC that is now sitting to the left of it as my secondary screen. If I had an extra $275 to spend, I'd buy a second U2412M to replace the AOC in a heartbeat.

Cons? Well it came with a single link DVI cable that is a bit too short for my setup and I'll probably end up buying an after market 8' cable.

Some would call the lack of built in speakers or an HDMI input a con. Really? If you want those, then go get an HDTV and use THAT as a monitor. This is a COMPUTER monitor. DVI and Display Port connections are what are in vogue here. Yeah some computers DO come with HDMI outputs, but those are probably intended for HTPC use. I have a good pair of full range wall mount speakers hooked up to a 30 watt per channel amp for my computer sound system. I don't need a pair of two by nothing speakers in the monitor!

The computer seemed to work ok, it was only $435.00 so the expectations weren't huge. I use it for work, I wanted a lower end unit for basic work, email, spreadsheets, etc. After a flight the screen went crazy, it started rolling in a very tight band in the middle, you could make out what was there but had a heck of a time clicking it. I looked it over and there were no cracks in the screen. I had been on a bumpy flight the day before but it wasn't that bad and the computer itself was never dropped; for all the turbulence it sat on my lap. I powered it down at the end of the flight and then the next day at work it developed the issue with the screen as soon as I started it. No cracks and as it is under warranty I called Lenovo and sent it back. They got it and called me to tell me it was $300.00 to fix it, the led was cracked and that wasn't covered under warranty. I told them nothing was cracked when I sent it to them however they insisted, $300.00 or they wouldn't fix it. I told them to ship it back as is, I wasn't paying them $300.00 to fix it. Then two weeks later I got another call, they wanted $300.00 to fix it. I told them don't fix it, send it back. Another week goes by, same call to tell me they wanted $300.00 to fix it, I tell them the same thing, send it back as is. It's been another two weeks and still no computer so I called them. After getting the run around (they couldn't find it, sent me to numerous different departments) they hung up on me. I am sitting here is shock at 1) how poorly the unit was built, 2) that they had the audacity to try and get me to pay them another $300.00 for a computer that I only paid $435.00 in the first place, and 3) what horrible customer service they have. DO NOT BUY LENOVO, junk that isn't supported and the worst customer service in the business! I am letting everyone I know what I have been through, I don't recommend anyone doing business with them, it has been just amazing how little they care about my business, and if they don't care about mine why would they care about yours?

Update: 8/28/2013. I got the laptop back from them after numerous calls and complaints. The screen is now cracked, it was not cracked when we shipped it back to them. It is scuffed and banged up like it fell from a work bench. Totally disgusted with Lenovo, if I could give negative stars to the company for customer support I would.

I bought this device in order to use it for reading textbooks. It seemed like a much better option that carting around a bunch of heavy expensive books that once sold back would give me hardly any money. I got it after the semester started, so I waited and instead read other books to test the reading capability. As an avid reader I must say the paperwhite has a beautiful display. Reading for long periods of time on laptops or tablets hurts my eyes, I have really bad eyesight and astigmatism so long periods of working on my computer can make my vision worse (which sucks since I'm a college student).

I wasn't sure how the Kindle Fire read, and after researching I found out that the reading quality was like that of a tablet or laptop (plus as a procrastinating college student with very little time, I didn't want to be distracted by all the bells and whistles that come with the Fire). So then I looked at the Kindle Paperwhite.

Reading on the paperwhite was like reading an actual book. I could read for hours without my eyes hurting, and the lightweight quality along with the ability to change the brightness, font size, font type, line spacing, and even margins allowed me to personalize my reading experience. I absolutely loved reading on it, and couldn't wait to get my textbooks.

As I prepared for my next semester I got a nasty surprise. Textbooks may ONLY be purchased on the Kindle Fire. So after spending nearly $200 to buy the Paperwhite without the special offers, a charger (because I bought the wrong adapter and then lost the original charger chord), and a case I find out that my sole purpose for buying the paperwhite was not available. I have no idea why textbooks aren't available, and there was nothing that said I couldn't buy textbooks on the paperwhite. I mean why would they advertise that it's great for the classroom if textbooks ARE NOT available?

Like I said, I LOVE my paperwhite. But I am really upset (and I am trying to keep it PG) that I can't buy or rent my textbooks on this device! Like I said, I am an avid reader. But I enjoy the feeling of reading a paper book, the smell of a new book, the way the binding looks after you read a good book over and over again. I also love my overflowing bookcase, that can not keep up with my love for reading.

If I were to rate the paperwhite by itself, I'd give it 5 Stars.

But as a college student trying to make ends meet and find something more accessible, I'd give it 1 Star.

Hi!    I just got this drive (has been using it for around 18 hours so far), so I won't talk about reliability yet.  My setup:    + Dell Inspiron 6400 (2 x Intel Core Duo - 32 bits 1.83GHz) and old Compaq v2000 (1 x Turion 64 1.8GHz).  + RAM: doesn't matter (really, I'm not testing cached reads/writes).  + Debian GNU/Linux Lenny.  + LUKS encrypted hard drive (cipher: aes-cbc-essiv:sha256 - 128bits).  + ext2 filesystem over LUKS through device manager (DM).    Transfer rates:    Dell Inspiron 6400:    Sequential Write (bypassing OS cache, encrypting): 23.9MB/s  Sequential Read (direct I/O, bypassing OS cache, encrypting): 24.5MB/s  Sequential Read (direct I/O, no filesystem, no encrypting): 31.9MB/s    Compaq V2000:    Sequential Write (bypassing OS cache, encrypting): 20.9MB/s  Sequential Read (direct I/O, bypassing OS cache, encrypting): 22.4MB/s  Sequential Read (direct I/O, no filesystem, no encrypting): 22.1MB/s    I measured this on a Dell Inspiron 6400, running Debian GNU/Linux.    I'm very pleased, I know there are faster external HD out there, but this runs very cool, and is really quiet, I can only tell it is working when I put my hand over it.    I'm glad I got this hard drive.

This keyboard is absolutely awful. I find it impossible that anyone who has ever bought it hasn't hated it. It's just incredibly poorly made. The problem is a bit hard to describe but I'll try. Basically the keys are loose, that is, they're not solidly connected to the keyboard. Here's another way to describe it: Look at the capital letter T. Imagine that the \\"cross\\" part of the T (that is, the top part) is the key and the bottom part of the T is the piece of plastic connecting the key to the board. That's about how these keys are connected--via a too-thin, unstable connecting piece. Consequently, when you press down on one edge of the key, the opposite edge rises up, like a seesaw. This means that unless you firmly press down directly on the center of the key, there's a chance that your key-press won't be effective. For a fast typist like me, this means that at least once every five-or-so words I'll misspell a word due to an ineffective press. This is especially common with the letters on the top and bottom row, as your fingers naturally strike those at somewhat of an angle (unlike the middle-row keys, which your fingers press directly down upon).

In sum, this keyboard is awful. I bought it because I need a built-in touchpad. I do love the touchpad. It's nice and sensitive, and the scrolling works very well. However, as much as I want a touchpad that works exactly like this one, the pathetic build quality of the keyboard made it necessary to return it.

Windows XP was 32 bit, Windows 7 made the transition and had 32 bit and 64 bit versions.  32 bit can access 2.19 TB of a single hard disk.  Thus a 3 TB or larger cannot be fully used by a 32 bit system.  But, it does not end there.  You can have Windows 7 or 8 running in 64 bit mode and not use but 2.19 TB if your Bios on your computer is 32 bit.  When you install you will be given the option to format the drive for LBA which is 32 bit or GPT which is 64 bit.  If you use GPT and your Bios is not been upgraded from 32 bit to 64 bit then your computer will not be able to mount the Hard disk.  In which case you will have to start over and select LBA and run 32 bit unless you can upgrade your bios.  The disks are good!  It is your operating system (such as XP or Win 7 32 bit) or it is your bios that may limit you.  Hope this helps.

I can NOT recommend the HP USB 3.0 3005pr Port Replicator. The problem is that the HP USB 3.0 3005pr Port Replicator "DOES NOT" live up to HP's claims and description.

1) There is a "Chronic Issue" with the Display Port making it unusable.
2) The LAN Port only works at 100 MB speed, NOT at 1 GB as advertised.

I have used the device for just over 12 months now after receiving the unit as a gift. I had hoped that by now that software updates would have fixed the two major issues. I have applied the latest software updates and the issues still persist. My unit was replaced by HP once when the original unit become unusable. The replacement has the same issues but is more stable. The Display Port on the HP USB 3.0 3005pr Port Replicator has a chronic problem of blinking in and out, the screen can go blank for minutes at a time. The HDMI Port on the HP USB 3.0 3005pr Port Replicator works OK.

The LAN port on the HP USB 3.0 3005pr Port Replicator works only at 100 MB connected to the same router port and cable that always works at 1 GB when hooked directly to my HP ENVY dv7 Notebook PC.

Here I am again, giving another one star review to a Toshiba product.  Bought one their portable hard drives recently and that didn't work at all.  Completely forgot that I bought this hard drive in 2011.  So today I tried it out.  Hooked it up to my 3.0 hub, but it has a 2.0 mini connector.  That's not a negative.  It's advertised as a 2.0 device.  I decided to back up a large work folder.  No problem with the installation of this drive, unlike the other Toshiba drive.  Selected a folder with 60,000 files (60gb) and dropped it onto the Toshiba hard drive icon.  Everything seemed to be working fine.  About two minutes into the copying, an error message pops up warning me that they weren't able to find a file that's supposed to be there.  OK, fine. Skip that file and keep going.  But that choice isn't offered.  There were no choices at all, except to click the "X" in the upper right-hand corner of up window.  That being the only choice, that's all I could do.  And that stops everything.  So, apparently, in order to complete this transfer, I have to hunt down this problem file, resolve the problem, and then start all over again.  And with every problem file, I'm going to have to repeat the process and start over again.  There's probably always going to be a few corrupt files in a batch of 60,000.  When you come across a problem file in Windows, it gives you several choices.  Skip it, replace the file, copy both files and give them different names, do this every time the same problem arises, etc.  I don't care if there's a problem with a particular file.  I have duplicates and triplicates of these files all over the place.  Missing a file here or there probably will never make a difference.  I just want the hard drive (and its software) to copy as much as it can, skip over any problem files, finish the job as best it can, and don't create additional work for me.  I guess the people at Toshiba disagree with that.  One star.

This is a well-designed USB 3.0 hub, which lets you add additional USB devices to a single USB port on your computer. The hub has its own power switch and it can provide USB 3.0 speed if both your device plugged into it and the original USB port that the hub is plugged into support that standard. This item is relatively small and lightweight and it seems to work fine with any operating system and any USB peripherals. I would just be cautious about connecting multiple devices when using it with a USB external hard drive - this is an issue with any USB hub, since the power current has to be split among the ports when multiple devices are plugged in. Sabrent provided this item to me at no cost for review purposes.

Watch out for Fake product on this card even though they are sold by Amazon

I ordered one of these cards based on the good reviews on the product. Amazon shipping was prompt as always. The Card arrived in its original Asus packaging. The first thing that i noticed was that the package seemed to be sealed differently with a long tape instead of shrink wrap or circular seal. Another suspicious thing that was noticed was that there was a sticker over the UPC number. But the card seemed to be as described from its looks. I went ahead and installed it in the system and the first thing that was noticed was that the card does not install on the motherboard since the CPU fan was hitting against the BIOS battery. I then went ahead and reviewed the diagrams on the card and it looked like the heatsink was mounted incorrectly, so went ahead and remounted the heat sink turning it around 180 degrees and now it fits properly on the motherboard. Further all installations went smoothly and the system properly booted up.
So my thoughts at that point was that this was a quality control issue with ASUS. After installing Windows 8.1 everything seemed to be working fine. I then went ahead and installed the driver from ASUS and it seemed to go smoothly. The system asked for a reboot and now windows started complaining that the driver for the video card is outdated and wanted to update it, and this is when i noticed that the card detected was a 6670 instead of 7250 which is one generation older.
I then went to AMD site and downloaded the driver and even that was detecting the card as a 6670 instead of 7250. I decided to get more in-depth into this and started reviewing the card in detail and that is when i noticed that the card i received had a different mounting plate than what was given in the ASUS site and video outputs were all in the wrong places.
Called up Amazon and they agreed to send a replacement by next day air. So hoping that the replacement card that i get will not be a fake one again.

I was assembling my first PC and I researched each component carefully.

If you have an up-to-date home router and understand computers and the internet somewhat, then you will probably be able to get this product to work for you, and it will work fine. The setup is slow. Amazingly slow actually, where it may take a couple minutes for administrative changes to work. Administrative changes may also require a re-boot of this device and the computer you're using to set it up.

You may need to read the manual, which comes on the CD. You may need to update the firmware on the device (I didn't have to, as of Sept 12, 2012.) and the PC or Mac or Linux drivers (I did need to do this, and I was careful not to install features I did not want). Another thing you may need to do is have your router's DHCP reserve a local IP address for the MAC address of this device. (If you don't know what that means, don't buy this!)

You may not need to install the Iomega software on your home PCs or Macs, because on up-to-date operating systems the built-in network software will recognize this device and do the right thing. The Iomega software may only be needed for the \\"Personal Cloud\\" and other backup features. Windows 7 will see the shared disk space under \\"Network\\" and allow you to assign a drive letter that will work, for example, under cygwin. Finder in Mac OS X will allow you to mount the drive under the \\"finder->Go\\" menu and this will allow you to select the drive as a TimeMachine backup. Probably a good idea to set up your DHCP so that the local IP address is always the same.

Update: 6 months later it has forgotten everything in its programmable memory, including the partitioning of the hard disk.
All my data is gone. Except that it's still on the drive, and I was able to recover by disassembling the unit and installing the bare drive in a Linux box.
For home use, it's probably best not to enable the \\"security\\". This is primarily intended to protect areas of the drive from computers on your local network, and home users may want free and open file sharing within their home system. The drive is still protected (more or less, depending on your firewall) from the outside internet as a whole, and backups can still be encrypted.

About the Mac interface: the \\"search for updates\\" button in the version supplied with the CD did not find the new version, I had to go to the Iomega website and find it. Also, Apple \\"Time Machine\\" files made according to the manual instructions fail. There's an Iomega FAQ on this issue, you have to mount the backup volume on your Mac using the \\"Go\\" menu in Finder the first time you select it as a Time Machine volume, rather than refer (in the Time Machine setup menu) to the image created by the Iomega software. After that one setup glitch, Time Machine backups work just fine.

If you get it all set up, and you install the drivers on your various computers, you will have share volumes that show up on all those machines, even when you're outside your home network. It does email out administrative problem reports, that works fine.

In terms of drive longevity, it's probably a good idea to use the \\"energy conservation\\" feature and set the disk to power down after an hour or so. It will start up again when needed.

Of course IT'S JUST A SINGLE DISK, so sooner or later it will fail. Don't store your one-and-only copy of anything on it! If you need reliable long-term storage, go to the cloud or get a network attached storage device with RAID capability.

I use it to backup my family's Mac laptops using the \\"Time Machine\\". This works just fine.

Quality control on these cables is okay on the finish and fit HOWEVER not on length or matching end parts.

I ordered five of these cables from ValexOnline EXPECTING to receive five 12\\" C7 figure-eight power cables that all looked the same and were 12\\" long. What I received was five cables that were all different in length and had different plug end fittings. They were the right plug end type but were made by different companies so they all looked different.

Cable 1 is 21.75\\" long
Cable 2 is 21.25\\" long
Cable 3 is 20.50\\" long
Cable 4 is 20.00\\" long
Cable 5 is 19.75\\" long

So from the above measurements you can see that there is a 2\\" (2 inch) difference between the longest and shortest cable and the shortest cable is 7.75\\" longer than the advertised 1 ft (12 inch) cable being sold.

These cables are so close to 24\\" that they should be called 18\\" or 1.5 foot cables. Too long for what I needed and don't match so they look very odd in my project.

Amazon should really crack down on this sort of false advertising since now reading all the reviews I see the sizing issue is well documented. If anyone states that I should have checked this first before buying then my reply is why hasn't Amazon done something already instead of turning a blind eye.

I'm not a big gamer but in the last year I did get introduced to EVE Online which is a fun online game. A big part of online gaming I have found is the interaction with other players, and a lot of that interaction is best done through voice. I quickly found that my old cheap headphones that went over the top of my head with their boom mic were just uncomfortable for longer durations and the sound quality was poor. I didn't want to invest a ton of money in a new headset, but I definitely needed a new headset.

Logitech is a brand that I've long known from having purchased many peripherals over time. Their quality has been decent enough that I figured this headset would more than likely meet my needs. And, so far I've not had any complaints.

The headphones obviously go around the back of your neck so they don't create any pressure points on the top of your head. The band extends quite a bit so it can fit a big head like mine quite easily, I wear 2XL hats. The microphone boom swivels up and down and can be easily swung all the way back to be out of your way if you just want to use these as headphones. This feature is also quite handy if you happen to be munching on food while using the headphones.

The cord is long enough that I never feel like it's getting snagged on anything or in my way. It terminates in two mini-jack plugs so you can plug it into standard mic and headphone jacks on a computer. It also comes with a USB connector that has two connectors for the mini-jack plugs.

Personally I'm not a fan of using the USB connection since I've had poor experiences with USB sound cards before. When the computer gets busy with other things suddenly the USB connection loses priority and sound gets choppy. There's a few guys I play with who have USB headsets and they are frequently chopping out when the game gets active. So I plug the mini-jacks in and let the dedicated sound card hardware in my computer do the work. But, it is nice to know that I have the USB connector so if I ever want to use this headset with my laptop for a Skype type service it is there.

So far, so good! I've just begun to use the battery in a Dell E6410. Seems to work as advertised. It is clearly NOT an original, although it's a very close copy. It fits in the computer fine and the plastic case is nearly identical in all respects to the original. Tiny differences, and different labeling make it clear that it's a replacement. For the cost, it seems to be a great deal and I would recommend it. Keep in mind, this is also a larger battery - it has about an extra inch extending out the back of your laptop. It's the same size as the optional extra power battery you could have gotten with the computer, and it DOES fit in the standard Dell docking station, as others have said.

So the past year i've been writing an album on my ipad that I got for my birthday, but i wanted to take my writing to the next level. I wanted to get that professional sounding music.. And in order to that, I needed a high end computer that can get the job done. So I did my research for a good year or so and came to find that macs are great for people who want to make music! Not only that, It's for people who want to make movies, edit videos/photos, and just be flat out CREATIVE.

I've been using my family's windows PC ever since I was young and the main thing I don't like about it is that it's super laggy, awkward, and loud. I needed my own computer. So a couple months ago, i decided to get a job so I can save up for this machine. and now... 3 Months later, I saved up a whopping $2,400, bit the bullet, and bought it. (I got the 1TB Fusion Drive since I heard such great things about it).

All I can say is WOW. Computing Perfection.

I ordered it june 7th, and it arrived just last night! It said the estimated delivery was going to be the 18th (Yesterday) so after work i drove home, ran to the window, and just waited for the Fedex truck to come. I sat there for 3 HOURS. Just waiting. At this point is was 8:00, i lost hope for the day and decided to accept it was coming the next day, BUT! Out of no where, just as I was about to leave the couch, the truck came. My heart rate shot up and I just ran out to the truck before the delivery guy could even get out of his truck. I signed for the package and ran inside.

I cleaned out my room so the iMac would look nice with its surrounding. and THEN, I unboxed it.

I was pretty much screaming the entire time because it was so exciting. I remember lifting up the Styrofoam for the first time and seeing how incredibly thin it was. After unboxing it, I plugged this bad boy in and hit the power button. Again, WOW. It walked me through every step I needed to get my Mac setup and running smooth.

I clicked \\"Start using iMac\\". And thats when the experience really kicked in.

This computer is not only fast, responsive and fluid. It's so ridiculously simple to use.. But at the same time it is so complex! I spent hours just playing around with the settings.

I still have yet to try most of the programs, but from the programs i have already tried \\"Garageband, iMovie, Safari, iPhoto, and Photobooth, it's amazing!

I've never bought anything so expensive in my life, But it was completely worth every penny. I've never been more happy with a purchase I made than this one.

It's time to start writing my album:)
Thank you apple for making my first computer an amazing one!

This unit was not the most expensive out there, but it gives me a strong signal all through my home and about half a block down the road in both directions. I tested that with my Galaxy S-4. I'm not at all a computer geek, but had this up and running from my PC with a security password in less than an hour. Interaction with the company's website during setup and driver download and software upgrades went smoothly. I no longer have to rely on miserably slow 3G (our area does not have 4G) to download e-books and such, and our houseguests no longer look at me like I'm Fred Flintstone for not having wifi.

After a few weeks with this monitor, I feel compelled to give my impressions...    The screen is exactly what it advertises itself as, that being a quality 22\\" widescreen monitor. Shipping was unexpectedly fast (the time from placing the order to setup was less than 50 hours for me) from Antonline. Setup was a breeze, taking no more than a  few moments.    Using this screen with my 2.0 GHz Macbook running Mac OS X Leopard, all I had to do was connect one end of the DVI cord to the monitor, then connect the other end to the Mini DVI to DVI adapter I had purchased. After plugging in the power cord, the notebook automatically recognized the monitor, optimizing the resolution to 1680 x 1050 instantly. And I have to remark what a breath of fresh air it is to finally enjoy the kind of screen space I've sorely missed since ditching desktops 3 years ago (no offense to notebooks, but 13.3\\" inches of screen space just doesn't always cut it). A very easy and hassle free set-up experience, although this is clearly my specific account of proceedings.     The images are very crisp. No dead pixels, no light leakage, no noticeable problems whatsoever. The included 3 year warranty definitely goes a long way toward my feeling secure that I'll have a functioning monitor for the foreseeable future. And should also add that Acer includes both analog (VGA) and digital (DVI) output. Many comparable monitors sometimes exclude the digital option, so to see both ends of the spectrum covered is in this instance a pleasant surprise.    There are a few shortcomings worth mentioning, the most notable of which is the omission of any sort of speaker system. I bought it as a monitor, so this was not a major problem for me, although I suppose it would be convenient to consolidate the various PC peripherals in the name of conserving precious desk real estate.    However, at the end of the day there is very little to complain about here. The monitor offers a quality picture at a price point that is virtually unbeatable for a unit of this size. This definitely a product worth considering for anyone interested in upgrading to a unit with a little more screen space, or for anyone looking for an affordable second monitor.

I was looking for a basic sleeve to protect my iPad and Apple wireless keyboard while stowed inside my backpack.  This case fit the bill perfectly.  Additionally, the quality of design, materials, and construction FAR exceeded my expectations considering what I paid (under $15).    General comments:  Basic sleeve design for a netbook or iPad, as advertised.  The construction is high quality, especially for the price.  The material feels sturdy in hand, but is exceptionally light.  Both sides of the sleeve are padded (neither side is rigid).  The interior surface is smooth nylon.  The interior portion of the zipper is protected from contents by a lip of fabric which, by its design, does NOT get caught up in the zipper.  The zipper itself runs from the top left corner of the sleeve all the way down the right side of the sleeve, giving you the flexibility to only open the sleeve from the top or open it up more widely.  Accented patches at the bottom and front center are a nice touch, providing good grip points.    iPad specific:  Bought the sleeve to house my iPad.  Was despairing because I could not find a simple case to house both my iPad and my Apple wireless keyboard.  Thought I would be forced to leave the sleeve open at the top with the keyboard sticking out.  To my surprise, the iPad AND keyboard fit nicely together in the sleeve.  The keyboard takes up the maximum height of the case, but the zipper closes nicely without being forced or rubbing, even with the iPad inside also.

In theory, this would be an excellent router if they would fix the existing issues.

Wifi signal strength is not too great. If you buy the router buying an antenna is a must, but then again it seems this router is more designed for being portable and not to feed internet to your whole house. There are MANY MANY existing issues which have not been resolved in firmware upgrades, even Linksys site has the issues listed yet has not put out a new firmware in well over a year. Yet they recently put out a firmware for Britain which fixed the issue with connections being dropped. Even then, this router randomly drops connections after a few hours, VPN through this router is nearly impossibly if you need to use your connection for more than 10 minutes. And what takes the cake is that a simple firmware update bricks the router, amazing. Between this and the rest of the Linksys routers I've owned, I'd say Linksys is going downhill with the crap they're pushing out. Coming from someone who used to swear by Linksys, thats pretty bad.

After wearing out my 3rd Nostromo I decided to try this out, and I've now been using, or trying to use this device for over 2 years. I have never been able to get used to it. I basically have 2 problems both boiling down to the complete lack of ergonomics in the design of the G13. The thumb stick drives me absolutely crazy for 2 reasons, the position relative to the buttons (claw hand) and the awkwardness of using a thumb stick in games designed for button presses.

One of the things I liked about the controller when I saw it online was that it had so many buttons, when playing MMOs you seem to never have enough so I figured more is better. Not so much. Even after 2 years I struggle to hit the right buttons consistently which I attribute to the fact that they didn't put a home key bump on any of the keys. With so many buttons, and with my eyes on the game, I lose track of where my hand is on the device. Additionally reaching the far buttons is difficult, and next to impossible to reach while using the thumb stick. Also having 2 rows of 7 buttons is a very odd choice because it really doesn't map to any UI implementation in the game universe that I can think of.

Lastly, the LCD screen is nice eye candy, but it's not really very useful. At least I can't find much of a use for it. As I said before, I like to keep my eyes on the game not the controller.

I planned to use this cable to upgrade my internet speed by foregoing wireless, and simply running a wire through an old cable outlet in the wall to the next room where the modem/router was. I am impressed at the quality of the build of the cable, and its performance. The gold plated connectors are a nice touch, and the crimping and connector ends seem secure. The only complaint I had upon unboxing was that there is a pretty heinous crease created in the cable due to the way they ship it, but this is mainly cosmetic.

I primarily needed the upgrade for gaming purposes. I did see a noticeable reduction in latency, over switching from the wireless connection from the same router/modem combo. and I was attracted the to flat profile, as well as the capability of the cable. The cable easily fits between the carpet and the wall, but could easily be secured with a staple gun. You could easily run this cable throughout the walls in your home and you'd be set for a good number of years as far as increases in the capability of data transmission. Most Ethernet cables are category 5, which were cutting edge in 1990. Welcome to the space age.

You can use this cable where ever you would use Category 5, 5e, 6, or 6a cable with a RJ45 connector. I highly recommend it.

I was happy with the price, and service of recieving this product, but i am not satisified with the quality. I discontinued using it because the electrical cord began to unravel.

The Hardware:
The first thing to say about the hardware is that the screen is beautiful. Vibrant color, great viewing angles, high pixel density. There is some backlight bleeding around the edges but it's pretty minor and also pretty standard for thin and light laptops with such thin screens. The chassis is thin, light, feels reasonably durable. The screen appears to press against the keyboard with fairly small amounts of pressure when closed so I'd recommend a protector to sit between the keyboard and screen when closed if you intend to carry the laptop in a soft case which might allow some pressure on the back of the screen. The keyboard has very little travel, which is typical of such thin notebooks but the mushy feel at the end of the key travel is not so forgivable. The track pad is nice enough, it won't blow your mind but it gets the job done without hindering your use. On the whole I'm fairly positive on the hardware. Many of the shortcomings are part and parcel of such a thin and light notebook. The only one that really bothers me is the mushy and cheap feeling keyboard. But it's matched with a really lovely screen so pick your poison. On hardware alone I'd probably give this notebook 4 stars. It's not perfect by any means, but it's a nice balance of mostly well built elements, light weight, thin profile, decent battery life, inexpensive. The software is what really kills this notebook though.

Software:
The big reason for the 1 star review is the extremely cynical and user hostile shovelware that comes with this laptop. It's been a few years since I've bought a new laptop so maybe they are all like this now, but in my opinion Samsung set a new bar for computer crippling crapware. I'm used to shovelware on new windows machines, but this is frankly ridiculous. In addition to the usual software that you don't want but can easily uninstall are some Samsung utilities and updaters that hog resources at every second and cannot be removed. As far as I can tell they can't be removed at all, like a bad virus. And you have to jump through some major hoops just to disable them from running all the time (but still not remove them). And when running they love to point out that you removed Norton security and would you like to reinstall it so Samsung can get another dollar from Symantec. It's shameful and disappointing. I blew away that windows install and put Ubuntu on it (some hiccups but it works quite nicely). I you are tech savy enough to scrub the windows install that comes on this machine and install something fresh, either Linux or a fresh Windows install, then consider this laptop a 4 star machine. If you intend to use it as it comes out of the box, then a 1 star machine is what you will have.

For those of you who haven't installed this "kinda" protectors... Below are the few most imp things to take note of.
1. Watch the video on their web site. This is really imp.
2. Apply the liquid thoroughly on both the sides of the screen protector and on the device.
3. Make sure u cover the speakers on both sides with a tape. Liquid could get into our speakers.
4. If this is the 1st time u r using this type o protector you will see lot o patchy air bubbles ,which will look like dirt.... Just ignore them... They will disappear in a day.
5. When you push air bubbles during installation with the rubbery thing provided in the kit... Make sure u wet the outer side of the screen protector. Else u will end up having tiny scratches.

Over all this is a easy one to install..... But........ You have to watch the installation video...
Good luck....

This case is great and is exactly what I was looking for (and I did look through all the pages of results that I could find with a search). I got this case for my new iPad mini, and the fit is as I had hoped it would: snug, but easy to use. It's not too tight to get the case on and off easily, but it also doesn't have tons of excess space around the device. I use the grey side out, but the orange is also very nice; the colors seem to be pretty true to how my computer displays them.
I love that it is reversible, which is something that played a part in my choice for a sleeve. Something that wasn't clear (at least to me) from the images is that there are two pockets: one for the device, and then another one, which due to the reversibility can be positions in front of the pocket for the device with the flap covering it or in the back (opposite side as the flap). If you are using the grey side out, if you flip the second pocket to the back, it will be orange. Likewise, if you have the orange side out, the second pocket will be grey when you have it to the back. Some pocket positions are somewhat awkward, mainly with all orange outward, both pockets towards the flap side, but that's the only potential downside I can see.
When I bought this, I was worried that the flap might be difficult to work with, but I have found it to be no trouble at all, very easy to work flip over the device when opening and closing the sleeve.

I bought an original Kindle when they first came out and loved it. All the variations that followed didn't seem to offer enough new features to upgrade, so I stuck with mine. When I saw the features of the Paperwhite, I hesitantly decided to upgrade. I DEFINITELY made the right choice! I absolutely LOVE it! The built in light is great, the touchscreen is a lot better than the original keyboard, and I love how you can see how much time is left in the chapter/book that you're reading. Amazing product. If you're trying to decide if you should buy one, I HIGHLY recommend it.

There is a reason why this company only provides 1 year warranty on the NSA325. It fails shortly after a year. And has costed me $1000 worth of data recovery. My suggestion. If your data is critical. Purchased this unit on Friday, Jan. 8th, 2010 at Walmart.  The clerks told me they no longer had them and when I saw three of them in the cage he then told me they were no longer $228 but now were $279.  I told him I wanted to see the box so he got one out and then I told him to scan it.  He was  a little reluctant to admit it was still $228 but did so.  All that said if you go to look for one of these look in the on hand inventory cages of the laptop section.  I have seen them now that way in three stores and none on display or anyone to admit or realize they even have them.    Unpacked this unit and it was very well packaged and protected in fact better than some very expensive laptops I have purchased in the past.  I plugged in the battery and powered it up and turned it on.  Immediately it came to life and started the Windows 7 starter edition set up.  Everything loaded it hooked up my wifi did the registration and it was ready to go.  Display is clear and bright.  Keyboard is responsive although the keys are a little small so it takes a little getting used to.  Touchpad works very well.  Good sound quality.  Battery life about 3 hours, maybe a little more in power saving mode.  Huge 250 gig hard drive much larger than most netbooks.  Build quality is very good.  This is without a doubt an Acer One with Emachine's name on it.  The Acer's on display had 160 gig hard drives and were $299 so as I said this is a great buy.  I upgraded the one gig memory to 2 gigs which was super easy as it has an access door with one screw to get to the chip.  Also it has an access door for the hard drive so if ever needed it would be an easy replacement.  I removed the extra trial programs, (Norton, MS Office and also reset the startup files removing some of the auto load stuff.  Loaded the MS Mail program and set up the email accounts, downloaded the free Open Office program and AVG antivirus and you now have a very well functioned netbook!  Loads well and everything worked perfectly from the very beginning.  With the Emachine recovery manager and a external DVD writer drive you can create restore disks or you can restore the unit from a hidden partition on the hard drive.  Super light unit and easy to take anywhere.  Nice black and silver finish which looks more expensive than some of the higher priced units and brands.  One year warranty which I don't know how good any service would be from Emachine but if it continues as it now works I don't expect to have to use the warranty.  If you are looking for a small form factor netbook that has pretty much anything you would need in a netbook this is a hard to beat deal but I am sure they will disappear before long as the Walmarts that did get them for the never happened Day After Christmas Sale only got 10 of them so when they are gone they will be gone.  If you are looking for this kind of unit get to looking and if you find one buy it.  You will be very pleasantly surprised!

The roo case was heavier and thicker for overall placement and protection of your Kindle HDX, where the Slim Shell Origami Case was much thinner and lighter, but had a great concept of folding the front cover in different positions to act as a back stand for using your Kindle HDX on a flat surface. Both cases had cutouts and ports for all the unique buttons, camera and microphone that are part of the new HDx design. My previous PC (which is still in use) was an excellent computer, but in the past three years a lot of improvements have become standard issue on PCs while I had to keep buying adapters and dongles to use new technology on my older machine. I am delighted that this computer came standard with Bluetooth capabilities, USB 3.0 ports and HDMI support. With this unit I was able to hook up my bluetooth keyboard, wireless mouse, and HDMI monitor and really minimize the amount of cords going into the back of my computer and the amount of stationery devices on my desktop. The PC was entirely hooked-up in less than a minute. Actually booting up the PC for the first time with Windows 8 also seemed faster than my Windows 7 launch. Be forewarned that you need to sign-in with an existing Windows Live ID or create one.

The design of this computer is very attractive. It stacks up as slightly taller (about 1/2\\") than my last HP PC. This largely seems to be because of the top-mounted headphone, Microphone, and USB 2.0 jacks. These jacks face the back of the computer. The top of the PC (minus the dash for the plugs), has a beveled shape which makes it nice for charging and storing devices since it minimizes the chances for accidentally knocking a peripheral off the top of the PC (see my picture uploaded by the product images). The splashes of red color you see in the photograph are actually light strategically peeking out from the case to lend a specific aesthetic to the tower.

I wanted to focus on the details above first since the product description page offers almost all the item hardware and software specifics an individual would need to know. However, I do have a few comments about those also.

The computer does not have a VGA input, but it includes a dongle that adapts your VGA cable to fit in the DVI port. I was delighted by this because I was able to use my HDMI cable from my monitor to this computer and use my existing VGA cable to keep my older computer hooked up to the same monitor (the HP w2207h).

It only took me a couple of days to get accustomed to the Windows 8 interface, but I can see how it would be a bit overwhelming to someone not already familiar with apps in another OS or without a touch device that maximizes it. My bluetooth keyboard (the PC comes with both a standard cord-attached USB keyboard and mouse) allows me to scroll through open apps and the other actions are easy enough to do with a standard mouse and the use of the Windows start button on keyboards. I found that claims about being able to reach the old desktop are greatly exaggerated unless you pin everything you love to the taskbar since there is no way to add the classic start screen button to the desktop view without installing third-party software and tweaks. For those who do not want to adapt, this computer has such incredible hardware that buying it with the Windows 8 and then installing Windows 7 would be an option provided you have the tech chops to handle any potential driver recognition issues that would pop up - HP warns that this is a possibility - there is a Computer World article this some depth if you search their website.

So far, I have installed the full Microsoft Office Professional Suite and one of the design variations of the Adobe Creative Suite 5.0. It features a little over half of the CS programs. After installing these programs and the initial launch, I could click on one of the programs, like Photoshop Extended Edition, and have it fully up and ready to run in 1.8 seconds. Word launches in approximately the same amount of time. For the price of this PC and considering the hardware, I would expect that, but it is still incredible to watch. My old computer had an AMD Quad Core processor with acceptable speed, so I unsure if this unit would be faster, and I definitely should not have been. I've never had these programs launch this fast. Also, the somewhat large installs barely made a blip in the hard disk space.

Windows 8 and HP have added a few new features to the computer that many of us will probably appreciate. Now, after connecting the computer with my Facebook account and iPod touch, the \\"My Photos/Pictures\\" shows off both my uploaded pictures and the photos from Facebook and the iPod all in one place instead of my needing to manually pull them in from the device. These can be browsed both in the standard manner from the desktop screen or with the \\"Photos\\" tile. The \\"Photos\\" tile offers full screen images without prompting and features handy delete, rotate, and crop buttons when you right click. HP also has a \\"connected remote\\" you can download as a smartphone or tablet app which allows you to play videos and music from your smartphone or iPod. I like this feature a lot because it kept me from having to import the music I have on my iPod that isn't stored in Apple's Cloud into this PC for listening. You can just play it through the system from your phone or player. When I saw the computer specifics mention a remote, I presumed it was a physical remote, but this is much better. Another really nice improvement with this PC is that I did not have to manually install my HP wireless printer, the PC recognized it automatically.

I only have one complaint. I am a bit surprised that this unit did not come standard with a Blu-ray player installed. I have seen a Blu-Ray player featured on many PCs with a lower cost and that aren't geared toward gamers or massive resource consumers like myself. There is an expansion bay that would allow me to install one, but it feels like something that should be a given in a product of this cost at this point in time. However, I am not ducking a star on the product since it is clear in the product specifications that only a combo DVD player/burner is included.

When reviewing an item like this, I always feel like I am forgetting to mention something important, so feel free to ask me a question by leaving a comment if there is something you want to know.

Got the drive for Christmas but did not use it until April because of relocation, When I got a chance to use it, it installed fine. I proceeded to transfer 1,000 photos from my camera's SD card (Europe pictures). Thinking all was fine I erased the SD card, The very next day, the second time the drive was to be used, the drive was not recognized by the computer. No problem I thought, I purchased the Data Recovery coverage for three years so I'll just be inconvenienced while the drive is sent back for repair. Boy was I wrong! I got a call from Seagate saying (essentially) tough luck fool! Apparently Seagate knows their drives are likely to fail quickly because they have placed in the terms and conditions of the Data Retrieval coverage a condition that no claims will be accepted within 60 days of the Data Recovery coverage purchase! In other words, if I wanted to be sure I was covered for the data loss I should have waited 60 days before using their product!! Seagate also will not refund the purchase price of the drive and Amazon says its too late to get refund. Anyone interested in a class action lawsuit? The mere fact that provision is included in the terms and conditions tells me Seagate has had these problems many many times.
Junk.  Avoid at all costs.

My 6 year old Mac Pro is so much faster now due to the Solid State portion of this drive.

I added 8GB (2x4GB) RAM and 240GB SSD to this, installed 8.1 Pro with Media Center, and I'm using it to view live TV and to record TV shows from a HDHomeRun Prime using a FiOS M-Card.

Thoughts:
- This is a great value for the price. You should shop around as it is currently on promotion elsewhere.
- Able to record 2 shows simultaneously while I watch live TV
- No playback stuttering regardless of the file format I throw at it
- Surprisingly quiet, even when fully loaded
- 8GB was overkill as however hard I push it, it doesn't use more than 2GB RAM. I would recommend 4GB (2x2GB) instead
- Installation is very easy and tool-less given the use of thumbscrews
- I initially loaded all the drivers that Zotac has on their site. Windows update suggested I upgrade the Intel graphics driver, which I did. But there were too many stuttering issues. I ended up rolling back to the older version provided by Zotac and its working great again.
- Card reader is a great option for immediately reviewing photos after an event
- Works well with my SONOS surround system (DD Plus)

Cons:
- No IR receiver or Wifi. I use LAN with Gigabit switches anyway, but I did end up buying an external IR receiver
- Glossy curved two-tone black and white finish. Its an outdated look. A Matte, boxy finish with flat surfaces would have been much better and would have gone well with the rest of my equipment.
- Has a laptop style power brick. This could have been smaller given its incapable of using more than 30W.

Overall, this is a great value for the performance you get for a HTPC.

I bought a Airport Extreme just back in august based on the promise of wireless backups.  The removed feature from Leopard is wrong.  Apple owes those that purchased the airports in the period after Steve's announcement a free/ discounted upgrade.  I called first to make sure I understood the feature and was later removed after I bought.

PROS::
* Good price. I picked one up new for $19.00
* Drivers installed easily
* Easy to configure under Windows XP
* Works with Ubuntu Linux out of the box
* Performance was not outstanding but very acceptable for most applications. I was able to get a signal pretty much everywhere that I can get an signal using more expensive cards from Dell and Buffalo wireless.
CONS::
* No external antenna adapter (not applicable to most users)
* Documentation on the website is a little weak.
* If you do go to the website it is hard to tell which model of card you are using. This seems to be a common theme for Alink+ products across the boards. I also have used an Airlink+101 router; good luck finding the model numbers on any of these products if you don't have the box handy.

OVERALL:
If all you want to do is get the wireless networks at home, at the library or in most coffee shops, then you really can't go wrong with the Airlink+ 802.11g Wireless CardBus Adapter; especially for the price.
If you work with Linux or you have a tendency to tinker with this setting or that setting and are really into customization, then you may want to go with something that is a little more robust.
Geek Gage: If you have any of the following at home then you will probably want to look for a little more robust card:
* A domain controller
* A Linux Router
* Two Wireless Routers that are connected to each other

I would highly recommend the Simple Drive by Hitachi.  The unit is so small and easy to use.  It looks nice when sitting on my desk next to my laptop.  It has PLENTY of storage space and is simple to look up files.  The only thing I did not like was the back up software that came with it.  It is great for a beginner but doesn't have a few things an advanced computer user would want.  Eg. It does not allow you to pick certain dates for the backup. It allows you to pick daily, weekly and a few other things.  The main thing about the back up software was it DOES NOT erase any old backups after it creates new ones.  You have to manually go in and erase any back up you want to get rid of.  I ended up using a new 100 dollar back up software for the drive and it was worse.  Do a lot of research and make sure that you get the right software.  The best I have seen is an Image back up software that will erase old back ups and allows you to set all those settings yourself.  For the amount I paid for the drive it was WELL worth the money and perfect for a Laptop and/or travel purposes.  I fully recommend this drive!!!

I heard various explanations for this--they had to ask Best Buy and *they* said no, there isn't a warranty unless I bought it directly from Lyncsys/Belkin, all they can do is replace it. They are replacing the slow, poorly designed, and extremely expensive device with another slow, poorly designed, and extremely expensive device, and that is their response to my request that they actually do what they promised.
I've had probably 10 Lyncsys or Belkin products in the past, which all worked very well. I don't know why this one is an aberration, or if my customer service experience is an aberration. First of all, the item pictured is not the item that was sent to me. Instead of the CPU cooler in the listing, I received what appeared to be an 'updated' version of this unit - one that did not come with a fan, had a much smaller and rickety looking CPU block, and lacked spring loaded screws that work great on Xeon LGA1366 motherboards. Suffice it to say, the unit that was sent to me was a piece of garbage. I have a dual socket Xeon motherboard - and one of the CPUs has already been outfitted with the item that I thought I was purchasing while the other is still air cooled. The entire reason that I purchased another one was to have two MATCHING CPU coolers (obviously). Just for laughs, I decided to install the one that I had just had shipped to me despite the fact that it was clearly a different model or unit - whatever - I figured, 'Same brand, almost the same model...how much different could it be.' In short - the temperature differences blew my mind. The first 8 cores were running at about 39-40c at idle, while the second set of 8 cores (on the cpu with the new cooler) were running between 68-75c!!! Long story short - do not buy this item unless you are certain you are receiving the correct version.

I purchased a CityGear backpack a while ago, which lasted for 5 or 6 years. I was really quite pleased with it and when it finally wore out I bought what I thought was a matching copy. However, the replacement I bought last year was very disappointing.  Targus had severally downgraded the quality of the materials used in the backpack, going from a durable weave and thick interior dividers to some sort of cheap polyester blend and very thin cloth dividing the interior pockets. As a result, the lining dividing the two main sections inside the backpack tore in 9 months, rendering the backpack useless.  I returned the defective backback and it took almost a month for the replacement to arrive. Despite the backback being under warranty, I had to pay UPS for the privilege of returning it. The replacement backback did not match Targus' website description and did not reveal that carrying handle was permanently attached across middle of the should straps, making it completely unwearable. Targus now wants me to pay again to return their incredibly poorly designed mess.  Do yourself a favor, skip Targus' shoddily made Chinese garbage and buy something made by a local company.

Wireless depends so much on environment, but here in the burbs, in a nice old brick co-op, I have this device sharing my upstairs neighbor's broadband connection, via her Linksys wireless router. Signal strength is showing pretty low, but even fixing the TxRate at 11Mbps works beautifully, with no lost frames. There's an auto setting to optimize the TxRate in the event of an unreliable signal, and 11Mbps is way more than broadband needs, AFAIK.
The installation under Win98 was accomplished seamlessly, truly PNP; it hopped right on the network and got all the info it needed from DHCP. Which reminds me, always restrict access to (and encrypt) your wireless network, unless you want to give free bandwidth to any chucklehead in a 200 ft radius. This chucklehead helps his neighbor with her computer pretty often and I plan on proposing that I continue to do so free of charge and/or share the costs. Power to the people!

You know, sometimes we are just stupid. Everybody gets bit by the bug now and again. For example, I recently bought this brand new router for my home network because I wanted to install an external drive to use for back ups (recent hard drive crash - few backups...oops). I shopped around and chose the RT-N16 router based on various reviews posted on Amazon and other sites. Those reviews showed love for the router, but not so much for the router's firmware.

So I got the router, and immediately downloaded and installed the \\"recommended\\" firmware (DD-WRT). Now the reviews said that using DD-WRT, I would need to be at least \\"moderately\\" tech savvy. I thought that would mean 'not afraid to go into settings and change a few things around'. What they actually meant was \\"Are you within just a few hours shy of getting your Computer Science Doctorate?\\" Now, I'm not a computer noob, I've built my own computers, done some programming, I am regularly changing settings and experiment with my home network, computer, etc. but this was just way, way over my head. I have to give a great big thumbs DOWN to DD-WRT. I followed their wiki directions to the letter (what I could translate) and failed at every turn to accomplish my desired task.

Anyway, I spent over a week in research and attempts trying to set up my network drive (I do enjoy solving technical problems, and I'm stubborn...) all to no avail. After talking to a couple friends, who suggested I just buy a router with the capabilities I wanted built in (which, of course, I had already done with this router) and try that. Finally, after trying a couple more versions of the software I was using, I decided to give the OEM operating system a try.

It was so easy. It did what I wanted to do easily, and without the Computer science degree. It even shared the drive with my DVD/Blu-ray, so my saved movies can be watched on my tv. It has a nice, friendly GUI, scans things for you so you don't have to try to remember complicated settings, and reads hard drives formatted in NFTS. It has a function to share iTunes libraries across the home network. It has a function to make my drive accessible across the internet. Yeah, I was an idiot for not trying the OEM first.

So, I'm liking the router a lot more now. Thanks ASUS!

I am among the people who buy this router because of the 5 star review and so called 3rd party firmware support. But the truth is this router almost freeze daily, mostly at night, when it happens, there is no single packet recieved from the wireless router, which means the wireless is completely down, you need to manually restart the router to make it work again.    I am trying to find the possible solution for this problem, you can google \\"wrt54gl freeze\\" or \\"wrt54gl lockup\\" to see how common this problem is, people give numerous suggestions, such as \\"try using tomato or dd-wrt firmware\\", \\"TCP time out tweak\\" or \\"Qos\\", none of these really make sense but I still tried all of these and it does not work. The only one I find may be reasonable is the one [...]/. In short, due to the author, the reason the router freeze is due to a very cheaply maded power supply, so when there is sudden drop of power grid, which is pretty common at night when a lot people using electricity, the router can not get enough voltage and malfunction, thus not a single packet you will recieve from the router.    According to the author, the wrt54g is also affected due to a similar design in router power supply. For $60 router using an outdated broadcom chipset with slow CPU and almost zero function firmware, linksys still want to save pennies from several capacitors of power supply, I really have nothing to say.    ***  Update: I don't know that amazon dose not allow url in user review, if you are interested in the artile about the power supply issue, try google \\"Savel brain dump in English wrt54gl\\".

Typing on dock is no joy if you are used to a real keyboard, mouse pad continually moves cursor while typing, there is no delete key that I can find (get used to using the backspace), touchscreen is sporadic at best. Many websites don't display properly, for example...instead of having 7 or 8 items shown horizontally, it will line them all up on the left in two columns for pages and pages. Wireless response is slower that iPad (tested between this tablet and wife's iPad).

Pros: Sadly I cannot think of one thing positive to say about this tablet. Save your money and buy something you'll be happy with. After a lot of research and waiting for price drops, especially on Dell and Sony, I decided to go with Toshiba. Then I found a great deal on Amazon. Final price without tax or shipping is lower than from Best Buy or Circuit City (and don't have to wait for the store rebate). Plus I got a set of accessories for free, and rebate (free) on a backpack. But perhaps the most impressive thing was that I ordered this notebook on Sep. 16, using free, standard shipping, and got it on Sep 18 !!! Almost too good to be true.
About the computer, so far so good. Quiet, fast. One thing I have to warn you is that this computer is set to \\"hibernate\\" when you close the display panel, meaning that it will shut down. I'm not very familair with notebook computers so I don't know this, and the computer doesn't come with the manual, causing a little frustation trying to solve the problem. So I found out that you to push the on/off button long enough to boot it back on. I almost thought I got a defective one.
It's a little heavy like other reviewers said. Screen is better than I thought (but maybe not for large 3D games). Speaker is ok, standard. Should include a manual instead of a user guide file(because if you can't get the computer to start, how can you read it!??). But if you plan to use it as a desktop replacement, it's looks and feels sturdy enough, and I trust Toshiba, in terms of reliablity.

I bought this battery for my Lenovo Thinkpad SL510 on May 14, 2014, as my original battery couldn't hold a charge for more than five minutes. It came in a nice, clean package. Since then, this battery worked just fine. Just one day I had a problem (After a full charge cycle, it seemed my battery had less than 15 minutes remaining), but I managed to solve it buy removing the battery for a while and putting it again in its place.  UPDATE: (November 11, 2014)  Almost six months later, it started giving me problems It didn't fully charge anymore (it reached its peak at 50%) but still held power as it should. I wasn't sure if this was normal for an aftermarket battery, but considering that my OEM battery lasted about three years, I felt disappointed.  UPDATE (May 15, 2016):  I replaced my hdd with a ssd a few months ago, and now my battery works as good as new after two years. Quite odd, but welcome. So I decided to improve my rating. Will it last as much as my OEM battery?  UPDATE (November 3, 2016):  Finally its starting to falter. But since I have had this battery for two years and a half, I can say it's almost as good as an OEM battery. Even though it certainly has its issues, it's not a bad product nonetheless. I recommend this product.

I bought this laptop from sony directly back at the end of September. I have the C2D P8700 Processor, the 1080P screen (get it, it is SO worth the money!), and the 1 GB graphics card, and the bluray reader. I got a free upgrade to Windows 7 Home Premium through Sony. This thing is an entertainment powerhouse. It can play most games I have thrown at it (San Andreas, Oblivion, others) at medium to high settings. The 1080P screen is absolutely gorgeous, with excellent black levels (much better than most competing LED screens can offer, with the possible exception of the RBG LED of the Dell studio XPS 16. The brightness is more than adequate, in a slightly darkened room, the screen must be turned down or it hurts my eyes. Thats a great screen in my opinion.    Despite many of the negative reviews on the keyboard posted here, I feel that this computer has one of the best laptop keyboards I have ever used. It does not feel \\"cheap\\" or flimsy at all to me, and the keys have a nice click to them with no \\"give\\" if pressed quite hard. That said I do have a slightly older model than the one listed, and I hope that Sony has not changed the keyboard out for a flimsier model.    I popped in the Planet Earth Bluray and was blown away by the detail. It looks better on this computer than it ever did on my Sony HDTV.    Complaints: There are very few  1. There is a slight creak that has developed underneath where my right wrist rests on the bottom edge of the computer. This may just be a loose screw, but I haven't had time to open up the bottom of the computer to check it yet.  2. There is a slight amount of wiggle in the top bezel of the LCD. It is not enough to worry me, but it is noticeable when you grip this part of the screen to open the computer. Other than these two minor niggles, I have no complaints about build quality. The outside of this computer (at least the Chocolate Brown model that I purchased) is made of Magnesium not plastic, with a plastic bottom and keyboard.  3. The speakers flat out suck. This is the only truly disappointing aspect of this computer. This thing is so amazing at all things related to multimedia, I cannot believe that Sony would fit such terrible speakers. I have ordered a set of Logitech V20's to put in my bag for when I travel with this computer. Output via headphone is just fine, but don't plan on enjoying bluray-quality sound through the built-in speakers.    Other than these minor complaints, this thing absolutely rocks my world. I am an engineering student, and I rely heavily on this computer day-to-day at school, and it has not let my down. With the extended battery, I see nearly 4 hours of battery life with WiFi on.    Ive done the research, and I don't believe it is possible to get a better quality computer for less money than this. Sony should have called it the FTW.

I got this from a friend threw a trade and after using it for 4 months straight, everyday, I felt I should write my review. As for price goes, I would have picked this up. If I would be testing it, I would pay 60 dollars for this keypad.     Pros:    -Comfortable-  I'm 21 5'7\\" and my hands aren't big, nor are they small. Just average size and this thing fits my hand perfectly! I find myself sitting on my computer surfing the net and just feels comfortable laying my hand on this thing.     -Responsive-  I have never had a problem with the response on this keypad. All the buttons work when they are pressed with no delay.    -Customizable-  Every single button is customizable. Either macro or single key.     Cons:    -USB Cable-  I find it's to short. I just moved my computer so it doesn't clog up under my desk and the cable barely makes it. I'd estimate it around 4ish feet.    -Feels Cheapish-  I didn't really knock off anything for this because you really don't notice it when playing, but it feels cheap but again never failed.    Conclusion:  Totally pick this up. Even if you are not a daily gamer, This thing will not disappoint.

This keyboard has ultimately been a nightmare for me, and I honestly regret purchasing it.  After updated all the drivers and software, the keyboard and mouse intermittently drop their connection to my PC. Sometimes it corrects itself, other times it requires that I turn off all wireless connections in hopes that it will reconnect. At times when it drops connections, the PC interprets the last received input and repeats it over-and-over again until a connection is reestablished. This is incredibly frustrating.  The mouse click wheel just doesn't seem to work as flawlessly as advertised. Scrolling down works great, but the scrolling up requires more force than is comfortable for the user. I set up a wireless network with the Belkin wireless N router and three computers containing the desktop card. The first two worked fine, although they've been lightly used. They're both within 10 feet of the router. The third computer (unfortunately my main desktop) is located about 30 feet away on the same floor down an open hallway. It's hard to know exactly what's going on because the computer freezes periodically with the desktop card installed. When it doesn't lock up, it has video problems and switches into some God-awful default mode. All three computers are running Windows XP, but my computer is the only one to have these problems. During the brief intervals when I'm actually able to bring up the Belkin wireless networking utility, it either shows the wireless network with minimal signal or the wireless network doesn't show up at all. I've uninstalled, reinstalled, updated drivers, and everything I can think of to no avail. I also have a laptop running the PC card N1 adapter. It works OK but the signal varies between good and poor, again in the same room 30 feet away from the router. Needless to say, this has been a discouraging experience and has soured my impression of Belkin as well as 802.11n. Unfortunately, as I've read reviews of competing products, they all seem just as bad. I think I'm going to break down and run a wire to my bedroom and drop the wireless desktop effort for now.
