I got two of these drives to work with the DS212. They seem to work great and I am getting great speeds. I live in NYC so I may have a different view of what quiet is, but these are really quiet. I haven't heard them once. Additionally they are running cool. Good purchase for the price!

UPDATE April 2014:
I purchased two of these drives to put in my DS212 in 2012. I had pretty flawless operation until the last few months. Most recently one of the drives has failed and I am hoping that the one left can hold out until I get the replacement drive to repair it. What I have learned is that if you are operating a NAS it is a good idea to purchase a hard drive that is built to operate 24x7. This drive may be great for the few hours a day you use a computer but a NAS is always on. I have moved to a WD Red Drive and I am hopeful I can get more than two years out of it. In the end I am glad I set up my NAS in RAID as I would be out a ton of precious data had I not had a mirrored copy ready.

I AM DEEPLY DISAPPOINTED, and vow never to buy any HP products again. My advice: put your money into a different solution, at least until all the bugs with the current servers [1st Gen..] are fixed. Ordered this laptop last weekend. First thing I noticed was that the box had been opened. The sticker to seal it was dirty and wrinkled and not very sticky anymore. The emblem on the back of the laptop was all scratched up. There were fingerprints on the inside of the laptop near the keyboard. And on top of that, there was no clear protective tape to take off over the keyboard/camera lens. After a few hours of use and setup I also realized the right side speaker didn't work, but being that it was Saturday there wasn't much I could do about it.

Here's the real kicker. My first move was to contact MSI about the issue with the speaker. Found out through them that this standard warranty doesn't even cover shipping. So the representative from MSI was completely content telling me that the laptop I purchased with a problem would have to be shipped in for repair, and I would have to pay to ship it to them. Pretty ridiculous.

This same representative helped me to register the laptop, The serial number on the outside of the box where it instructs you to look didn't work and i had to actually open the battery port to pull it off there. The best part about calling MSI about my problems was that this representative was able to tell me that my serial number had previously already been used to register. So, just as i suspected the minute i started to open this laptop, Amazon had got a hold of this as a return, not fixed it, not properly repackaged it, then they sold it to me as a brand new laptop. Funny part about that is they have a link on this page to see refurbished deals for other MSI products, but i didn't realized i had inadvertently clicked that link. HINT: I DIDN'T

Definitely keep your eyes open if you purchase this or anything else from Amazon for that matter. Clearly they think they can get away with selling people damaged and used products advertised as new.

I Will say that once I got a hold of customer support the lady didn't question my complaint whatsoever, and I'm supposed to get another "brand new" laptop tomorrow. We'll see about that.

This keyboard and mouse combo is great. The keys are not loud at all and the mouse fits comfortably in my hand. So far the product has worked like a power supply should.  Fanless and efficiency are great.  After a PicoPSU brownout issue killed a hard drive, I wanted the most efficient ATX power supply I could get.  I'm pretty sure I got it.  Seasonic needs to realize that if they're promoting a "green" Platinum level power supply, that the amount of packaging should reflect that.  What the heck am I ever going to do with a velvet bag designed to hold an ATX power supply, or even less useful is the gigantic folding nylon pouch to hold my power supply cables?!?  Especially when most of the cables are in use in my PC.  The most frustrating part is knowing that you're ultimately paying for all this packaging that's headed to the landfill just as fast as it came into my house.  No one is looking for an Apple experience when purchasing a power supply.  Drop 10 bucks off the price and sell it in Amazon frustration free paper packaging that I can wholly dump in my recycle bin.  Now that product would get 5 stars from me.  Then I'd at least have the choice of throwing 10 bucks in the garbage if I wanted to.

After reading several mixed reviews I decided to buy this battery. Came incredibly fast in the mail and was packaged very nicely. The paperwork that came with it concerning product description/instructions was written in laughably horrible english, barely even comprehendable. And as far as the battery itself is concerned, it definitly looked new. It's a little larger then the standard dv6000 battery, so it does stick out a little bit making your laptop not sit flush against a table top (not a big issue.) The battery took a couple of hours to charge each time I charged it and got roughly 6 hours of full on gaming time with it. The issue I do have with this battery is I litearlly only got about 4 days out of it. 4th day I had it just shut down while I was using it. Won't start off the battery now and will not charge. I never once charged the laptop with it on, and I've always made sure to drain the battery before charging it to insure it keeps its maximum battery life. We read a lot of advice on how changing the BIOS settings would address the processor overheating that my wife's HP (G42t-200) laptop had been having but eventually I just bought this fan because it was a cheap thing to try. I fitted it to the existing heat sink, cleaned & re-added the thermal paste and it solved the problem like a champ.

One thing I will add is that the fan isn't super easy to get to, or at least not as easy as some online instructions had suggested. It isn't impossible but it will certainly take a jewelry screwdriver and another one that's just one step bigger (along with a bit of patience) to do the work. group the screws on a piece of paper and write down where they go!! it's easy to forget which one goes where! I'd also recommend drawing a little caveman sketch of the motherboard to remember where the 4 or 5 cables you unplug go when you re-assemble. The motherboard will need to be removed from the laptop itself to get at the fan. I managed to get it all back together with only one surplus screw at the end and everything works fine!

Our two options were either pay less than $20 for this fix and add some patience/TLC or buy a new laptop. This route worked fine and saved us hundreds on a new laptop.

update 2 months later: i hate this thing. autocorrect nonexistent, battery life is still meh when you use the workaround below, RAM is under powered, doesnt capitalize anytime youre trying to type, keyboard wont pull up automatically when you select a field(btw these are all standard features on iOS and Android), trying to maneuver on sites is horrible (say hello to the buggy scroll bar and no swiping). trying to find your way to most settings in windows takes the skill of google and sherlock holmes. i feel like a chump for paying $100 for this.  Battery tip: If i put it to sleep something kills the battery. Overnight it can drop to 10% from a full charge. This was almost disasterous when i had class the following evening and had a full charge the prior night. I found through the forums that if you mute the vol and kill the wifi before putting it to sleep it is fine. I have no idea what sorcery that is but whatever, it works.  I can't tell if its win8.1(it probably is) but it seems buggy. Sometimes the power button will put it to sleep, sometimes it will prompt me to shut down. It can still go to sleep by dragging the right side and selecting Power, but cmon. This shouldn't work inconsistently. Its hard to navigate to commonly used areas like the control panel. Currently my workaround is to hold the desktop background, select Personalize and then go to the top bar and select Control Panel. This area has critical functions that should be accessible easily. I'm sure this us windows doing this so I didn't dock stars for that. Windows apps are lacking pretty severely, android has them well beaten in this. Why I took off stars: Battery life is meh. I've had better, the above trick is what I've done to extend the life. Memory is OK but you won't get the full 32gb, more like 14gb after windows uses its hogshare. Be prepared to get a microsd. Currently HP says you can only upgrade to 32gb. Why does HP restrict the size??? Camera kinda sucks, no clue why such a low resolution when they could have installed far higher ones. I'm not talking prosumer 18mp. Just more than 2mp(if I remember right).  Touch screen. Holy hell I almost threw this tablet against a wall trying to select some text. My motox and 3rd gen iPod must have spoiled me because trying to get a precise area, like between a word to correct a misspelling is a Herculean effort. I just corrected Herculean so easily on my motox, I would have to take a walk around the block to cool off if I tried to do that on the tablet.

I have a Trendnet Wireless-N Router, it works perfectly and is quicker and more straight-forward to setup than my previous Linksys Wireless Super-G model.  When my cable provider switched out my cable modem, my wireless setup \\"broke\\" and I couldn't connnect either to the router using a network cable, and had no internet access at all.  Prior to my cable company swapping out my old modem (because it wouldn't support a higher download speed (which they were charging me for but I wasn't getting), my wireless connectivity using the Linksys router worked fine but wasn't very smooth.  I was completely unable to get my Linksys router to recognize an internet connection using the cable company's RCA modem, so I thought I'd give another router a chance.  Went to Fry's and spotted a Trendnet Wireless-N router on sale for $25 so it came with me back home.      At first, I was unable to get it to talk to my modem either, and I inadvertently reconfigured it with a new password, which it then refused to recognize.  A quick call to Trendnet's tech support quickly straighten me out on how to reset the router back to the factory defaults, and after going through the Trendnet user's manual, instead of using the quick setup guide, it  became apparent to me the problem was the default subnet settting was at 255.255.255.0 while my cable provider had a different subnet value.  No problem in changing the subnet setting in the router software to the correct value,and I had internet connectivity, both wired and wireless.  I was thrilled with the Trendnet router, and it was much faster even using my built-in Wireless-G card in my laptop than before when I was using the Linksys (which refused to accept a new subnet value when I tried to modify the settings).    So, now I was quite curious to get a wireless-N adapter for my laptop to bump up my overall speed.  After reading a ton of reviews of usb and pcmcia adapters from various manufacturers, I thought what the heck I'll try a Trendnet cardeven though some of the other reviews I found weren't that complimentary.  So bought one for $26 including shipping through an Amazon seller, and in 2 days I had the card.  Followed the instructions, installed the software, plugged in the card, and with a very small amount of configuration it worked, but at a transfer rate no faster than Wireless-G (54kbps).  I checked my router settings and it was set to a mixed signal (to accept WirelessB/G/N connections).  I changed the value to only N connections, and the connection speed jumped up from 54kbps to 64kbps.  This was with the laptop within 2-3 feet of the router.  I then carried my laptop across the house, about 25 feet into another room (and didn't turn it off).  Plugged the laptop back into an AC-powered outlet, and tried logging onto CNN.  Took about 20 seconds and the connection worked, and then I checked the speed.  The connection was \\"good\\" but the speed had dropped down to 6kbps.  Whoah...!!  That was bad, very bad.      Moved the laptop back to within a few feet of the router, back to 64kbps.  Now, the card and Wireless-N is supposed to support up to 300kbps, and here I was about 25 feet away getting 6kbps.  That was that, shut down the laptop, pulled the pcmcia card, put it back in it's box, and requested an RMA for a return.  I hope this discourse helps you decide NOT to buy this card.      However, Trendnet does have my total recommendation for their low-cost wireless-N router, it's much better than the Linksys Wireless Super-G router I had previously...

This review for the \\"IOGEAR MediaShair Wireless Hub with SD/USB Input and Built-in Power Station, White (GWFRSDU)\\" seeks to address some of the features that this device lacks with respect to file format support.

The drawback of this device for the iPad (iOS) is the device's very limited ability to play the following files through the iPad. In the days I've had this device I can confirm the inability to open the following file formats on the iPad:
.AVI
.FLAC
.FLV
.MKV
.MPEG
.MPG

While one may assume initially this is a deficiency in the iPad iOS as opposed to the \\"MediaShair\\" app; I would point out in response that a similar mediastream product titled: \\"Mediastreamer (by Dane Elec)\\" and it's associated \\"Mediastreamer\\" app can open all the above listed files on the iPad.
So, my concern here is what appears to be a deficiency in the \\"MediaShair\\" app for iPad.
IF this deficiency in the \\"MediaShair\\" app for iPad can be addressed and updated by the manufacturer, so that all the above listed file formats can be played on the iPad; I implore the manufacturer to make that known because as of this writing (03/28) this device lacks a large file format compatibility.
IF such an update is released or made aware of I will ofcourse will give a new rating based on the new update. This lack of file format connectivity is indeed a deal-breaker for me since that is the draw to having an iPad to begin with (a larger screen for video viewing). As of this moment, I am considering returning this device, and contemplating ordering the 5-in-1 RavPower mediastreamer instead.

On a positive note this device has excellent connectivity on first connect as well as consistent connectivity (ie. staying connected) while using the device over a significant timeframe with the iPad.
Thanks.

Is it leather?   No. Does it do the job?   Yes. Have I had issues with it sliding out of the sleeve?  No.    Upon receiving it, I marked the spot for the light sensor. Using a paper hole punch, I made a perfectly round hole. Then I used a lighter to seal the edge around the hole. No fraying and no separating.    Don't buy it expecting high quality leather. But, if you're like me, and just spent $500 on your iPad, and want to protect it temporarily without breaking the bank, this is definitely the case for you.    I do intend to get something better down the road, but for right now, this is an excellent, inexpensive option.

I've had this thing for over two years and it is a constant source of frustration. If you want your connection to randomly drop down to 1mbps, this is the router for you. You will have random connection problems seemingly out of the blue after weeks of steady performance. It will drop your connection in the middle of a game, streaming videos, and transferring files.

I've done just about everything to troubleshoot the issues with this router. DDWRT. New antennas. New wireless adapters on the clients. Heatsinks on the chipset. Adjusting power. Setting fixed channels. Setting fixed bandwidths. Twenty Hz. Forty Hz. This and that. On and off. I've concluded that this router is just a piece of junk.

Unfortunately, I bought a 4 GIG Transcend, which is still working but it's not dependable. I've only had it about a year. On the other hand, the old Kingston is as solid and dependable as it ever was. And I've owned it about four years.

Bottom line: If you want to store mission critical files, don't buy this. Invest more money and get a Kingston Traveler. I have another flash drive but haven't owned it long enough to recommend it yet. I can, however, recommend the Kingston.

TL:DR; If you LOVED the original \\"Illuminated Ultrathin Keyboard with Backlighting\\" you'll probably HATE the K800 !

Back in the day I used to hate thin keyboards due to their poor ergonomics until I saw and bought the \\"Auravision EluminX Illuminated Keyboard\\" back in ~2000 from ThinkGeek. The reasons it was fantastic were:

* thin,
* cool blue led backlighting, :-)
* _felt_ sturdy,
* _felt_ comfortable.

These last two points are what most thin keyboard manufacturers completely fail to understand AT ALL. A thin keyboard MUST feel sturdy and BE comfortable!

My EluminX eventually died due to extreme gaming and was I disappointed when I couldn't find any good replacements for a few years. I rejoiced when I saw the \\"Logitech Illuminated Ultrathin Keyboard with Backlighting.\\" I absolutely loved using the Illuminated Ultrathin; I thought \\"Here is a company that _finally_ understand what makes a thin keyboard great!\\" I loved them so much I bought 2 more because Logitech has this extremely annoying habit of producing a fantastic product and THEN pulling that particular model from the market in about a year when they flood it with other half-a-dozen el-cheapo \\"upgraded\\" variations which are even worse then the \\"original\\" instead of fixing their _drivers_ with functionality, but I digress.

So having added more computers to the \\"man cave\\" I needed a few more keyboards. Seeing as the \\"original\\" Logitech Illuminated was discontinued I decided to tried the \\"Logitech Wireless Solar Keyboard K750\\" since I thought \\"Surely, Logitech would keep the features that worked and make it even better!\\" Right? Wrong! Unfortunately Logitech threw out what they learnt about thin keyboards. The Wireless Solar has 2 major design problems:

* It feels cheap and flimsy. The pop-out legs on the back feel like they break with any pressure!
* The plastic shape of the keys has the wrong angle on the sides and the top concave angle feels like your fingers never feel like they can \\"just rest naturally at home.\\"

Which brings me to the K800...

Sadly the K800 has the same broken design as the K750. The new plastic mold feels cheap and flimsy. The ergonomics are off due to the wrong concave angle.

Does that mean the K800 is wrong for everyone? No. What it means is that there are probably 2 camps:

* If you loved the original Illuminated Keyboard you probably hated the K750. You'll probably hate the K800 as well.
* If you liked the Solar K750 then you'll probably also love the K800.

The one redeeming feature of the K800 is that you are not forced to stay wireless. You can keep the keyboard plugged in and never worry about losing battery in the middle of a gaming sessions. If Logitech would take the original and make it a dual-combo wired-wireless and fix their drivers they would have a hit.

Why is it so hard to buy an GOOD _wired_ illuminated thin keyboard these days??

One of these days Logitech will get around to \\"fixing\\" their keyboard drivers and let you remap a key to any mouse button, offer advanced mapping of the Caps Lock key to any key (without resorting to Windows Registry \\"Hacks\\"), and providing full featured OSX drivers.

Until Logitech _understands_ what makes a thin keyboard great I recommend everyone AVOID the K800. It is garbage compared to the original Illuminated Ultrathin.

The hp mediavault 500GB version was delivered to me yesterday. Because of the following, I'm going to return it:    1. No Mac Support - yes, hp says this product works with mac os x. What they don't tell you (until after you buy it) is that they don't *support* macs. I opened the box and saw the installation cd. I popped it in my mac only to notice that all of the files seemed to be windows files. I rechecked the box for the mac drivers. I scoured the disk, looking for the mac folder. Nothing. I found on one of HP's support pages how you can do a standard \\"connect to server\\" to at least see the drive. Big deal. I could do that with samba for any drive on the network! However, where's the whole \\"back up your whole hard drive\\" option?     Assuming I must have missed something obvious, I finally called HP. To my shock, the tech person told me, \\"We don't support mac\\". He said it as if I should *obviously* know that macs aren't supported. When I read him both amazon's and hp's website indicating that it says, \\"works with both windows and mac\\", he said, \\"oh, it works with mac, we just won't support it.\\" (!!!) I tried to explain to him that that is what's called \\"deceptive advertising\\". I have no problem rsyncing my data. However, it would have gone a LONG way in my decision regarding whether or not to buy this product. If I have to rsync the data myself, why shouldn't I just get an old beat up machine, stick two 500GB drives in them and rsync to that?    2. You don't really have access to the second drive - When I opened the box, the first thing I was curious about was what kind of drive was included with the media vault? Is it western digital, segate/maxtor, or their own drive? So I tried opening the door only to see that I couldn't. Only one door opens; the other is a false door. So when I spoke to the HP tech person, I brought this to his attention. If the extra drive I bought fails, I can replace it. I asked, what happens if the drive that comes with the unit fails? \\"Oh, just return it to HP and we'll put a new drive in and return it to you.\\" I was more specific. \\"What happens if the drive fails beyond the warranty?\\" I was told that in that case, I have to pay. So if you thought you could just pop out the failed drive and stick in a replacement, you can, with one MAJOR caveat. As long as the failed drive is the additional one you bought, you can. If it's the one that comes with the unit, you'll have to ship it back to HP and pay whatever they feel like charging you. Along these lines...    3. You can't pop the drive out yourself and replace it. Well technically you could take the drive out with screwdrivers just like you could any hard drive in any computer. However, the little mini-operating system used to do the mirroring isn't on a ROM chip; it's on the drive that comes with the unit. Furthermore, that mini-os (I think the tech guy said it's a modified linux variant) doesn't get mirrored to the second drive in raid 1. So when the first drive fails, which has the os on it, you have a very heavy paperweight!!! Again, you are forced to go through HP to fix this. HP uses their own os and they don't provide it on their site so you can't just download it, install it on a new drive and pop it in the machine. Once you buy this product, you're married to HP. I don't like that at all!!!    If the problem was just the first point, I would have gladly given this product five stars (assuming everything else worked over at least a couple of months time). But the whole purpose of me having mirrored data in a raid 1 configuration is that if ANY of the drives fail, I pop it out and put in a new one. YOU DON'T REALLY HAVE THAT OPTION WITH THIS, ALTHOUGH THAT'S NOT MENTIONED ANYWHERE!!!     I'm going to return everything I bought and just put together my own machine dedicated to backing up the network. You've been warned.

No, no, no, no, no!  I wish I had gone with my original idea of purchasing a regular kindle for my boys, and then adding the content I wanted them to have later.  Instead, I got this terrible "kids" kindle that keeps freezing up, claiming insufficient storage, and will turn off its own WIFI randomly.  My five year old son does not have a problem with my kindle, however, when he tries to use the one I just bought him, it freezes, and will not download any content.  I spent well over two hours setting the kindles up for my boys for Christmas presents, and it took them all of an hour to lock it up by trying to download extra content.  There are so many kids apps available, that if they touch them, it will try to begin downloading it... Which means if they touch, say five, it will automatically freeze up, turn the WIFI off, and stop working all together.  Since Christmas morning I have had to trouble shoot these things ten times!  It's time consuming and not worth the effort.  I've been looking for a number to call to get help from Amazon so I can lock the apps... That doesn't appear to be an option at this point.  The only thing this kindle has going for it is the bumper that came with it!  I do not recommend buying the kids kindle.  Buy a regular one and set it up for your child yourself!

After really great experieces with a Linksys 4 port DSL router three years ago and later a similar product with a built-in 802.11b access point, I was more than willing to give the Linksys Instant Wireless PrintServer (WPS11 ver. 3) a try. What a mistake that was. Spent 2+ hours filddling with it and another hour with Linksys technical support (mostly on hold). I consider myself pretty good with software, networks, and hardware (going on 10+ years as a programmer) but the WPS11 had me beat. I did manage to get the device installed and configured, I just could not print from any programs on my PC -- I kept getting the error message "The handle is invalid" when attempting to print via the WPS11. That was the problem I called Linsys technical support about. I spoke with two people and the only thing worse than their english was their knowlege of the device and its configuration. Ultimately, I was disconnected (or they hung up on me) without the problem getting resolved. Some observerations: 1) The documentation is terrible. 2) The interface for the two programs you install on your PC to configure and use the print server are clunky and amateurish (not very professional looking). The interface for the web browser accesible program that lets you configure the print server is clunky and slow. 3) In order to get the device to go into "wireless" mode after you unplug the CAT 5 cable, you have to power it down and back up again. That little fact isn't mentioned ANYWHERE in the documentation or on Linksys' web site and it cost me the first of the three hours I spent trying to get this device to work. I gave up on the WPS11 and bought the Netgear Wireless Ready Print Server (PS111W) instead. It requires the seperate purchase of a Netgear 802.11b wireless PCMCIA adapter (MA401) but it was the right decision. Crisp, very clean looking configuration software and less than 10 minutes to install. Works like a champ - wish I had tried the Netgear first.
my charging point got loose with in few months. now it is not charging at all. Really not happy with the kind of hardware provided by asus.

While this will work for most people's needs and the build quality is decent, the product listed is not the product they are shipping. Very carefully look at the pictures and you can see that it does not, in fact, have the +5 pins refereed to in the product name. It only has the +1 wide pin. It should work for most people, but do not expect this product to handle anything analog. 24+5 infers that it would be a DVI-I (I for integrated, both analog and digital). This is a DVI-D (D for digital) dual link to HDMI adaptor with 24+1 pins.

Check wikipedia for more information: [...]

First of all, I am a huge Apple fan, turning into a huge samsung fan. While this laptop is not as compact and thin as a macbook pro, it is sleek and stylish, and half the cost.

Pros:
-Super fast

-Sleek and stylish

-Runs very cool, has not yet gotten warm.
Fan is very quiet, I think I've noticed it twice.

-Screen is pretty good, seems a little washed out, but then again I just switched from an iPad, so no comparison there.

-Has nice island style keys just like the macbook

-BATTERY LIFE!!!!!! No joke 8 hours easy on this thing with light office work, even with screen brightness turned up

-Compact power cord

-Sturdy

-Speakers are pretty good, but hey, it is a laptop so no high expectations there

-TRACKPAD is multitouch, just like a macbook! This is so essential!

-Price, got it for $600 at Best Buy. Worth more like $900.

CONS:

-Like I said, the screen is pretty good but nothing to shout about.

-When you are first initializing the set up, make sure you don't accidentally partition the hard drive like I did, that is the default option, I don't know how to get it back.

********UPDATE****
So after a few months with the machine I still quite like it, however I have noticed a few things. More and more I have notice how washed out the screen looks, the colors just do not pop. I do not know if this is common with mid-range laptops, it certainly pales in comparison to a macbook pros screen and my cheap LCD TV.
Also, the amazing 8-9 hour battery life that I was raving about has already dropped to 5 hrs in a matter of 3 months. Again, don't know if that is common, but I miss being able to go all day without the power cord.

*****UPDATE*******
last summer this laptop fell out of our car and got pretty banged up. Bought a MacBook Air off of amazon for $800 and have never looked back. Iknow it's a bit more money, but everything about it is superior, highly recommend it. Screen is much better, crazy thin, and ssd just screams. And this is a 2011 model. I received my Kindle as a birthday present, and part of the gift was a gift card from Amazon that would cover the price of the extended warranty. The card was purchased at the same time as the Kindle, and yet it wasn't delivered until weeks after my birthday (we had to get Amazon to resend the gift card). By the time I finally had the funds to purchase the warranty, it said that I was no longer qualified to purchase it. The 30 day time frame to purchase beginning with the delivery date (not the activation or registration of the Kindle) is completely ridiculous, especially when considering some people receive their Kindles as gifts and therefore don't have the entire 30 days to purchase. I took my issue to Amazon, and all I got out of it was more information that I already knew - like that there is a one year warranty included with the Kindle anyway, and that you have thirty days to buy this one. Not helpful. I expected a bit more understanding and better customer service on this one, but I guess since it's a third party providing the warranty this is the sort of inflexibility you can expect if anything goes wrong with your order. And like other people have mentioned, it's really only an extra year of coverage, not two like the name implies.

This USB 2.0 is for the birds.  Otherwise, it was very quiet and discreet, as it can fit behind my iMac and not really be seen at all.

Turn off Bluetooth and the wifi bandwidth speed shoots up to max, turn Bluetooth back on, and get maybe 2-3mbps.  Called HP, they didn't have a solution and after going through multiple tiers of support, they quit calling me back.  Decided to just send it back and get something that works.

My ancient machine was feeling strapped for memory so I went looking for an upgrade. I'd always had good luck with the few PNY products I'd purchased before so with that experience and the excellent rating here at amazon I purchased these sticks.

I tested the memory with Memtest 86+ for 72 hours just after I installed it so I thought I'd be safe. One month later the system starts to be unstable, I tested the disks and found file corruption (which meant my backups were also corrupt.) I did a short Memtest (2 runs) and had no errors shown. However pulling and testing the disks on a different system had the disks themselves test out perfectly. So I went back and ran Memtest again and low and behold I had intermittent errors that always occurred at the same location but might take up to 8 hours to show up. Unfortunately it's just a few days too late to return them to amazon.

Note: the memory was set up at stock (auto detected) settings, no overclocking on cpu or memory.

The New Trent Airbender 1.0 Wireless Bluetooth Clamshell IPad Keyboard Case is very nice. I bought one of these to use as a home built DVR. After installing a 120GB SSD and 4gb of RAM I was off to instaling an OS. I chose a copy of Win7 PRO 64bit I had laying around. Using an external USB DVD drive the install went smoothly. After logging on for the first time installed driver software and connected to the internet and installed updates. I tried some HD youtube video and it seemed to play ok but still wasn't great. I previously emailed Shuttle Support and asked about using the Broadcom BCM970015 mini-PCIE card for better hardware video decoding. I was told it should work but there is no way of knowing for sure because they haven't tested it. I then did some research and found a newer video driver directly from intel that improved the video playback. I was even able to play 1080p video file that looked great. I also didn't like the wifi network card's performance. So I dug out a card I had previously purchased (Intel® Dual Band Wireless-N 7260 Plus Bluetooth4.0). That card was designed with newer chipsets in mind but works flawlessly in the XS35V2. There is the possibility that newer Wireless-AC cards will work as well and they are fairly cheap. I will look at installing another wifi antenna in the future as it only has one built in. I will be purchasing a couple of USB TV tuners soon and then installing XBMCBuntu for the main OS+DVR/Media Player. I would really love to be able to install Android on this. I believe these little machines would be great as Google TV/Android TV devices. The only thing it is missing is HDMI out. I will be purchasing a VGA to HDMI dongle sometime soon. Upon opening it up to look at the internals. Mainly to check how the second HDD will connect when I purchase the adapter. It looks as if they could have actually made these to possibly support an MXM Graphics Module upgrade. If manufactures would do something like that with their systems they could make a base system then charge extra for a video "card" upgrade similarto a full size desktop.

I'm a photographer, and I'm very disappointed with this purchase. I bought it in September and have tried to calibrate it, but I've now decided this is just a poorly designed product. Unfortunately I've spent too long trying to get it to work, and I'm now past the return period, so Amazon won't let me return it either.

Here are the reasons I have to give it one star:

1) The colors looked washed out and dim initially. I spent $180 on the X-Rite CMUNDIS ColorMunki Display calibrator. After calibrating several times, the monitor still doesn't look right.

2) The buttons on the bottom of the screen are ultra sensitive. They don't even need to be pushed. If you just brush up against them, they are activated, and you can accidentally switch color profiles without noticing. They right underneath the monitor on the right side, so it's in a place you are always reaching on your desk, and it's easy to push them accidentally. My kids have accidentally pushed them many times too. Now every time I sit down to edit pictures, I'm paranoid that the color scheme has changed, and I have to re-check it each time!

3) The monitor wiggles slightly on the stand. It is not sturdy.

No internet at vacation house.
Using an xfinity subscription wifi hotspot picked up from across the street several hundred feet away.
Using laptop internal antenna I had to keep laptop pushed into the window and positioned-just-so to get one bar.
Tried a Hawking HWDN2. Got two bars. Better - but it had a parabolic dish! I expected MUCH better.
Not just another measly bar.
Going to have to crack it open and see if it's really a parabolic dish or if that's just a plastic facade.

Next tried the Alfa AWUS036 with the 7dBi flat antenna panel.
All five bars! 82% signal! Wow! 86% link quality.
The connection was good enough that I could easily stream video.
Only trouble I had was when the pest control man parked his truck in the street right in my wifi line of fire.
But he was gone in an hour. As were the bugs.

If you don't mind wasting money… buy it…

My experience with Amazon…. I have been a long time amazon customer and purchase from them because use to think they valued their customers… not so much anymore. I have loyally purchased kindles since they first emerged on the market. This was my 3rd personal Kindle (I've bought them for my mom and sister as well) and this will be my last purchase. I purchased my kindle in July 2013 and by February of 2014, it increasingly stopped holding a charge. I continued to use my Kindle and finally by May, I was unable to use my kindle for more than 15-30 min. without it being plugged in. Not very convenient. I called customer service and they had me wipe and reinstall the software. It still didn't work. So I called and they said they would replace my kindle. The online invoice indicated that the condition of the replacement kindle was "new". However, when it arrived, it had a refurbished sticker on the box.

I spent $250 on my kindle when i purchased it. Refurbished models are now valued at $150. I had to call Amazon twice to address this issue. The first time I called Amazon to complain and ask why they were trying to replace a $250 kindle with a $150 one, as well as giving me a refurbished unit instead of a new one. They told me they no longer make the model and had to replace it with a refurbished unit. I asked to speak with a manager because I didn't believe that this was appropriate given the expense of the item and was told a manager would call me back. Two weeks later and no call from Amazon, I called again. Again I was given the run around and offered a $20 credit that I guess was suppose to make up for the additional $100 my original kindle was worth versus their replacement.

As I explained to Amazon,
1) I could have bought a refurbished model in the first place if that was what i wanted. I didn't. So why would I want a refurbished model now.
2) Maybe your warranty does allow you to replace a model with refurbished unit but just because you can doesn't mean you should. That's not good customer service. Who wants to spend $250+ in July to have that item break within 6 months and then get a used replacement?
3) Why are you telling me you don't make the item anymore and can only give me a refurbished unit when you are still selling them new online for $229???
4) Why are you sending me an invoice stating that the replacement is "new" when the package clearly states its refurbished.
5) How is the fact that this refurbished model is under warranty suppose to make me feel any better about it being a replacement for a new model that only worked for 6 months… Yes, I want to spend my time on the phone with Amazon replacing this unit as well.

This is why people buy Apple products. They break you take them to the store and they replace them or upgrade them, no questions asked. Amazon didn't want to give me the next version of the HD 7 which is valued at the same price I paid. That's just cheap. Who losses out in this scenario? The customer.

Not only do I buy the kindle, but I buy movies, apps, textbooks and ebooks, exclusively from Amazon, and what do I get in return for my customer loyalty and hard earned money???? A refurbished Kindle and $20 to spend on Amazon.That's like your parents giving you money to buy them a present. Well, Amazon may be convenient but the customer service is sub par. I think I've spent enough money on Amazon to warrant a little loyalty from them and a lot better customer service

Its only a bargain if you can afford it and I can't afford to spend $250 on something that only works for 6 months and is then going to be replaced with something that is worth half as much. That sounds too much like a scheme to me. This was my last Amazon purchase. I'd rather drive to a store than feel cheated.

It makes reading a better experience for me. I can make the font bigger, I can read without a light on at night, and I can just relax. I've never been a big reader, but the kindle has helped me become better in that regard.

After completing an enormous amount of research hoping to find a legal work around to have iTunes movies available for our kids we emailed Seagate directly.  They confirmed that because of iOS 8, we are not able to stream iTunes purchased movies directly to our devices.  They suggested we continue to use it as a portable hard drive for other purposes.  $154 for a 1 TB hard drive is too expensive and we don't need another external hard drive at this time.  This device will be returned.  iOS / iTunes buyer be aware!  Don't make the same mistake we did.

This device is the best thing available for anyone who reads stacks of PDFs and is looking to move away from paper. For work it's not enough to read PDFs, you need to highlight, make notes, and be able to export and share annotations with co-workers and archive them on you computer or other devices for future reference. The EE does all this and much more. The e-ink screen is large enough to view full sized PDFs with only minor reduction in size. Plus, since the margins are adjustable, you can have some flexibility to increase the size without having to zoom, which it also does well.     Taking handwritten notes is fantastic. The note-taking experience feels and looks almost as good as paper. You might want to get an additional wacom pen though, since the one that comes with the device is pretty skinny. While working on documents you can add links to other PDFs, files, or websites within the document at relevant points. The tablet side makes it easy to organize and upload documents to read and annotate. With the library, you can organize all your work under different tags. For classes I have all the readings for the class, as well as a journal document under the same tag. The journal is my class notebook. Switching between the PDF and journal functions is done with a single click. You can create different tabs in your journal that act like separators in a notebook. This creates a table of contents for the journal so it's easy to see and navigate between different topics. This is all I take to class now. It's also my indispensable companion at conferences and in the field.     I've also recently been making great use of the audio recorder, which takes very clear recordings of interviews, even in meetings with ten or more people around the table. I can record and take notes, check things on the web all at the same time. And I can work all day on a single charge.     With Dropbox on the tablet, this device is linked up with the work on my computer, saving tons of time and just making everything easy. I've been looking for years for a way to annotate scholarly articles without going blind staring at a backlit LCD screen for hours at a time. The e-ink screen makes an enormous difference. It may not be as slick as some of the LCD-only tablets, but there's no comparison in terms of the reading experience.     If you're looking for a lightning fast, slick device for playing around, there are probably other options that would be more impressive. If you're looking for something with incredibly smart and practical design meant to make your life easier as a juggler of endless documents, the edge is really still unbeatable. Until Pixel Qi can really offer the indoor reading experience (as well as outdoor) of e-ink, this will probably continue to be the best on the market for actively working on documents.

This little guy got delivered by Amazon a few days before it's original release. I am not much of a directions guy, but was extremely pleased with how easy this was to set up and how intuitive it was when it came to setting it up. I've got 1 workstation, 2 netbooks, and 2 laptops that backup wirelessly to this guy. If they are already on the same wireless network, it's simply a matter of clicking the 'add computer' button. There's no need to fuss with any of the backup settings unless you are particular, as it will do the work automatically for you. You can then either access your files via the console or remotely at your convenience.    I can't stress enough how nice and convenient it is to be able to centrally access all my files without having to shuffle files back and forth between the local hard drives and having piece of mind knowing it's being backed up automatically. I previously did this with Time Capsule which while it worked at times, was tempermental and slow. I'm not sure how well this will work on Mac, but I am running various flavors of XP and Vista in 32bit and 64bit configs.    I even decided to add another storage drive (Seagate Barracude 1.5tb 7200rpm)for redundancy. Adding storage was a simple as pulling out an open drive bay, popping in the new drive, then going into the management console to click through the add storage wizard which took less than a minute. Now I've got 2.6tb's of storage, more than I'll probably ever need and 2 open bays to expand down the road.

I am a card carrying AMD, ASUS and Corsair hardware enthusiast.  This latest model of the Corsair Hydro H60 is remarkable!  I had the original version and it lasted me 5 years working smoothy to keep my CPU cool, always in 30C's idle and loaded at 45 to 48C's.  This new one is so much quieter and is keeping the temperatures in the 30C's ad idle and in the 40C's fully loaded as well. So what's the difference between old and new Hydro H60?  I can run the fan on Turbo setting which is quieter than the older Standard speed (I like quiet).  Plus - a big plus. The bracket for AM sockets, in my case AM3 and AM3+ is so easy to install compared to the older model.  All you need do is put the bracket over the top of the Cooler and a magnetic attachment holds it in place while you tighten the fasteners by hand until the cooler is snug on the processor. Nothing more to do for us AMD enthusiasts.  The AM sockets have the two catches for the regular fans to fit over then tighten up.  The same catches are all you need for the Hydro H60 bracket for snugging up the cooler to the processor.  Outstanding Corsair!!  I have Corsair Looped Cooling in two rigs and Corsair Memory and Corsair PSU.  Yep, big fan of Corsair.  Kudos for upgrading the H60 to take on moderate to extreme overclocking with the Athlon, Phenom and FX series processors. Other upgrades to the H60. Impressive larger hoses and a much sturdier built cooler/pump module.

I recently purchased these locally to ago with my new laptop. I currently have a Logitech surround sound setup for pc's being used with my TV, Blu-ray player, and my Xbox and that system sounds fantastic. For under $50 you cannot go wrong with these speakers. It pushes a good amount of sounds with some very nice rich bass. It will fill a room with sound without peaking, distortion, or hiss. All of the highs and lows are rich and distinguishable as well which is very important.  I have seen people complain of a hiss issue. The most common cause is old audio cables or having your mp3 player on a usb charger while playing music. This goes for any stereo or pair of headphones. It is not the speakers, it is your setup. It may also be the quality of mp3 you have on playback. Anything lower than 192k in quality and you will hear a loss in audio quality.  Logitech makes nothing but quality products. Call me a fanboy if you will. I have a range of their products including remotes, wireless keyboards, mice, and now 2 sets of speakers. You will not be disappointed with purchasing this set of speakers if you do not have the budget or space for a larger setup. It may be compact but the system delivers.

Yeah, 5-stars, and worth every one of them. Not sure why some other reviewers complained about the weight of this thing, 'cause it's not heavy. It is, however, extremely well made. Quality parts weigh more, but Wenger has designed this pack so well that every ounce, and we are talking about ounces here, is well worth it.

My previous pack was exceptionally light, and after two semesters of school, only eight weeks with an Algebra tome, it tore itself apart. This pack, on the other hand, looks like I could carry a short block V8 in it with nary a care in the world. Seriously, I wouldn't think twice about loading this thing to 60 lbs.

Attention to detail is perfect. Love the straps; they're so comfortable, and adjusting them while wearing it is so easy, I was laughing the first time I tried it. My old pack demanded I take it off to change strap length.

The laptop sleeve is a thing of beauty. It swallowed my 17" Mac without trouble, and it is so well protected that I have no qualms about traveling with it like this, saving me a precious carry-on slot.

The zippers are so awesome. They seem like, with proper care, they will outlive me. The pull tabs for them are just another small detail that was not overlooked. Ergonomic and tough...nicely done. They are a joy to use.

If you're looking for a good, cheap pack, Jansport is a fine choice. But, if you're looking for something to last forever, this is the one.

It is teh sex. I absolutely love this mouse. It saved my profile without me doing a thing or installing software again after I re-installed Windows 7 fresh & new, in the mouse itself, so I didn't have to set everything up again. That made me very happy. Setting up all the buttons to do your bidding is a piece of cake & once you are using it & remembering you have all these buttons, you'll realize you don't know how you ever were without them! It feels lovely in the hand, battery lasts quite a while & even though I don't use it for gaming, I'm sure it would absolutely be awesome in that case (I used to game a lot). I love it for navigating & stuff like Photoshop & the like.

I set mine up so the back & forward button do the usual, in the usual place, while G6 is undo, G7 is ctrl, G8 is alt, G9 is shift & the last two are copy and paste functions, which just rock my socks a lot of the time. I spend pretty much every waking hour on my computer, so it's made a huge difference.

My one beef with the thing is the horrible, absolutely dreadful texture of the plastic thumb rest & around the rest of the mouse areas besides the palm & buttons. It drives me insane, it's this rough, terrible texture that drives my OCD (no, not the stereotypical kind, it's different) crazy & sometimes I can't even handle touching it. However, I do believe it's like that because of the fact it is a gaming mouse & the thought behind it is likely them wanting to prevent slippage from sweaty hands during hardcore gaming sessions, so a lot of those who are interested, I'm sure it's perfect for you. I do think they could have used a different material/texture, though & still achieved the same result. It doesn't lose any points for this, since this is most likely a plus for gamers & the mouse is intended for gaming, not to mention this is mostly a personal preference/issue. It's fantastic & you shouldn't hesitate. I only hesitated because I hate Logitech & didn't want to buy another product of theirs again. I'm glad I went through with it, especially considering the hassle I was going through trying to find something that would be just right for me. This was a bit higher than my price range, but it had everything I wanted & needed in a mouse, & I thank me every day for having gone through with it! :)

Battery compartment is very easy to deal with, set-up is quick, painless & easy, battery life is good, reaction time seems good (though I haven't tried it in a really necessary environment for that), the two battery consumption options are awesome, buttons are all easy to access & react quickly to your press, the scroll wheel is ok, and something that makes me pretty happy is the off & on switch on the bottom, which really is necessary, I think, especially when you want to do something like wipe the mouse down with something & don't want it to click a bunch of stuff in the process, among a bunch of other reasons. So do it! Buy the mouse already! (oh and btw, I absolutely love the USB extension cord, which I am using for my 4-port hub instead, actually, & the range is pretty good as far as I know for the mouse, but I never need to go further than a foot or so from it anyways, so this might be the one area I have no knowledge about)

Just received this monitor.  Selected it after a fair bit of research.  Wanted high definition, a non-glare screen, and speakers.  This unit exceeds my expectations on all those counts.  Picture quality is outstanding.  Stereo speakers are fine -- okay sound quality and just loud enough, nothing fancy but what I expect/need in monitor speakers.  Frameless design is quite nice looking and saves a bit of space so it fits on my desk next to my other monitor (an HP S2031, a fine budget-priced monitor, but it is outclassed by the Viewsonic's color rendition and clarity).  Stand is solid enough and tilt adjustment has a large and useful range of movement.  Don't miss the lack of  height or swivel adjustments.  Cable connections are easy to access and in the box comes  a RGB, HDMI, and audio cable!  Per other reviews, the controls are hidden away below and behind the screen and require scrunching down to see but then I don't use them that often.  Adjustments to the screen were easy to make once I found the darn controls.  Overall, I am very pleased with this monitor.  Have already enjoyed seeing my pictures, documents, and videos in a new light.

Motorola makes solid iron and this product lives up to that reputation.    I have had Motorola cable modems (along with phones and radios) for many years now and never had a single problem.  Eventually noticed I was not getting the advertised speeds from Comcast and called customer service, thinking there might be an issue with the line.  I was told that my old SB4100 modem did not support the higher-speed standard and I would need to upgrade to get those higher speeds.  I automatically turned to another Motorola, this time the SB5101.    Changeover was truly painless.  Plug in the new one, call Comcast, give them the identifying information and I was up and running within minutes.  I recall there was a small glitch when my computer was not found by Comcast.  It turned out it was necessary to power off and on the Linksys router also.  I immediately noticed the increase in speed which, according to the various online meters, doubled.    I have now had the modem almost one year, have had no problems with it at all and continue to cruise at advertised speeds.

I went through Two new Motherboards , bought new Kingston 1600 Memory , Two new CPU's and nothing worked. After I replaced this new EVGA 500W with a new Thermaltake 600W power supply unit my computer starts up and runs great. Biggest POS I've had to endure in quite some time. Modem takes FOREVER to reboot, if it does at all. Most of the time, it hangs, saying it can take several minutes to update. Many pages time out before loading or only half load, 5mb data downloads cut in and out and end up failing. Forget trying to stream movies as they constantly stall and buffer every 4 minutes. And I'd hate to be a gamer trying to survive gameplay through this piece of carp.

The one good thing is that when the modem hangs and I lose my wifi, I can jump on my neighbors uVerse network where he has a more robust service plan.

As soon as this next modem dies, I'm canceling TWC all together and will forward that money to my neighbor for permanent access.

I bought this after being prompted by my HP TouchPad that I needed an OEM charger in order for it to charge effectively. I ordered the product and it worked as intended, and usually gives my tablet a full charge within 2 hours of being plugged in on standby. That said, you do not actually need the OEM charger to charge your tablet in full. If you use an aftermarket charger you can simply turn the tablet off entirely and leave it plugged in for roughly 2 days. It will then be able to be fully charged and turn back on just fine etc. If you use your HP TouchPad on the go with regularity though, go for the OEM version here.

I bought this iPad Mini case because my wife had a very similar one for her standard sized iPad. Although it looks nice and I like the elastic closure, I'm not really satisfied with it in use.

1) The iPad Case does not always shut off/sleep my iPad Mini. This is VERY irritating as I'm constantly moving the iPad around inside the case waiting to hear the "click". Clearly ShopNY has used substandard magnets in the manufacture of this case because it ain't rocket science...

2) The 360 degree swivel is VERY loose - so much so that I half expect it to pop apart. You don't want a swivle that's hard to rotate, but you also don't want one that has absolutely no friction on it at all.

3) My iPad Mini does not like standing up in landscape mode on the case and the slightest bump of the case or the table make it fall down. I'm not sure what can even be done about this. Thankfully I don't put it on a table to often, but when I do it usually doesn't go very well.

Overall the case looks really great, but the operation of the case is what matters and in this the ShopNY iPad Mini Case flunks the test.

Running Amahi home server on a machine I built with old spare parts. In my haste to get it up and running, it dawned on me after the fact that the on-board network interface is only 10/100. Doh! Not so great for large file transfers (like ripped BD's).

Long story short: I disabled the on-board LAN in the BIOS, installed the TP-LINK card, and booted the OS (modified version of Fedora Linux). Card was detected and I was off without a hitch. Transfers over ethernet went from ~10 MB/s to between 80-90 MB/s.

Couldn't be happier. Thanks TP-LINK!!

The company that I work for now hands these docking stations out to our laptop users.  My job is to hook these things up and support then from an IT perspective.  Drivers are an inconsistent mess - having constant issues with either the Targus embedded NIC conking out or throttling connections, slowing down the laptops themselves, sluggish displays or just displays dropping out completely, etc.  It's a vicious circle with these things, once one driver is re-installed, something else invariably dies.    Updating the drivers helps out with issues for a little while, that is until for some unknown reason something dies again.  As another user pointed out, you will need to go to (at least) two different sites to get updated drivers - [...]    They are a nightmare to support.  I do not recommend.

I should have listened to the negative reviews about this battery from other users. Arrived well on time and plugged it on my laptop running win 7. The system showed it is 70% charged. Fully charged it and then left my machine running to drain the battery to the critical level so that it can be calibrated.

Once the machine turned off reaching the crital level, plugged back the AC power and turned on machine. Windows 7 showed a message that i need to replace the battery. Left it to chage and it did not retained the charge and there is no way i can tell what % the battery level is. Tested this with Battery Care Software that tell you Total Capacity and Available Capacity (i save the readings when i first plugged it in and after the calibration ) and it was indicating that the wear level has increased. Sent it back the next day.

Its better to buy a the one which is more reputed and also a little expensive. Total waste of time and efforts - have ordered another one to replace the battery.

Good thing i did not recycled my existing battery on the same day.

Product came in 1 day and was as described.

Update:
I figured it out. See this website ([...]), it explains it all, it is my user error. I have a DVI-D (D for digital) connection to my monitor, so I need a conversion box to go to VGA (VGA is analog signal). You have to have a DVI-A or DVI-I connection to not need a conversion box.

I bought this OCZ Agility 3 480G to replace the harddrive in my brand new Sony SVS1511 (2012 VAIO S-Series, core i7) hoping to gain a little more performance out of it. The mistake I made was not reading review here before I bought it.

My experience echos that of a few reviewers here; i.e. that it will frequently freeze up on Windows 7. Most of the time it occured during disk I/O and the HD light would be stuck on. I'm already on the latest firmware (.22), running all the proper Intel SATA drivers, and locking the drive to operate in SATA2 to match the laptop but neither of these actually improve anything.

After struggling with it for about 2 weeks, I replaced it with Kingston V200+ SSD and magically it hasn't even freeze once. The OCZ drive will go back to OCZ for a warranty replacement and then I might try in on my desktop PC instead.

Update:
I've reached out to Tech Support via there forum. They are prompt and responsive and suggested changing the ACHI Link Power Management setting. This requires some registry addition, removal, tweaking, and deleting of Intel 7 Series SATA driver and force use Microsoft's. It's going to take a few days to see whether it help.

Either way, I have to give two thumbs up for their support team.

Every once in a while, a device comes along that changes how you go about your life.  The Ipod, the Iphone, and the Kindle are three such devices.  I don't believe that I could ever go back to being without the Kindle.  If you are an avid reader, here are some of the advantages of owning a Kindle:  Ebooks are generally much cheaper than the book itself; you no longer have growing piles of books that take up more and more space; you can take numerous books on trips in one very compact package; and you can purchase that latest book you want to read without getting out of your chair.  Are there disadvantages to the Kindle?  Of course.  But most are minor and of no real concern.  When faced with the advantages versus the disadvantages,  I'll take the Kindle every time.  I researched Ebook readers on the internet extensively before buying the Kindle.  Without a doubt, I made the right decision.

I love this lap desk so much that when I lost (or rather, left at a coffee shop by accident, and never saw it again) my first one, I immediately ordered a second!

It is thin - no bean-bag padding, no pencil holder ridges or any superfluous stuff, just a neoprene-covered slab. This was just what I needed! It takes up so little space, and it is so effective at what it does - it holds up my laptop or my textbooks when I am working without a desk.

It is easy to clean because it is just a neoprene-covered slab; there are no cushions or pillows or fabric parts, and no strange ridges for pencils or drinks or whatever else. Just wipe it down with some water! That's what I've been doing.

This is great with laptops, but also with textbooks and notebooks! The neoprene actually makes this the ideal surface for notebooks and textbooks, because the grippy nature of it keeps them from sliding around! I do not know what kind of system the people who gave this thing 5-star reviews are using, but this adapter is not worth the money at all.    Since its purchase I have had nothing but trouble. On my Dell Inspiron 8600 laptop running Windows XP SP1, in order to use this adapter I must plug it in *before* powering on the laptop and to remove it I must shut down the laptop. Otherwise, a good 9/10 times the laptop will \\"Blue Screen\\" and crash. Even when shutting down my laptop it crashes.    Reliability also leaves much to be desired as I have experienced, as well as co-workers who also puchased this product, the connection mysteriously disconnecting even though the access point is a reasonable distance away through standard dry wall.    I contacted Hawking Technical Support and they passed blame onto the USB controller Dell used in the laptop and did not seem genuinely interested in fixing the problem as was shown through slow/non-existent response to e-mail inquiries and canned answers. The drivers available for Download on Hawking's site have been marked \\"Final Version\\" for months now.    Because of my experience with this and its sister product (Cardbus version), I will not be buying Hawking products again since they cannot be trusted to actually support and maintain them.

There was one reason that I decided to try this cable - it's the photo of someone with it twisted and wrapped around their fingers. I thought to myself, "wow, that looks like a tough cable." So, as soon as it arrived, I pulled it out of the box and started wrapping it around my fingers and pulling on it. :) Well, "pulling" is a bit light of a word for what I was doing. Guess what? It really is a tough cable. I love it.

I didn't get this for the lightning plug, so I've only used the Micro USB portion. As should come as no surprise, that part works great. It's difficult to mess up a Micro USB cables these days. It's also pretty darn easy to separate the lightning adapter from the Micro USB plug. The one thing that I wished this had, but it's not nearly enough reason to dock it a whole star, is an adjustable bumper stop near that end of the cable to keep that adapter piece from sliding (conceivably) all of the way to the USB plug side. That adapter has nothing to stop it from sliding down the cable as it is. While not as elegant, you could always wrap just a little bit of tape around a spot a little distance from the adapter end to make it thicker in that area and keep the adapter from sliding much.

The flat nature of the cable is pretty cool, IMO, but it does mean that curling it up like in the photos is easier than bending it into loops like you'd normally do with a round cable to reduce the size and pack it somewhere.

I want to reiterate just how tough that flat cable is. It's super well made as far as I can tell. The end connectors are nothing fancy, but they're made well enough. It comes with plastic caps for each end, too. I admit that I never thought about abusing my round wire USB cables before, but even after trying that out on this cable, I'm not willing to do that to most of the ones that I own - they just don't seem nearly as well made. Granted, they were much less expensive and often came included with some other product. Which brings me to this point - yes, this is an expensive cable at the current $15 price. It's more expensive than other cables. However, it's super tough. Mine also, as odd as this is to either experience or mention, smells like berry candy. Me likey. :D

So, if you just want a cable and are gentle on your gear, you may not want to pay the price premium for this. However, if you want something rugged, then I do recommend giving this some consideration. For shear toughness, this is my favorite cable. For shear coolness, I will point out the [[ASIN:B00UB9NG74 DATASTREAM Blue LED Flowing Current Micro USB Cable]] if you don't need the lightning plug. While both have a price premium, I don't think you'll be disappointed in either.they were much less expensive and often came included with some other product. Which brings me to this point - yes, this is an expensive cable at the current $15 price. It's more expensive than other cables. However, it's super tough. Mine also, as odd as this is to either experience or mention, smells like berry candy. Me likey. :D So, if you just want a cable and are gentle on your gear, you may not want to pay the price premium for this. However, if you want something rugged, then I do recommend giving this some consideration. For shear toughness, this is my favorite cable. For shear coolness, I will point out the [[ASIN:B00UB9NG74 DATASTREAM Blue LED Flowing Current Micro USB Cable]] if you don't need the lightning plug. While both have a price premium, I don't think you'll be disappointed in either.

Right from the beginning, I liked the design of this cover. The strap in each corner of other covers didn't appeal to me either! In the comments I read about the odor. That concerned me because I am super-sensitive to smells. I ordered the cover before I have ordered the Touch Kindle and am very glad that I did. The cover is very attractive and well made. I believe the odor comes from whatever was used to put the two fabrics together.

Now to go to how I have eliminated/minimized the odor! In the bottom of a 39-gallon size leaf plastic bag, I placed a garden bench, the kind that can be flipped over to kneel on. It fit in the bag perfectly! On the bottom of the bag underneath the bench, I placed a 1-quart size glass measuring cup filled with white vinegar 5% acidity. On top of the bench I placed the cover, open and resting up to stand, looking like a V. Carefully gather the top of the leaf bag using a long twister to close. Once or twice a day, take the cover out and let stand to get air for about an hour or so. Then place back into the bag. This procedure can take 3 to 4 days until the smell becomes agreeable to you! I just did a sniff test!! Odor hardly noticeable! I am so happy!

I can't believe this is possible and so easy to use, yet everyone isn't doing it. Well I guess not everyone feels there is a need for a video phone just yet.

This one is great because all you need to do is place it atop your television, or empty spot in your entertainment center like us, and it will wirelessly connect to your wireless network in the home and you can call anyone else with a video conferencing unit, or other i2eye owners. My cousin has a unit at their home and we call each other all the time now. :)

The initial setup is fairly easy as long as you follow the directions in the easy setup guide they give you. I was looking for a case for a couple of weeks.  They all seemed so expensive and the reviews weren't that fantastic.  Somehow I happened upon this one and I am extremely happy.  The price was outstanding and the case itself fits perfectly.  After I have used it for a little while, the \\"leather\\" (or whatever material it is) has softened up and feels very nice to hold.  When converted to stand alone, it does it without any problems and is very sturdy.  I am really happy with it!

Beware buying this product from the vendor \\"Citi Electronics.\\"  They shipped me generic no-name brand cables, instead of the unique Cables-To-Go snagless custom boots.  The \\"generics\\" are like typical Ethernet cables with the thick molded boot that fully encapsulates the plastic tab used to unlock the cable from a jack.  I've found trying to press on this thick \\"thumb bump\\" boot to push on the tab difficult to use and sometimes I have to pull the boot back in order to press directly on the tab to properly disengage it.  It seems these generic boots are just too large and may actually be pressed up against the jack housing causing tension on the jack and making disengagement harder (hence my need to peel back the boot or forcibly push the cable further into the jack to unload the tension on the tab).    Which is why I now use the Cables-To-Go snagless versions as it uses a light and small vinyl flap that rests on the plastic locking tab to aid in disengaging yet allows easy unobstructed view and access to this tab to ensure you are properly disengaging it without adding any stress or tension to the connection.

I am amazed by how small all electronics are getting.  I am use to the big bulky devices that have to project out to get good reception.  This little guy works great, I ended up getting a second one for another computer.

At first I had my USB receiver plugged into the back of my desktop (10 feet away, but blocked by sub-woofer and coffee table) and was having issues with a lag with the keyboard, I did not have a problem with mouse reception without direct line of site.

I found a little 2 foot USB extension to point the receiver in my general direction while minimizing obstructions and haven't had any other problems with lag.

Just keep in mind that you will need a 80-90% clear line of site between keyboard and receiver.

If they had allowed me to give this product a MINUS 10 stars, that's what I would have given it.    We researched various tuners and bought this one. It was a disaster. The TV antenna has a very powerful magnet in the bottom. However, there is no mention on the package that a magnet is included or a warning not to get the antenna too close to your computer.     Unfortunately, I had my laptop in my lap as I was unpacking the unit. As I was unwrapping the antenna, the magnet attached itself to the palm rest on my laptop. I had to pull it off. My computer instantly went off and could not be rebooted. The magnet had totally erased all of the data from the hard drive. The hard drive had to be totally replaced. I called Pinnacle to tell them what happened. They said they would get back to me, and never did. I can't believe that they would create a product specifically for use with a computer and put a powerful magnet in it. Then they won't even take responsibility for the havoc it created.

This computer lasted less than 24 hours.     I called Acer's tech support and after several attempts to fix the computer the tech gave up. He told me that if the computer was shaken during transit it could have damaged the hard drive. I asked if they were telling me that they're product could not handle a car ride and was told basically, yes. The tech also put most of the blame on Amazon for they're product's crappyness. But to be on the safe side they're going to mail me a disk to try and re-boot the computer. I will receive this in five to eight business days!     I expressed to customer support how upset I was with their product's quality. Then he asked where I purchased my new $661.00 boat anchor and I informed him Amazon. That is when Acer told me I would have been better off if I had purchased this computer from Wal-Mart.com because I could bring it back to the store and have it replaced ASAP. I was shocked to hear that a company that deals with Amazon would recommend I purchase their product from one of Amazon's competitor's.    I called Amazon and they're shipping me another one of these wonderful machines. I can't wait to see how long the new one works for until, it too is taken out by a car ride or a gentle breeze.    So either way I spent over 600.00 and now have to wait five days plus until I can have access to a computer again. I'm not sure I even want this replaced, and according to the manufacturer, I should shop else where to begin with! What a wise purchase this was!    Update:  So it took four weeks for the new on to start acting up. It shuts it self off, even when plugged in. I called Acer, they told me they had no idea what was wrong with it. Ican't say enough about the terrible customer service that Acer has, they really would not be bothered. Amazon has agreed to refund my purchase and that what I plan on doing. So after five weeks and two computers I stand by my statement, this computer is PURE JUNK!

I purchased a Vaio (specific model number no longer sold) a few months ago. My review is both about Vaio product quality in general, and the Sony customer service/repair process. I am posting it on Vaio products to alert other consumers what customer service level they can expect when they buy a Vaio.

The screen on my unit had the backlight fail after a few months of use. I have had Sony repair it three times. Each time they returned it, it still had the same problem. After the third time, I gave up on Sony and purchased a comparable ASUS notebook, which has worked perfectly.

The reason why I have given 1/5 stars is because Sony was inefficient, rude, and downright dishonest about their \\"repair\\" process. Only once out of three times did they get the shipping box, repair process, or return process done in the turnaround time they promised. At no point did they actually repair the laptop!

After receiving the still defective laptop back for the third time, I called their service center in Laredo Texas and asked what they had done to repair it. They told me that the internal cable for the screen had never been properly connected, and they plugged it in. I asked if that meant it was repaired, and was told by the representative that they were unable to commit that the laptop had been repaired or would be functional. Out of the 2 months I spent dealing with Sony, this was one of the few honest statements they made: My laptop is still as useless as the day I first called their tech support.

I will never purchase another Sony product as a result of this experience, and to anyone that buys a Vaio: Hope that it works perfectly. Otherwise, Sony will take it from you for 12-20 days (not the 10 they promise) and then return it to you still broken -- 3 times in a row.
