Having gone through 4 different types of case protection for my iPad 2, I think I finally found my favorite solution when I look to protect \\"the new iPad\\", otherwise known as the iPad 3. I wrote this review for the Black and Clear variants of the case, but I just got the blue one for another iPad and thought I should share my similar thoughts on it as well.

The question becomes how much protection does your iPad need, and what do you want to do it? I had a folio-type case before, but it's a little bulky and if you enjoy gaming, it makes it hard to do things like accelerometer based games. I also tried a sticker-skin-type protector to protect the back from scratches, but it doesn't do much for the edges or corners.

Finally I settled on a [[ASIN:B005GOINEK Just Air Case for Ipad - Black (8271)]] and a naked iPad 2 except for a sticker on the back.

When I bought my iPad 3, I wanted better protection, and the Amzer Silicone Jelly Skin provides it.

It is the pinnacle of simplicity. It's a nice thick silicone rubber skin that stretches around the entire iPad. There are a few other similar products, but this one seems to be the best. Installation is easy - stretch it like a rubber band and it holds tight to the device. This case is a deep blue color, not translucent but a solid blue, and the color looks very sharp with the iPad under it. My other iPad uses a black Amzer Jelly Skin for a more professional look. The Blue is fun, but not so bright that you couldn't use it for work as well.

Unlike other skins, it wraps around the edges and also covers the screen frame in the front. The screen is not blocked, but the extra lip provides protection from falls directly on the screen. As the case provides no other screen protection (and I don't like protective screen-stickers), this is a useful feature.

The case features rubber buttons over the volume and power switch, along with cut-outs for home, mute, cameras, microphone, speaker, power port, and headphone jack. I have a charging cradle for my iPad that holds it in portrait mode - the Amzer Jelly Skin is a little too thick for the iPad to properly dock, but I'm not too surprised. I'll just using the charging cable instead, but just remember it won't likely fit in a cradle with this Jelly Skin in place. The only weak spot in the case is the hole for the \\"home\\" key - it's a little thin and doesn't lie perfectly flat.

The other great part about the case is that while it is thick enough to provide protection, it is thin enough to still put it inside my [[ASIN:B005GOINEK Just Air Case for Ipad - Black (8271)]] for travel. The neoprene sleeve protects the screen while inside my briefcase, and the Amzer silicone skin provides enough protection while I hold just the iPad. Recommended, and it is available in just about any color you'd like.ameras, microphone, speaker, power port, and headphone jack. Recommended, and it is available in just about any color you'd like.

The 2014 edition of the Razer Naga is indeed a comfortable mouse, and I enjoyed its ergonomics, but the mouse requires that Synapse 2.0 be installed on the computer, which breaks it. Here's my story.

I originally had a Blackwidow Ultimate keyboard with an Imperator as my mouse, but because I play a good deal of MMOs, I wanted to get the Naga for all of its buttony goodness. The mouse itself is well built, feels sturdy, has a lovely grip for the ring finger, and a rubber pad for the pinky if you like a claw-style grip, but the software is unusable.

1. Synapse updates all the time. Every other day it seemed to have an update, and would incessantly nag you until you applied it. Many of these updates required restarts.

2. At random intervals, the mouse would stop tracking movement. This would occur on a fastidiously clean, just booted up PC with no other nonsense in the background other than system and peripheral drivers. Unplugging the device and replugging in would do nothing. Updating firmware did nothing. The worst part was that it was random; there was no way to predict when this would occur.

3. The Synapse software broke my keyboard. Keys would fail to press, ghost keys would be repeated, and once again, it was random.

Removing the Software fixed all of these bugs. I will be going back to my original setup of the legacy drivers on the Blackwidow Ultimate and Imperator. The extra buttons are not worth all of this hassle. As long as Razer insists on using this Synapse 2.0 nonsense, I will not be supporting them by purchasing their products.

I'll start by saying that my gripe is much more with the CinemaGo package than with the BV-5005HD unit itself. The only thing extra you get with the CinemaGo is the wireless dongel. It is essentially completely useless. The dongle is garbage. The fact that they packaged such a piece of junk with a media player whose primary purpose for existing is to play HD video is pretty much criminal. This is probably one of the worst wireless dongles on the planet. Forget HD video. You won't even be able to watch standard non-HD files without some lag.     The file copy feature through the dongle is also worthless. It's buggy and slow beyond comprehension. And you can't use any other functions of the unit while it's copying. So if you want to attach a hard drive and just copy a file wirelessly to compensate for the inability to play files over the network, enjoy waiting hours for for the file copy process to complete... as opposed to just taking the hard drive in the other room and copying it via usb in a few seconds.    The \\"extra\\" internet features such as torrents... worthless. It's so slow and limited you won't even take it seriously. The internet radio is nothing special. Tons of the stations don't play and you can just get them on the net for free anyway.    And to top it all off, in order to get this thing to connect to your Windows 7 machine, you have to go into the registry and manually change security settings to allow for anonymous password free guest access to your machine. The best possible security settings. Great job!    As for the unit itself... it's pretty good for playing most files. It's very buggy though. Also, you'd think they frequently update software to allow for various codec changes, etc. Not the case. This thing can't even play files with the flv extension. Oh, it can play flv files. If you rename them to mp4 or whatever, they'll play just fine. It's simply the flv EXTENSION that it has a problem with. And the support team can't fix that. Great job! Not to mention it can't play mkv files with header removal compression. Something easily fixed. But they can't seem to get it done at Brite-view. So you'll have to use software to edit the mkv header compression yourself.    Honestly, I thought the biggest benefit to buying this unit would be software updates as needed. Boy was I naive. Anyway, as it is, this unit is way overpriced for buggy performance with non existent wireless functionality... even though the video quality is quite good.    ------------------  2010-11-29 update  ------------------    And now that piece of junk dongle is fried. Stopped working. I know what you're saying.... why do you care? It was a piece of worthless junk to begin with. True! But at the end of the day it did have at least one function. And that was to do software updates. That's the only functionality it had and apparently THAT was too much for it as it died after a month. We'll see how Brite-view customer support handles this issue. I will report back with an update.    ------------------  2010-12-14 update  ------------------    Well, this thing with all it's malfunctioning and defective parts is complimented by a customer support staff that is completely absent and disinterested. I've contacted them multiple times. All they say is that they forward the request to the RMA department and that's it. You never hear from them again. Horrible company. Cheap device. What a mistake buying this thing was. I'm buying the Patriot Box Office and hopefully my credit card company will refund me for this lousy defective purchase.    ------------------  2010-12-27 update  ------------------    This company is horrible. I contacted them to replace the defective dongle. They emailed telling me they would forward it to their RMA department. Didn't here form them again. I contacted them again about it, expressed my displeasure and asked to return the device and get a refund altogether as the whole thing is buggy and malfunctioning. They told me they'll forward the request to the RMA. Never heard from them again. This company is a joke. Do yourself a favor and do not buy anything from this company.      ------------------  2011-01-21  ------------------    They promised to replace the dongle. Never happened. They even commented here that the dongle has been sent out. Never got it. Never heard back from customer support or the RMA department. Very buyer beware with this bush league small time company.

I am very disappointed in Cisco and this router. The router is advertised as supporting USB external hard drives. However, after you buy it, you find out that only 11 !!! drives are tested as being compatible (Article ID 25333). By the way, it's not easy to find the list. I had to use Gooogle to find it. The Cisco support site search was totally useless.

Why Cisco only supports 11 drives is beyond me. Everybody else seems to support whatever you plug in to a USB port. Pretty sloppy engineering - \\"Doesn't work - declare it incompatible and move on.\\"

The router is very sneaky. If you plug in a Cisco untested USB drive, it may connect and look like everything is fine. Then BOOM, it crashes and the router goes into a re-boot loop, taking down your whole network. Then when you disconnect the drive you find out that the file structure has been corrupted and you need to run CHKDSK or in one case, the Linux disk repair utility.

When you try to use the Cisco support web site, be sure to turn off your pop-up blocker; just about everything you do requires a pop-up. And be careful of the Live Chat, one false move and it disconnects and clears itself in mid-chat.

Maybe Cisco should have spent more time on making the router work instead figuring out how to make it supportable from the Internet (which they had to back off from later after people found out that all of their traffic was being monitored by Cisco.)

Usually I check user reviews before I buy something like this, however, I was in the middle of exchanging a Netgear router with a dead wireless radio and didn't have time. I thought Cisco should be a good bet. Boy, was I wrong. I'd give this router zero stars if I could.

I got this, followed the instructions and used it for three months when it failed completely and instantaneously and sucked my lifetime of photos into a black hole. I got quotes for data recovery from $300 up, and up, and up..........
Customer service is very unhelpful. They pretend they can't imagine such a thing as a hard drive not accepting a connection and just disappearing like that. Level two (they asked me to call back the next day) tried harder, but same result. I spent a total of 9 hours on the phone over three days with them (mostly phone tree and holding) had my calls dropped THREE times and had to start over, just very, very frustrating.
So..............they tell me to send it back (data and all, which will be forever lost), and they will send me a 're-certified' unit, which is all the warranty will allow according to them. I didn't buy re-certified unit, but now I am supposed to thank them for that because 'it has been gone through' and the techs make sure everything is right.
No they don't. What I got was a repackaged USED unit with scratches and dust in the vents. It had a power supply that was for some other unit, some other country and not only wouldn't plug into the unit itself, it also wouldn't plug into a U.S. power outlet.
You can't trust this product, and I think people should know that. You also can't trust the company's very slack customer service. But my biggest beef is this: after they put a customer through all of that hell, they still INSIST that they only will give you a used unit to satisfy their phony-baloney warranty. Yes, I read the fine print. If they had allowed an ordinary consumer to know that they would forever get used units as replacement, I doubt people would buy the new unit in the first place. So they hide it.
I didn't buy a used unit. I expect a new one in exchange when the first one fails so soon and so miserably.
I'm on my third one, and I honestly don't think it's going to be any better. I'll never trust it, that's for sure. And I don't plan on going back to that rat-nasty customer service again either. it's just way too frustrating.

The laptop is quite expensive for casual PC users, but it is worth it for long-term use and anyone who needs a little extra power.  It is not an alienware, but for the price, what were you expecting?  The Toshiba M-645 S4118x provides one of the best portable all-around laptops. It easily runs any professional software that one might wish to use.  I have used Revit Architecture 2012, and it works fairly well, though I might need to add another 2 gb of ram (comes with 6 gb standard with 8 gb capacity).    It includes all sorts of aspects for anyone needing performance: a Blu-ray player, GeForce GT525M, Wireless-N card, Bluetooth,a USB 3.0 port, and Harmon Kardon Speakers.  The Blu-ray drive is decent, but when mirroring to a display unit such as your television, I think Blu-ray content can only be supported on one display (so the movie will not show on your laptop LCD and external display simultaneously).  There may be a way around this limitation, but I really do not need that feature.  Also, I believe the video card can output external content on a 3D display with Nvidia 3D Vision or other software.  I am not sure about the limitations on 3D display models as I have not used this feature yet.  The wireless networking card works well.  I have not used the USB 3.0 port, but I hear it is super fast.  I have to admit the Harmon Kardon speakers are amazing.  They are not super loud, but the quality for laptop speakers is excellent.    The laptop comes with some bloatware, but some people may find it useful.  The only downside to all this power is the meager battery, which has usually lasted me about 3 hours on normal performance operations.  There is an optional battery, but it would have been better to include it in the first place.  Another downside is the the lack of gigabit ethernet.  I really don't need the feature, but it is useful for home network set-ups for high transfer speeds.  There are not enough negatives to lower the rating, though.    I conclusion, I recommend this machine as a casual gamer and college student, because it has great performance for the price.  No problems so far, and I hope the laptop will last for awhile.
did not order this, don't know anything about it.

The complaints with this product mostly center around its inability to lay flat after being shipped tightly rolled up.  I had this problem at first too (I had the beige concealer).  I was a bit fed up but thought perhaps a little bit of heat might help loosen it up.  I had cut it into two 3 foot sections to use at different doors, so I got on my hands and knees at the first door and used a hair dryer to gently warm up the rubber.  It seemed to work but was taking forever, so I grabbed both sections of the cover and tossed them in my bath tub.  I let them soak in very hot water for a few minutes, and pulled the first one out, which felt pretty limp like a noodle.  I drained the water off (gave it a few swings to clear the water from the channel) and laid it on the floor to cool off and dry with some heavy items pinning down both ends, same with the second.    The heat \\"reset\\" the rubber a bit, and letting it cool while sitting flat locked it in nicely.    Since then, both of the covers have worked flawlessly.    Using wide strips of 3M double sided foam tape has helped keep them very flat and very much locked into place.

It snaps shut neatly and easily. It protects reasonably well--no case alone will be perfect. It stands up very well in a variety of positions, upright for typing, angled for movies. The cover folds all the way back to use the tablet one-handed. The color is just as shown in the photo, which is what I was hoping for. There are four oversized business card slots. For depth they are about right for a business card so that only a tiny bit peeks our. For width, because they run the entire length of the case split in half, they are very large. I found this helpful because my work ID is a bit larger than a business card, and I wanted to tuck it in there.

There are a few small items I dislike, but they are minor.

The cover does shift a tiny bit, which can cause some bits of the bottom or top to be exposed, but not enough to endanger the screen. I have the habit of putting the device in case and the case in a sleeve, for extra protection. I have rather destructive cats, so I get a bit paranoid about these things.

The little snap strap can swing in front of the device blocking the screen, and it can get a bit annoying sometimes. I've gotten it to stay out of my way most of the time. You kind of have to trap it between the device and the cover.

I'd give this zero stars if I could. Installing with the setup disk is impossible in many if not most settings. The first step requires a modem connection to the Internet. How many people with broadband have a dial-up account these days? Even if you have one 1) you can't connect a modem through a digital phone system like my law firm uses and 2) the computers we buy these days don't even have modems built into them. They are gone the way of 3.5 inch floppy disks.

I got it set up but it took me about anhour and a half of wasted time. If you skip the standard setup procedure and go directly to WiFI setup (hard to see in the startup window due to very low color contrast) you can configure your SSID and security settings. There remains the problem configuring the network settings. Only because I have set up several other routers did it occur to me to direct a browser to 192.168.1.1. That worked but I did not know how to log on. I checked the product manual that is on the CD ROM. I found the information buried in there. That got me to a place where I could enter the appropriate IP address, subnet, gateway and DNS. Then the unit worked. What a pain.

I cannot comment on the broadcast range since we always have this router and our laptops in the same room. It works fine at short distance. Connection by ethernet cable is as it should be. However, Linksys should be ashamed of bringing such a poorly designed product to market. One of the reasons I bought it was Linksys' good reputation and the trouble-free use of other Linksys products in my home and office. Their reputation has now plummeted. I will think twice before buying anything else from them.

I currently have an ASUS AC68U AC wireless router. I was increasing security in my house by getting a dedicated firewall router since the ASUS didn't shine in that area. I thought Ubiquiti would be rock start quality. I was wrong. I stood both devices side by side. I setup different SSID's on different channels. I tested both 2.4 and 5Ghz bandwidth on both N and AC devices. I started using a program called LAN Speed Test to gauge throughput on both AP's. I was shocked how my ASUS got better SNR than the Ubiquiti received. Below are my average tests. I was shocked how the ASUS beat the Ubiquiti every single time. I was hoping it was different because I love the look of the Ubiquiti.

Also before anyone thinks this guy doesn't know what he's doing, I work for a wireless internet provider. I know wireless pretty good. I also tried different channels, signal power levels and also I tried the different bandwidth settings 20/40/80. They did make some different (obviously) but not enough to pull the Ubiquiti ahead. The unit also runs hot which is shocking for an AP. Also just to ensure that my AP's didn't have to fight for bandwidth I powered off one unit as I tested the other to make sure I didn't get interference.

ASUS: 20Mb File Test
Write: 18 Mbps
Read: 275 Mbps

Ubiquiti UniFi AC: 20Mb File Test
Write: 11 Mbps
Read: 130 Mbps

I also had an older 2.4Ghz Ubiquiti LR (Long Range) access point I ended up selling because the performance wasn't there either, I thought the AC would be better. I guess I'll end up putting my ASUS into AP Mode and just using what I have.

I am an avid book reader; my shelves here are bowing under the weight of all my books. Wasn't sure if I even wanted to try this new tech item.
PROS: I now find that though I still try to "turn the page" from time to time; being able to just gently tap my thumb anywhere in the center of the kindle takes me to the next page? Pretty cool. Still learning to work on some things, like trying to go back a few pages, though you are to tap the left side at the bottom, doesnt always work, but you can tap on the very top and it will give you the option of going to the last page read. I will still occasionally have books I want to purchase; especially the hardbacks; I collect certain types of reading, but this even gives you options for other books that we might be interested in. If you aren't a Prime member; you really should be, since many books are free or greatly reduced in cost if you are a Prime member. (and I love that if I decide I want to purchase a certain book; most can be purchased and will be wired to you within minutes! The Con: does the company who makes these products need proof readers? I ran a magazine, was the head writer and a journalism major with many articles published, and also was editor of a fairly large newsletter for many years and can pick up on miss-spelled word like a magnet and am finding many in these kindle books. For those of us who are avid readers, glitches like that kind of stop us instantly; not supposed to have reading material with words spelled wrong, or even "hey; use the lower case, thats not supposed to be a hash line, its supposed to be a period!" So if that kind of thing bothers you, you may want to just build another book shelf. It *is* nice to be able to grab up my Kindle and quietly read; no pages to turn, it has its own "nightlight", you pick out what size font you'd prefer, can highlight sentences, words, whatever. I am a cancer fighter and sometimes need to just lay down, relax and bury myself into a good book, so this does the trick. Plus, if I am rushed to the hospital; I don't have to settle for whatever book my husband grabs; I just grab the Kindle and the power cord. Just do let me know if you need proofreaders; as long as I can control what types of books I'd need to immerse myself into; I can easily help with the misspellings and wrong keystokes easily; bet there's a few more who'd love to help; most of my friends are avid readers as well.

The top reviewer had this to say:
\\"
Size:
- They are both the same size with one slight exception, the Naga you place your ring finger next to the mouse and use it as part of your 'grip'.
- The place your finger is on is extended on the G600 to be an actual button your finger rests on.
- THIS is the major 'comfort' difference between the two mice and where I see a lot of complaints.
\\"

The shape of the side keys are big issue too, but this is the main reason not to buy this mouse. It's heavier than the naga, and that ring finger button dramatically changes how you hold the mouse. If you like the feel of the naga like me, then you're going to hate this mouse.

The side buttons are useless, I can reach all of them on the naga with a bit of effort, but the ones on this beast require me to stop what I'm doing and feel around. Especially those top corner buttons, they just feel too small.

That's my 2 cents, I didn't like mine so I returned it. Guess I have to by another Naga.

I bought this card in May 2002. My operating system is Windows 2000, and I had no problem installing it. However, after using it for 3 weeks, the card died. There was no sound. At first, I thought it was due to corrupted driver, so I tried to reinstall the driver, but the setup software kept saying \\"No audigy sound card is detected\\". I've tried downloading new drivers, swapping PCI slots, but nothing worked. At the end, I contacted Creative Support via email. Although I told them that I have already tried swapping slots and downloading latest drivers, the sluggish customer service asked me in their reply to \\"try downloading latest drivers and swapping PCI slots\\". These guys never bother to read what you wrote in your email. Anyway, after corresponding with them for over one month (they typically take more than a week to reply each email, using a one-line response), finally one agent told me I had a defective sound card, and authorized an exchange.
Upon receiving the replacement card, everything worked fine. Installation was as easy as the very first time I'd installed it. But yesterday (March 09, 2003), my card died again. Exactly the same problem. The setup program cannot detect the card. It's still under warranty so I will ask for another exchange.
This card has really disappointed me. My previous Creative products all worked very well, but now I must say that the Audigy is really bad in its design. Avoid buying this card by all means.

I received my Kindle today.  And I was immediately impressed with it.  I started downloading the 6 books I had purchased for only $25.99, and started reading the first book in a few minutes. I've been using linksys products since the 1990's, hubs, switches, wireless routers, etc., and have always been extremely satisfied with them. I upgraded my old Linksys BEFW11S4 to the ea4500. Overall I have been happy with the ea4500 (won't go into the issues I'm having with it) but the coverage range was an issue. I purchased the "refurbished" linksys RE2000 V1 and was able to manually set it up with relative ease. It performed as advertised - I had a strong signal in the area that previously had a weak signal. Everything was great for about a week and a half. The devices connected to the RE2000 would lose the connection and not reconnect until I reset the RE2000 by unplugging it. The device was extremely warm, bordering on HOT, to the touch. I reconnected and in about a week the same thing would occur.  I contacted linksys support. They were very responsive and courteous and eventually decided I had a defective unit - I gathered from my conversation with the tech rep and CS rep that this was a common issue. They sent me out a replacement. This time it was an RE2000 V2. Set up was a breeze and everything seemed to work great - for about a month - then I began to experience the same problems. Devices that were connected to it would drop the connection and it was warm/hot to the touch. At this point I'm going to "eat" the loss and not ask for a replacement as it is clear that these devices have not actually been refurbished but plugged in and tested - but not allowed to "heat up" - then labeled as OK and resold. Needless to say I am not inclined to recommend Linksys/Belkin products to family and/or friends.

I bought this drive as a file back-up unit about 2.5 years ago.  It worked fine until last week when I heard a clicking noise when it powered up and it failed to properly initialize.  A quick search of the web proved that this is apparently a common problem for this drive and it signifies a drive failure.  Now, my only option to retrieve my data is an expensive data extraction by Western Digital.      I think they spent too much money on exterior design and not enough on reliability !  I would gladly trade the look of this drive for one that doesn't fail.  A responsible manufacturer would recall a product with a failure rate this high or at least warn their customers that they need to back-up their back-up before it fails.    Not sure what I am buying to replace this but it won't be a Western Digital external drive.  I think I will pick out the ugliest one from now on since it means they are spending their resources on the inside where it counts.

This card is trash. Do not waste your money. The specifications on this GPU are false. Advertised specs are 4gb @ 224 GB/s memory bandwidth. True specs are 3.5gb @ 196 GB/sec then 0.5gb @ 28GB/sec. I tend to overshop for my computer equipment. After studying ZyXEL as a company and this particular unit, AND relying on Amazon's product pictures, I gladly bought this unit. Unfortunately, this is one of my purchases which truly deserves a one-star rating.

One of the Amazon product pictures showed this unit as having 4-pin DSL connection. That feature immediately put this unit high on my list of possible purchases, because I wanted a 4-pin connection to give me the best performance with my high speed service. When the unit arrived it had only a 2-pin connection. I don't believe that Amazon was trying to deceive anyone by using this picture, but I made my purchase largely because of this inaccurate picture.

The product arrived DOA. These things happen with computer equipment, but I needed a modem right away when I bought this one. I chose to go to the local WalMart, where I bought an Actiontec unit which fit my needs but also has a 2-pin connection.

Amazon was great, as always, on my return of this unit. They accepted it back without question and without the original packaging. They provided the postage to ship it back, and promptly credited my credit card when they received it.

I don't like to give one-star ratings, as most products have some value. However, because of the incorrect and misleading (aka deceptive) picture, I effectively bought something I didn't want which also turned out to not work at all.

My motherboard only had USB 2.0 ports, so I bought a USB 3.0 add-in card.  I did not realize the front headers on my case required a 20-pin connector, so this adapter cable was a quick and easy solution!  Put the 2 USB plugs into the add-in board ports, route the cable back inside my case, then plug 20-pin into my case front header connector.  For the person who said the 20-pin connection can come undone, my plug seemed pretty snug.  Just in case, I used some black electrical tape to make sure the plugs stayed together.  Every device I have plugged into the front headers has been detected correctly and transfer speeds are super fast.

This is only a problem with one of the two computers, suggesting that it depends on the video card (one card is an old, but fairly high-end nVidia, the other \\"built in\\" to the mobo).

Anyway, in my case, it's unusable at the higher resolution. Unfortunately Belkin seem to be the main competitor, and my experience with them (an old 4 port switch) has been poor too.

[added later - the nVidia card later failed, so it's possible that there was a problem with the card]

Absolutely LOVE my new Kindle Fire! I had never used one before and bought one for my myself with Christmas money during a Cyber Monday deal on Amazon. Great looking, lightweight, easy to use. I have already read 16 novels in my first 12 weeks of having it so it has definitely helped me step up my reading.

Note that most libraries have "Overdrive" accounts where you can download e-books for free. There's also sites like Project Guttenberg with tons of older books for free as well. I had tried the "Kindle Unlimited" on here for a month but found is ironically quite LIMITED on the selection of books. My library has all the current books I want to read not just obscure titles like "Kindle Unlimited".

I also love the pink and keep mine in a pink leather case I found at Staples. Note that there's several generations of Kindles and not all sellers of cases on here are clear which Kindles theirs fit. I returned one that didn't fit mine and was REALLY cheap looking and the M-Edge one I found at Staples is a nice hot pink leather with black suede inside and fits perfectly, feels great in my hands. In my opinion far better to buy the case in person or at least see the case you want in person THEN buy it on here if Amazon sells it for a better price.

This router's range is extremely disappointing.  I have had it for close to 2 years now.  It is in the kitchen on the first level of my house and is connected to a hard wired cable outlet. It was placed there to be the primary router for most of the house, versus the G router from the cable company that is in the basement. Unfortunately, no device can locate the signal from this router outside the kitchen.  That includes an iPad, multiple iPhones and various apple and windows laptops. Each device will grab the signal of the G router before it grabs the signal from the Media Bridge.  And some of those devices are set to prioritize this router. The G router, despite its disadvantageous location, trumps this thing in spades.

Amazon sent me this for free because there was an issue charging my Kindle Fire HD 2 with an ordinary charger. While the issue went away on its own (and was never explained), I am glad to have the charger because it can charge the Kindle in 2-4 hours instead of 3-6 hours with a normal USB charger.

I tested it with my cell phone and it charges it at the same speed as a high quality USB charger. Faster than the charger that came with the phone but no faster than any other charger: apparently the kindle somehow knows to draw more power but the phone firmware doesn't. I bought five of these HDD's to match a Synology DS1511. After one month of use, I have no complains.  I'm using previous Seagate 2TB LP (ST32000542AS) for over a year now. And, I was never very pleased by the older model: it make some strange noises that scared in the beginning. All four ST32000542AS units that I have do the same strange \\"click\\" noise. Googling I discovered that this annoying noise is normal for the first LP generation. This is a problem when you have 5 of then working together in a NAS.    So, the first improve I noticed in STL2000DL003 is the quiet operation.  Then I made some benchmarks using  HD Tach:  - Compared with ST32000542AS (firmware updated to CC35) the unit is faster in average read (113MB/s against 97.1MB/s) and uses less CPU (2% against 3%), but has worst Random access (17.4ms against 14.2ms).  - Compared with WD20EARS:  the unit is faster in average read (113MB/s against 100.6MB/s) and same CPU use (2%), but has worst in Random access (17.4ms against 16.2ms).    Anyway, it's a nice HDD for the price.     Other Thoughts:  Some people do prefer WD hard drives, but in my experience there is no advantage in this particular brand. In the past I need to use worldwide RMA (from Brazil, to be specific) from WD and from Seagate. More than one time for both companies. Seagate was always fast and painless: no more than one week between send the defective unit and receive a new one (again: outside USA!).But with WD was a nightmare every time! More than one month to receive back the same unit, but refurbished. Guess what? The defective unit that they refurbished  and sent me back has become defective again... Another \\"over a month\\" waiting for a solution. This happened more than one time, first with external HDD then with internal HDD (green caviar)! Since these events, I never bought a WD again and I don't recommend to anyone.  So, in my opinion and my experience, the Seagate costumer service is another highlight for this HDD.

This is a great bag. Sure, the color is a bit garish but really not that bad. The laptop compartment is a little snug for my Dell Vostro v13 (a really sweet machine by the way, small, light, good looking, adequate horsepower and less than $500 new) which is a pretty small without being ridiculous 'netbook' small, but I'd rather have it a little large than a super-snug fit. There's also neat little velcro 'tabs' that you can place anywhere to get a nice snug fit.    Overall I'm very happy. And you will be too!

System setup: Asus G53 sx-1, core I7's 16GB ram, 2GB Video card, etc, etc. I just installed this SSD to make my computer faster for start up and for longer battery life when unplugged.

What I did: Before the SSD I had a 5400 RPM 750 GB as my c: drive and a second as my d: drive. I used cloning software to clone the c: to the SSD after I put it in the physical location of the d: drive. After cloning I installed the SSD as the c: drive and put the original d: back in as it has most of my music and pics.

Review: Before the SSD was installed start up time was right at 2 minutes 45 seconds, now with the SSD installed it is at 33 seconds (yes, I averaged 5 start ups to get a more realistic time). My windows assessment went from a 5.9 (lowest being the hard-drive) to a 7.1 (lowest coming from graphics GTX560M), the SSD has a score of 7.7. I have only had it installed for a couple days so I really can't discuss how reliable it is so I will simply put that it is fast, quiet and saves the battery (about 30 min extra).

Conclusion: Well worth the money.

This cover is perfect.  The leather exterior has a rich feel to it and I love the steel blue color.   I also like the soft  interior.  It makes holding the Kindle very pleasant and also protects the all important screen when you are carting your KIndle around.   I think the way the light fits into the back of the cover is awesome.  I take my kindle with me everywhere and just pull it out to turn a frustrating wait into a pleasant reading break.  The case is the  perfect package, attractive, well-designed and makes your Kindle ready to read in the light or dark.  I purchased mine from the Amazon Outlet store and got a great price on it.  The only downside was that there were no instructions but it was easy to figure everything out with one small exception which caused me some concern.     It was pretty stupid of me but I almost returned mine shortly after it arrived because I thought it wasn't working properly.  I would pull the light out of its recessed position in the back cover and sometimes it would come on and sometimes it wouldn't.  This made me sad because I was so pleased with the cover that I really didn't want to return it.  I was sharing my problem with my spouse and we realized there was a click when i pulled the light out.  We quickly figured out that you have to pull the light out until you hear that click or the light doesn't come on.  I haven't seen anyone else with this problem and I don't know if it was covered in the instructions but thought I would share just in case anyone else had the same problem.  Once I figured it out, i felt pretty stupid for not figuring it out immediately.    All in all this is an awesome product and I highly recommend it for every Kindle owner.  It keeps your Kindle safe and provides a comfortable and, when necessary, well-lit reading experience.

I originally bought this USB hub in September 2013. I have had a few USB hubs burn up in the past, it will eventually happen.... that is why I prefer to use external hubs instead of plugging up every port possible on my PC.

As luck would have it, this USB hub just died yesterday - a little over 5 months from the day I received the product. I went to Anker's website to find their service center phone number, called them up... and guess what? In just a few short minutes I was guaranteed they were shipping me the new upgraded version (as the model # I purchased was discontinued) and also an RMA to send this defective one back.

Hello? How can anybody complain? Most electronics are usually only warrantied 30 to 90 days without an extended warranty (which is not offered many times) but here it is over 150 days and they going to replace it with no extra charges.

THANK YOU ANKER! I am very happy to have made a purchase decision with a company that stands behind their products!

I bought a new iMac, then the first thing i did was so put these rams in, and then after one afternoon, the iMac won't start, so i had to take my new iMac to the apple store to see what the problem is, the apple store told me it was a hard drive issue, so they told me it'll be the best if i just return the iMac since it's still in 15days return policy. I'm a professional photographer and recently had an Apple Cinema Monitor die completely during a very busy week.  I ordered this monitor, overnight, from Amazon and have been very pleased.  It's, in my opinion, a much better monitor for digital photography.  It displays 100% of the AdobeRGB gamut, which is better than the Apple, and offers much easier calibrating (I use an X-rite i1 that works beautifully with this screen).  I calibrate it weekly and have noticed only minimal shift the first week or two as it adjusted to being used 8 hours a day.    Positives for this monitor: it's big and sturdy, bright, even, crisp, and has awesome color range.  The USB hubs work very well, allowing me to plug in a mouse, keyboard, and printer with no problems.  I've taken it on location, and it's held up well in transit.  It looks professional.    Negatives: It seems to take a few minutes to warm up to accurate color.  When I first start it up in the morning, it looks a little green for a few minutes.  Also, it doesn't have the old Apple's on/off control for the computer tower, nor does it respond to the brightness keys on the Apple keyboard.  It does, however, sleep when the computer says to and wake up again with the computer... not bad.  Also, I strongly recommend Not using this screen for serious graphic work without calibrating it.  The difference the first calibration made was very striking....    I strongly considered much more pricy monitors from LaCie, Eizo, etc...  But decided to give this one a shot.  I was prepared to return it if it didn't live up to my very high expectations.  I will be keeping it and am very pleased.    Highly recommended!

It didn't rest easily using any of the cradles, but it did recharge and play audio well.    HOWEVER, the other shoe would soon drop. This device's speakers generate excruciating feedback when an iPhone is connected to it. Despite being a clock-freekin'-radio, and despite being an iPhone docking station, the speakers are apparently not shielded against signal interference. Worse yet, because the two small satellite speakers are tethered by a cord only inches long, they can't be distanced from the dock. God help you if the bass is cranked up on the subwoofer. It's brutal. I see anotehr reviewer here experienced something similar.     Very shoddy. I received my Synology two days ago - on first impressions, the 412+ is an excellent NAS solution. Those complaining about the plastic drive sleds and or the case - don't get it. Given the price/performance of the Synology and the applications that ship with the unit are top notch. The combination of fast CPU,RAM and Synology's DSM software clearly turn the Synolgy into a full fledged enterprise like NAS solution.

I should note I am upgrading from a couple of Drobos. I didn't realize how bad Drobo's performed until I booted the Synology. Drobo's are extremely slooow and the SW/firmware wt DROBO is just garbage compared to Synology. After two days I've migrated 4TB of data which is extremely fast. A Drobo would take almost a week to transfer a similar amount of data. Additionally the Synology is almost silent compared to slow and noisey Drobo product.

I would highly recommend spending the extra money and look to the Plus series due to the increased performance gains from the additional RAM and CPU. The small uplift in exchange for a life of superior performance is worth it.

I installed and configed the 412Plus using the stock firmware. I wanted to see how the unit performed out of the box without an update. I experienced ZERO problems. After I gen'ed the disks, I upgraded the firmware.
More updates after I complete my 10TB migration.

6/20 update

After migrating 8TB of data, I decided to move the unit to it's permanent location, powered down the unit and discovered what many have called the Blue Light of Death - a blinking light. I wasn't sure if this was an error or the unit was simply booting the disks. After a min or so of BLOD - I depressed the power button again, this time depressing the power switch for a few seconds - the units beeped - and quickly re-booted. I am wondering if this is the flashing blue led people are complaining about. In closing, I am so impressed with the Synology DS412+ I purchased another unit from Amazon. Synology is great Drobo is garbage.urchased another unit from Amazon. Synology is great Drobo is garbage.

I purchased two kindles for my kids for Christmas 2012. When we opened them one of them would not work, the keyboard software had a glitch and would just type whatever letters it wants. So after an hour on the phone trying to troubleshoot they did send me a replacement promptly, the best part of Amazon is their amazing customer service and return policies! So here it is 7 months later and somehow my kids, ages 6,5,5,3, changed the password in the Freetime I pay every month for, which is the reason I got it so they can't buy and change things without passwords that only I know, and have their own personal accounts. Therefore I cannot log out of Freetime to change their accounts. And somehow I also lost my access to wifi, which I cannot try to reconnect as I cannot get out of Freetime to get into settings! I just had to deregister my Kindle and will now have to reset it, losing all my info! The other Kindle I have the screen freezes constantly and goes on and off a lot. We have not used it in months. Also the charge time through a computer usb port is HORRIBLE! I estimate it takes at least 4 hours, to maybe as much as 6 hours to charge it. Sure you can buy their 19.99 fast charger, but after paying $200 a piece I would expect that a wall plug would come with it. I got myself a Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 for Christmas, along with the 2 HD's. It was $20.00 cheaper than the HD, came with a charger that plugs into a wall outlet, and it performs much better! Not once have I had to contact Samsung about my tablet, but this is now the third time I have had to call about the HD in 7 months. If I could return these and get them a Samsung instead I would! These really perform poorly! I researched for a month on which tablet to buy, and went with the HD because it seemed the most kid friendly, the best educational tool, and the best deal over a mini ipad. I now regret the money I have wasted!

Medialink proves that a product can look slick, have quality construction, work as promised and sell at an honest price.  And unlike many companies, Medialink wants to hear from you if you need help.  I didn't need help but it's the thought that counts.      The Wireless N is very easy to set up, you don't have to log into a confusing multi-screen set up page and feel exasperated because you're out of your league.  Set up goes like this.  Power up the Medialink and wait for it to cycle.  When 2 of the blue lights are blinking on and off it is ready.  Put the installation CD in the computer and it takes it from there.  In a couple of minutes it is connected. Just follow the steps on the set-up instruction sheet and you can't fail.      As for how well it works I have to say it works great. It makes a terrific difference. I'd tried a Buffalo router some years back but with or without it my dsl connection got very slow and dropped too often to be acceptable.  I gave up on the router and just had the dsl modem plugged directly into the computer.  I still had connection drops throughout the day, every day, and was not a satisfied customer at all.      When I set up the Medialink, I wanted it and my ugly dsl modem and phone lines and wires, plugs and cords out of my sight and off my desk.  I put it all in another room and the wireless signal strength is full on solid. It is fast. I have no connection drops at all.  This wireless router has allowed me to get connected, enjoy a fast connection, and stay that way. Plus it let me get all that connectivity technology off my desk.  Three cheers for Medialink.  It is quality all around.    All those arrogant, profit hungry, rip-u-off famous name corporations don't deserve our business.  Companies like Medialink deserve our business. It's a win-win situation like it's supposed to be. Thank you Medialink for doing it right.

This charger is for a Dell laptop that I only used as a backup laptop to my main computer.  I have had the charger since 5/2014 but have only used it for about 6 months of that time.  Recently I plugged it in to recharge the laptop with 40% left and the charger itself was completely dead.  Its plug has a blue light on the end so you can see if it is on and nothing.  Curious, I cracked it open to see what the failure mode was.  Its case is not meant to be opened and had to be forcefully pried apart.  Once apart I found it totally encased in potting cement to keep its components unmovable.  This unfortunately made it impossible to troubleshoot because you could not get to the components to test or repair.  From the reviews, it looks like about 2/3 of these charges work OK and 1/3 go out in short order.  This charger label says it is an Original Dell that I ordered  from TexasDiscountElectronics but not sure if a knock off or not.  This seems to be a problem with many of the replacement chargers but there is little recourse but get another one to try.  I don't know why they can not make a reliable charger like true original ones that come with laptop new and last for years.

This is my second purchase of the FreeAgent GoFlex drives. I had a 3TB and a 2TB. The 2TB model contained a ST2000DM01 hard drive, but the version I had contained the 3 x 0.67 TB platters, instead of the better version which has 2 x 1 TB platters. Both drives died in 2 years. First the drive becomes noisy. Next, it isn't detected.

In Windows it shows up as raw/unformatted in the disk manager. In Linux, it shows that it can no longer read the partition table. In both cases, it is the drive, not the USB 3.0 GoFlex Desk Adapter. The drives were removed from the GoFlex case and connected to a SATA/USB adapter, but the same errors occurred.

See more information about the drives they put in here in the review of that product by niels: http://www.amazon.com/review/R205L2P2CHJ02D/ref=cm_cr_dp_cmt?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B005T3GRN2&nodeID=172282&store=electronics#wasThisHelpful

I bought this reader approximately 5 months ago. I was extremely happy with it (transferring pics from my CF and files from a SD Card was a blaze), but about 5 weeks it started to failed. I thought my camera software was failing because I couldn't transfer any pic from my card to the computer. I upgraded it but still didn't managed to make it work.

To make long story short, I went on vacation with my girlfriend, had a lot of nice pics and when I tried to transfer them... they were all gone. A complete pic folder was erased by the reader.

Today I transferred my pics directly from my camera via the provided USB without problems, confirming the reader was the one giving trouble (maybe I should've tried this before =S).

If you want to take the risk of losing all those Kodak moments, take the less than $9 road. Surely, I won't be so confident next time.

I bought this card, originally for my Galaxy Note II, with the intentions of using it as my primary downloader, but I could not get it to format correctly for the phone, even using third party format software.

I then tried it in my Galaxy Tab2 7.0plus......same problems.

I finally, and ridiculously, put the card in my Nikon D5100 camera. I could take a whopping 8k photos, on high/large settings (not that I would ever need to take that many photos in one session). This was the last option I had, to use the card.

It worked well, taking photos of a holiday, and thankfully, it did not fail before I could get my photos onto a computer. Since then, I have inserted it back in the camera, and reformatted (like you always should), and bam, one photo is good, after that, failure, every single time. So now I have a 64GB card, that is capable of taking and storing ONE PHOTO at a time, before I must run a \\"fix file system\\" on my computer.

Don't waste your money on this card, over priced, not really faster than the other cards I have, and zero longevity. This may be a one off, but I think it is a problem created by the proprietary format exFAT, that makes this card a loser, or more to the point, the poor customer who buys it.

UPDATE JULY 2012
After contacting sandisk, they have offered an RMA, but first they must verify that I have not tried to \\"recover\\" or \\"wipe\\" the data on the card, and I must ship it, at my expense, to Taiwan. I have since emailed them in reply to the requested information (date of purchase, photos of the card, packaging ect), and I told them that the data on their is my data, and if I could have accessed the card, I would have wiped it, why should I give them my information, stored on the card? That makes me less than happy, I am guessing that they want to discourage returns. Who would want to send data to a company, not knowing who will access it, and what they will do with the information contained? I would have wiped the card, but it was unreadable, unable to format, unable to do anything. I will send it to them, hoping that the information is destroyed, along with the bad card.

Sandisk, you are asking a whole lot of your customers, and since this card has gone bad, I have had several other cards from them, go bad as well, seems to be a whole lot of cards being shipped that die in very short time periods. I used to love their products, and their older flash drives are great, still using a micro cruzer that is 6 years old, and going strong. I have not had one single microSD card, from this company, last more than three months, since I moved to the Philippines. Either they send their junk to the Philippines, or they have dropped QC from their business model, to create higher profit margins.

**UPDATE 2**

After emailing Sandisk, and expressing my displeasure with having to return the item, intact, so that they can \\"assess\\" the card, and look at/recover what ever personal information may have been stored on the card, they rescinded. I can only assume that they want to get the card back, to verify that it is bad, or make sure that you are not just trying to get a free card out of them, which I can understand. Instead of requiring me to send the card back to them, they asked that I cut the card, and send a photo of the \\"destroyed\\" card, so they could process a new card, to be sent to me, directly in the Philippines. I hammered them pretty hard in this review, and in the email I sent to them, regarding the bad card, and sometimes, you get results, in this case, I give them 5 stars for doing the right thing. I had no problem cutting the card, since it would not operate in any of my devices anyway, but I did have a problem returning the device, intact, with out knowing what information was stored on the card (banking, amazon account info, passwords, ect.) I would have just kept the card, destroyed it, and never bought another from sandisk. With their faith restoring gesture, I will not remove them from my list of companies to avoid. I just hope that they get better at QC. I returned another defective card to the retailer yesterday, only to find out that you MUST have the original packaging for a replacement. I was lucky to still have one of my packages, but since I bought several of the cards, I am not sure if I gave them the matching package for the card I returned.

I would suggest that if you are like me, and have several devices (2 DSLR's, galaxy Tab2, galaxy Note 2, SII, LG-P920), that you find a way to mark each card/package, and keep the package, in the case that the card should go bad. I have had more than half of my sandisk 32gb cards, fail on me, in less than 6 months. I only buy them, because of the cards available in my area, these are the best, which is scary, with such a high failure rate.disk. With their faith restoring gesture, I will not remove them from my list of companies to avoid. I just hope that they get better at QC. I was lucky to still have one of my packages, but since I bought several of the cards, I am not sure if I gave them the matching package for the card I returned.

I would suggest that if you are like me, and have several devices (2 DSLR's, galaxy Tab2, galaxy Note 2, SII, LG-P920), that you find a way to mark each card/package, and keep the package, in the case that the card should go bad. I only buy them, because of the cards available in my area, these are the best, which is scary, with such a high failure rate.

I've been a big fan of Sony monitors.  So, when my old Sony monitor got old I decided to get this one.  I'm not disappointed.  The picture is sharp, bright and incredibly clear.  It beats my old monitor Sony Trinitron monitor by a mile.  I see details that I missed before.  It has brough new life to my digital photographs.  What I also love is that it's flat.  It takes up almost no room on my desk.  My old monitor dominated my desk.  It as huge, and my desk wasn't.  Now, I have more than enough room.  You might think that being 15 inches means that his monitor is too small, but I just bring it in a little closer.  And, because it's bright and clear, I'm not straining to read even the smallest text.  There is a 17 inch version of this monitor, which might be better for some out there.  But, when it comes to picture quality, I haven't seen a better monitor out there.

I know we don't want to admit that different HDD's are for different things so we buy the cheapest one then complain when it doesn't do what we want. This reason is the largest reason drives get low scores. The other two reasons being DOA's (it happens) and user error.

Green's are meant for data storage. A place to put information -like movies, so it can be accessed from time to time. It's not meant as an OS drive/boot drive. If you try and play games from it speed will suffer. It is an energy efficient, cost efficient, cheap storage device. The Black's and raptors are meant for your OS and gaming (or better an SSD). The Reds for your redundancy systems (raids, NAS, etc).

Order the right HDD! Once you have the right one, resist the urge to copy your entire collection of all 30,000 Simpson episodes over until after you have done a full and thorough scan of the drive.

The HP Slate 500 is one of my favorite tablets, in fact for my needs I prefer it to my work iPad that I have used over the past year. In my opinion the best thing about the Slate is that it is a tablet that works like any computer with a Microsoft operating system. I was even able to get mine tuned-up by remote technical support (which isn't possible on most tablets) because it has Windows 7 Professional as its OS.
I love the fact that is has a 64GB hard drive giving me plenty of space for my Bible Explorer, Christian Library, Microsoft Office, Photos & basically everything I keep on my lap top (which is much of what I keep on my desk top).
I have two wireless printers connected to this little dynamo, which were installed quickly & easily.
The HP Slate 500 has 2GB of Ram & with the Inntel Atom processor I find it at ease running multiple programs on it.
It's also great to browse the internet, check & send emails, create documents & I especially like reading my Kindle books on it.
The Slate 500 is a surprisingly fast little tablet - no, it's not like a laptop with 8GB of RAM and an Intel i7 processor, but it's pretty impressive for a tablet. The 8.9\\" screen is bright, clear and reabable in any lighting condition I have encountered. The battery life (at about 5 hours per charge) is not the greatest, as my net book gives me over 10 hours a charge & my lap top provides me with 8, however it has not been a problem for me, as I've yet to need to be unplugged for that amount of time.
The (included) digital pen cursor (runs on one AAAA battery) is a must and the dock is a great aid, with additional USB ports which come in handy.
I'm someone who has avoided tablets, because I prefer a traditional keyboard, however the HP Slate 500 is the one tablet that I truly enjoy using, and this is being written over 3 years after the Slate's original release date.

Short lifespan. I've owned 4 of these over the last few years of varying sizes, purchased locally. They all died within a year of purchase. First, you'll occasionally hear the tell-tale "DA-dunk...da-DUNK!" USB sounds in Windows as if you'd quickly unplugged and re-plugged the drive. This is the drives controller board/chip starting to go bad. Over the course of a month or two, it'll become more frequent. Eventually it'll happen while you're writing files to the drive and it will become corrupted and unusable. If it doesn't manage to corrupt itself with this self-disconnection business after a couple of months, it'll eventually just cease to be recognized entirely and your data will be lost anyway.

If you already own one of these, avoid keeping them plugged into an "always on" computer. Run-time seems to be the biggest factor in killing these drives. Also, as with ANY external/usb drive, ALWAYS use the Windows "Safely Remove hardware and Eject Media" wizard to avoid corruption when you disconnect the drive. If you keep your computer off for most of the time, or the drive lives unplugged in your desk drawer for most of it's life, you'll probably be just fine with these. Still, why use a drive with such a short lifespan when there are plenty of other portable drives on the market without this issue at comparable prices?

This card does not work in a Lenovo T500. Product decription states is will work in this laptop.When system boots system error 1802 is displayed. System will not continue to boot.

From Lenovo's website.
Numeric error code 1802 prevents system from booting. Unauthorized network card is plugged in. Network cards distributed by Lenovo have a unique Subsystem Vendor ID / Subsystem Identifier (SVID/SSID) which is checked at every boot. If the SVID/SSID doesn't match, then error code 1802 is displayed. The purpose of this check is to guarantee that both network cards and computer systems distributed by Lenovo are used in card/antenna pairs which have been certified by regulatory bodies like the FCC. Consequently, there may be both Lenovo versions and Generic versions of a vendor's network card, and even though they are electrically similar, they are registered as different cards by the regulatory body.
An absolute rip-off. Never buy this for anything beyond $35 (plus shipping).

If there's one thing you should know about MSI tech support, or customer service, is that one does not simply call MSI tech support, or costumer service. Because you will get no answer. No matter how many messages you leave, or that you call in the middle of work hours. The recording will talk at you, then promptly give you the figurative finger.

After cursing and raving at my broken new computer while trying to type e-mails with a cursor afflicted with tourette syndrome, I finally got a helpful reply with information to send my computer to the RMA department. This was two months later. I was so happy they they were finally going to fix it that I almost didn't get annoyed about the fact that I had to find my own shipping box to fit this behemoth computer, buy my own package materials, and pay for the shipping. But then I got annoyed. I live in Alaska.

The story doesn't end there. I get an e-mail today from the repair department with pictures of the package, and it looks like someone dropped it in a muddy puddle, then a velociraptor promptly stomped on it after chewing on it for a while. Despite the big red sticker stating \\"FRAGILE! HANDLE WITH CARE!!!1\\" plastered right on the front. Now, I know it's not their fault, but they want another 300 dollars out of me to repair the resulting -surprisingly- small dent to the corner of the blasted machine. And for me to send them all my credit card info.

So, yeah, you can buy this computer if you want to take a gamble that you will never have to deal with MSI after the purchase. I read that customer service sucked in previous reviews before buying this computer, but I never thought I would have to deal with them. I wish I had a time machine so I could go back and slap myself in the face for wasting 1700+ dollars.

Shipping felt like it took FOREVER but that's probably from all the anticipation. I've been running this card about a week now and have put it through numerous and frequently repeated stress tests from 2004's Half-Life 2 Source SDK to FutureMark11. As for the driver and crash issues that everyone keeps reporting I have had only one crash. I never even touched the included driver disc, installed the card - turned on the PC then went straight to AMD's website. DL'd the latest CCC Suite and the driver has not ONCE given me any issues.
The card did crash once though not from/during game-play. There is a new feature built into most of the newer AMD GPU's that when the PC goes to sleep or standby the card goes into an ultra-low power consumption mode. A BRILLIANT idea on paper on AMD's part but the chinks haven't been worked out quite yet in the execution. So MOST of the driver crashes and locking up you read about is caused by the computer going to sleep and the card failing to properly reinitialize on start-up. Be confident though that future updates will work this out and all those complaints will not have been in vain. AMD is very good about listening to user feedback and utilizing it.

**Turn off sleep/standby mode in your power control settings until such time as the issue is patched and you will be golden.**
**DOWNLOAD the newest drivers instead of trying to use the ones shipped in-box, they are almost NEVER up to date or even worth installing.**

Build/Quality
I bought THIS version on the card because GigaByte is the same brand-name as my MoBo and I like things to match. (NOTE** This has zero effect on anything so don't think it's going to help or hinder you at all; it is 100% a personal preference on my part!) Also it didn't hurt that the total price (item+shipping+tax) was at the time the lowest I had found anywhere. And for the most part I am satisfied with it. The large fan creates PLENTY of airflow over the heat-synch andis oriented to pull-in cool air across the GPU, pushing hot air away/out of the case. This helps keep circulation up and system temps down, especially under load. It does create more background/white noise, but honestly you can't run anything with this much power and NOT make some noise to cool it. That being said I was disappointed with the thin and VERY cheap plastic surround that the GIGABYTE logo is stamped on. Known for being one of the best, high-end, quality manufacturers of PC components; I was not expecting to see something that looked this cheap and felt so very flimsy. The fact of the matter is this bit of dressing, serves no actual function except to be the placeholder for the logo. So ultimately it's a moot point but still... It just seemed out of place for an otherwise high quality construction.

Technical Stuff
I am pleased and very excited about my purchase and since it's the first time I have the room for it I WILL probably buy another one in the future to utilize that CrossFireX so brazenly stamped all over the place. It's a GREAT value and a great card. It has taken every bit of punishment my stress tests can through at it and dominated them all. Frame-rates are consistently in the high 60's on every game/video-test I run. Even @ 1280p with 8x anti-aliasing and 16x Anisotropic filtering! My current test rig is an Intel Core i5-k OC'd @ 3.5GHz, 16Gb DDR3. After upgrading from an Nvidia I was blown away. This card is CRAZY powerful and I was salivating when 5 minutes after I placed my order I found the same GPU in a card with 2GB of on-board memory and a similarly OC'd GPU with a bigger/nicer looking inter-cooler for only about $30 more. To be honest that is the card I would say you SHOULD get, but at the end of the day I can't say a single bad thing about this card, it REALLY woke up the beast in my machine and only has room to improve with future driver updates! You really can not ask for more in a GPU. Sorry this ran so long but there is just so much right about this card I want you to know it's worth your investment!

In Closing
This GPU I would say is second place only to itself in the \\"Bang-vs-Dollar\\" for Budget-Gamers market! And to be honest for the near future, this really is more than enough power to run any program out there. The next level cards are more than $100 step up in price and tout lower core-clock speeds; go with the 2GB version and you've even got more memory than most next level cards. The pros and the well versed users will be the only ones that actually gain any advantage by using the more expensive GPU's. Because unless you really know your stuff, and are able to/willing to custom tweak your settings for every task you perform, you wont even begin to tap all the extra stuff on those MUCH more expensive cards. I run everything on true-maxed settings, with v-sync anti-aliasing and anisotropic filters turned up and my lowest results yet was Starcraft II during an extremely busy battle scene - the frames dipped into the low 30's for a couple of seconds there. And THAT is something I say with pride, this card has everything you want and need and then some. I HIGHLY recommend this card and brand name, if you don't choose the 2GB edition.

This is a revised review of the Kindle.  Thanks to all the people who commented, particularly those with helpful suggestions.  Here is why I changed my mind and went from a 1-star to 5-star rating.  I cannot seem to make that change above where the stars are located.  So, assume it says \\"5 stars\\".    First of all, I DID have it wrong. There was a plastic strip inside the cover and it does hold the book in place.  The problem was in the instructions on just how to get it to work  I still do not like the design of this method, but it does function.  And yes, it was finally someone really helpful in customer service who explained in detail how to make the plastic thingie work.  (I believe this is an art and a skill).    This makes reading a pleasure as the pages mostly stay in place and do not slip.  Further, I have developed a habit of frequently book-marking the pages so that if I get lost, I can find the page I was reading without too much difficulty.  I devised this strategy while reading a 500+ page book and inadvertently losing my place.  It took hours to find it again.    I still think Kindle could improve the lighting, and also the method for tracking one's progress and pages.  I look forward to a later version.  I have to say I LOVE the Kindle now that it works properly.  Have read over 30 books on it so far, and my favorite thing is that when I travel, I can carry a library with me, and not the weight of loads of books.  It is convenient and has brought me much joy.    I am leaving my original comments below, and do read the comments others posted to it.  I am forever baffled why people react so hostilely to negative reviews.  I post reviews when products cause me to react.  I appreciate those who let others know that there are problems with something so that they do not make a purchasing mistake.  However, it seems that others react  strongly to a negative review, maligning the writer, superimposing their judgments on why the person has written a negative review (the reviewer must be a social misfit, hates society etc.) Give me a break!  Reviewers post negative reviews often to warn others, not to express, at least in my cheery optimistic case, a vendetta against the world.    OLD REVIEW POSTED ABOUT 6-7 MONTHS EARLIER      I waited 6 weeks to get this device and am deeply disappointed for several reasons.  It is so poorly designed that the slightest movement sends the pages scrolling forwards or back, and it is easy to lose one's place. The back screen on which the print appears is uncomfortable--you cannot change it to make it lighter or darker, so you are stuck with a dark background and the print is not easy to read,especially in artificial light. There are only 6 font sizes, you cannot change how dark or light the print itself appears.  It hurts my eyes.    The Kindle is supposed to sit and be used in a carrying case.  It constantly falls out.  Nothing grips it.  Also, it feels heavier than most paperback books. It is not that light to hold.    Customer service is awful.  They seem, by and large, untrained, surly, and unsure and have no idea what causes problems.  For example.  I ordered 2 books and it took 10 hours, 10 HOURS, not seconds,as they promise, before they showed up on my Kindle. When I called to ask why, customer service said they had no idea and had no help or apology. They then hung up on me.  Not at all like Amazon's great customer service in other areas.    The Kindle concept is superb, but the execution is poor.  Maybe the next generation will eliminate the flaws, but I am going to return this piece of junk.

This box didn't work for us, and for a simple reason. Unlike every other router or similar device I have ever used, this one didn't provide direct access to the configuration parameters. Until *after* successful configuration, the only parameter screen available is the so-called \\"wizard,\\" which was unable to configure the Extender properly for our system.

Like many wireless router users, we have two kinds of security: WPA2 personal and a permitted MAC-number list. We manually added the Extender's MAC number to the router's permitted list. Then the wizard successfully downloaded the parameters for the first security but (apparently) not the MAC-number list. So the Extender could then access the router, but the the same computer that I had used to set it up could no longer see the Extender.

I've worked with computers for fifty years. Our neighbor is a certified network engineer, whose wireless AP we are using, with his permission, from across the street. Both of us tried to configure the extender, collectively spending a couple of hours on the task, to no avail. We couldn't get past the brain-dead \\"wizard.\\"

When I asked for help by e-mail, the rep advised me to disable MAC-number screening on the router, set up the Extender with the wizard, and then re-enable the MAC-number screening on the router. The only problem was that our neighbor's router (unlike most) does not have a software button to temporarily disable MAC-number screening. So we would have had to delete all his twenty MAC numbers and re-enter them by hand, just to follow the rep's advice. Then we would have have to manually enter the MAC numbers for the three devices in our house, also by hand, into the Extender's list.

The Extender, of course, doesn't need to serve all the twenty MAC numbers for devices in my neighbor's house. It only needs to serve the three or so in mine, which would not have been hard to enter by hand. Since my neighbor and I already had spent hours trying to configure a $70 product, and since I had little confidence the programmers had done their jobs right, I sent the box back.

My advice to prospective buyers is simple. If you are sure your router has the latest easy-config software (called WPS, I think), try this box. If you like to configure things by hand, look for another product that can do this. If the programmers had given users direct access to the Extender's parameter list, we would have been up and running in ten minutes.

This was a big disappointment of a purchase.  This adapter does not work well at all with my Acer notebook -- it makes it even the keyboard very warm after a short while (within 15 minutes) when plugged in to my notebook.  Even my cooler fan doesn't work well to cool it down. I didn't press the issue and continue using it to see if it becomes HOT.  The reason for this is because while the voltage of the adapter is correct (19V), the current rating (3.42A) is one and a half times more than what my notebook needs (2.15A).  The laptop is sucking in more current than it needs, and expends the extra energy by way of overheating. Therefore, while this product may at best be safe to use, it is NOT really and truly compatible with my Acer notebook as advertised.  It doesn't work as a replacement adapter for my notebook. What would be a real, true working compatible replacement for my original adapter is one which is 19V, 2.15A and not 19V, 3.42A which this product is.

I bought a Kindle Paperwhite on 11/27/14 and received it on 11/30/14. It was slow slow you could see the letters forming with each page change. A replacement was sent 12/1/14. Around 1/1/15 the screen started turning blue so I called and was told they would replace it again. I received it and it's \\"refurbished\\". No one told me I would be getting a refurb, and I don't know what they do to refurbish it other than wipe it off but the firmware was two versions old. I don't even know if it was the newer model with more memory.    I called Kindle support and after being transferred twice was told I couldn't have a new one because the return period was over, except the return period for items bought in November & December 2014 is end of January 2015. So I said I'll just return it all the one being replaced, the refurb replacement and the case. They said they would process it and send a confirmation email with a return shipping label. I had to call back ask for it since it did not arrive promptly, and when it did, they did not include the refund for the case.  My wife and I have been good customers for Kindle. Between us we have four Kindles, not including the Paperwhites. At this point I am completely dissatisfied with Amazon's handling of this and frankly, pretty disgusted with the whole process.  And before people start whining this isn't a review of the product, it is. Having to replace two of them in a five week period says a lot about the product. I'm going back to my Kindle 5. Its screen looks better than the Paperwhite (which I bought for the touch screen) anyway.    PS My wife picked up a Kindle 7th Generation today, and unless you absolutely need the Paperwhite's lighting, the cheaper one has a better looking screen and text.
