Final update: I just cannot tolerate the smell of this case--a disagreeable chemical odor. The manufacturer suggested I wait 7 days for the smell to abate. Well, waiting the 7 days didn't help--the odor (apparently emanating from the paint they use on the case, according to the manufacturer) is just too much for me. It's a shame, really...the case is nicely designed. Simply put, if it didn't have such a terrible chemical smell, I believe I would have enjoyed using the case.

Update #2: Starting to have my doubts if the terrible smell of this case will ever go away. I have had it airing out for five days now, and the awful smell persists. The company has contacted me and offered a replacement. Well, I'm not convinced that's going to help. The reason? Check the reviews of their other cases on amazon, and you'll see: customers are complaining about a smell associated with their other cases as well. This is completely ridiculous...buy a product, and \\"air it out for several days\\" before you can even start to use it?!?!? The features of this case make it appear to be a very attractive purchase. But the odor emanating from the case makes it unusable. I suspect I am going to have to end up returning it. I'm going to wait a couple more days and see what happens. But after five days of airing it out already, I really don't expect much is going to change.

Update #1:
Third day of ownership...the rooCASE is still in my garage, \\"airing out.\\" Feeling pretty frustrated. I realize it's only the third day of \\"airing out,\\" and the manufacturer asked me to air it out for seven days...but, sheesh! Shouldn't I have to \\"air it out\\" for ZERO days?!?!? Deducting another star...we're down to 2 stars now. More to follow...

Original review:
Received the case after a short delay. Opened the box and was immediately confronted by a terrible odor, a very strong chemical smell. I contacted rooCASE's support personnel and they explained thatthe smell was from an oil-based paint used on the edges of the case. They suggested the smell should dissipate after about seven days. They further indicated this odor problem resulted from their rush to get the cases out to customers, and that normally they let the cases air out prior to shipping; but they have not employed this practice of late due to customer demand.

Right now, after two days of ownership, I still consider the case to be unusable due to the extremely strong odor. I am letting it air out as advised by customer support. Now really, c'mon...should it really be necessary to let a product like a Kindle case \\"air out\\" for seven days prior to use? To my way of thinking, this is completely unacceptable. The manufacturer is clearly aware of the problem, but has decided to ship them out in this condition anyway.

The case looks like a fine case, and I will likely use it...if the smell does indeed dissipate. I certainly hope I do not have to wait seven days, as the manufacturer indicated to me. If the odor does not dissipate, I will have to return the case--it's really that strong.

FIve stars for potential; zero stars for shipping a case that has to be \\"aired out\\" for seven days prior to use. Thus three stars at this early point in time. I will update the review as things progress. So far, overall...disappointment.

As it turns out, the version as of Oct 30, 2012 does not have bridging functions available in the user interface for the common person.  This means if you have your own router like a NetGear or an Apple Airport or Apple TimeCapsule, you can't just check a box in the setup config and just hook them into the modem.  This is all over blogs on the internet as a disastrous shortcoming.  I have tried using the router that comes installed within and it just doesn't stack up to the brand names I mentioned in the previous sentence especially if you have thick walls or obstacles.  Ironically my old 2wire DSL modem provided better functions.  This is a lemon and as long as AT&T pushes this as the only solution, I would question using AT&T uverse for my internet service.  On a hopeful note, there is an apparent a workaround to the bridging to an external router issue, but apparenly involves technical entries at several lines in the config screens.  There is no manual on this, but if you have networking experience, this might not be an issue for you.

I have used Maxtor internal & external drives for years. Then, along comes this piece of junk. First off, the drive is housed in a cheap case made of very thin metal and plastic. It hooks up easy enough, but this one only lasted 3 days before dying. If you read reviews at various sites, you'll find that this is an epidemic with this useless paperweight, but I was in a hurry and didn't do my homework. Stuff like this really makes you wish that some attorney would put together a class action against Seagate.

Regarding service, you can't understand the tech on the other end AND they clearly don't know how to do anything except tell you that they will send you a reconditioned drive once you return yours. When you think about it though, this makes perfect sense because they've had so many returns on these things that I'm sure they have a warehouse full of reconditioned units. One thing to think about though is this ... do you really want to send back a drive that has lots of your info on it and run the risk that some techno-weenie at the factory in a third world country might get their hands on it? Not me. I threw this piece of junk in the trash after I drilled 4 holes in it and counted it as an expensive lesson.

The next thing I did was spend $50 more and buy a LaCie that is built like a brick, looks great, is quiet and just plain works. Bye-bye Maxtor (Seagate).

- Like me, you needed an amazing HTPC / Media Keyboard.
- Like me, you are sick and tired of looking for a keyboard to fit your needs.
- You don't mind this not being a 'mini' keyboard.

I bought one of the original first "Rii Mini Wireless Keyboards" (That now, there are dozens of clones of...). That one finally died after 3 years, it was amazing, and I loved the damn little thing... But trying to replace it, I kid you not, I bought maybe 6 or 7 different versions of it, they all suck and are NOTHING like the original one.

I finally decided to give this a try, knowing that it's more of a full size keyboard (I used to have a DiNovo one that I ended up hating for being so unpractical).

Why I like this one:
- The wireless connection is flawless.
- The illumination is beautiful (And useful too!)
- Charges via Micro USB.
- Battery says to hold 10 days, I've charged it once in almost 2 months and we use it on our media PC ALL.THE.TIME. So I guess they mean 10 days of actual use.
- The keys are amazing, very responsive, good feedback.
- The touchpad is REALLY good.
- It has a VERY CLEVER Mouse button on the back-left corner of the keyboard (it sounds weird, I know) but it's amazingly practical.

The things I don't like (But still give it 5 stars overall)
- It's a bit heavy.
- The function (F) keys are usually for the already-programmed functions instead of F keys (I am sure you can change that if you install the Logitech software, which I haven't done yet).
- It is big, almost full sized... we got used to having it on the coffee table, but I do miss how tiny and practical the Rii was.
- Pricey...

All in all, great buy!

So what programs do I use? I use a LOT of them, Adobe Photoshop, Zbrush's 2D image possibilities, Adobe Flash, Autodesk Sketchbook Pro, Paint Tool SAI, Artrage. And you know what... Monoprice has issues with every single one of them!

[[VIDEOID:mo2QLSSRZ5UPYM6]]quickly: thank you to all that review products with great experience points that help refine everyone's needs...and also provides feedback to the manufacturer for product improvement...that's what I call a free market and why I'm writing this review:

Anyway, Greatsheild's product is the 2nd screen protector I've bought for my Samsung Series 7 Slate; so I now have context within which to review.

I use the slate for medical school...meaning I ink with the wiacom pen a ton. I mean a ton, and I use MS OneNote exclusively for school, and have literally 0, zero, paper notes for my classes...to give you an idea.

The first screen protector I bought was MXH Photodon's (HD) screen protector. This cost $19 for 1 sheet. It was good.
I now have the Greatsheild (matte) protector, which costs $13 for 3 sheets. Also good.

So what's the differences?

(1) APPLICATION/INSTALLITION:
Both excellent, really easy, fit basically perfect, and easily reversible without leaving any residue what so ever incase some spec of dust got stuck under the film. Only minor caveat is both products have a \\"sticky\\" underside, so you have to be careful dirt doesn't get stuck to it while installing. Just annoying to clean, nothing permanent, and by \\"sticky\\" I don't mean like a glue its more of a texture.

(2) REFLECTIVENESS:
Highly important to me because its very annoying trying to study under the white fluorescence lights in the library...especially since I use the slate much like a notebook lying relatively flat on the table as oppose to an upright monitor. The MXH sheet was without a doubt noticeably more reflective (obviously not as much as the naked native glass (which is insane). I would say the MXH Photodon cut down the reflectiveness ~40-60%). The GreatSheild is far better in this respect. The \\"matte\\" description is spot on. Reflections are way more blurred out and less intense (I would say itcuts it down around 75-85%). Can't eliminate it completely, but with the GreatSheild I am able to read through the reflection, which is impossible with the native glass, and difficult with the MXH Photodon.

(3) CLEARITY:
in my opinion the MXH Photodon film was slightly (emphasis on slightly) more clear. Both films seemed to change the way the image from the native screen looks at first, but after a few hours or days its not noticeable nor an issue. Over all the clarity \\"difference\\" is only noticeable when looking at tiny font (i.e. Calibri font, size 8 or less) from a distance of more than 4 or 5 feet away from the slate...so not really a big deal for my purposes, and I can't really think of a situation it would be an issue unless you have really long arms (perhaps with the newer tablets running 1920x1080 resolution vs. my older model Slate that runs 1366X768). Nevertheless, the MXH Photodon does have a small edge on clarity...which is probably why they advertise as an \\"HD, Anti-glare\\" screen protector.

(4) FEEL TO TOUCH: the MXH Photodon felt a little harder with a more hard-plastic-ish feel, while the GreatSheild feels much softer like a piece of paper; in fact it feels exactly like my desktop PC's matte LCD monitor. For example, when I move my finger across the screen I hear a noise very similar to the sound I make moving my finger across a sheet of paper. In a way it gives a paper-like feel when inking on the slate.

(5) FEEL TO INK WITH THE PEN: There is a difference here. Its not a giant difference, but consistently noticeable and will depend on individual preference. The MXH Photodon is more slick, while the GreatSheild holds more resistance while in writing. I personally like this, makes it more like writing on paper. A good way to put it in perspective is: the native gorilla glass of the Slate is the most slick for inking with the pen. This would lead in a more messy script on my part, and thus a higher error rate & processing time with the text recognition in Windows 8. The GreatSheild would be like the opposite end of the spectrum; not to say its perfect, inking is still more slick that an actually pen/pencil and paper. The MXH Photodon in somewhere in the middle (I would say a little bit closer to the GreatSheild end than the native glass end).

(6) SCRATCH RESISTANCE:
So, the reason I went with a different choice this time around (other than cost as a student) was because the MXH Photodon accumulated scratches from inking with the pen. The scratches would not happen every time I would ink, just on occasion as I would be writing or drawing I'd hit a \\"rough\\" stroke, such that a minor scratch would be left on the film. A single scratch was not noticeable to the eye (unless you looked really really close at the screen) but I could definitely feel it in my hand when it would happen.

It's hard to say why this would happen. It's never happened on the native gorilla glass. It may be because the tip of the wiacom pen that comes with the Slate is not a perfect dome if you look close. It's more like tapered cylinder that does a sharp cone towards the tip, then the absolute tip is smoothed out.
looks kind of like this:

_tip of the dome
/.\
| |^the sharp edge
| |

Anyway, while 1 scratch was not noticeable, after a full 9 months of using the MXH Photodon (i.e. the entire 1st year of medical school = ~5000 pages of notes) the middle portion of the screen where I (apparently) do most of my writing had accumulated so many scratches that the content behind it became noticeably blurry to the point that I had to zoom in to continue reading. At first I though I was starting to need glasses, then one day I realized the text at the top and bottom of the screen was clear and I didn't need glasses. I first noticed this about a 1-1.5 months ago, and removed the screen protector for my last exam cause it was too annoying. Nobody expectsthese protectors to last forever, and the MXH Photodon lasting 7-8 months with the intense use I put into it was still great value.

Now, I can't give an honest comment about the scratch resistance for the GreatSheild since I've only been using it for ~2 weeks. If I can edit this review after my next set of exams in a month I will. My suspicion is that the issue will persist given the GreatSheild feels softer and is likely made of a less resistant plastic...Then again...I haven't had a single scratch yet...and maybe the texture of the GreatSheild is such that it won't scratch with the wiacom pen...only time and studying will tell :)

Hope this helps, lol, best wishes.

UPDATE:
Now that I've used the Greatsheild for sometime... just wanted to add that: YES The Greatsheild will also accumulate scratches; there are a couple on the screen protector now. However I still maintain the \\"inking\\" is better, with more resistance meaning less messy script and lower error rate. However, the reduction in image quality is still apparently as well, particularly when viewing the screen corners from an angle (Not that big a deal).

Like my iPhone, I put an OtterBox on my iPad.  OtterBox is the best way to go for anyone who will carry their iPad along for their ruff and tumble adventures like I do.  The case lid also coverts into a stand that allows for two viewing angles, one for use if the iPad is in your lap, and the other for use when watching videos etc, because it is a more vertical angle which I find to be perfect when watching Netflix.  If you are super concerned about the perfect crispness of the new display, some people find that the built in screen protector distracts them.  However, I have found that I have become accustomed to the look of the screen behind the protector and it is something that I feel is a compromise in order to protect the screen.  The fit and finish is great and I have found that the box works perfectly for me and the added weight and bulk actually help me to keep ahold of my device.  When I operated the iPad before putting the OtterBox on it, I always felt that the iPad was about to slip out of my hand.  However, the Otter is not for everyone and you know what you want in a case.  If you want a sleek and slim feel with by little bulk, then the Otter is not for you.  You would probably be better with a portfolio or other style case.  It's kind of like buying a four wheel drive vehicle.  If your main use is going to be driving around town getting the kids and groceries then a crossover is probably best for you.  However, if you are going to be going off into the mountains and wilderness then a more hardcore SUV is best.  Same with the OtterBox.  If you don't think that you need the ultimate protection, then you will be much more happy with a thinner and lighter case.  However, for those of you that want the ultimate protection regardless if you are prone to dropping things or you plan to travel a lot, the Otter is a great choice for you.  For all of the tough guys out there, this is definitely your case!
The RAM was installed the day it arrived and has performed flawlessly since that time.

The product itself works but the software can make you hate this company to the guts. They are [Amazon Censorship]:mentally-challenged software-wise. In order to understand why I must describe my setup so you appropriately know if it can affect you.

My setup:

-Main PC (you must select a \\"main\\" PC): Asus P5E motherboard running Windows 7 Ultimate 64-bit edition, overall a high-end PC.
-Secondary PC: HP EliteBook 8560w running Windows 7 Enterprise 64-bit edition; also a high-end PC.
-Main PC's user account: Let's call it John, which is a domain account in my home domain (yes, I use Active Directory at home). Username John doesn't have administrative rights at all. It is an account belonging to the BUILTIN\Users group. This is awesome to avoid destructive viruses.
-Secondary PC's user account: Let's call it Work, from my office's domain. It has admin rights to the PC but User Account Control is On. But this part is really irrelevant. I just mentioned it for completeness.

How this device works:

This USB device is actually several devices in one. After you plug it in, Windows 7 will search for and install drivers for 5 different USB devices. It took a bit of time, but not too much. After these are done, a new virtual drive is added to your PC. Look it up because you must run the EasyLink.exe file contained in it. A stock Windows 7 PC would have shown the Autorun dialog box, but that's just the vanilla Windows 7 configuration. The instructions pamphlet doesn't take into account any other possibility. If your PC has Autorun disabled, you must browse for the file yourself. Not a biggie for many users, but other users may find this misleading and obscure.

Anyway, you have to run this EasyLink.exe file. But this is exactly where the nightmare begins. You see, this file requires administrative privileges to work properly, or at least that's what it seems because it just won't run by double-clicking it. To behonest, I am not very sure because the [Amazon Censorship]:mentally-challenged software engineers working in the software department of StarTech digitally signed the executable and then altered it, rendering the digital signature invalid. I actually suspect that Windows is refusing to run it because of this fact, and I was only able to circumvent it by right-clicking EasyLink.exe and selecting \\"Run as administrator\\". At this point I am warned that the certificate is invalid, but I am allowed to enter credentials. So I have this OTHER user account from my home domain that does have admin rights. I typed that account in and the (in)famous EasyLink.exe finally runs. It is only at this point that I can proceed with the other part of the installation, which is done in the secondary PC.

The story in the Secondary PC is the same: Plug in the other end of the cable, wait for the USB drivers to install, then run EasyLink.exe. Again, I must elevate the process because it either requires admin rights, or is the only way Windows 7 will run it because of the damaged digital signature.

At this point I know this will be trouble after a restart, so after watching in awe for 1 minute how easy and SUPER NICE it was to use this thing (after the digital signature odyssey), I proceed to restart both PC's.

WAIT! New problem: My main PC refuses to reboot. It turns out that this device confuses the ASUS P5E motherboard's BIOS to the point where the BIOS just won't POST and the PC won't boot. Nice. One more thing to do: If I restart the PC, I must disconnect this USB thing, wait for BIOS to POST, then connect. Granted: Asus hardware is a [Amazon Censorship]:worthless piece of equipment with non-existent customer support, but still it is quite unbelievable to me that it generates such interference.

Anyway, after discovering the problem, I was able to reboot the main PC. When it logs back in, the EasyLink.exe software is nowhere to be found. Again,Windows has refused to launch it because of the broken digital signature, or at least I think this is the problem.

The rest of my odyssey revolves around trying to make EasyLink.exe to run automatically somehow. Summary of attempts:

- A Windows task run as SYSTEM or LOCAL SERVICE on session logon. No go.
- A Windows task using SysInternals' psexec tool. No go.
- Second best: Autorun of EasyLink.exe in HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with creation and addition of an application manifest for automatic elevation of rights. Completely futile.

Ok, so I just abandon all hope to make this work. At this point I know I'll just have to start EasyLink.exe manually every time I log in my PC.

And you, avid reader, probably think all is over now, right? Well, no. This product assures it can transfer files from one PC to the other by either using the clipboard or dragging. It did not work for me at all. I am thinking it may be because of security issues between the user running the EasyLink.exe program and the file in question. But that's just my guess. In short: It doesn't work.

But wait! Let me throw in the cherry on top: The software only takes into consideration the main monitor screen of the PC's. My secondary PC uses a second monitor. Well, with this thing the secondary monitor is useless. StarTech's software is so simple-minded that it doesn't conceive the fact that a PC may be using more than one monitor. Therefore when you use this thing when you have two monitors in the secondary PC, you can kiss your second monitor goodbye because the StarTech software will refuse to let the mouse leave the main monitor area. Nice, I know. And what infuriates me the most is that I discovered all this in one afternoon. It's like StarTech never QA'd this product at all.

So in summary: StarTech has GREAT hardware engineers and complete [Amazon Censorship]:mentally-challenged software engineers programming their software. I tried to give this a two-star rating because seeing this thing working is just awesome, but I just can't. Not after testing multi-monitor support.

The switch between PC's just by moving the mouse to the configured screen edge is SUPERB, which I think is the merit of the HARDWARE engineer(s) at StarTech, but let me be clear: THAT'S THE ONLY THING THAT WORKED. The core functionality. The extra goodies were left out in my case.

Would I recommend? Tough one. The actual product with better software may be amazing. I don't know how good this company is when it comes to software updates, and I think that would be the key to answering such question. So I'll just say this: If StarTech can patch their horrible, horrible software, yes, this is an amazing product I would completely recommend. I'll contact them and update.

This thing is awesome! I've been using it for a few weeks now, and the difference is remarkable. I'm using it as the main drive on a Lenovo W530 laptop (known among developers as "The Beast"). The beast already had 32GB of memory, and is a rock solid machine, so I was already pretty satisfied. But I run multiple VM's a lot and have a lot of services running on the beast, so startup was exceptionally slow (3-4 minutes for a complete reboot). Boot time now is under 30 seconds, and everything is just much faster. VM's are very fast and start instantly.

Installation was ridiculously simple, and the two software programs that came with it work well. The migration tool is spectacular. If you plan to make this your primary drive, you will need a USB 3.0 to Sata III cable, which is separate. I bought the following from Amazon when I placed this order:

StarTech.com USB 3.0 to 2.5" SATA III Hard Drive Adapter Cable w/ UASP - SATA to USB 3.0 Converter for SSD/HDD - Hard Drive Adapter Cable

The cable was also very good and worked perfectly.

To do the swap, the "general" instructions are below. You still need to RTFM.

Install the software that comes with the device.
Plug the new drive into the Sata III cable.
Plug the Sata III cable into your USB 3.0 USB port.
Run the migration software that comes with the drive. It will copy your old primary to this new drive.
When the migration completes, remove the old drive and replace it with this drive.
Sit back and be all pleased with yourself for making this terrific decision.

Some tips:
Make sure any services that may interfere are turned off. The migration software will not copy files that are in use.
If you don't have USB 3.0, the migration will be excruciatingly slow. With USB 3.0 it took about an hour or so.

In need of a corded landline phone that would work during an electrical power outage, we did a side-by-side test of the AT&T TR1909 Corded Telephone versus this RCA 1104 Corded Telephone. The AT&T TR1909 Corded Telephone was the clear winner, based on sound quality (AT&T quite clear, RCA very muffled), ease of operation (AT&T no issues, RCA handset fits too snugly in base and Caller ID is too small to read quickly), and ringtone (AT&T just like a phone in a nice hotel, RCA like some kind of obnoxious alarm). We returned the RCA 1104 Corded Telephone, and now own two of the AT&T TR1909 Corded Telephones, in both black and white. The AT&T TR1909 Corded Telephone is highly recommended. This RCA 1104 Corded Telephone is NOT recommended.

Initially this product worked to specifications. Within days, data transfer capabilities stopped. Upon further inspection it was discovered that the circuit board for this hub had the most sub-standard assembly that I have ever seen. Pass through components had only enough solder to make an attachment. Component leads were not trimmed and are touching other components or traces. And there is enough slag solder on the board to compensate for the lack of solder at the components. My grand children can do a better assembly!!!  If you are shopping for a powered hub, DO purchase this one !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I don't know if I can find strong enough words about my experience so far with Amped Wireless and STEVE in particular!!!  I purchased the REC10 range extender and, of course, I got roadblocked at step 3 because I'm old and not tech savy.  I was on hold for a time but got the offer to receive a call back. (I am not a racist on any level but I get so frustrated trying to muddle through with many tech support people who do NOT and who call me \\"mam\\" every 15 seconds...can they not train these people over there??)  Anyway...I digress.  Steve was the epitome of FANTASTIC CUSTOMER SERVICE!!!  He was knowledgeable and personable and used the word \\"perfect\\" a lot.  I liked that...it gave me confidence!! I felt like I was plugged into a real human being who was listening intently to me and actually gave a crap as to whether or not my product was up and running.  After a few trial and error issues (nothing bad to do with the product...mostly my personal computer issues)...I was up and running.  I had to do the setup with the extender in a place I didn't really want it because there wasn't enough signal to do the set up where I really DID want it.  So...having done the set up and seeing that the product worked perfectly, Steve told me to unplug it and take it back to where I wanted it.  If it worked, congrats.  If not, I'd have to find another location.  Well...GREAT NEWS STEVE...I am currently typing from the farthest point in our dead area and I have FIVE BARS OF SERVICE!!!  When I am laying in bed, unable to sleep and feeling happy because I actually have enough signal to watch Breaking Bad on my Kindle...I will sing the praises of this product -  The Amped Wireless High Power 600mW Compact wi-fi Range Extender - and of a delightful young man in California named Steve. Pros : Really fast, small, motherboard attached, and bleeding edge tech. Boots on Asus X99-E WS and runs like a scalded Ape. It took quite a while to sort out but it is worth it.
This drive is an OEM laptop drive but can be installed in Desktops with the latest PCIe 3.0 M.2and UEFI support.

Cons : Samsung OEM product, not sold as retail so Samsung offers little no support so you have to have pretty advanced skills to get this to run as Windows boot drive. Don't buy this and expect it to be plug and play.

Other Thoughts : The SM951 won't show in Asus x99 BIOS as boot drive when first attached. But it will show in BIOS after you have sucessfully installed Windows on it so be patient. You will see it during the windows install when you are prompted to select the drive location for your new Windows install but you might get an error message that Windows can't install on it. I tried many times and failed at this point.

The trick for me (not in the guides) was to first attach the SM951 to the MB along with a proven boot drive with Windows 8.1. Then boot the system with the proven Windows 8.1 install. Then use Windows Disk Management to initialize the SM951 as GPT (or convert to GPT if MBR exists). Remember the SM951 and the USB boot drive need to be GPT and UEFI. Now install Windows 8.1 to the SM951 from a bootable USB (GPT + UEFI) Windows 8.1 ISO made by Rufus or Windows Bootable Image Creator (see guides below). In order for Windows to install at this point the SM951 needs to show as unallocated space. If you get an Error trying to select the SM951 as disk just use ADVANCED to delete the volume on the sm951 and it will show as unallocated space.

Good guide here for install with Asus X99: (Format in GPT and do everything in UEFI)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=No-ct8pQcIg

Good Guide here to create bootable USB using Windows Bootable Image Creator
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S5Jzt1r0Qzw

Good guide here for generic Bios and bootable USB Windows Installer using Rufus
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUAw0CZFHcUsing Rufus https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUAw0CZFHcU

Hey guys and gals.  Okay, I've had this machine for a week now.  I will probably update this after more time has passed.  I also like the small keyboard because there's less hand and finger travel involved so I find it much easier to type.      THE BATTERY is UNREAL.  READ your manuals boys and girls, ESPECIALLY the part about conditioning your battery three times.  Search the internet and download the free program \\"CPUID Hardware Monitor\\".  It shows the \\"wear level\\" and capacity of your battery.  VERY cool.  My battery started with 10% wear level out of the box.  After 3 \\"conditionings\\" as explained in the manual, I have zero wear level and today my power meter says I have 11 hours and 48 minutes to go!  Each \\"conditioning\\" I did, I watched the battery's capacity level in CPUID go up!  I have NEVER seen ANYTHING like this in my life and I have had multiple laptops since 1995.  The battery life is CRAZY.  Obviously those numbers will go down faster as you start and run programs.      I wish they could put decent graphic cards in these netbooks.  NONE of them in this price range on the market have one.  But then that would also kill the battery life as well.  This one will get you by with BASIC graphics handling.  I can watch HD video MP4s only with Quicktime.  VLC Media Player and Windows Media Player (after installing codecs for it) jitter and stutter with HD MP4 videos, Quicktime does NOT.  I have run several BASIC games, Hoyle Casino 2008, MS Pinball Arcade, Virtual Pool 3 and they all seem to run good, no issues.  As you have no T&L or anti-aliasing capabilities with this video card, the heavy duty 3D games stutter and jitter if they run AT ALL.  After a couple days I upgraded the RAM to 2 GB to see if that would help and it did not.  Basic, low graphic games run just fine.  What's funny is I watched HD video on YouTube with zero issues.  I run an older version of Adobe Photoshop without any issues.  Microsoft Office 2007 runs beautifully.    UPDATE: HD VIDEO EDITING  My Sanyo VPC CG10 HD digital camcorder creates videos in HD MP4 format.  I had to do a few things to get this computer to work with them.  I had to install the codecs from shark007.net to get the PC to work with the MP4s. After that, they will play in Windows Media Player as well.  HD editing? I bought the \\"Wondershare\\" Netbook converter suite which includes their \\"DVD to netbook converter\\" and a pretty quick and efficient \\"Video to netbook\\" converter. They have a trial and that's what made me buy it. It's simple, fast, efficient, has many options and takes up very little space on my hard drive. Google them. After trying several other converters, I found this to be the best for me. I convert the videos from MP4 to WMV and load them into the old XP Windows Movie Maker. I found out that XP Windows Movie Maker uses profiles. The default settings don't allow you to save your creations in HD format. HOWEVER, I found dozens of *.prx files, which are the profiles, all over the web. I downloaded several HD profiles. Some included instructions on which folder to copy them to. WALLA! Like magic... I am now editing and saving HD videos with this netbook using Windows XP SP3 and the old XP Windows Movie Maker on a 1.66 Ghz processor, 2 gigs of RAM! No stuttering, no issues, zero problems and the videos come out great!    UPDATE: SEE COMMENTS BELOW ON MY RAM MEMORY EXPERIENCE!    Overall speed.  This thing flies!!!  Clicking on things, opening programs, Windows start up... zooming in a map in Delorme or Microsoft mapping software... ALL wayyyyyyy faster than my 2.2 Ghz Dual Core, 4 GB RAM Windows 7 Professional laptop.  How does THAT happen???  Everything just seems to happen FASTER.  Is it Windows XP?  I don't know but I did WANT a netbook with Windows XP.  I wanted one before you can't buy them any longer.  As it is now, you can't buy them in stores any longer.    Overall, for $300, I LOVE this little machine and have decided I will keep it.  I'll save the HD video editing for my other laptop.  Although, I have not tried it yet on this little machine.  Maybe in a review update.  It's more than half the size as my other laptop and even with a case, can EASILY fit in an airplane carry-on or under a car seat.  I fit MOST of the programs and files I need on the 160 GB hard drive.  Too bad Windows XP does not support any larger sizes.  I anticipate this little machine will be going with me everywhere I go... never leave the house without it!    I give it 5 stars out of 5!!!  It's a keeper!!!    Juan

The PCV-W20 is one awesome integrated desktop. Sure it's pricey, but you get a lot of features plus Sony's award-winning styling. The widescreen 15.3\\" (measured diagonally) LCD is beautiful and has excellent contrast ratio. The CPU is actually 1.8Ghz, not 1.9 (which doesn't exist), but it's still fast. Sony apparently optimizes the system so it feels as speedy as a 2.4Ghz Dell Dimension 2350 or 4500.
Unlike most other one-piece PCs, this one has all the ports loaded: three USB 2.0 ports (but one already taken by the optical mouse), two 4-pin i.Link/IEEE 1394 ports, one line-in port for hooking up an audio input source (e.g., a portable CD player or MP3 player), two PC Card slots, and one Memory Stick slot. Modem and ethernet are built-in, so you can surf web either way you want. You also get a DVD-ROM/CD-RW combo drive, but no DVD burner.
The W-series is really designed for family users who don't need to tinker with the system, so the biggest downside for us geeks is that you can't expand the system easily. For example, you can't put in a bigger hard disk, although you can get an external USB 2 or IEEE 1394 hard disk, or use an IDE hard disk with an external enclosure kit (e.g., ADS Pyro). You also can't upgrade the graphics card, which means if you are into the latest 3D games, you are out of luck. And you can't put in an internal DVD burner; instead you'll need to get an expensive external one (usually at a one-hundrd dolr premium).
Specs aside, the W20 is a pleasure to use. The keyboard does suffer from Sony's annoying policy of doing away with the insert/home/delete/... keys, and the arrow keys are cramped with the main keyboard which makes them hard to use. But that's about the only gripe. As mentioned before the system is speedy, and Sony bundles the system with a generous offering of software titles. The user experience is very positive, so if you can afford it, this is a highly recommend system for your home.

My Google Nexus 7 2013 purchased at Best Buy went back today. (The manufacture date on package said 2013 07) IT WAS EXTREMELY BUGGY! The response to the power button was sporadic. The unit would hang and become unresponsive and could not be shut down. Tech adviser said to hold the power button for 20 seconds, which didn't work. Finally after several rounds of holding the button for a count of 60 and beyond, the unit finally shut down.

It then would shut down randomly, all the way to the total reboot state rather than just the sleep state.

The touch screen was erratic and finicky, sometimes responding and sometimes not.

Upon return, the clerk said that he owns the same unit and it works perfectly, but that some of these devices are definitely duds. When I asked if they get a lot of returns of the Nexus 7, he said \\"some.\\" That said enough for me. I did a return rather than an exchange.

Wait for the manufacturer to figure this out and then be sure you're getting a freshly manufactured unit.

I was pleased with delivery and that this was an OEM part.  However, the internal mfg. date detected was 2006, and first used date 2007, with a sticker on the outside of the battery with a written date of 12/11.  So, after a number of Lenovo battery utility deep-cycle charges, the best I can get is 89% of rated capacity.  So, does that meet expectations??  Not from prior experiences with other LiIon battery vendors, where I am advised 3 to 4 years on the shelf is about it.  The product page did not mention anything about it being new, but actually old.  I am waiting to hear from Amazon and this vendor, because this is a bit contrary to the vendor's general ratings. I will update upon a response.  Update: Amazon processed a return and credit, and I bought the same product from a national vendor via Amazon. I am pleased the product I received this time actually had a very recent internal manufacturing date, and exceeds ratings.  So buyers beware with batteries suggesting they are new; ask beforehand if they may have been on the shelf for 5 years!!!

I bought this repeater a few months ago.  It was easy to install, and was working almost immediately.  However, I find that if I am connected to the repeater, I can get long delays in response from the server on the other end of the network.  I'm using SSH over VPN, mostly.  The delays can be as long as 10 seconds.  If I connect directly to my original wireless, the problem goes away.  I blame the repeater, though admittedly there's not a huge amount of evidence here.  It does do a nice job of boosting my signal where many other products have not made a difference.  I wish it offered access to the statistics that it surely keeps about response time, dropped packets and connections, and so on.

Perhaps I got one of the first ones off the assembly line, because I have encountered nothing but problems over thirty months of use.

Tech support, somewhere in India or Pakistan, told me my chip set is damaged, even though the unit has been plugged into APC UPS with filters, etc. for the last 30 months.
When the unit did work, I never got better than 30 foot range. Beyond that the signal would degrade to the point of no connectivity.
Company unwilling to offer a coupon or discount on latest and greatest unit, so I'll move on as you should.

DRAGON OUCH !!! or Dragon Douche....
Given the fact that it's a cheap tablet it still doesn't have to be a piece of $**t, but it is!
After charging it the required time (10 hours) I turned on and started to see the first thing BAD.
Holding it horizontally, the characters on the bottom of the screen (home, return, screen change, volume up & down) were totally USELESS!
If I wanted to use these characters, I had to flip the tablet 180 degrees or hold it in vertical position, but even holding it vertical, I noticed that the 1/2 inch of that (bottom screen), is not responding to touch!
The whole tablet was acting Sluggish and had lag delay in response to touch.
Finally, connected to WIFI and downloaded Solitaire which I couldn't play NOT a single game because of the portion of the none responsive screen.
Called the Toll free support line, "nobody home", they called me the next day left me a message, sent an email explaining the problems, response came 24 hrs latter to reset to factory original setting.
That improved just a little bit the sluggishness, but the screen was still NOT responsive.
I wanted to send it to be replaced but because it was a gift and I didn't have a receipt.
They kept "bombarding" me, requesting the ORDER number which I didn't have.
The tablet was kept OFF for a week and not plugged into the charger, I tried to turn it ON, battery was empty, recharged it again and wanted to reset to factory original settings, it took me 2 hours to sign in, the cursor was moving erratically and the password was "self" writing the whole alphabet by itself like it was possessed!
Finally, the next day (two weeks latter), I caved in and returned back the Gift!
If you need a headache, buy this tablet, you'll have plenty of, but if you want something that you can use and enjoy, get a brand name, and a tablet with a Parent company, that's what I did!

I ordered this as a replacement for the chord on my DELL Inspiron 4010. I honestly wasn't sure just because the official part from Dell is $50.00 and this is so much less expensive. EDIT: WOW, I couldn't have been more disappointed with this purchase. Two days ago the chord started on fire. Yes, I said it started on f@&*ng FIRE while plugged in to my laptop. I originally gave 5 stars because it seemed to work fine at first. In fact it seemed to work fine until two days ago when it started to \\"turn off\\" meaning that the indicator light turned off occasionally. The next morning, I plugged it in and I heard a surging buzz sound coming from the power supply, then POP! As I pulled the chord from my laptop and tossed it across the room it basically exploded and started on fire. Luckily my computer was unharmed. I would say DO NOT BUY THIS ITEM. I have since wen to a local battery shop and got a better model with a warranty.

I was a big fan of the product when I first purchased it last year.  The product was a relatively easy install and management.  This time I purchased two 3-packs for a couple of offices and ran into problems with the current software (UniFi V3.2.10) and Java after installation.  This is posted as a known issue on the company site for a previous version (v3.2.5) and was supposedly corrected with version 3.2.7.  Unfortunately the solutions they have posted (for v3.2.5) did not work and required contacting Ubiquiti for a solution.  Ubiquiti ONLY offers support via email (no phone support).  When I received the correct solution I asked why it wasn't posted on their support site.  The response I received was that it is on the site and I should read the link the support tech just included in his second response.  The link provided didn't have the same solution they e-mailed me.  I informed the tech of this and his response was "This case is closed".  I don't feel comfortable using a product that lacks adequate support and puts out software that doesn't work as stated!

If you've never tried an SSD drive...get one ASAP! It's probably the best performance upgrade for the money you can find (other than maybe RAM itself). Even if you're still rocking an SATAII chipset...an SSD will speed drive search/access up quite a bit!

I've been booting Windows 7 from an older 64gig 830 model for about a year and love it!

I wanted a second SSD to speed up the cache of some of my larger applications and give some room for a few extra software installations so I got this one on sale.

I'd read that the 830 was 'faster'...in my case the 830 is nearly full (with about 10gig plus the empty management partition I left) and isn't quite as fast as the newer 840 (yes, I do use trim and run the included optimization software from time to time). So...I've moved all the page/cache files to the newer 840 drive. The faster benchmarks on the 840 for me could have something to do with the 830 being over a year old now and being nearly full.

I've no complaints about this 840 drive (nor the year old 830). It's way faster/quieter than the spinner I was using before :)
For my money, the Samsung drives seem to be really good Consumer grade SSD units.

I had a rapidly failing 1 tb Samsung drive which needed to be replaced. I decided to go with a ssd drive as the replacement. The drive took more than 9 days to arrive which was really pushing it, if I had known it would take that long I would have purchased it local. Anyways these drives are amazingly quick. They boot up to Windows 8.1 in 15 seconds. Speaking of Windows 8.1 I installed windows from a thumbdrive and I was at the windows prompt in less than 10 minutes. It took so much longer for the updates... hours to complete. You do need to install Samsung Magic and Samsung SSD 840 EVO Performance Restoration and run the restoration program once a month but the return is amazing as you can see by my attached Benchmark test run just a minute ago. I will always buy a ssd drive for any new computers I buy or build whether pc or mac. 5 thumbs up from me!

I liked netgear routers - in fact I had many over the past 7 or more years.

When I bought this one, it was the top of the line router from Netgear about a year ago. However - with this version the security functionality got changed - and not to the better.

In the past you had a MAC filter and the obligatory WIFI password. If your device was not in the MAC filter list, you did not get access to the router and the network.

Now there is an "Access list" which grants internet access to certain MAC addresses. You might say - what's the difference? Well - once you have specified the password you are in the network. No matter if your MAC address is in the filter list as allowed or blocked. In other words an attacker is able to figure out what the password is and is one step closer (if not even in) your network.

Maybe you are intrigued by the fact that you can use this "Access list" for wired connections! But - well... Block a MAC address and you see that you can still see the rest of the (at least) intra net. So what is the security? Blocking a system to access the internet?

And then comes the next. Wifi devices are piling up for all kinds of reasons. So you enter them - until you run into the fact that you add devices to the filter and they do not get access anyways - in fact all your clicks on "allow" and / or adding devices to the exception list are forgotten instantly. You will do this game for minutes until you realize that you must have hit a limit in the list length and they didn't even bother to output an error message.

If you are looking for a router - the WNDR4300 might be a much better choice (if it still has the old version of the software).

I've applied enough screen protectors and figured out exactly what I need to do to get satisfactory results every single time.

1. Choose a dust free work area, a room free of floating dust is a big plus.

2. Perform a practice run before actual application to recognize any potential issues. Such as orienting the tablet in the desired working position, etc..

3. Wash your hands, face, and arms before attempting application (avoid falling skin cells, donut crumbs, etc..) Clean the screen and edges thoroughly. Apply the film as fast as possible immediately after cleaning the screen to avoid all particles from becoming sandwiched in between.

In the case of the Armor Sheild, I did the above mentioned, pulled the film from the paper backing, sprayed it down and immediately applied it, all in a couple of seconds. It went on beautifully and aligned perfectly. I carefully swept away the air bubbles and wiped away any escaping liquid with the micro fiber cloth. Gave it a good look over and all was well, however, there were many micro bubbles that gave it a very ugly overall look.

I removed all of the bigger bubbles, so, I was satisfied with that and followed the directions which stated that micro bubbles are normal and will disappear after a day or three. I am writing this just shy of 24 hours after application and happy to report the screen look 99% perfect. I will wait another day to see if a couple of very insignificant blemishes in the upper corner will fade. It is already looking better there so I think it's going to heal itself just fine.

The better news is NO DUST PARTICLES......this is because of working quickly between cleaning and applying.

The skin is very nice and overall, the experience was much better than expected. Working with large protectors such as this is always kind of worrisome, but this one couldn't have went better........use patience and the payoff will be fantastic!

Over the years, I have applied many screen protectors to both the e-Ink version of Kindle and the Fire. While most of the experiences have been favorable, and some of them not-so-good, I will have to say this is one of the worst experiences I have had with a screen protector.

Part of the dissatisfaction comes from the fact the product is poorly packaged: the two screen protectors are in-between a folded and very thin piece of cardboard that gets damaged and bent during shipping. If the screen protector's packaging gets damaged and / or bent during shipping, the screen protector could possibly get damaged or bent during shipping. In my case, one of the two protectors in the shipment is worthless. While that is not a reflection on the screen protector itself, if you're going to shell out almost twenty bucks for two screen protectors you should be able to safely receive two screen protectors.

With just one shot to get it right, I lined everything up just right on my new 8.9\\" Fire HDX. The included instructions are in English, Japanese, and Chinese, but the corresponding positions they refer to for the peeling sequence are in what I assumed to be Japanese on the label. That's a problem as I don't speak or read Japanese, but I was able to figure what went where.

Most screen protector packages come with a cleaning cloth (as you don't want to apply a screen protector over dust or existing smudges), but this one did not; before applying any screen protector you need to clean the screen. Most screen protector packages also come with a straight-edge so you can smooth out the bubbles but this one did not have one, either. Despite my best efforts, and about 15 minutes of pushing with a straight edge, there are four bubbles right in the middle of the reading screen that just won't go away. That makes this screen protector worthless as the bubbles are very distracting. Seeing as how the second one arrived D.O.A., I'm out of luck. Granted, all of these issues may be a function of bad product packaging that makes their product defective due to the bends mentioned above.

To add insult to injury, while the product description says it has \\"fingerprint resistant coating to enhance experience) there are already fingerprint smudges that took a little extra \\"oomph\\" to remove with a cloth I use for cleaning glasses.

With the pain in the neck with the above, there has to be a better product or else everyone will be wasting $20 on this version. I would avoid this one and try to find another brand.ay be a function of bad product packaging that makes their product defective due to the bends mentioned above. Bought this as a gift for my wife's birthday.  Had shopped around and read reviews of all the other e-readers, and for what the wife would want this was it, strictly books.  Or so I thought.  She discovered Scrabble on Kindle and achieved a whole new level of addiction!  Good thing she is a dedicated house keeper because every other minute seems dedicated to either reading books or playing Scrabble!  I am 67 years old and this is the most astounding dead on target gift I have ever bought.  Yeah Baby!!    Connection to our DSL wireless modem was intimidating, (would not hook up), but the phone company people were able to walk her through getting it to work.  Since then she has used the Kindle wirelessly in Walmart's parking lot, and in McDonalds no problem.  So far there have been no operating problems whatsoever.    Battery life seems pretty good, but staying hooked up to the internet is not necessary and soaks up battery power uselessly, (she has to remember to disconnect).  Selection of books is amazing, and the number of books available for free or 99¢ is great, (saves a ton of money).    We will be using this on our upcoming two week trip across country and we will both be able to enjoy it while riding shotgun.  Oh, the car power cord for our GPS works with the Kindle, who knew!

I bought a 14z with similar specs in April 2013. It was on a really good sale, but all they had available was refurbished machines. I had bought other refurb items before and assumed it was a safe buy. That was my first mistake. As soon as it was delivered, I started having issues. Something was wrong with the monitor and the backlight would not stay on, so I would always have a dim screen. I checked all my settings to make sure I was doing everything correctly. I called tech support, and they walked me through a few steps to ensure that my settings were correct. They concluded that something was broken and sent a tech to come fix it. Tech didn't fix the issue. I went through this a couple more time before Dell told me to send it back to them and they would fix it. When I got it back, my monitor worked, but I was missing a component I had paid for and that I had before I sent the machine back into Dell. I called Tech Support, and they called me a liar before they agreed to send a tech out to replace the missing component. At one point I had to reinstall Windows (I forget what issue prompted this).

Earlier this week, I had a new issue. My laptop would stop charging when connected to the power cable. I borrowed a friend's power cable from another Dell laptop, and the issue persisted. I called Tech Support yet again (I have lost count of the number of times I have had to call them for this machine), and they would only help if I paid $358 to replace the motherboard. They came to this conclusion with only minimal troubleshooting. I complained that I could almost buy a comparable laptop for that money, and the finally agreed to only charge my $179 to fix it. I told them that I could buy a new tablet for that price with almost the same functionality as this machine. They would not budge. I asked if they were essentially telling me that I had bought a defective product, and they agreed to this statement. Because my machine was 2 months out of warranty, they would not help me, despite the numerous issues I have had and that are logged in Dell's records. They told me that "parts can go bad at any time" to justify the huge cost.

Bottom line: this is a defective machine. Dell refuses to help customers who have bought machines with a history of breaking.

However, when the machine worked, it was amazing. I was lucky enough to be able to buy a machine with Windows 7, so I never had any of the issues with Windows 8. I installed the OS to the SSD, and boot time is under 10 seconds. This machine helped me through my senior year of college. It is light, so carrying it in a backpack full of books added minimal weight. The screen is on the smaller side, but I prefer that for laptops. The battery is not easily removable because it is placed in the laptops innards beneath the keyboard. Only the RAM is easily accessible. This machine is not really capable of any kind of serious gaming, but if all you need is a small machine for web browsing and word processing, this is a great machine, when it works. Every time you call customer support/tech support, you have to talk to some one from India. Half the people I talked to I could not understand and had to ask to be transferred to some one else.

With the issues I have had with this machine and other Dell machines in the past, I will never buy another Dell.

I purchased this router a few days ago. I received V8.4 and googled around to see which DD-WRT build date would work. Apparently no one has tried any build date past July 2013, in fears of bricking it.

I decided I'd try the latest build from Dec 24, 2013, and it worked. Go to the DD-WRT website, then search the router database. Here's what you need:

12-24-2013-r23204 › tplink_tl-wr841ndv8 > factory-to-ddwrt.bin (If you're upgrading from the factory firmware, you only need the factory-to-ddwrt.bin file)

You can also flash back to factory firmware (I did so just for testing purposes). To do this, Google "Files for reverting from DD-WRT to STOCK FIRMWARE". Signup and download the file for TP-Link WR841N/ND v8.x

I uploaded a picture to Amazon showing the latest build.

I have to unplug it just to get past a certain point in our BIOS. I've had no problems with other USB devices at all and the available BIOS updates for my motherboard (GA-7S748) do not address any USB issues which leads me to believe that the unit we have is defective.

NOTE: I don't believe anyone should give a review until the item has been used about a year ( Unless the item stops working in less than that time.)

I was reluctant to do this but here goes.

From the beginning of my computer experience 1989 to 2007 I only used Logetech mice. Specifically the Mouseman. I still have 2 of my 3 original Mousemen, they don't look good but they work very well. I only bought new ones to get extra functionality, not to replace faulty equipment.
From 2008 to 2011 I have owned 4 different "At the time top of the Line" Logitech mice. They lasted from 1 month to 1.5 years before becoming totally unusable. The list is as follows:

M 525: Less than 6 months. (Demagnetizing didn't work) Button failure. (Double clicking, Won't hold)
M 705 Marathon: Less than 1 year. (Demagnetizing didn't work) Button failure, poor tracking..
Anywhere MX: 1.5 years after using the internet to find out how to demagnetize it. After 1.5 years button failure.
Performance MX: Less than 1 month. (Demagnetizing didn't work) Button failure, poor tracking.

All of the above mice initially had poor tracking performance compared to the original Trackman corded mice. I attributed it partially to Microsoft's degrading Windows quality. After this dismal performance record I swore off Logitech and promised myself never to buy another Logitech.
Well, I happened to be at a computer shop that said I shouldn't be having these thoughts and was talked into a cheap Logetech M325 for the sum of $12 full retail.

I was fairly impressed, I got 1.5 years out of that mouse before the buttons wouldn't work like the other four failures. It still had only acceptable tracking from new, but at $12 and 1.5 years with today's dismal manufacturing performance. It was not a bargain but acceptable, so I went against my better judgment and bought another Logitech. An M 510, (because I liked its feature set).
I hada fresh load of Win 7 and a brand new mouse, things looked good except for slightly erratic mouse movement that I attributed to a white table surface and no mouse pad (I now live on a small boat and use the drop down table as a mouse pad).
Well things got worse as weeks went by. Because I liked the M 510 features I scoured the internet again to find fixes for the logitech mouse:
I:
Demagnetized
Adjusted settings.
Downloaded drivers.
Deleted Setpoint.
Installed old versions of Setpoint.
Uninstalled programs.
Laughed at some of the fixes.
Cried at some of the fixes.

The mouse only got worse, until tracking was a joke. The M 510 can no longer be considered an interface device. I guess coupled with the worlds smartest operating system Windows, (Quote from Bill Gates.) It developed a mind of it's own.
Time frame??? How about 1.5 months!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I've called Logitech, they said they never heard of these problems before???????? Huh: The internet is full of Logitech fixes. Logitech's solution: Demagnetize, Demagnetize, Demagnetize , Demagnetize , Demagnetize , Demagnetize.
And if that doesn't work , Demagnetize. As if it could never be a mechanical problem!!
(Guess if you think I'm off Logitech for good this time. My Google search is now Mouse ---logitech. (That's 3 minuses), in case Google doesn't get it the first time)

The only way I can figure Logitech gets all the 5 star reviews is that it found writing reviews a more cost effective method of doing business than "Building a Better Mouse Trap".

(This document was written with the aid of a Radio Shack Gigaware $8 mouse, which I have to have as backup for high end "performance mice".)
I have now given up on feature sets and focused on pure cost criteria and no cordless. At least the cheaper cost factor last longer??

I bought this Linksys WRT55AG at Fry's on my trip to the US then come back Taiwan. Tried to set it up with my ADSL dial-up (dynamic IP) for whole night and still can't get throught the line. Its WAN/PPPOE doesn't work at all.

What happened is it retried PPPOE dialing to the ADSL modem for couple of times; could't establish the line for some unknown reason; then simply RESET itself. Once it reset, the PC used to configure it through Ethernet port runing IE Browser lost connection, then I have to wait for the lengthy bootup sequence before IE browser can connect it, then it failed to establish ADSL dail-up again, then RESET, then .... This happened just like a dead loop until I unpluged the ADSL modem.

After all night failure, I downgraded it to be an AP(instead of an IP sharing router that it supposed to be) and used WinXP to do the PPPOE job, then everything was just fine (even with strong AES security ON, but I just tried G band, not A band). But why you pay extra for this useless \\"router\\" feature?

Its PPPOE protocol definately has bug, and the RESET-system-upon-WAN-failure problem make this bug un-tolerable.

>>Received item 06/12/2014
>>Initially 4 stars

Initial slight issue:
I did the manual setup initially(without using WPS), both the iPod and Nook connected without issues. The Toshiba Tablet sees the SSID, but could not authenticate, until I rebooted the tablet(I think the issue is more with the piece of junk Tosihba tablet than anything else).

Samsung UN60F7100 LED 60\\" Smart TV:
I tried connecting the smart TV to the extender, but to no avail. Until I spoke with D-Link's tech support personnel ID AR004204, he suggested first upgrading the extender's firmware from 1.1something to the latest 1.21B01 RevA2(must search online for it and not rely on the self latest firmware check). They said that some of those TVs will not work, possibly due to different frequencies that those TVs are using, since the DAP-1320 uses 2.4Ghz, while some TVs uses 5.something Ghz. Looking at the specs on my Samsung TV, I was not able to find out what Ghz it was using, but right after updating the firmware on the extender, the TV suddenly started working with the extender. Then I also updated the TV's software to the latest and it's still working just fine. All is well now, happy!

Down stream test with Nook & Android Tablet:
Connecting the devices directly to the router from about 40 ft away, I was getting an average of about 3-5 Mbps. Set the extender to different locations(not the sweet spot) and gotten the same result. Then moved the extender a little closer to the router at less than 40 ft(finding the sweet spot), now the devices are getting an average of 12Mbps, even at 40 ft away.

Conclusion:
Maybe a little confusing to setup at first, but once you figure out that sweet spot, it's all good. One thing you need to know, is that once you connect your device to the extender, it's gonna get the transmission strength from the extender and not the router(e.g. If you are connected to a router that is a few feet away from the device, you obviously will get better reception, but because you are now connected to the extender that is further away, the reception is not as good, but that is the compromise of being more versatile with your device at different distances. Or, just switch between the different SSID, depending on where you are going to be at).

I know what needs to be improved to make an ultimate product, but I need to be paid as an high end CEO with a golden parachute before I can give my advice.

>>UPDATE 6/16/2014

The android tablet sees the SSID, but just could not connect to it, even after rebooting the tablet. I had to unplug and plug the extender back in to the outlet to make it work again. I've read other reviewers having similar issues. So far, as long as it does not happen too frequently, it's all good.

>>UPDATE 6/18/2014
>>Downgraded to 1 star

Why? Mainly the portable Wi-Fi devices will see this SSID with strong signal and when trying to connect to it, it just won't and will automatically switch back to the previous connected SSID. I had to unplug the DAP1320 AGAIN to make it work, now this is just happening a little to frequently. Returning it and getting a different brand.vice, you obviously will get better reception, but because you are now connected to the extender that is further away, the reception is not as good, but that is the compromise of being more versatile with your device at different distances. At first I was not sure that a cheap switch could do such a good job, (I got mine on sale for around $30). I have had it now for a number of months and have not needed to reset it. Unlike a lot of other switches this one is wall mountable (screws are not included but most standard screws will work) which makes my install look so much better. I was able to get very speed over old beat up cat5e cable, I have recently rewired my house with cat6 but have yet to preform a speed test. I plan on buying another TREND network soon to expand my network.

Somethings to note and explain if people don't know them:

TRENDnet makes two different 8 port Gigabit switches, one with a power supply built in and the other with a power adapter. Both seem to get good reviews and don't seem to have other differences so go with whatever is cheaper at the time you buy. The power adapter one is a 90degree angel one so for most strip plugs it will not take up more than one space.

This is a switch not a router, I have noticed in some reviews some people have left bad reviews because of this. The difference between a switch and router is that a router shares the internet connection with multiple computers and in the case of most home networks assigns the IP addresses. This device is used to expand the network. This device will provide gigabit speeds between devices plugged into it even if the router it is plugged into is not a gigabit router.

The \\"green\\" means that it saves energy by only using the power needed on each port. A standard non green switch will send full power out over each port (enough for the max of a 100m cable run) where a green switch like this one will only send out the power needed for the length of the cable.

Gigabit Ethernet \\"requires\\" at least Cat5e cable and uses all 4 pares of the cable (as opposed to only 2 with 10/100 Ethernet), you can try it on something else but it may not work right.

This switch is what is known in the IT field as a \\"dumb\\" switch, meaning that it is plug and play and there is no configuration necessary, if you don't know the difference between a \\"dumb\\" and a \\"smart\\" switch it is safe to say that what you need is a \\"dumb\\" switch and this is a good choice.

UPDATE ON July 29, 2014
Switch is still running fine. Have not had any issues with it. I have also found out although cheep it has more memory than most name brands(close second to the Netgear prosafe). People have successfully reported this switch working with AT&T Uverse set top boxes.

When you're the only iPhone user in your family and your charger decides to stop working, things can get a little nightmarish.

I had seen this product before all of the angry reviews on Amazon and most of them were glowing. My Apple charger had gotten the turtleneck of doom and I wanted to get a new charger that wasn't expensive and didn't have a 1.5 star rating on the Apple website (which the real Apple charger has). And when I first got this charger, it actually worked really well. My phone charged incredibly fast and I liked the durability of the chord. However, after about three or four months, that's when the madness started to kick in.

It first decided that the only way it would charge is if the dodocool logo wasn't facing up. "Not a problem," I decided. "I'll only put it in that way." After a few weeks, it then further decided that I needed to unplug the USB out of the power adapter, plug it back in, and then plug in my phone--with the dodocool logo facing down, of course. I was starting to get a little annoyed, but I calmly reminded myself that I had indeed spent eight dollars on this thing and it had worked fine before. It was just running into some hiccups.

I was wrong. Absolutely wrong.

It finally stopped working all together unless I played this horrible back-and-forth game of plugging it into the phone, unplugging, turning the cable around, and then plugging it in again. It would soon take about a minute or two for it to connect, but as the days went on, the time extended. I was caught in a mind-numbing plug-in take-out plug-in process that would take over five minutes. And the reason why I've decided to write this review is because tonight I've been trying and begging and pleading and nearly crying over this stupid stupid charger for literally over HALF AN HOUR to connect with my phone. It eventually got to the point where the plugging and re-plugging became muscle memory and I was caught in adrooling daze that when my phone let out that celestial, blessed chime that it had connected that I had already pulled the cable out again. And that had happened to me three times.

Three. Times. Three times I was caught in that stupid loop.

I was about to throw my phone and nearly all of my possessions out the effing window.

My hatred for this charger has increased with every single word I type. So please. Please, I beg you, do not buy this charger. It has put me through so much pain and misery, and I have nearly been drawn to tears because of this charger from the very center of hell.

The Kindle DX (latest generation as of Sept. 2010) is as good as advertised.  I bought it for business, with the added benefit of use for my evening reading.  The larger size is perfect for using it to review business documents, which are easily loaded into the DX as PDF files.  Spreadsheets, contracts, scanned notes of prior meetings, financial statements are all useful items to carry in the Kindle to meetings or to review on the train or at home.      As for personal use, the weight is fine and certainly easier to hold than a book, with no likelihood of losing your place when you fall asleep.  The internet accessibility at no monthly cost is a real plus.  The download of books is super fast.  The battery life is also as advertised, in fact all features work very well.  The screen is comfortably readable in all lighting situations.  I am most satisfied, as the Kindle DX's reasonable cost has provided what I need.  Other optional readers /pseudo computers may provide other \\"STUFF\\", but at a higher cost and usually are coupled with internet connect charges ongoing over time; something very annoying to a person who likes to buy without locking in ongoing costs.  Thanks Amazon for developing a great product.

Not to mention my data!    This was the answer to a decades old problem that I've had. Two operating systems with corresponding data drives - one motherboard (computer). I don't mind dual booting operating systems, but there can be host of issues that I'd rather not deal with. Both Linux and Windows residing on the same computer and never the two shall meet. Also, I'm able to shut down any cold storage hard drives I'm not using, protecting my data and saving a bit of power at the same time. Installation was simple. Cable management can be a bit much with a case already full of cables, but I made it work. It's simplistic and very functional. The only downside for me was a non functioning LED on the number 3. The connection itself still works and I'm fine with it. That's the reason for the 4 stars.

Okay, I must start out by saying I loved this product. I particularly liked the e-ink display. I still would have liked it, if it had continued to work.  To give everyone some background, I purchased my kindle in late November 2010. About mid June 2011, the screen froze and had a lot of lines. Reset didn't work. I contacted Amazon customer service and they promptly replaced the kindle with a \\"new\\" one. I think they were aware of this problem. I was pretty happy at that time that the problem was resolved. I am not a heavy user (I read about 25-50 pages a week) and I kept my kindle(s) protected in a cover. About a week ago, the replacement kindle that Amazon sent me had the same issue with lines in the screen. When I filled out a form to chat to customer service person, \\"lines in kindle\\" is listed as one of the options for type of problem. This convinced me that Amazon is well aware of this issue with this type of kindle.  The representative who chatted with me, Jason, was very helpful in explaining that there is nothing he could do now that warranty has expired which was 1 yr based on initial purchase date of Nov 2010. He offered us an replacement option for which we would have to pay $65+shipping. I didn't ask how much the shipping was. He implied that the kindle must have been dropped or something to cause such failures. There were couple of issues with the deal. First, I didn't want to get another same kind of kindle only to have it fail again. Also, amazon would not offer any credit towards purchase of other kindle models (touch, fire etc). Second, to make matters worse, we would only get 90 days warranty on the kindle this time since it is considered a \\"replacement/extended warranty\\" deal. Finally, they took pity on me and offered $30 Amazon bookstore credit (which cannot be used for general purchases from Amazon). Now, why would I need that without an e-reader?  While I dont blame Amazon's service, I blame them for their inferior product. I am tired of electronics that dont even last an year. Shame on you Amazon. Enough with the Kindle. I am in the market for an android tablet now.

I bought this to use as a repeater to exend the range of my wireless network because my router is all the way at one end of my house.  The device was fairly easy to set up and everything appeared fine at first.  I used my tablet to set it up and it connected ok, but it seemed slow.  I did a speed test and it tested at less than half the speed my network normally runs at.  Then I took it outside to test the range.  Somehow, it actually reduced the range of my network.  I tried the same with 2 phones and a laptop and got similar results: reduced range and very poor speeds.  That was all the evidence I needed to box it back up and return it.  I don't know if I just got a lemon or what, but I can't recommend it based on my experience.

When a storm fried my ethernet port, the Mac forums I researched said you'd have to replace the motherboard to fix it. That, of course, would mean a ridiculous amount of money.

Fortunately, I found an article that recommended this under-$30 device. To make it work with Mac OSX, it explained, you'd just need to download the free Pegasus USB-to-Ethernet driver (found at sourceforge, among others).

Well, I got it today, plugged it in, and at first it didn't pull up an IP address. I called my ISP and went through a couple of simple steps -- something involving a manual setting in my network -- and soon up popped those beautiful IP address numbers. Who knows -- it might have just taken the modem a minute to figure it out and the settings I fiddled with might not have done anything. Point is, it worked with minor hassle.

What a relief! Great product at a great price. (Would be even better if it came with the Mac software/driver - we're not Untouchable Fringe People, you know, Belkin!) ;)

***ADDENDUM: When I upgraded to OS 10.5.6 several months later, the adapter continued to work for a couple of weeks and then it got futzy. It wouldn't work until I unplugged it and replugged it in -- every time I turned the computer on, I'd have to do this.

I was going to buy a replacement but first searched the net to see if this had happened to anyone else. I'm glad I did -- it turns out it *was* related to the upgrade, and a fix was available in the Apple support/discussion forums.

Again, Belkin: Please make your great product more Mac-friendly! One shouldn't have to jerryrig the software to get it to work.

I purchased this item due to the item being listed under HP Part No. C7845A, which is the part number HP lists for 32MB modules for my LaserJet 2200d. This item was purchased by third-party seller OEMPCWorld, and the item received was a generic 100-pin 32MB PC133 module. Either the parts received were DOA, or the printer is not compatible with the faster PC133 modules (the printer specification lists the requirement as a 100-pin PC100 Non-ECC module).

Either way, be aware of incompatibilities with generic modules and HP printers. I have since purchased what was listed as a compatible PNY PC100 module from another seller, and received HP OEM modules, which worked without issue.
