On the overall, I like my tablet. It is rugged, the screen is easy to see and it lasts a long time on a battery charge.

However there are a large number of major issues that one does not usually worry about initially on this type of item. The reason being that they usually get fixed by firmware updates.
To put it bluntly, almost a year of not being able to hold a wifi connection, having to reconnect Bluetooth on a regular basis (Others have these issues as well)
There is a seriously long list of issues, most all could be addressed by fixes in the firmware. When I called Samsung I was told that I would have to mail it into a service center to have a tech look at it. If they found something covered under warranty, I would not be charged. And NO, known issues with the firmware would not be considered covered since Samsung intended to release an update at some unspecified date in the future.

Also, Samsung does not provide a copy of the existing firmware. What this means is that if you are trying to develop applications for Android or you install an application that is not from this Google Store and it corrupts your Operating System; you are now the proud owner of a brick. I don't was to say it is a standard to provide a copy of the ROM/Firmware so you can reload it after a crash, but all other Android Device manufacturers do it.

Now Samsung has released the Galaxy 2, so any hope that they may some day fix the firmware or even provide support for the Galaxy '1', are pretty well squashed.

After 6 months this cover has proven to be a complete waste of money. I dont really use my macbook, it's strictly for travel and 90% of the time I use my ipad instead. So, you can imagine my dismay when I pull my macbook air out of my protective case logic sleeve and find the corners of the moshi protector cracked, chipped and splitting apart.

I contacted Moshi since it's been almost 6 months and they offer a free lifetime replacement warranty. I explain the situaiton and wait for a reply. Several days later I eventually get a response from a generic CSR rep telling me I need to email them photos of the cracking and a copy of my reciept. A few days later they email me and tell me they are willing to replace the cover but I have to break the exsisting cover in half and send them pictures of it broken with my name writen on a piece of paper in the picture. Only then will they send me a replacement that of which they cannot garuntee that the cracking wont happen on the new cover.

Even though I dont use the laptop that often I am unwilling to have it unprotected. I contacted moshi again and they told me I could pay for a second iglaze cover from their website and once I recieve it take pictures of the original one, email them in and they will refund my money.

No go. The process in dealing with their customer service department is stricly and ONLY handled via email. There is no phone number to get immediate help or assistance. I contacted amazon and was able to get an exception to return this much too overpriced cover. Apparently you don't \\"always\\" get what you pay for. I compared my $60 moshi cover againt my frined $15 generic amazon cover and asside from the cheap folding feet on the amazon cover the quality was nearly the same.

This cover is going back and I will avoid all moshi products in the future. What you are paying for is a name, not quality and if their business practices continue in their current direction the name soon will not be worth much either.

maybe I am just used to more complete and versatile PC based laptops, but the purpose of a dock is not to block ports but provide an island of them.

at any rate, this is a compromise solution for a compromised product on a compromised OS. You may imagine, i am not a fan and this is just a tool. i got it for my wife because she asked for one. little did we know that the great apps available did not possess the same features as their PC counterparts, they have less. heaven forbid the creative are burdened with options and choices. it is a form of censorship, some think all great art comes from censorship. i am rambling but who cares. there is more to the failings of the dock than the dock itself.

live and learn. when my. wife finally tires of the MBP, i will retask it with a real OS and hopefully, capable apps that let me create and work rather than defining how I am able to be creative.

i am certain I will be flamed over this but to those faithful who will excoriate me, you are showing signs of being in a cult, and not the good signs either like dressing for comicon.

The \\"Henge Dock\\" is actually nothing but a piece of plastic. You've essentially just paid $65 for a custom piece of plastic, two USB cords, a firewire cord, an audio cord, an ethernet cord and 7 screws. That's it. That's all you bought. For the record, a usb cord is like $3x2 = 6, firewire $5, audio free (I'm not joking they typically just charge you for shipping and make money that way), and ethernet cord is what a dollar? I'll let you do the math, but that's a lot of money for some plastic. And better yet if you buy the standard minidisplay port cord online, it doesn't fit in the henge dock because the square in the bottom is too small. I could understand if this thing were $25 and at Wal Mart, but for $65 it's a hulking pile of crap.

I am not one to usually bash something, or really even write a review about an item. However, I feel really compelled to say something about this mouse and keyboard combo set. I have had a few issues with it.

Cons:
1st: The mouse is practically unusable. It will go in and out of connection like the batteries are dying. This happens while the mouse is less than 2 feet away from the receiver. I have tried 3 sets of batteries, with the same effect.

2nd: The Keyboard has a similar issue of kind of fading in and out of communication. There is also a fairly noticeable delay while using the keyboard. If you are just using it for basic typing you cannot tell it that bad; but if you are using the keyboard to control something that is time sensitive, like a game or using it as a midi keyboard controller, you will defiantly see it.

3rd: I tested the Mouse and Keyboard on 3 different computers, 2 running Windows 7 and 1 running Windows 8. The negative effects seemed to happen on each of them.

4th: To give it the benefit of a doubt, I thought maybe I need to go download the drivers from the site. Hah! Good luck finding them on the site. I could locate my product, but there was nothing about a driver anywhere! All I could find was a paragraph stating that “most” of their products did not need drivers and that your operating system should have one built in for it. Well, that really is true, it works with the built in drivers, horribly… but works. Note: The set did come with a disk, that might of had drivers on it; but me in my infinite supply of stupidity through it away with the box. meh...

Pros:
Keyboard: I will say that the keyboard feels really great while typing. If you are doing nothing more than typing a letter, email, regular style office work, etc, the thing works great.

Mouse: I really have nothing good to say about the mouse. I trashed it the 2nd day of use.

Note: I did not test the keyboard with MAC or Linux, might later and update this thing.

In Conclusion:
If I had it to do over again, I would not have purchased this item. Howbeit, mine could just be a bad one and others might work better; but after seeing how worthless their site was, I don’t think I will buy any more of their products.keyboard with MAC or Linux, might later and update this thing.

In Conclusion:
If I had it to do over again, I would not have purchased this item. Howbeit, mine could just be a bad one and others might work better; but after seeing how worthless their site was, I don’t think I will buy any more of their products.

Having researched netbooks since January 2009, I had narrowed down my choice to Asus 1000HE due to battery life, since most netbook features are similar.  Recently Asus released the 1005HA and I was certain that was going to be my next purchase since it was improved over the 1000HE.  I decided to check out Acer (blah), MSI(blah), HP/Compaq(blah), Samsung and Toshiba as well.    My main requirement was a good size keyboard, solid build, and great battery life.  Toshiba NB205 excelled at all my requirements.  I read every review I could find and even have google alerts set to Toshiba NB205.  Office Depots have this netbook on display.  Definitely visit your local store and try it out before you buy it.  Then goto Best Buy to try out other selections and order it from Amazon.com.    Some key points:    1. Keyboard - great size, the keys are similar to the current gen apple laptops.  I am typing this review on the NB205 so still getting used to it.  The only strange thing is the ~ key sits to the left of the space bar instead of the ALT key.  The ALT key is to the left of the ~ key.    2. Build - VERY solidly built netbook.  Does not feel flimsy like all the other ones I have seen.  I have a Dell XPS 1530 which I thought had a super solid build, this Toshiba NB205 is just as solid.  Construction and design are great.  I did not like the glossy covers and fingerprint magnet designs of the other netbooks.  NB205 has a matte cover and texture to it that does not attact ANY fingerprints.    3. Battery life - Reviews tested well and better than the Asus 1000HE.  Been using it for 1 hour and says 90% battery life after installing updates and downloading.    4. Trackpad - VERY large and controls well.  Glides smoothly.  No dinky trackpads like other netbooks.  Has 2 separate buttons instead of just one.  The pad is slightly recessed so it's easy to find it by feel.    The ONLY thing I dislike about the laptop is the 6 cell battery sticks out the back about .85 inches.    As for colors, ALL of the NB205 have the silver keyboard, the color difference is only on the screen portion.  I chose the Blue because I liked the color the best.  The White I saw in store looked very close to the silver keyboard color.    I thought about waiting for the ION, but the screens will be almost 12\\" and the battery life will be worse.  Also, the cost difference.  I don't need a HDMI output either.

Crapped out after a year. I purchased this for my phone and it worked really well at first, but then after about a year, it just totally died on me. I lost photos and other files and could not recover them. Other posts talk about fakes, but I'm pretty sure this one was purchased directly from Amazon and not a seller.

TL;DR version: Don't buy this. Ever. I'd give it 0 stars if I could.    Full review:  I needed a laptop because I was starting college, so after days of internet searching my dad and I settled on this laptop. Oh how I wish we hadn't.    What seemed good when this was compared to other laptops:   - Price (though this was only because it was on sale, as it is now it is DEFINITELY not worth the nearly $700 it's charging)   - RAM (I needed at least 6GB to work well with the Adobe programs I use like Photoshop)   - Decent hard drive storage   - 24 GB solid state drive   - i5 core was sufficient power for my needs    We were excited for the laptop, but a few months of use have revealed SO many problems.    What's wrong:   - Internet connection is temperamental. The laptop will say there are no networks available when 10 minutes later it will miraculously find 5. When there are networks detected it will only sometimes connect, other times when it says it's already connected it actually won't be so the page just keeps loading and loading. When it works the speed is average.   - Keyboard does have a bit of flex, it was weird at first but not that big a deal.   - There's no way this battery is 6 hours.   - The laptop does not feel very sturdy.   - The touch pad is screwed up. Big time. It'll jump from the top of a 20 page document to the bottom one moment, then make you scroll over and over just to move a few inches down the page. It will keep scrolling when you want it to stop, and has an absolute spazz attack if you have more than one finger resting on it at a time. Sometimes it doesn't respond at all. Seriously an issue.   - The biggest problem is that the laptop selectively shuts down. Whether you close the laptop or not, it's always a gamble when you come back to it (be it 5 minutes or 5 hours later) whether or not the laptop has shut down. I learned the hard way to always exit out of documents when I leave my computer--I lost 150 pages of editing when the laptop unexpectedly shut down and corrupted the file to the point it was unrecoverable. I would guess it decides to shut down 1 out of every 5 times.      Overall, this laptop is not worth the money, especially when it's listed for nearly $700. Get a different laptop.        12/30/14 UPDATE:    I have had this laptop for a little less than a year and a half, and the computer has steadily declined.   - Wifi connect is still spotty at best and disconnects frequently, no matter how good the Wifi signal is.   - Battery life has reduced to about 2 hours.   - Something broke inside the laptop that held the two lower halves together, so when I opened the laptop (lifted the display screen) the lower halves would begin separating. As of now the only thing holding the laptop together is a piece of Avengers duck tape. Literally.   - The screen brightness display got offset from the button controls a long time ago, which I didn't care about enough to change, but recently the display has started to dim to black at random times, forcing me to restart the computer if my random pressing of buttons doesn't turn it back on.   - The computer now selectively shuts down every other time I leave it.

I didn't purchase this wireless headset through Amazon, but I wanted to share my thoughts before I head back to Best Buy and return it (it cost $10 more there too!)

I did some research before buying to learn that I need a USB headset in order to have the mic work on my MacBook. Already wasted $30 on another headset before I learned this fact (with no help from the guy at Staples who assured me it would work).

Anyway... this time I read all the packaging on this Logitech H760 wireless USB headset, and it plainly states that it \\"works with Mac OS\\".

The set up was easy, though if I had to go into System Preferences every time I wanted to use this headset, it would be inconvenient.

I quickly went into Skype (my main reason for buying this headset) and changed the audio prefs to indicate I was using the Logitech headset (which showed up as an option automatically). Called the Skype test number, and once again - the mic does NOT work. Grrrr.

So I went to logitech.com/support as the included guide suggests. Not only is there absolutely NOTHING listed under the troubleshooting FAQ for this product, I also discovered that suddenly my wifi connection had seriously slowed down. Turns out having the USB receiver connected to my MacBook interferes with my wifi connectivity (and yes, I was using the extension as recommended).

Once again, a product that states it works with Mac OS doesn't deliver. There must be a mic'ed headset somewhere that will work with my MacBook. Hearing music, Skype, etc works fine. But the microphones never work.

If anyone reads this and happens to know a headset that will work for me - please comment. Much appreciated :)

Living in a 3-story house has inherent problems for an efficient Wi-Fi hotspot. Hawking has a solid reputaion with its antennas and generally with its product line therefore after reading the reviews here I purchased this range extender. The instructions were easy to follow yet I encountered different installation problems throughout several attempts with the setup wizard. Over the course of 2 weeks of calling the tech support number listed in the provided Quick Guide and getting a busy signal, I located a working number on the Hawking web site. Of course I was connected to a call center in India. Usually, with a little patience, the language barrier can be overcome but the technician I had required me having her repeat everything at least once and often twice or more. After 90 minutes of intence configuration she got me running. Each of my 4 PCs recieved \\"IP conflict\\" errors upon starting which was resolved with Windows \\"Repair\\" function. Unfortunately, this was required each and every time a computer was started. Also, if the router was restarted I had to go through a complete reset of the Hawking extender. This became tedious and the daily time consumtion to keep it working quickly became far more trouble than the signal increase benefits. As the refund window with Amazon approached it was an easy decision to pack it up and return the product.

This silver stylus was Sold by: Amazon.com LLC when I bought it, and it has Targus packaging, has Targus pamphlets/fold-outs included in the packaging, and has about the same price I've bought a previous Targus stylus for. But it's not the same quality - the silver stylus is significantly worse in quality than the original black Targus stylus.

The silver stylus looks exactly the same as it does in the picture. My original black Targus stylus had the metal part that said \\"Targus\\" on it. The silver one doesn't. I knew when I bought it they would be different - I just didn't realize that also meant the quality would also be drastically different. Just FYI, when looking for Targus stylus to buy, pick a stylus that has the \\"Targus\\" on the metal part in the picture.

This silver stylus also doesn't write as smoothly as the black Targus stylus (I stopped using my black one since I had scratched up the tip pretty badly by accident) does. I liked with the original Targus stylus how responsive it was. I didn't need to apply any pressure to write anything on my iPad (I used Notability and Draw Something and both aren't as responsive with the silver stylus). With the silver one, I have to apply a bit of pressure and my hand cramps up after long days in the lecture hall.

Length-wise, my black Targus stylus is longer. They weigh about the same. I didn't measure the exact length, because the length doesn't really bother me at all.

EDIT 7/1/14: It's been a while since I've used the silver \\"Targus\\" stylus. It crapped out after a couple of months (technically ~1 month of heavy use) as my iPad barely responds to it. It also leaves black marks all over the screen and now the tip itself seems to be disintegrating/thinning out without me even using it at all anymore. My previous black Targus as well as other styli I have used have never ever done that, so I brought my 2 star rating down to 1 star. I can still use my old black Targus funnily enough - even though it doesn't work very well any more, but this \\"Targus\\" silver stylus is a piece of over-priced, cheap crap.

Shipping was quick and the product is just as described. I really like all the attention to details in making sure the customer is happy, including a separate email after ordering that included a link to a video of how to properly apply the screen.  Although I've had it for several weeks, I just put the screen on my iPad yesterday. I have to admit, it went on much easier than I had expected. Read the instructions and do just as it says and you should have no trouble! One thing I will recommend when applying...sit the device so the light shines on it from the side to where you can see any dust particles. It's amazing to me how you can clean it and remove all smudges and dust and in a moment's time, a dust particle falls from the sky onto the device. So keep a watch out for that. I had a couple under the skin but used the tape (as recommended) and got them out easily.  Seeing I've only used it with the screen on less than a day, it's hard for me to report on the longevity of the product. It does seem to show prints/smudges the same or maybe even a little more than without a screen, however I'll take the protection over smudges any day.  So far, so good and definitely recommend!

This is a good quality wheel. Overall I would definitely give it five out of five stars. But it is not perfect and there are some idiosyncratic aspects that I have encountered.

I bought this wheel to play GT5, and Midnight Club LA and similar car simulation, driving and racing games on the PS3. It works for PC too but I haven't tried that yet.

Quirky things I have noticed:

*Whenever I first power up the PS3 the G27 does a full calibration by turning all the way to the right and then all the way to the left and then turning back to the right until it centers... but when I start a game (for example GT5) it does the calibration again... but this time it doesn't center... it ends up slightly slanted or crooked. Also, maybe its just my wheel but when the GT5 starts and it first starts to turn to the right to do the calibration thing it \\"shutters/stutters\\"... the rpm lights and the turning motion momentarily freezes and \\"shutters/stutters\\" during calibration, but only when it is turning to the right... and this only happens as GT5 loads, it doesn't happen during the initial calibration when PS3 first powers on....

*The G27 claims to have a \\"push down\\" reversible gear. But I could never get the G27 to reverse with the gears. Also the whole thing can not be \\"pushed down\\"... so I don't understand what they mean by a \\"push down\\" reverse-able gear... you can NOT push the snifter down at all! There is no way to reverse the car using the shifter/gear because it won't even have the grooves to let you put it in reverse! The diagram on the shifter is not how it actually is... I can put the gear in 1, 2, 3, 4, and yes even 5... but the reverse does not work! It seems to be a fake position that doesn't even exists on the G27

*It took me a while to figure out that G27 has to be put as controller #1 in order for it to be recognized and work in games like Midnight Club LA. On the Logitech website they list both the GT5 and MidnightClub LA as fully compatible with the G27 out of the box. This is not entirely true. It is not actually plug and play. At first I thought I got a bad/dud G27 until I had to Google for tech support online and came across forums that said you must put the G27 as controller 1 because it will be recognized in the game... but the thing is if G27 is in controller 1 spot, the ps3 controller itself no longers works in the game, even when I put it on controller 2.... what ends up happening is the ps3 controller becomes useless inside the game itself, meaning I have to use the buttons on the shifter/gear in order to navigate the menus and such in the game... This is annoying and a MAJOR hassle.

*For the Midnight Club LA the G27 wheel is WAY too sensitive and over-corrects too too too much. This makes it almost impossible to accurately and enjoyably play. In GT5 there is option to adjust sensitivity of G27, but in Midnight Club LA you are SOL... Of course on the PC you have the drivers and software and can do what you want with the wheel, but for PS3 it is locked down and especially for games and titles like Midnight Club LA the G27 sensitivity makes it useless and it can't be adjusted.

*The \\"real leather\\" on the wheel feels fake. I'm not saying it is not real leather... it just subjectively feel like synthetic leather... this is not exactly the kind of leather you find in a Lexus or anything...

*There are too many wires with this setup... it is a mess and easily you can trip over yourself or worse someone trips it over and damages your G27... it makes it worse that the wires are so short... if you have a large TV and want to sit back a bit from the TV you run the chance of accidentally pulling the wires out.... not good...

*You really need to get a playseat or similar item for this G27 .. that will end up costing you more than the G27 itself. The attachment devices that comes with the wheel and gear is cheap quality plastic and cannot secure anything at all... I tried to secure it to my table/stand only to have the whole wheel free fall to the carpeted ground 4 feet below... cause the darn plastic attachor thing came unhooked and loose... the wheel is very heavy, so even a free fall of 4 feet could permanently damage it... I'm not sure if mine sustained mechanical damage or not... I ordered playseat with this device but the device came sooner than the seat... so I had tried to mount it to a table but really it doesn't work well at all....

* There is no way to turn off the force feedback in GT5 for the G27. In the options I know it seems like you can turn it off... but in actual races when you hit something or run into rough ground the force feedback comes into full swing.... it is annoying, and it is powerful force feedback that makes you lose control.... especially when you are already drifting and trying to countersteer, the force feedback will make matters worse and cause you to lose concentration and then crash you on purpose.... In GT5 there is NO way to turn force feedback off! This means if you drive on the dirt road it will be impossible to maintain control, might as well use a ps3 controller...

In August, I bought a Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1.  The product itself pretty much rocks.  HOWEVER, I cannot recommend one to anyone because of the support.  More precisely, the incompetence of what little there is.  A few weeks after I bought it, it stopped being able to connect to my pc and transfer files.  It says it's connected, but the pc just tries to install a driver update, and fails to do so.  So I did some research online, and found that there's an updated driver to install.  Finding it on the Samsung page was a major pain.  There are drop-downs in the page that simply don't work, for one thing.  Finally found the driver, downloaded, and it won't install.  It goes into a loop \\"Do you want to upgrade?\\" click Yes, \\"Must uninstall the prior version in order to update.  Do you want to uninstall the prior version?\\" click Yes, animations indicate it is uninstalling, then \\"Do you want to upgrade?\\" (same window as the first one) click Yes, \\"Must uninstall...\\"  No matter how many times I click Yes, restart my computer, et al, it just keeps looping through that.  Found out there's an uninstall utility that can be downloaded.  Downloaded it, ran it, got a message that it was Done.  Tried again.  Same loop.  Manually deleted every folder with Samsung in the name in both Program Files and Program Files (x86).  Tried again.  Same loop.  Manually went through the Windows Registry (after backing it up, of course) and deleted everything I could that had the string \\"samsung\\" in it.  Tried again.  Same loop.  Searched their support pages several times during this process.  No help there.  They seem to recognize that their software is complete junk, but all of their offered solutions result in the same loop.  Can't request support through their online form, because one of the drop-downs is empty, and the form won't let you submit it unless you select something from that drop-down.  Nothing to select, so it's a complete dead end.  Tried calling their support line a few times.  Nomatter when I call, I get \\"all lines are busy, please try again later\\".  Tried e-mailing them for support, but that didn't work either.  Tried asking for help in their support forums.  No replies.  So, I can only transfer files back and forth by uploading them to a cloud drive of one sort of another, or (for small files) by e-mailing them to myself.  The lack of file transfer is merely annoying. I can live with it, but it's certainly a drawback.  The misleading, false, unworkable, incomplete, and just plain junk support, and the software that gets into a loop and can't even exit gracefully, makes me say I can't recommend this product, nor anything else by this company.  Rating: Product 9 of 10  Service: -5 on scale of 1 to 10.

The outer box was pretty beat up and was worried that the monitor was damaged. This package was clearly knocked around a bit. (Will post photos). Luckily, the inside box with the monitor was fine. It was packed pretty well in styrofoam. The monitor is big, it looks like a little HD TV but its sleek, thin and modern looking. You have to connect the small stand but it was easy and no tools needed as there is a screw with a pin built into it.

Turning on the monitor is easy with its buttonless touch. I have mine connected via the dvi cable because my pc didn't have hdmi. The sharpness is really good and the contrast too. It takes a minute to get used to because the monitor is large and your not used to it but in a good way. Games look incredible on this monitor, the clarity and detail really show off what it can do compared to my older hp 19\\" monitor. You definitely notice the difference between LED backlight and the old bulb version. I have it set for the full res of 1920x1080.

I know i said its thin but its so nice to have a thin monitor like this take up less space on my desk. The only not so good thing is that its not VESA which means if you wanted to wall mount or use one of those posable monitor arms on your desk, your out of luck. Most people won't, but I used to use one myself. Being this has such up to date tech i thought that was something basic it should have had.

My games took on a whole new life because there is so much space to use being its 27\\". Everything isn't crammed in like before. Another thing I noticed and its expected is that moving the mouse around takes a bit more because things are further away on the screen.

Lastly, the viewing angle is pretty good for this monitor, I can see it clearly and with no shift in colors when far away and slightly to the sides.

If you need a nice sized monitor and are looking for something thin with high HD resolution with great color and sharpness I really recommend this one. I think its up there with some of the nice HD TV's that are out there.the nice HD TV's that are out there.

I bought a Samsung 840 EVO and I wanted to use this to clone my Ultra Compact PC into the new SSD. Installation was easy, and the product looked good enough. The SSD was immediately recognised by the PC which was all good. But that's as far as the good news go. From that point onwards, I encounter one problem after another:

1) The product gets extremely hot after less than 3 minutes, and it freezes (hangs)
2) During this time, the transfer speed was incredibly slow

I was desperate, so I took the SSD and board out of the casing, turn on the aircon at full blast, and aimed a strong standing fan and blow at the board at full blast, hoping that it will take the heat away. I didn't go far at all. It froze in less than 5 minutes. In the end, here's what I had to do to clone my hard disk - in case anyone should need this workaround:

1) Use Acronis to clone hard disk (250GB) to an intermediary hard disk (normal 2.5" external USD 2.0 hard disk, 500GB)
2) Swap the mSATA SSD in the PC into the new one (500GB)
3) Use Acronis to clone intermediary hard disk into the new Samsung EVO

It works flawlessly.

The cover is lightweight, sturdy, attractive, and it feels good. I love the color and that the Kindle is completely unobscured when in the holder. I am very pleased with the product and definitely recommend it.

UPDATE: 12/20/10:

My Kindle was behaving itself just fine until I put this cover on it. Now, it reboots without warning and for no reason. Why blame this on the cover you ask? When I contacted Amazon.com's Kindle support with my reboot problem, the FIRST question they asked was whether or not I had a cover. You might think that customer service was admitting that the cover is a problem by jumping in with the solution, but you'd be wrong.

When I asked the customer service agent he was *very* cagey about answering. He even got angry with me for asking if the cover was the problem. He kept saying he didn't know if it was the problem. I kept asking why he'd offer to take the cover back if it wasn't. When I asked if I could speak to someone who DID have an answer, he asked me why I wanted to know so badly. Huh? It was a weird and hostile conversation.

Anyway, I loved this cover, but it apparently interferes with the Kindle performance, so clearly it is not worth having. Bummer.

UPDATE: 12/26/10

I thought about it and realized that, if the cover is the problem, it has to be something to do with the metal contact in the hooks of the cover. I just covered them with Scotch tape (a thin layer) and re-inserted my Kindle. This was three days ago. I have had ZERO problems since then. So...I'm again pleased with the cover. I won't change the star rating because I spent money for something I then had to rig with tape. No stars when I have to invent a solution for a thing's design flaws.

I needed better WiFi connectivity in my workshop which is about 200 feet from my house. I like listening to podcasts or running YouTube playlists while I work on cars. It is also incredibly useful to look for maintenance procedures and parts online without hiking back into the house. I've used a homemade high-gain "cantenna" in the past, but my success was spotty. I also wanted my phone and any other WiFi device I bring out to the shop to be fully functional.

I had my doubts about how well this inexpensive device would work, especially since putting it halfway between the workshop and my router would put it in the middle of my yard. So, my intent was to sync it up to my router and park it in my workshop. If it didn't work very well, I knew that it had a standard WiFi antenna port (of the RP-N sort) so I could always plug in a high-gain antenna and point it at my house.

First I brought it into the room where my router was located and synced it up, which was very easy using the WPS function. Then, I brought it out to my workshop and checked signal levels using the Network Signal Info app on my Android phone. At first, I was very disappointed with power levels that appeared unchanged from before I turned the device on. Then, however, I realized that my phone might still be trying to connect directly with the router in the house, rather than going through the extender. So, I shut WiFi off on my phone and restarted it. I did the same on the old desktop computer I keep in the workshop.

Both came back on showing a full set of bars. Naturally, I was close to the extender which showed a strong signal, but was the link between the extender and the router strong? A moment later I was streaming Netflix on my Android phone, and I knew that I had a good strong connection. The computer could also now stream my YouTube playlists without any hiccups. The device works very well and makes a very strong connection with my router!

At the sub-$30 price point, this is an excellent device, and I'd certainly buy it again.very well and makes a very strong connection with my router!

WOW - I love this thing! I've been working with computers for a very long time, and see a lot of gadgets. This thing is just about the best thing since sliced bread and I'll explain why. I use my laptop for most things because I need to be able to take my work with me. However, I also have all sorts of things that connect to it, since I use it like a full-blow workstation. Well all those cables made it such a pain to unhook my laptop and then hook everything back up that I almost never used my laptop the way it was intended. It wasn't practical... until I stumbled across this :) Now, there are only 2 cables the plug into my laptop - the power, and this, via a USB 3.0 cable. That's it. Everything else including the ethernet cable, both monitors (dual display works great), sound, and other devices plug into this little device.

Now, one thing to clarify is that even if your laptop does not inherently come with dual monitor ports, since most commercial models do not, this device *gives* you that capability. The only connection to my PC is the USB 3.0. The Plugable provides both DVI and HDMI monitor connections, that work with your computer of the USB 3.0 link. So the Plugable is providing the dual-monitor capability.

To fully use it, aside from following the minimal instructions, you'll want to change your default sound to go to Plugable, and you'll need to configure your displays by right-clicking your desktop. From there it depends on your OS, but in Windows 7 you'll want to click on "Screen Resolution" and then make sure your displays are set right. For me, display 1 is the laptop's built in display. Display 2 is the DVI, and Display 3 is the HDMI.

This smart repeater (\\"SR\\") finds Wi-Fi signals very well - and does what it says - it repeats an existing Wi-Fi signal on to a new SSID (not the same SSID of the Wi-Fi signal source you are repeating), and offers a second \\"guest\\" SSID that you can use for people whom you don't mind if they are using your network, but you don't want to grant access to your private Wi-Fi SSID (and your computers).
The setup is reasonably simplified by Amped Wireless. But like most networking, it is not trivial when you go beyond the most elementary setups. Suggestion: start with the defaults - it should start working with just minimal effort - such as find your own network SSID that you want to have repeated. Enter the WPA2 (or whatever passcodes you have, if any). Just take the defaults and play with it to get familiar with it.
The obvious things that matter are to ensure you have a good signal available to repeat. Then place the device (per the instructions) and see if you can get the new Wi-Fi signal where you need it.
I've picked up signals easily through walls, but metal walls (such as metal walled pole buildings) attenuate the signal you are receiving. I was pleasantly surprised to find the SR10000 gives a stronger signal than I expected - even through a number of walls to an out building easily 100 feet away.
When I read some of the reviews, I see some people express a lot of frustration. Very understandable - if you are a novice, allow some time to work with the system to get it right. Read the directions carefully and follow them - I found the instructions well developed and very helpful. But then, I have had some network experience years ago - to make me more tolerant with the latest twists on the technology. Patience is a virtue if this is new to you. But I think this device will please most people because it meets their needs to extend or strengthen their Wi-Fi.
[[ASIN:B005UBNGY6 Amped Wireless High Power Wireless-N 600mW Smart Repeater and Range Extender (SR10000)]].

I bought the 8gb pro X2 card, and have run it in several cameras.

It works well at its basic function, uploading to your home wifi network. It does not work at all for its other claimed functions, such as public hotspot or \\"direct mode\\", which is the name eye-fi gives to the ability to upload to a designated laptop ( or even iPad ), which thereafter is supposed to upload to the EyeFi ( Internet ) center via whatever connectivity it has.

We have been in extensive contact with Eye-Fi support, who are well meaning and nice and responsive but wrong.

The problem is, I can already upload photos just fine when I'm at home. It's when I am not at home that I want the eye-fi card to work.

I am no neophyte at this kind of thing ( I work as a software engineer at a major computer company, and have for a long time. I have set up lots of wifi networks and computers and cameras. ) I worked hard at making the Eye-fi card work, because I really wanted it to work for an upcoming trip. I had seen warnings from some fellow engineers that it does not work, but hoped I could find a way around the problems. I can't.

The eye-fi software has simple-looking icons on top of a confused design. Poor user interface throughout. As an example, they call their application \\"Eye-Fi Center\\" and their web portal has the title \\"Eye-Fi Center\\" and the two are not the same, or even similar. You need to configure both; one configures your card and the other configures their server, telling it how to handle any photos it gets from the card. I think Eye-Fi is intentionally glossing over the complexity of what is underneath, which would be fine if it all worked. But it doesn't.

Customer service assures you that if you only do such and so, it will work. We have spent easily 20 hours trying to make it work, but its basic function is missing. For instance, it cannot navigate the splash screen at a McDonalds wifi hotspot. Therefore it cannot use its \\"hotspot\\" feature, which is supposed to automatically upload the photos you take. Surprisingly, it also cannot handle adding a specific McDonalds wifi network as a \\"private network\\" as it calls them, or a known network, because even the login software cannot handle a splash screen. And even more amazingly, if you enable \\"direct mode\\" and take your laptop along and have the camera right next to your laptop which is right next to your Egg McMuffin, it STILL does not work. Nor does it tell you why. What does finally work is directly inserting the card to your laptop. The same thing you would have to do with a standard card. But it demands the Eye-fi specific USB reader, and it uploads to the Eye-Fi center, which promises to delete your photos in 7 days. Not a terrific deal as far as I can see. And it will take you a long time and a lot of glib assurances and \\"please take 5 photos and upload the log file and we will get back to you\\" sort of interactions, which take time but don't end up helping. They are nice folks, they are trying to help, they want it to work, but unfortunately it does not work.

If you really want something highly automated for your home or other standard existing wifi network, it works great. If you want to be able to upload photos when you are traveling, for the time being you are out of luck. Me too!

If the game has a mic boost then most the time people can hear me in game but some games don't have the option. Other then the mic everything else is great and i would recommend this.

I purchased this product because my Nvidia GTX 260 kept getting extremely hot after several hours of gameplay. This, by far, was the WORST product that I have ever purchased on Amazon. The cooler comes poorly packaged in a cheap plastic box, and the instructions are very minimal, not fully explaining how to install the product. The cooler comes with a large metal heatsink for the gpu, a plate with insulation for the right half of the video card, and small heatsink tiles that you're supposed to put over the rest of the IC chips.     There is Nothing that restrains the heatsink tiles from falling off. They come with a thin thermal layer pad on the back which is supposed to act as an adhesive, but barely stuck to the chips. I literally struggles for several hours trying to keep the heatsink tiles on while replacing the video card into my pc.     After starting my pc, the Video Card quickly overheated and my pc kept crashing after every restart. Even after removing the new heatsink, my video card wouldn't work, so I had to return it for an RMA, which was rejected. Now I'm left with a heatsink that I can't use or sell, and a video card that doesn't work. I would give it a 0 out of 5 if possible, and strongly recommend any customer browsing this product NOT to buy it, as it will end up being a pure waste of money.

Wow! These modules not only look cool but fully deliver on performance too! DO NOT purchase these unless you are or have upgraded to a 64-bit operating system because the 32-bit systems will only read and USE up to 4 gigs of RAM.     My system: Windows 7 Ultimate 64-bit  Asus P5N-D 750i SLI  Intel Core 2 Duo E8400 3.00 GHz  8GB Corsair XMS2 PC2-6400DHX 800MHz DDR2 Dual Channel RAM  2 x nVidia 8600GT graphics SLI mode  2 x SATA 2 300GB Disks  2 x 2TB Fantom Drives Mega Disks (triple interface eSATA, USB Firewire) external storage drives.      I was running XP 32-bit with 4GB of Kingston RAM.  I have not updated my BIOS in years.   The transformation to win7 64-bit was flawless.  My motherboard with its outdated BIOS detected the new RAM upon 1st Boot with no need to configure anything.  Performance increase was through the roof!  If you do things such as video editing I strongly suggest this memory upgrade (if your specific system is compatible).  The compatibility document from Asus has not been updated in some time so I wasn't sure if these would work.  I suggest going directly to Crucials' website where the RAM Guy has tested tons of boards and modules. Type your board in and see what's been tested on it.    Also, I paid for next day delivery. Ordered it in the afternoon and before noon the next day I had them. Tip of the hat to Amazon who has yet to let me down.

I would point out a contrasting situation: My Seagate drive had a problem, and their website analyzed the drive online, in real-time, and issued an RMA on the spot. These OCZ drives are cheap, but you're wasting your money. Buy Intel, Corsair, something from a REPUTABLE company, but DO NOT BUY OCZ ANYTHING.

By recommendation from a friend, I came upon this motherboard for my first PC build.  From what I have seen on the internet, I thought that MSI was a good brand that built quality motherboards that were "Military Class."  How I was wrong.  Installation went nice for a first time PC builder like myself.  However, during the installation of Windows 7, I encountered a problem when the computer had to reboot.  The monitor would enter sleep mode, but the actual computer would stay on.  It would then require a manual shut down and a manual push of the power button.  Since this was prior to any software being installed on the computer, I had reason to  believe that it was the motherboard.  Through further research on the internet, I found out that another person on the internet had the EXACT same problem on the EXACT same motherboard.  This person managed to solve the problem by simply purchasing a different motherboard.  After that I have returned this product.  If anyone with knowledge on this or has experienced a similar problem, I am welcome to comments.

This computer appeared to be a good deal. I wanted to take the 2TB data hard drive out of my wife's computer and put it into this computer. There are 2 extra SATA data jacks and 2 extra SATA power connectors.

I tried to find a place to mount the drive in this spacious tower but there are zero drive mounts. I contacted HP technical support thinking that they could help me. I asked where the mounts are and he told me that there are no mounts. He suggested to connect the drive and leave it loose inside the case. I told him that this is not safe and not an option. Imagine a loose drive banging around shorting things out and HP having to repair it for free! They need to retrain their CSRs!

I asked if I can purchase an extra drive bracket. He sent me a link to the bill of material for the machine. I asked where the extra drive mount is in the list. He said that they don't have one. What was the point of him sending the list and wasting my time? I asked what can I do. He suggested to put it loose in the case. I told him that is not an option.

After asking for other options, he suggested mounting it external using USB. I told him that I wanted SATA speeds not USB speeds. Again for a third time, he suggested to put it loose in the case.

I went to a local computer store. I asked if they had any drive brackets that I can use to mount the drive. He said that HP sucks for this very reason. They would like to sell me a solution but there is nothing they can do.

I went to another local computer store. They suggested using velcro to stick the drive to the bottom of the case. Okay, I was finally on-board with this less than optimal solution. I bought the velcro and started to mount it but stopped when I realized that the SATA power connector is too short. DARN!

I went to a local computer store. I asked for a SATA Y-Power cable about 12 inches long to reach the bottom of the case. He said thatI was the very first person to ask for that. He said that they don't have that cable only a Molex to SATA power cable. That won't work because it does not have the Molex connectors. They suggested swapping the power supplies from my wife's old machine into the new machine. I just bought a brand new machine and now I need to put an old power supply in it. UGH!!! I attempted to do this but then realized that due to the placement of the drives in the HP case, the extra connector won't reach from the C: down to the old D:.

I am very frustrated. I bought a tower so that I can put a data hard drive in it but this has been a complete screw up on HP's part. I don't know what to do. It's too late now to return this box.

I bought this item in March of 2015, and by the end of April 2015, there was a clicking sound when you plugged it in, and it didn't work. I have never had a hard drive even close to that quickly before. What a piece of garbage.

I bought this product in early July 2010. I was a little concerned because the adapter itself did seem sort of fragile, but I initially had no problems with its operation. Recently the adapter has become a little loose and will disconnect if it's touched the right way, but in general the performance wasn't greatly affected by this. Over the past two days the adapter has stopped working. My computer detects that it is connected, but the adapter will not connect to any network, and the blue indicator light flashes for a few seconds then turns off. I know this isn't related to the other issue because it will continue to do this even when I hold it in place. When I contacted customer support they informed me that the product was still under warranty, but in order to get it replaced I would need to go through troubleshooting first. This sounds fine until they tell you that if the product is more than 90 days old, you have to pay $38 to go through troubleshooting! Why should I pay money to get the product which is STILL UNDER WARRANTY replaced?! Needless to say I am absolutely outraged, and I would not recommend that anyone buy this product or any other Netgear product.

The excellant cooling properties of this product have been covered extensively in other reviews. What I wish to add is that I am astounded by the ergonomic benefits of having your laptop raised up on a pedestal of this type. We gave my 8 year old a kindle fire hd for christmas and i searched everywhere for a heavy duty case to protect the kindle. But i couldnt find one before christmas. I see now ( few days after christmas) there is one. But i didnt want to give her this with out some type of case on it, so i went with this one in pink. The plan was to later buy a heavy duty case when one was made. But i think we are just going to let her use this one and not worry with a heavy duty case. Its a very well made case. Altnough it wont really add the level of protection we really wanted with heavy duty case, it will protect from scraches and light bumps. I was worried how well the kindle would be held in place with case because the pictures appear there isnt much holding the kindle in there, but it holds the kindle so well its actually a bit tough to get the kindle out of it. So that is not an issue at all and it leaves the screen of the kindle uncovered totally for the best viewing experience. Im pleased by small things in life, but a feature i love it the kindle name in the case at the opening. Its a neat little feature. My daughter really wanted the KINDLE and not another tablet so i was happy to give her a case with that name proudly displayed on the front, seeing is how these are not things we buy for our kids often with that kinda price tag. I wanted to go all out. Another feature that is PERFECT for us is the slle/ wake feature. For an 8 year old she would never remember to turn the thing off so to be able to just flip it open or shut and it turn it off or on is perfect. The buttons on the kindle are very flush to the device so this case actually makes it easier to feel for volume buttons which made it a lot easier for her to find the controls. The charging outlets and everything are great because you can charge the device with the cover shut. The only drawback as others have mentioned is you have to find the right headphones to fit in the headphone jack. We bought kidzgear headphones and they do not work with this case. She kept taking the case off ( which she needed help with) to plug in her headphones. So she tried apple 's earbuds and they fit great with the case no problem so she just uses those with her kindle. Her grandfather offered to drill the hole bigger so she could use a larger selection of headphone but i hate to mess with the case that way, but we will see if tbe earbuds start annoying her we may take him up on his offer. But overall this is a great case that will offer a decent amount of protection and looks great.

I have been using Thinkpads almost every day of my life since August 1999. I started with the Thinkpad 600e, then the T30, then the T41, then the x61 tablet, and now I have an x220 tablet. I have owned docking stations for 3 of them. I'm a pretty loyal Thinkpad customer. I have a lot of experience with Thinkpad equipment, and my current and last Thinkpads were Lenovo-branded.

I ordered this AC adapter because it appears in the picture to be a genuine Lenovo Thinkpad adapter. It does not behave like any OEM Thinkpad power adapter I have ever used. I received it yesterday (very, very fast shipping) and started using it today. When I plugged it into the wall, it sparked. That has very rarely happened other Thinkpad adapters I've used, and usually due to international travel. I didn't think too much of it though.

I only got my laptop up to 80% charge when I smell this horrible smell: it smelled like burning fish! I started worrying that my oven is on fire, so I got up to check on it and my foot brushed against the transformer on this power adapter. Burning. Hot. The smell is coming from the adapter! And feeling the cable on it, it almost feels melty. Not good. I pulled the plug from the wall and filed for a return right away.

Save yourself the time and trouble and don't bother with this. The one from Lenovo is twice the price and it's worth every penny of not having the worry of burning your house down!

I see a lot of reviews talking about the need to have 20 inches of space away from electronic devices for the base. Don't be scared. The manual is wrong. It's actually only 8 inches - 20 centimeters. The in/cm values are switched in the illustration. I'm surprised so few people noticed this error since 8cm would be a whole lot less than 20 inches.
Other than that, I fully agree with most of the reviews. This is a fantastic mouse - great fit, great response, and I even prefer the weight of it over my old Intellimouse Explorer. The only problems I've had have been with the MouseWare drivers. Even version 9.75 (available from Logitech's website) didn't fix the use of the middle mouse button in Mozilla 1.2.1 for launching new tabs. It just absolutely would not work unless I uninstalled MouseWare altogether. So, until that's fixed, I'm going without their additional features (and losing the functionality of a few buttons with it).

Okay, first of all, I have not bought this system. I actually was just looking at the reviews left by others because the system is built using a processor that I am considering using in a PC I build myself. The Processor scores well in benchmarks and is highly rated by the people who have bought it and when I saw that this pre-built system was so poorly rated it made me wonder why that is. What I then discovered is that with the exception of one every review is left by someone who, like me, prefers to build his/her own system and who also is unable to wrap his mind around the idea that not everyone is interested in building their own computer nor the fact that many people have enough money to be able to afford to pay others (like those same reviewers, should they wish to go into a computer building business, for instance) who know how to build PCs and enjoy doing so. Reading their comments I would almost think they were the work of only one person using different accounts because the sole complaint seems to be that this computer is sold with a markup of the price it would cost to buy the components and assemble it oneself. Odd that 4 or 5 reviewers should all be so single-minded and all so disregarding of the disservice they are doing to other consumers who are trying to compare computers by lowering the rating this product receives for reasons that have nothing to do with the quality or performance of the product. It doesn't seem to occur to them that the people who are looking at the ratings of pre-built systems will for the most part be people who have no intention of building their own computer and are not interested in doing so regardless of the opinions held by a group of rogue reviewers. Therefore I have given the system a five star rating in an attempt to return this product to an overall rating that is more reflective of it's value. I am not making an in depth analysis of the product but it has a processor that has received a great deal of praise and performs well when objectively tested. The people in the market for a computer and the seller of this system both deserve better than to have the ratings system rendered useless by people who either don't understand the point of that system or who are just bent on ... I don't know ... some vigilante cause devoted to promoting the idea that everyone must build his or her own computer? Hard to say -- it's strange.

Before I get into too much detail about this laptop let me tell you, this is a MUST buy for ANYONE who wants a FAST, POWRFUL, or INEXPENSIVE computer to use. This is an OUTSTANDING laptop, with only a few cons that I will go over. But first, the good stuff:

PROS:

* It's VERY fast! With the quad core i7 processer and 8GB of ram, you never have to worry about this laptop slowing down. You can run multiple applications at the same time, and it still won't break a sweat.

* There's PLENTY of space! This laptop comes with an 1TB hard drive, though you only get to use about 900GB, after Windows 8 software is installed, it's still more than enough space for music, movies and games.

* GREAT graphics card! Most benchmark websites will rate the \\"NVidia GeForce GT 650M\\" as a mid-ranged graphics card. However I have, Skyrim, Borderlands 2, Far Cry 3, Civilization 5 and many more games, running on High settings and I get 50-60 FPS with each game. For some people reading this and not understanding what I'm saying, it means I can run those games with High graphic settings and get smooth gameplay! Which is great for a \\"mid-ranged\\" graphics card.

* NICE display! It won't blow you away or anything; however, the 1600 X 900 screen resolution makes games, movies and YouTube look pretty good!

* TREMENDOUS price! Most gaming laptops can cost over $1300 or more! But for around $900 you're getting an OUTSTANDING deal!

And now for the bad:

CONS:

* The lid is a little flimsy. I'm not saying it's going to break on you, but it's not the sturdiest lid I ever seen on a laptop.

* The disc tray is also a little flimsy. Again, it's not going to break on you, I just think it's worth mentioning.

* The battery isn't the best. I can only get about 4 hours off of this laptop when I'm using the battery. And that's not including when I'm playing games. If you ONLY want to get a laptop so you don't have to keep it plugged in for more than 4 hours at a time. Then DON'T get this laptop! Though keep in mind, that with MOST powerful gaming laptops (not including Alien Were) you're going to have a crappy battery life, no matter what.

In conclusion, this is a nearly PERFECT laptop and with such a low price with great system specs. There shouldn't be much holding you back from getting this laptop!you don't have to keep it plugged in for more than 4 hours at a time. Then DON'T get this laptop! Though keep in mind, that with MOST powerful gaming laptops (not including Alien Were) you're going to have a crappy battery life, no matter what.

In conclusion, this is a nearly PERFECT laptop and with such a low price with great system specs. There shouldn't be much holding you back from getting this laptop!

Let's set the record straight on this refurbished laptop. I've been a computer power user for almost 15 years. For the price you pay, this thing is a dream. You're saving $200+ over box retail on a very high-performance laptop for its size and weight. I can chew through HD video on the go with this thing and it doesn't wince. No, you're not going to be able to play the latest Steam games with high graphics settings, but for those on the go with student or professional applications this machine is perfect.

In the box are two things: The laptop and the charger. That's it. Why on earth would you want all the promotional papers and throwaways that come with a normal laptop from the electronics store? It's a laptop. It doesn't require a manual or all that trial software that you'll never use anyway. Speaking of which, the amount of trial and promotional software (bloatware) that I had to uninstall was minimal. Thank you, Asus.

I will note that this is the second of these laptops that I've been through. The first one had a bad hard drive (kept locking up and screeching after a few hours of use) so I sent it back and got another. No big deal. Bum hard drives are somewhat common in refurbished laptops and it comes with the territory. It's an easy process thanks to Amazon's great returns policy. Just make sure you use it for a few days to test it out before you throw away the box and make sure you back up your files, as you should anyway.

Let's get straight to the pros and cons.

Pros...
- In mint condition and has no signs of being a refurbished machine
- Lightning-fast startup time for a laptop with a hard drive
- Great performance and specs for the price
- Backlit keyboard is wonderful in the dark
- Keyboard types comfortably for the size and it doesn't bend in the middle unless you apply an unreasonable amount of pressure to it
- 3 USB ports (2 USB 3.0, 1 USB 2.0)
- Fairly quiet fan noise
- Battery life meets the 7 hour advertised length when in a balanced or power saving mode
- 8gb of RAM is a nice surprise in a laptop of this price point
- Charger has an angled plug that goes into the laptop. Easier cord management and prevents accidental bumps.

Cons...
- Charger is small but bulky enough that it may cover up two outlets of a power strip. Outlets should be alright.
- Speakers are lousy. Bring a pair of earbuds or external speakers along if you want decent sound.
- It's a little clunky and heavy for use as a tablet. Buy this thing if you want a laptop that has a touchscreen, not as a tablet replacement.
- One port serves as a headphone jack and microphone input combined. USB microphones can circumvent this.
- Webcam is grainy and not of terribly high resolution.

The pros outweigh the cons easily here. This refurbished laptop is one I recommend!

B&N advertises a ONE YEAR WARRANTY with FULL REPLACEMENT. Whew!!

Contacted B&N 800- warranty number. Ended up talking with a 3rd-party service
contractor in South America on a dial-up. [crackle, crackle] 'Si, senor, we need
your credit card number to ship you a new unit.' OK. 'Hold for your RIN number."

Then the line went dead. I called right back. A guy answered this time, "Que?'

'Uh, yeah, I just left my credit card and shipping address but didn't get a RIN.'
'Bueno, diga me your e-mail and we'll send it to you. Puero, what's your DOB?'

I hung up and of course, no RIN came, so I had to call my credit card company
and say my credit information had been compromised by a B&N 3rd-party con.

Wait, it gets better!!

Over the next MONTH I contacted B&N online Customer Service SIX TIMES.
Each time I sent them ALL information on the product, model, serial number,
shipping invoice, order number, credit card, shipping address, ...everything.

EVERY TIME they claimed that their records didn't show me as the purchaser.
I HAD ALL THE RECEIPTS AND EVEN SENT THEM TO THEM, REPEATEDLY.

The Breakthrough!!

Today, B&N contacted me and said 'Your unit is our (sic) of warranty. We will
be happy to ship you a REFURBISHED unit, at substantially REDUCED COST."

I only had the unit 90 days before it bricked. Their warranty is for ONE YEAR!
IN OTHER WORDS, the 'NEW' (sic) UNIT THEY SOLD ME WAS REFURBISHED!!
DON'T PAY FULL VALUE FOR A REFURBISHED UNIT THAT'S GONNA BRICK!!

Don't buy from B&N unless you're just throwing your money into a hole in S.A.

Run Forrest, Run!!

This keyboard has several design flaws which I will outline here.

1. Amount of force needed to press the keys is too high. This causes the user to pound the keys.

2. Keyboard seems to miss double leters effectively. Probably caused by #1 above. >>>Notice that I left a letter out of 'letters' in the sentence before. That was not on purpose!<<< I hit 'l' two times, but only got one. Hapens al the time unless I POUND the double letters intentionally. And again, the missed leters here ('Hapens', 'al') are hapening naturally.

3. The keyboard is very loud and clacky as another reviewer mentioned. Probably caused by #1 above. I sit near a person at work that uses this keyboard and it is LOUD. She said her fingers have gotten stronger since using this keyboard, probably because she has to pound the keys. I'm actually considering buying her another keyboard out of my own pocket... Here at home, as I type this, I'm two rooms away from my sleeping wife, and I'm actually wondering if my typing will wake her up.

4. They keys are recessed in a flush enclosure that has a rigid rim around the base of the keys. If you accidentally hit the edge of the left shift key for example, you'll hit the rigid edge, which is at the same elevation, and miss the shift. This is the first such keyboard I've ever used with this design peculiarity. I now know why keyboard keys should be raised instead of recessed into a flush case.

On a positive note, it looks good. So if you are going for looks only, this is the keyboard for you.

Greetings Everyone,

I bought this motherboard to replace an ASUS Rampage IV Extreme I bought on Craigslist dirt cheap. Unfortunately that one would not accept a bios update without first installing an i7-3000 series LGA 2011 processor. I read in some forums that some would flash via USB and some would not regardless of what ASUS said.
My EVGA X79 Classified did not post initially upon install. However, I bought this board for four reasons: Price, EVGA's United States Based Customer Service, The XL-ATX Form Factor, and reports that this board would work with my Intel i7-4930k right out of the box! I registered the motherboard online through EVGA's website and then called EVGA. Within two minutes I was talking to a tech support rep that spoke perfect English. I told him my problem and he asked if my motherboard box had 4th Generation CPU (Ivy Bridge-E) Ready written on it? I responded yes, and he told me to flip a bios switch at the bottom of the board to the left. Viola!!! It booted up flawlessly!!!! I have a Crucial 960GB SSD and it seemed like my Windows 7 Ultimate 64Bit installed in less than ten minutes!!!
This motherboard has an interesting layout. I have a super-sized Cooler Master V8 GTS CPU Cooler and an EVGA GTX 690 video card. The X79 Classified is one of the few mid-entry level boards that accept a V8 GTS cooler without covering the PCI-E x/16 slot. However, my GTX 690 covers both the PCI-E x/1 and front audio header due to the board's layout. I can move the video card to the lower X/16 slot, but that puts it closer to the PSU and affects cooling air flow. So for right now, I'm without front panel sound until I get a sound card or move the video card. No biggie, since I use the system as a hybrid HTPC and gaming PC.
The EVGA GUI Bios is amazing!!! You can literally control every input and output on this board. Everything from fan headers, slot voltages, to SATA ports are controllable through the bios.
The LED post code trouble shooting display is a must for every computer. It should be a federal requirement!
This board skimped on internal USB 3.0 headers (only one) and the SATA ports by giving you only six, four at SATA II and two at SATA III. I bought cards to remedy both of those issues at less than $50 total. The red and black XL board looks great in my Cooler Master Storm Trooper Case with the clear side panel upgrade. A standard ATX motherboard would just be wrong for any full tower case with a clear side panel.
I think EVGA is friendlier to a wider range of RAM manufacturers than ASUS. My previously owned Rampage IV Extreme did not take well to my 16GB of Avexir Yellow LED RAM. I tried the RAM in my Gigabyte motherboard on another one of my HTPCs and I had the same problem. The red LED CPU cooler and yellow RAM combination makes a nice pseudo flame effect inside the case. I’ve gotten tons of compliments from friends and family.
Overall, if you have an Ivy Bridge-E processor, you cannot go wrong with this motherboard. It has less SATA and DIMM slots than EVGA's top of the line model, but adding $50 worth of cards brought me up to 99.5% of that board's capability under Widows 7 64Bit while saving me $80. The XL-form factor was a deal breaker for a full size clear panel case. I had to have function, form, and features at a reasonable price, and the X79 Classified came through with flying colors!
Thanks EVGA!!!

**Update: The SD slot is failing after 10 months of use.  At this point, I have a failed mousepad, routinely filling hard drive (from Windows updates completely filling the hard drive, and a failing SD slot.  Get a third job if necessary to buy a better laptop.  This one is not worth the cheap plastic case its built in.  **Update: The operating system updates have completely eliminated the free hard drive space.  I have reinstalled the operating system three or four times already due to this issue.  Spend the extra money on a real laptop.  This one is garbage.**  Tiny hard drive needs to be augmented with an SD card, which is also available on Amazon.  After doing a system restore, there were 11.7 GB free.  I believe it was closer to 3 GB free as delivered though.  Doing a system restore seems to have *briefly* eliminated the issue of constantly running out of HD space.  The small hard drive still fills up on its own - something to do with the WinSXS file.  Win 8.1 simply does not belong on a 19 GB hard drive (32 GB minus 10 GB fixed recovery drive minus 3GB mystery).  The recovery drive cannot be removed even after copying it to a USB memory stick.  The system restore will ask if you want to delete the recovery partition but will not actually permit you to delete the recovery partition even when restoring from a USB drive.  As a result, there is no way to use the 10GB partition dedicated to the recovery drive, leaving the buyer with just 19 GB including space taken by the operating system.  Finally, the mousepad constantly stops working.  Having a wireless mouse on hand is essential.  After 7 months the mousepad buttons failed permanently.  Save your money.  Get something with a bigger hard drive and perhaps a Chrome laptop if your needs are so limited.  **Update: Windows 10 absorbed the recovery partition and is smaller than 8.1, so the disappearing hard drive space is no longer a problem.  The mousepad and SD slot are still not working.  The mousepad is possessednow - the arrow dances around the screen and clicks randomly.  I barely use this machine because it is so crappy.  Now though it is unusable.

Wow! This is a powerful router with tons of options, but you do not have to be a network pro to set it up. It just works. Setup is simple and then when it works, it increased range substantially over the Apple Airport that I was running. I hope to eventually set it up to work in tandem with my Airport; I will report here on the results of those efforts.

Overall, there are just a bunch of pro's to report with this wi-fi router
-Incredible range (tri-band allows for super fast short range and longer-range too).
-Not only does it work far away but it works consistently. 6 antennas make for no observed deadzones.
-Fast. Wifi theoretically as fast as wired connection. Most devices honestly don't feel the 1.3 Gbps max speed for internet because internet speeds don't approach the gigabit speeds in most situations (soon Cox will be installing gigabit internet in my region so I am looking forward to maxing speeds out). With the right devices you may feel it with in-network transfers
-USB 3.0 outlet takes advantage of fast wifi speeds to have always connected external hard drive connected via the network. (also has a USB 2.0 plug which I have not used)
-USB allows USB printer to become a wireless printer. This is not a unique feature, but a powerful one if you need it. I do not have any wired printers to have tested this with.
-Backup software uses USB-connected hard drive to automatically backup my pc. I wish that my Mac would do it, but this is a limitation with the Mac not the router. If anybody knows how to automatically backup a Mac to this (like time machine) let me know.

Cons
-Size. The router is very large. I had to be creative on where I placed it.
-Cost. It is expensive, but having consistent and fast internet and network connectivity should be worth the money for most people. It's expensive, but worth it in my estimation.

Do not get this product. I am lucky that I got this on sale at the price it was at. I thought with the two fans (woopdiedoo on the lights) and having that extra USB port that it was going to be a good product for the work that I do on my laptop. Sadly, it was not and I am writing this review after having this product for two months.

First lets start out with construction. Great on the top with the mesh. That's it. Otherwise it is horrible! The bottom is plastic and the lifter to be able to have the laptop at in angle was great for the first week. Literally on the 10th day the plastic snapped in half. It isn't like I have that heavy of a laptop in the first place (13" Macbook Pro). For me that's a minor issue. As long as the fans keep on working I am perfectly content. Well within the first month I had this the "lights" went out and the far left fan kicked the bucket. So I am down to one fan and finally that kicks the bucket at the end of February. I tried it on my friends laptop just in case to see if it was something to do with my laptop. Nope.

The other issue I had with it was the usb ports. It seemed to me that they eventually got loose within three weeks of having this product. Since it was loose, it seemed like that if I moved the cooler at all, it wouldn't read what was in the port and at this point I felt like if I breathed on the cooler that the usb port would not work.

Pros:
Two USB ports
Noise level of fans

Cons:
Not the greatest construction
Breaks easily
Died on me completely within two months
Loose USB ports

I recently purchased a late 2008 - 2009 Macbook Pro w/ 512MB 9600M GT video card. While playing games such as the new Prince of Persia under the High Performance settings the laptop would get extremely hot, and the game would begin to lag.    Here are the temps(while playing PoP) according to iStat widget:  HDD:39 CPU:96 Enclose Base:34 Enc. Base (2):34 Encl. Base(3):33 GPU:75 GPU Diode: 83 GPU Heatsink: 66    Temps After using the Cooler Master Infinite:  HDD:35 CPU:87 Enclose Base:33 Enc. Base (2):32 Encl. Base(3):32 GPU:72 GPU Diode: 78 GPU Heatsink: 58    (Temperatures are in Celcius)    As you can see, the Cooler Master made a HUGE difference, especially in the CPU, and GPU. My game no longer lagged, and I was not worried about frying my $2500 computer.    I did a lot of research before buying this laptop cooler and I am glad I made the jump. The biggest selling point was that it did not draw in air from the bottom of the cooler, because I usually have it on an uneven surface such as my bed or sofa (which would have totally defeated the purpose of the cooler).    The Cooler Master is slightly larger in the front, but fits my Macbook Pro perfectly width wise. Some people complain that it is too loud, but I barely hear it; I don't mind the little noise that I do hear as long as it cools my laptop! The black finish and overall quality of the product is outstanding as well and does not detract from the looks of my laptop at all.    All in all, I would say that I am extremely happy with the purchase, and would highly recommend it to anyone that needs a cooler laptop.

In other words, this case is only good for carrying the tablet but to actually use it the tablet must be extract from the protective case.

Waited 3 months to get the drive after placing the order. Amazons reps kept lying to me, nominating different delivery dates and kept breaking them. After I finally got the drive it lasted 1 month before it died. Bad blocks and eventually boot failure - lost a lot of important data. This drive also has official bug in the controller, acknowledged by Intel, where it converts 600GB to 8Mb.

When I installed the part, it took 2-3 minutes for my PC to boot compared to a normal 20-30 second boot off an SSD. Other reviews had stated incompatibility with a UEFI BIOS interface which I also have. Once the part was installed and I booted up, there was a series of numbers and letters that would flash in the lower right corner before the OS booted (Win 7) which I have never seen before. Once I was in the OS, the part was never detected. I went to the website and no drivers could be found.

Just in case, I tried the other connector on the motherboard to see if that would make a difference. This time when I booted I smelled something burning and immediately turned off the PC to take the part out. I was unable to start the PC up again after. I took the PC to a local PC repair chain to have a diagnostic done and it ended up frying my motherboard. At this time I don't know if the processor is shot.

I contacted Rosewill at first to see if a resolution could be met. I explained in the first email what I have explained in this review thus far. After I explained again what happened, Rosewill contacted Newegg (I stated I bought the part on Amazon in the first email) and I had to reiterate the issue again. After I provided the order number again they offered to send a replacement part and I had stated that I can no longer use the part (nor would I want to) as the part ruined my motherboard. They again apologized and said that they will send the part, that I don't have to send the damaged one back, and that I would have to contact Amazon regarding the refund. Not once did Rosewill acknowledge or address that their hardware caused the damage it did. I still await their next response but I'm already out at least $100-150 for the diagnostic, the replacement, and the installation of the new motherboard. Possibly more if the processor is ruined too.

BUYER BEWARE    !!!THIS CARD MAY NOT HAVE 10 MB/SEC TRANSFER RATE AS ADVERTISED!!!      I would be cautious in buying this.  The class number on an SDHC card refers to the write speed.  (Class 2 = 2 MB/sec, Class 4 = 4 MB/sec, Class 6 = 6 MB/sec)    A write speed of 10 MBs/sec is available in lower capacity SD cards. (6x = .9 MB/sec, 40x = 6 MB/sec, 66x =  10 MB/sec, 133x = 20 MB/sec)    This looks like false advertisement to me
